PUB-DATE: August 1, 1993

SECTION: Section 6; Page 21; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4898 words

HEADLINE: The (Bruised) Emperor of the Outdoors

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan is Seattle bureau chief of The Times and the author of two books about the American West.

 BODY:
A boy's life in the American West can be like a summer that never ends. So it was for Bruce Babbitt, who grew up with the sunset-colored breach of the Grand Canyon as his backyard. He chased deer, caught snakes, built tree forts, floated rivers, scavenged for arrowheads, fought forest fires, fished with Indians, shot birds, followed dinosaur tracks, skied the first snow of November and dreamed about it all at night. He never spent much time with the Boy Scouts, he said, because it would have been superfluous.
In January of this year, as Babbitt became the 47th Secretary of the Interior, the Bible had barely closed at the swearing-in ceremony when he allowed himself a kid-in-charge-of-the-candy-warehouse chuckle. The vast public domain, shrines of the natural world and the big scraps left over from the land America took from the natives, bought from the Europeans and wrestled away from the Mexicans, was his to run. Babbitt was given control of an area bigger than France -- 503 million acres of forests and open range, national parks and wildlife refuges, seashores and Indian reservations. 
 That Babbitt has gone from a rockhound in cutoffs to the emperor of the outdoors does not surprise longtime acquaintances. If the Babbitts, who are as established in Arizona as the saguaro cactus, are somewhat like the Kennedys of the West, then Bruce is most like Bobby. Roman Catholics who inherited wealth and a sense of destiny, both men dreamed big, fell hard, betrayed their class and followed contrarian impulses. Scion of a legendary Western ranching family, Babbitt lashed out at big cattle operations as rangeland villains. Though he is a liberal Democrat, his staunchest supporters have included the most conservative of Arizona Republicans, simply because they like him. As a reformist state attorney general, he so enraged organized crime that a contract was put out on his life. While he was a partner in a well-connected Phoenix law firm, he urged environmentalists to avoid the establishment, saying they should fight on as "barbarians in the hills."
Inside his Cabinet office in Washington, with its tea-colored, wood-paneled walls, working fireplace and bald-eagle sculpture (the raptor is caught in mid-flight), Babbitt is a long way from the front lines of rebel environmentalism. His work space is more like a 19th-century country club den, a place with a history of deal-cutting between men of great wealth and the guardian of public lands. But from this lair, Babbitt is directing a campaign against what he calls the "Lords of Yesterday," the old forces of Government-subsidized industry that have shaped development of the West, the main realm of Interior. It does not seem at all incongruous to him that a man whose family owns a ranch nearly as big as some Eastern states is leading this charge. If anything, he says, protesting his own privilege makes him more qualified.
After a very public trial ballooning in June as President Clinton's leading choice for a vacant Supreme Court seat, Babbitt seems more committed than ever to a job he says he was born to do. He has mixed feelings about losing the court nomination, which slipped away after Clinton, a friend of 20 years, was lobbied by rabid Babbitt supporters who wanted him to stay put at Interior.
"My consolation prize is I get to spend my summers fishing in Alaska and camping in Yellowstone doing a job I really love," he says. Hooking salmon and dozing next to a campfire will be the easy parts; Babbitt is challenging the forces of history, mythic and real, that shaped the American West. And one of his biggest obstacles may turn out to be his own boss, Bill Clinton.
BABBITT HAD NOT BEEN IN office more than a few weeks when he began barnstorming around the West preaching his new gospel. "The long dark period is over," he told a room packed with Federal employees in Phoenix. "The lights are on once again at the Interior Department."
He was alluding to a 12-year Republican reign of Interior secretaries, starting with James Watt, the pro-industry lawyer who did more to anger and galvanize the environmental movement than anything except the Exxon Valdez oil spill, and ending with Manuel Lujan Jr., who often seemed befuddled by the complexities of his job.
"We are all about the perpetual American love affair with the land," Babbitt said to a group of Bureau of Land Management employees in Albuquerque. "The Department of the Environment -- that's us." Somewhat puzzled by the pep talk, the men and women who wear the uniform of the B.L.M. have long been denigrated as the Bureau of Livestock and Mining.
And to an assembly of engineers with the Bureau of Reclamation in Denver, Babbitt issued an invitation: "Let's reinvent the West." Babbitt has long feuded with the agency nicknamed "Bureau of Wreck-lamation" for its dam-building projects, which have considerably remade the landscape. For years, he said the bureau should be abolished. Now, he envisions the Federal engineers getting out of the job of stopping free-flowing streams and into the business of trying to restore river systems damaged by excessive overhauling of the natural plumbing.
A few weeks later, Babbitt went even further, saying he would like to be the first Interior Secretary to blow up a dam -- a half-century-old plug on the Elwha River in Olympic National Park that was built without fish ladders and killed off a run of legendary 100-pound chinook salmon.
Blue-eyed, sandy-haired and as peripatetic as a preacher with five days left to the apocalypse, Babbitt delivers his speeches with campaign gusto and a seize-the-moment sense of historical urgency. At age 55, he moves through life at a sprint. To his critics, he comes across as a self-righteous zealot, pushing an urban environmental agenda on traditional rural people. They see him as a green James Watt. Babbitt says his mission, seven years before the end of the millennium, is to bring the public lands of the West into the 20th century, and to see if the rest of the country can make peace with its flora and fauna.
"The winning of the West is past," he says. "People don't want to win the West; they want to save it."
He is gambling that the New West, which, surprisingly, has the highest concentration of people living in urban areas of any region, is ready to challenge some of the mythological elements of its past, the ones that have ossified into policy on the range. There may be only 28,000 ranchers running cattle on 280 million acres of public land, but they are represented by a highly effective lobby, complete with slow-talking cowpunchers in oversized Stetsons brought out for Congressional hearings. Critics call them "welfare cowboys," millionaires who have been allowed to graze livestock on huge swaths of Federal land for fees that are but a fraction of the free-market rate. But there are many small, marginal operators, who depend on that same land as as well, whose livelihoods would be threatened. Babbitt says that for both big and small ranchers the low cost discourages good stewardship. Similarly, miners have been able to claw gold, silver and other minerals from Federal lands without paying a dime in royalties -- a system established by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1872 to encourage Western development.
In his first tour of the West as Interior Secretary, Babbitt signaled a historic shift: the era of the big subsidies, "the giveaway" of public resources, as he called it, was over. But only a few months into office, Babbitt's vision of the New West ran smack into the Old West. Just as he was gearing up the campaign for change, President Clinton, under pressure from some of the same Western senators who have long protected the livestock and mining industries, withdrew from his budget proposal the plan to raise fees.
Environmentalists cried cave-in; their hero had been kneecapped. "I've never seen a white flag go up so quickly," Michael Francis of the Wilderness Society says. Two months earlier, when Babbitt was selected, the same group had said of the Interior designee, "He is Babe Ruth to us." But as the Babe knew, swinging for the fences often brings more strikeouts than four-baggers.
Even the ranchers' lobby was stunned at how quickly Clinton had taken the entire Western land reform package off the table. "We knew some of the Western senators were trying to get some reduction, but we never thought the whole thing would be gone," says Tom Cook, a vice president with the National Cattlemen's Association. In dropping the land fees, the President was trying to line up Senate votes for his $16 billion economic stimulus package. But ultimately, he lost the jobs bill to a solid Republican filibuster. The Western lands proposal turned into an empty trade, and Babbitt was left looking humiliated.
What's more, the critics were emboldened by a taste of early blood. "If Babbitt's reforms go through you'll have a very severe political backlash," says Wayne Hage, a rancher in Tonopah, Nev., a hero of the so-called Wise Use movement, which is fighting environmental restrictions. Hage, like other ranchers, considers his permit to graze livestock on 700,000 acres of national forest land in Nevada a property right. Change is not welcome. Three years ago, when a Forest Service ranger in southern Idaho tried to place new restrictions on the way cattlemen graze their herds on the open range, one rancher publicly threatened to kill him.
Back on the Western trail after the setback, Babbitt made jokes at his own expense. Unlike many leaders in the environmental movement, who can be as dour as a wet sleeping bag, he has an active sense of humor. In jest, he can be at his most candid.
When a Federal biologist in Colorado asked him about the decision to retreat on grazing fees and mining royalties, Babbitt said, "You mean why did we wimp out?" The audience of scientists laughed, then applauded his follow-up.
"We got singed on that one," Babbitt said. "But I guarantee you, we are not retreating from the battle."
Before the year was out, he promised, he would have a new fee structure in place for ranchers, and the Government charging royalities to miners. "1993 will be the year of reform for public land and water issues," Babbitt said.
IN MID-SPRING, THE jet stream was parked over the Pacific Northwest, carrying a load of precipitation in from the Pacific. Babbitt stood on a ridge in the Olympic National Forest, a place where it can rain up to 220 inches a year and trees grow like teen-agers on a Snickers diet.
The midriff of the Olympic Mountains used to be mantled in green, Babbitt noted as he walked among a sea of clear-cuts, the ground scalped to muddy brown. Nearly 50 years ago, the United States Forest Service signed an agreement giving the Simpson Timber Company exclusive rights to log more than 100,000 acres of public land, a pact designed to keep timber jobs in the area. But now many of the trees and the jobs, along with the fish and wildlife of this forest, are gone or disappearing. Soil and debris from the clear-cuts have slid down into the South Fork of the Skokomish River, clogging the river with sediment. The Fish and Wildlife Service says the area is a disaster.
"A tale of death and destruction," Babbitt said, traipsing through the mud with foresters and biologists. But he also saw a glimpse of the future in the Olympic Mountain mist. A month after President Clinton held a forest conference in Portland, Ore., to try and settle the war between loggers and tree-huggers, Babbitt was in the woods seeking the raw shape of a settlement. He wondered how much it would cost to put unemployed loggers back to work restoring the land that has been scarred by timber harvesting. And if the rivers were full of salmon again, he asked, what would that do for the local economy?
In early July, Clinton announced his forestry plan, saying it probably would not please either side. He was right. The plan would reduce logging on Federal land in the Northwest to 25 percent of the high marks of the mid-1980's, and would provide $1.2 billion in economic aid to depressed timber communities over five years. It also seeks to protect the lifeblood of what is left of the old-growth forests, the salmon streams and watersheds. Clinton was not enthusiastic about the plan and fought Babbitt on it, looking for the win-win compromise he had promised. Babbitt tried to explain to the President that higher logging levels could not be sustained, legally or environmentally. The forests had been "cynically overcut in the 1980's," he said, leading to an ecological debt.
"The President was clearly disappointed," says Babbitt. "He pushed me around hard on whether there could be any other result. I finally had to say, 'This is the best we can do within the existing law.' "
Still, it was not enough to satisfy the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, who has long supported timber interests in his Washington State district. Calling the Clinton plan unbalanced and a threat to industry, Foley blew up at Babbitt. In the past, when powerful members of the Northwest Congressional delegation wanted more logging out of the Forest Service, they got it, by amendment or pressure. But not this time.
"The Speaker saw this as a fork in the road," Babbitt says. "He felt it was going to be necessary to re-examine the laws."
That sets the course for what could be a monumental collision over the Endangered Species Act, which Babbitt calls "the most powerful environmental statute ever enacted." All sides in the forest conflict were brought to the brink by the law that gives vanishing creatures equal consideration with timber operations and housing developments. It has been bashed as an eco-weapon out of control.
Babbitt has set out to make the Endangered Species Act a friend to business -- an impossible task, some critics say. Ike Sugg, a Competitive Enterprise Institute fellow who has written extensively about the high price of environmental protection, has estimated that the law has cost developers "tens of billions of dollars."
The Reagan and Bush Administrations seemed intent on sabotaging the law, allowing, according to Babbitt, different Federal agencies to issue conflicting edicts. "First they ignored it; then they abused it," he says.
Babbitt is trying to be less rigid. In Southern California, he brokered a settlement giving protection to the gnatcatcher, a songbird whose coastal sage habitat is fast disappearing, while still giving the go-ahead to housing developments that had threatened the bird. Then he approved a plan by the Georgia-Pacific Corporation to save the red cockaded woodpecker with buffer zones totaling about 50,000 acres. In both cases, Babbitt essentially swapped acres -- a nest here and there, stands of old trees and untrammeled ravines in exchange for plots of land that can go under the bulldozer or chain saw. "We are on the threshold of the most extraordinary test of our time to see if we have the scientific capacity and will to make that act work," he says.
Saving woodpeckers and gnatcatchers in the era of a President who promised to "focus like a laser beam" on the economy may not be an achievement a politically wobbly Clinton can take to the voters in 1996. Babbitt says the West, where 7 of the 11 states went for Clinton last year, can become a natural Democratic constituency, because of its high quotient of urban environmentalists. But he also sees an opportunity beyond the next election.
"In the American conservation movement, there have been two large moments," he says. "One was the time of Teddy Roosevelt, when we first started creating the land management ethic. The second came in the 1960's and 70's, when Rachel Carson's work stimulated concern about toxic chemicals and industrial pollution. What we are now getting into is a third era which is infinitely more complex because it asks a new question, a very subtle question of how we live in association with the natural environment. It goes to how we view ourselves living on the land."
The crucial word is "We." Other environmental leaders have excluded humans from their conception of the natural ecology. Teddy Roosevelt thundered against timber barons, and then created huge national forest reserves to keep industry from cutting the big trees down. The reign of Interior Secretary Stewart Udall in the 60's gave birth to the Wilderness Act and placement of millions of acres of pristine land in permanent sanctuaries. Babbitt would like to preserve the basic nature of the country's ecosystems, from the swamplands of Florida, to the lakes country of the Upper Midwest, to the Potomac River system, to the glacier-carved valleys of Alaska -- with people sharing the land with the creatures that are being pushed out.
It sounds idyllic. But the issue is being forced. Under a Federal court settlement that the Bush Administration agreed to, the Government must decide whether to put an additional 400 species under the protection of the Endangered Species Act in the next three years. Any one of those listings could blow up in the Administration's face -- as the next spotted owl nightmare -- or be a model for future consensus.
"I used to drive to work in downtown Phoenix and see the peregrine falcons nesting in the skyscrapers," Babbitt says. "I saw that as a kind of metaphor for how we are both trying to live in the same area. Really, the core issue for me is: Can we live without wreaking havoc on each other?"
BABBITT ONCE STAYED up all night atop an Arizona peak with Edward Abbey, the author of "Desert Solitaire" and other paeans to the beauty of the arid West. They sipped whisky under the stars, watched the sun rise, and then Abbey disappeared into the dawn.
It is impossible to understand Babbitt without a sense of what the outdoors means to him. With his Harvard Law degree and recent stint as president of the League of Conservation Voters, he can sound like an Eastern liberal at times, but he is more Teddy Roosevelt than Teddy Kennedy. He evokes the West of "A River Runs Through It," Norman Maclean's homage to Montana fly-fishing, rather than the land of Frederic Remington's cavalry brigade. His heroes are men of action with sunburns, people who explored hidden reaches of rock, ice and riverway and then wrote great books that rallied support for national parks.
His family imprint is all over the map of northern Arizona, where the Painted Desert folds into the San Francisco Peaks. He grew up in Flagstaff, a town of 48,000 people stitched to the Colorado Plateau, nearly 7,000 feet above sea level. An ancient land carved and colored by wind, water and sun over 10 million years, the Grand Canyon country is one of the few places on earth that has an instant, sometimes life-changing effect on people when they first see it. The Anasazi natives, still the source of great mystery as to why they vanished in the 15th century, lived for nearly 800 years among the red rock and layered bluffs. Later came the Navajos, Hopis, a one-armed American geologist named John Wesley Powell and five Babbitt Brothers from Ohio, who arrived in 1886.
The Babbitts, according to Arizona lore, were the original padrones of Flagstaff, arriving just as the frontier was closing. They acquired an enormous amount of ranch property during the Depression of 1893 and set up trading posts in and around the Navajo and Hopi reservations. They sold the native people tools, groceries and machinery, and bought jewelry, pottery, blankets and artwork from them. The arrangement still exists; the family's trading post in Tuba City is one of the oldest commercial enterprises in Navajo country. The Babbitts have sold some of their family holdings and they retain a 500,000-acre ranch -- a spread of shortgrass and ponderosa that covers an area two-thirds the size of Rhode Island.
Babbitt's childhood sounds like episodes from the young Indiana Jones. At age 15, he lied about his age to a Forest Service recruiter; by saying he was 18, he was able to fight fires in the woods above Flagstaff. "I lived for the next issue of National Geographic," he says. "I was always looking at the land and collecting fossils, always wanting to get to the next thing on the horizon, whether it was a mountaintop or another trail on the Grand Canyon."
More than anything, the 5,000-foot-deep canyon defines Babbitt. He has floated the raging white water of the Colorado River many times and skied into the breach in the dead of winter. A state trooper once got hypothermia accompanying Babbitt, as Governor, during one of his canyon expeditions.
At the University of Notre Dame, where he was student-body president, Babbitt took a degree in geology, but picked up a broader education in the Catholic social activism espoused by the Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, the school's longtime president.
While in graduate school at the University of Newcastle in England, Babbitt was selected to go work with Gulf Oil in a mountainous basin of the Amazon River in South America. "It was the apotheosis of my childhood fantasy: virgin jungle, research, flying across mountaintops in a helicopter," he says. "But at one point we were out setting up base camps, where we had these tents and cooks and martinis at night. And somehow I was just so struck by the contrast between a landscape of people starving to death and me sitting in the lap of this frontier luxury, that it started eating at me. I had found the Amazon, and discovered that it wasn't what I was all about. Watching these people in rags in Bolivia, I realized I'm more a part of the world and people problems than this extravagant adventure."
Instead of getting a doctorate at Newcastle and going into the mining industry, as he had planned, Babbitt enrolled at Harvard Law School. From there, he worked for Vista in Washington, marched for civil rights in the South, then returned to Arizona to practice law in 1967.
His career has had an uncanny resemblance to that of Bill Clinton's. Babbitt had no military service, was elected State Attorney General, then governor, and, with Clinton, helped to found the Democratic Leadership Council in 1985, which charted a more centrist path for the party. He married a lawyer, Hattie Coons, now the ambassador to the Organization of American States, and they have two children, Christopher, 17, and T. J., 15.
As Attorney General in Arizona, Babbitt became a local hero when he went after organized crime for land fraud. The mob fought back, putting a contract out on his life, as well as that of an Arizona Republic reporter, Don Bolles, according to court testimony. Babbitt escaped harm, but Bolles was killed when an explosion ripped his car apart in 1976 -- though it was never clear exactly who ordered the murder. The tough-on-crime image helped Babbitt win two terms as Governor of Arizona, a heavily Republican state.
With eight years in the State House behind him, Babbitt ran for President in 1988. He was beloved by the press, who followed him on sub-zero biking trips in Iowa and climbing outings in New Hampshire, but ignored by most voters. Though he denounced Ronald Reagan, saying he ran "a Government by Teleprompter in which words and deeds seem to have lost all logical connection," it was Babbitt's inability to master Reagan's medium that may have done him in. Despite his Jimmy Stewart amiability in person, he can come across on television as Richard Nixon without the sweaty upper lip. The voice is deep, the facial movements sometimes erratic. Asked during the campaign about his poor image on the tube, Babbitt said, "If they can teach Mr. Ed to talk, they can do something for me."
The 1988 campaign ended for him after a weak showing in New Hampshire -- the only election he ever lost. Babbitt says he has given up all aspirations for future elective office. But the ambition ticker started up again this summer when the President asked him if he would consider a Supreme Court nomination. "I thought, on the one hand I'm too young to take a vow of political celibacy and go off to the monastery," Babbitt says. "But on the other hand. . . ." his voice trails off, a hint of his disappointment. Clinton chose Ruth Bader Ginsburg instead.
AS INTERIOR Secretary, Babbitt's greatest challenge is in the West, where the Federal Government has been a landlord of many moods. Starting with railroad land grants of 1862, the Government has long subsidized development of the area west of the 100th meridian, America's mythic landscape. Most of it was thought to be largely useless land, there for the taking.
Today, Babbitt says, Federal mining laws remain an area where "the unrestrained, giveaway, environment-be-damned attitude of the 19th century persists." He knows the forces of the ages are strong, and will not change without a big fight. One opponent of Babbitt's reforms, Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, argues that charging royalities for mining public land will kill the small claims prospector and send the industry to South America.
In Babbitt's view, he is reflecting popular political sentiment in the West. Some Rocky Mountain states are leading the nation in the rate of new job growth, and they are doing it with businesses that are no longer tied to gouging the scenery. Booming communities in Colorado, New Mexico, Idaho, Oregon, Montana, Nevada and Arizona are full of people who do business by fax and phone, and then catch brook trout 15 minutes from their home.
"It is both good politics and good policy to have someone in there at Interior who understands that jobs versus the environment is not the future," says Phil Keisling, Oregon's Secretary of State. "Bush never understood that."
But after Clinton withdrew the Western land reform measures, and resisted the timber plan until it was obvious he had no other choice, there is now also a question of whether this President understands it either. Babbitt asserts, without equivocation, that Clinton will not undercut him. "We are 100 percent on the same bus. I have known him for 20 years, I respect him enormously and I accepted this job in the spirit of that relationship. The mining and grazing flap was about tactics, and I willingly defer to his political judgment on pace."
Throughout the summer, Babbitt has been visiting small Western communities, trying to sell mining and grazing reform. Typically, the crowds arrive angry, and organized, but leave with grudging respect and a sense of inevitablity. "We see some of the handwriting on the wall," says Cook, the National Cattlemen's Association lobbyist, who recently met with Babbitt. "But we are not going to fold up our tents and go away."
Babbitt, acknowledging political reality, points out that the New West is full of prosperous towns living side by side with wild and unspoiled land. But for every recreational mecca, there is a potential ghost town. The failure to help such communities make the transition could bring a backlash, and renew charges that Babbitt's vision of a green future is something only the elite can enjoy.
NEARLY EVERY WEEK, Babbitt's schedule includes a trip to some canyon, seashore, national park, mountain range, desert, wildlife refuge or historic site. With everything from maintenance of the Statue of Liberty to Indian relations under its aegis, the Interior Department is a grab bag of American history -- and its leftovers. Among his goals in the East, Babbitt says he would like to help restore Atlantic salmon runs in New England and fish populations in rivers like the Potomac. He has also targeted with special urgency the Everglades, sick from years of water mismanagement. In mid-July, Babbitt unveiled a plan to rechannel some of the natural flow of water in the Florida national park.
Meanwhile, environmentalists want desert land in Calfornia and a piece of tallgrass prairie on the Great Plains made into national parks. They would seem to have a natural ally in Babbitt, who as Arizona Governor used to lobby for wilderness by quoting from a literary hero and environmental pioneer, Aldo Leopold. But he has not shown his hand on future parks.
One of his biggest initiatives will be the creation of a National Biological Survey, a corps of Government scientists who will do a continuing inventory of American land and wildlife. In one of the early meetings of the group in Denver, Babbitt told them he had a personal stake in the survey. The first attempt to do an ecosystem study in America came at the turn of the century, when C. Hart Merriam set up base camp on the Babbitt family ranch. Merriam's ghost, like that of John Wesley Powell, Edward Abbey and others who have wandered from the crest of the Painted Desert to the lip of the Grand Canyon looking for answers from the geologic ages, have passed a sense of duty to Babbitt.
Right now Babbitt is acting on his dreams, But if during the next few years he runs into strong political turbulence, and becomes worn down by the winds of Washington, he can always retreat to the place in northern Arizona that was his boyhood haunt: "I have a wonderful spot above Flagstaff, a place in the mountains with aspen glades and wild iris and butterflys all around. I used to go up there alone, throw my sleeping bag down and spend the night. It wasn't a big mystical thing. I just like to savor it."

HEADLINE: Early Music Goes Flat in New York

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:
New York does not always lead the international classical-music scene, but it generally follows close behind. Lord knows, it is not the kind of city to get out of the way. Yet in one of the liveliest and most sweeping musical trends of the century, the Early Music movement, New York has seemed oddly content of late to lag far behind not only European cities like London, Amsterdam and Paris but also American ones like Boston and San Francisco.
True, music of the medieval, Renaissance and Baroque periods abounds in churches and small halls around New York. But the term Early Music has come to mean more: not only an ancient body of works but an esthetic of performance. Over the last decade, the ethic of period performance practice, originally meant to recreate the long-lost sonorities and styles of genuinely early repertories, has been extended boldly through the 19th century and tentatively into the 20th. 
 In the process, groups of period instrumentalists and singers have had to evolve just the way their historical counterparts did, expanding to meet the demands of increasingly complex repertory. Omens were good for a time in New York. As recently as the mid-80's, the Mostly Mozart Festival mustered a band of period players for the English conductor Christopher Hogwood. And in 1988, the Classical Band was formed for another Englishman, Trevor Pinnock. But both efforts died after a few years.
Mostly Mozart still makes occasional nods toward Early Music, this year with imported talent. Tafelmusik, of Toronto, will perform at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, followed a week later by Les Arts Florissants, from Paris. In a curious turnabout, these groups are led by Americans who might have been expected to settle in New York: Tafelmusik by Jeanne Lamon, originally of Larchmont, N.Y.; Les Arts Florissants by William Christie, a native of Buffalo.
Why have Ms. Lamon and Mr. Christie chosen to ply their trade so far from home? And why has no one come forward in New York to make permanent large-scale use of the rich pool of Early Music specialists? Why, in short, does Early Music still seem to struggle in New York while it thrives in so many other cities?
When that question was put to performers and presenters in New York and elsewhere, many causes were cited, ranging from an absence of certified stars and the sheer amount of competing activity to the basic conservatism of the city's musical establishment. The style, characterized by nuance and grace, is suited to cities with dominant academic communities, like Boston and San Francisco, and a poor match for the brawling, sprawling diversity of New York.
"Perhaps New York and Early Music are just culturally incompatible," suggested Stephen Hammer, a leading period oboist. "Having followed the Classical Band story from the beginning, I feel that it is very much a New York story, one for which our entire community, musicians, administration, audience and press is responsible."
It is certainly true that the Classical Band failed to capture the imagination of the New York musical community. The lackluster results achieved by an absentee director met with scorn from critics and indifference from audiences. Mr. Pinnock was quickly replaced by Bruno Weil, and although the group made strides toward respectability, the public, once burned, was slow to respond. The only parties solidly behind the venture, it seemed, were Deutsche Grammophon and Sony, yet despite healthy recording advances, the band fell into insolvency early last year.
So New York is left again without a period orchestra working in a major venue. But if the city and Early Music are indeed incompatible, 'twas not ever thus. In simpler days, when Early Music meant really early music, New York was a thriving center. Performances at the beginning of the century by the pioneering eccentric Arnold Dolmetsch paved the way for a sustained effort beginning in the 50's by the charismatic Noah Greenberg and the New York Pro Musica Antiqua, the group that put early music on the map for many Americans.
But came the Baroque boom of the 60's and 70's, and self-styled specialists like Dolmetsch and Greenberg gave way to performers steeped in musicology and eager to duplicate the circumstances of a work's creation, to respond to the composer's every intention, using "original instruments" in more or less strict adherence to period practice. Dutch, German and Austrian musicians took the lead but were soon surpassed in zealotry by the English. New York was poised to follow.
"Ten to 15 years ago," said the oboist Mr. Hammer, New York was a hotbed of activity. "Concert Royal, the Grande Bande, the Waverly Consort, the Mozartean Players, Aston Magna and a number of other enterprises were all giving well-attended concerts in major venues. I moved here from the Boston area in 1982 to be closer to this fertile environment." Now, Mr. Hammer added, he earns most of his living playing out of town.
Boston, meanwhile, has become the more fertile environment. Despite dire financial reports, the Boston Early Music Festival keeps rolling around every two years, in alternation with the Berkeley Festival in California. Although the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra, which had some splendid outings, no longer tours, Mr. Hogwood has transformed the venerable Handel and Haydn Society into a period group using many of the same players -- including the peripatetic Mr. Hammer.
All the groups Mr. Hammer mentioned continue to perform early repertory in small venues, often with good success. Yet they generate limited excitement. Some have fared well abroad, as the Grande Bande did early this year at the Hong Kong Festival with three programs celebrating the 350th anniversary of Monteverdi's birth. Typically, New York saw only one of the programs, an evening of madrigals at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine; "Orfeo" and the 1610 Vespers were for Hong Kong consumption only.
IF ANYONE CAN BE SAID TO wear the mantle of Noah Greenberg, it may be Frederick Renz, the director of the Grande Bande and of the Ensemble for Early Music, which grew out of New York Pro Musica in 1974. Mr. Renz has sometimes delivered superior performances, as in the Monteverdi concert. What is needed in addition is some of Greenberg's larger-than-life personality, to galvanize the Early Music scene in the city and fix the attention of the public.
"When I was living in the States 20 years ago," recalled Mr. Christie, "I already had the idea that one of the real problems was a lack of direction, a lack of inspired director-leaders. It seems so strange that New York has not really had a major Baroque figure for years. And that's what seems to me lacking: someone who's enough of a visionary, enough of a risk taker, and persuasive and seductive enough to get the public and the sponsors behind him." Mr. Christie, of course, has since become all of those things, to no particular benefit of New York.
Such figures are rare at any time, and a New York music world still largely governed by attitudes of Central European conservatism might not welcome one in any case. James Richman, the director of Concert Royale, views Mr. Christie's career longingly.
"I stuck here. Maybe that was a terrible mistake. Bill Christie had no hopes in America, so he moved to Paris, where there was absolutely nothing in Early Music when he went. And look what's happened. There's been a sea change here against it, in terms of funding and press and all the rest, and a sea change there in favor of it."
Mr. Richman has carved out a valuable niche for his group, offering polished, often invigorating concert and stage performances of Baroque music. In the current Balkanized context in New York, a niche seems to be the most one can hope for.
"We were all too idealistic," he said. "Ignoring the personality-cult thing was a terrible mistake. It was a mistake that wasn't made by our English brethren. We were just this sort of amorphous group of nice people doing this stuff, and it was kind of interesting, but it didn't have star impact. These people who came from Europe had a much brighter sense of what it meant to make a career."
Early Music in New York, of course, is caught in a confluence of larger problems: those of all classical music in New York and of Early Music in the country as a whole. Economic realities are hard. Subsidies and sponsorships for such activities are generally harder to come by in the United States than in Europe nowadays.
Nicholas McGegan, the English director of the burgeoning Philharmonia Baroque in San Francisco, said that he counts himself an honorary American, then leveled this criticism: "So long as arts is considered a four-letter word in American governmental circles, we're not going to get very far. That's the basic problem."
Still, some American cities do offer advantages. Mr. McGegan cited a San Francisco hotel tax as being crucial to the Philharmonia's success. "The city gets something over $30 million to support the arts, paid for by tourists," he explained. "My orchestra gets $30,000 or $40,000 a year out of the tax, which is certainly a make-or-break thing in the budget. And I don't think anyone in New York gets anything like that."
New York is also deficient in halls in the range of 800 to 1,000 seats: large enough to offer attractive financial prospects yet small enough to give the often delicate sound impact.
"To be able to create something new these days is really an assignment," said Frederick Noonan, the associate director of programming at Lincoln Center. "You have to have the charismatic figure. You have to have an administrator who really knows what he's doing and is a schmoozer and a fund-raiser and is organized and has a staff that is willing to work for low pay and long hours. And you've got to have a hospitable environment with a venue. And where can that happen?"
Many performers feel that it should be happening more at Lincoln Center. In addition to the "original instrument" sideline at Mostly Mozart, the center used to offer Great Performances series devoted to Early Music. Although the halls are far from ideal, most players find them a reasonable compromise: The overlarge Avery Fisher Hall (2,700 seats) is at least bright and clear; the dull-sounding Alice Tully Hall (1,100 seats) is at least close to the right size.
"What we're doing is sort of blending Early Music into our chamber-orchestra series," said Jane Moss, the new director of programming at Lincoln Center. "Our feeling is that it's become such a fixture in a way that it doesn't need special treatment. And in an odd way, I find that encouraging. The other direction I see in the future would be to have more of our presentations in that area be focused on repertory, as opposed to just the fact that it's a period-instrument group. I love the fact that it doesn't have to be ghettoized."
Ms. Lamon, of Tafelmusik, agrees. "It's good for Early Music to stop being a niche or a fringe thing. What we do I think would benefit any group: Stop calling yourself period-instrument or Early Music, and just call yourself a chamber orchestra and talk about the repertory you're playing. It's my business what instrument I choose to play on, not something that the audience has to worry about. They should just be thinking, 'Ah, I'm going to hear Vivaldi and Bach, my favorite music.' "
THE MOVEMENT, IF IT can be called that under such circumstances, has come a long way since the days when the phrase "original instruments" was emblazoned on records and concert programs as a Good Housekeeping seal of approval. Should New Yorkers take consolation after all in the thought that they are simply missing a monumental nonevent?
No. No one who heard the Boston Early Music Festival at its best or hears Les Arts Florissants next week is likely to be fobbed off so easily. There are qualities of suppleness and suavity to fine period instruments, well played, that combine thrillingly in quantity. Many of the best players in the world are based in New York. How we gonna keep 'em down on the farm after they've played Paris?

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Through the Looking Glass and Into 'Our Town'

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: PETERBOROUGH, N.H.

 BODY:
What Thornton Wilder seized upon as the simplest stuff of human drama is still scattered about this unaffected town more than half a century later, from cemetery glade to lacy front porch.
It feels natural here to remember young Emily and George shyly approaching love and beyond in "Our Town." Still, a visitor may owe it to Wilder's memory to also keep in mind a bit of murderous Uncle Charley terrorizing his small-town kin in "Shadow of a Doubt," the 1943 Hitchcock movie Wilder co-wrote from the same character ingredients of the shadowy American soul. 
 "I have set the village against the largest dimensions of time and place," Wilder wrote of "Our Town." This was after its revolutionary bare-stage starkness and stage-manager chorus was coming to be shaded in weaker, treacle-rich productions that overplayed his small-town evocations of life and death, love and suffering, themes that echo everywhere, no less in modern Peterborough, where he modeled and wrote the play.
"The recurrent words in this play (few have noticed it) are 'hundreds,' 'thousands' and 'millions,' " Wilder wrote, frustrated that his harsher points about life's ephemera -- "the life of a village against the life of the stars" -- might be lost. The playwright's stage instructions in 1938 included explicit cautions against sentimentality and lugubriousness; one Grover's Corners character, Simon Stimson, even earned his place in the climactic Act III graveyard scene -- all the dead patiently sitting in kitchen chairs -- by committing suicide. "To spend and waste time as though you had a million years," he scoffs at the living from Wilder's other side.
Charles Morey seems to have all this and more in mind as he directs a new production of "Our Town" this summer with the Peter borough Players, one of the nation's more durable resident stock companies, which is celebrating its 60th anniversary and presenting its fifth version of "Our Town."
"Every high school does it and people have a view of it as a sentimental postcard," notes Mr. Morey, who acted and directed in Peterborough for a decade before becoming artistic director of the Pioneer Theater Company in Salt Lake City. "But there is a real hard edge running through the middle of this play about death and loss and the ephemeral nature of human existence."
Wilder, who died in 1975 at the age of 78, had been a prodigy on the country roads about this 260-year-old town as he took walks during 10 summer stays at the MacDowell writers' and artists' colony, pondering Dante's "Purgatorio" and Peterborough's routine as he concocted Grover's Corners. "Each individual's assertion to an absolute reality can only be inner, very inner," wrote Wilder later. "Our claim, our hope, our despair are in the mind -- not in things, not in 'scenery,' " he decided.
Even so, the hamlets and Main Streets of the Monadnock region yield a cornucopia of graceful New England scenery that had to inspire Wilder, if only to strip down its stage presence to a few planks and chairs. If Wilder were alive to update the play, he now could have the stage manager dryly note that Peterborough lately held off an attempt to open a McDonald's here, recession or not, and that, thank you, there is yet no local Christmas-every-day shop reeking of potpourri and commercial schmaltz, as there is up north in the more touristy belt.
"Whatever you do, don't portray us as hokey," warns Nancy Gorr at the Chamber of Commerce. "We aren't. It's a pretty sophisticated area -- lecture series, hard-working residents, publishing companies, lots of foreign service people, not all blue jeans and overalls."
So true is this, in fact, that it would be hard to imagine how Wilder might integrate the brief evening tableau in a parking lot the other night when a tanned, handsome middle-class couple was noticed ducking behind a map in their touring car to snuff what seemed cocaine. They could have stopped the Grover's Corners show. (Better, of course, to use them to update Mr. and Mrs. Antrobus, the wacky-dense, prehistoric-suburban bourgeoisie of Wilder's "Skin of Our Teeth.")
SO EVERYTHING IS UP TO DATE in Peterborough. It is not the Grover's Corners of Wilder's imagination, never has been, and yet the town, which has doubled to about 5,000 residents since the play was written, comes close enough to Wilder's flinty silhouette. The town leaders drew 133 people to a soul-searching "civic profile" forum at ConVal High School recently for a candid debate over what is right and wrong about their town. Some admitted that neighboring hamlets found Peterborough a bit snobby about business development. There were vows of a friendlier attitude toward outside investors who now include Japanese managers at the local ball-bearing factory and some slick magazine publishers specializing in computer information.
Fifty-five years after "Our Town" opened on Broadway, Peterborough remains separate from yet entwined with the play. It's been some years since the death of Fletcher Dole, a milk delivery man and the last of the two or three real-life denizens who some think clearly were models for the play's characters. "Wilder used to walk at great length every morning and link up with Dole," says Mr. Morey. "I can see Fletcher Dole in the front row on opening night," he adds, speaking of a production he helped put on a generation ago. "That beatific look on his face watching Howie Newsome," the milkman of "Our Town."
The play's trademark blurring of life and fiction goes forward, in a way, without Mr. Dole. Many of the actors in the decennial productions here have aged in parallel and across Wilder's assorted roles. Joyce Cohen was Emily in the previous production and plays Emily's mother in the new one, which will be performed through next Sunday. Bob Alvin, in his 27th season, is not quite retired at the age of 76, having acted, taught and directed in New York and beyond, sampling his way through "Our Town" roles but never with more immediate inspiration than in Peterborough.
"Oh, it's a beautiful play," declares Mr. Alvin. "Doc Gibbs is my favorite," he says, trying Constable Warren this time, playing him as "the town's baby sitter." In truth, the current Peterborough police blotter does little to contradict the play's pastoral tone, ranging from two calls about "a sick raccoon" on Grove Street to worried parents reporting a daughter had run away from their town.
She was a girl just about Emily Gibbs's age when Emily was allowed her regretful post-mortem visit back to Grover's Corners. Through this plot device, Wilder dramatized the ordinary beauty of life that is often overlooked by the living.
"The only thing you have to watch in 'Our Town' is you can't overdo anything -- it's all there in Wilder's writing," Mr. Alvin says, making dialogue and stage directions seem plain as the windows and storefronts on Grove Street.
Wilder imagined the play from a pastiche of local towns he wandered, not just this one. Some nearby Jaffrey residents, for example, are convinced their historic cemetery is more apropos than Peterborough's for the graveyard finale. But the Stage Manager character still settles much of the debate of precisely where "Our Town" can be found when, near the end of the play, he stands atop the cemetery hill and points into the heart of the audience. "There, quite a ways down," he says, "is Grover's Corners."
Pertinent clues of the playwright's meandering are clear enough. They are chiseled plain as tombstone dates marking the childbirth deaths that regularly stalked healthy, hopeful women like Emily. They are suggested in the candor and grace of George Kendall, a 92-year-old genuine New Englander and retired general director of the MacDowell Colony, who is careful not to overblow his acquaintance with Wilder.
He recalls that the playwright, after some hard labors one summer evening at MacDowell, carefully, hopefully read from a play in progress. He wanted to top his own Pulitzer Prize success of "Our Town," but it became clear to all in his small audience as he read that this was not the writer's best product. "The second act was a failure and Wilder looked up and he closed the manuscript and politely said to us, 'I hope you stay and have some cheese and beer.' He didn't bother with the third act. He knew," Mr. Kendall recalls with as much respect for Wilder's self-honesty in failure as for all his greater success.
The special quality about "Our Town" for Mr. Kendall is that, even being quite familiar with it, he never knows when some new actor will bring something pristine from the real town into its dark setting, a fragment from the routine life that Wilder sought to capture when he said the play was "an attempt to find a value above all price for the smallest events in our daily life."
"There was one local guy," Mr. Kendall says, remembering a past summer cast member who shocked everyone by stepping most convincingly from Peterborough into "Our Town." "He was a hopeless mess in his personal life -- not misbehavior, things just weren't working out for the poor guy. But the tenderness in the man's voice when he was onstage and called out to Emily, it was very, very moving. A local guy. The best I've seen it done," says Mr. Kendall of his town and "Our Town."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: OUR TOWN (PLAY)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA (79%); UTAH, USA (77%); 

CITY: SALT LAKE CITY, UT, USA (77%);

SECTION: Section 5; Page 8; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2324 words

HEADLINE: Many Flavors of Florida's Panhandle

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME; PETER APPLEBOME is head of the Atlanta bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
THE license plates are mostly from Georgia, Texas, Alabama and Tennessee. The bumper stickers and T-shirts advertise ritzy Atlanta private schools, the epochal football season of the Alabama Crimson Tide and country music heartthrobs like Travis Tritt and Garth Brooks. The flawless beaches and emerald surf around Destin, Fla., may be to many Southerners what the Jersey Shore and the Hamptons are around New York, but it's probably time to retire the term "Redneck Riviera." Almost unnoticed by most non-Southerners, the heart of the Florida Panhandle has developed into one of the most inviting and affordable beach and coastal areas in the country. And from the overgrown fishing village turned condo alley at Destin to the unpretentious small-town eccentricities of Grayton Beach to the pastel dreamworld of Seaside, it's now as diverse and contradictory as the South itself.
The main reason for the appeal is not hard to figure out. The beaches are deep, clean and sugar white, and the Gulf surf is a startling blend of emerald, turquoise and aquamarine, blending finally into a deep blue about 100 yards out to sea. About 60 percent of the 24 miles of beaches around Fort Walton and Destin have been protected against any development by state or federal governments. 
 One well-traveled first-time visitor from Atlanta, taking note of the dazzling beachfront view outside her window and the $89-a-night price tag for a one-bedroom condominium, murmured, "Why go to the Caribbean, when you can come here?" Destin may not be Antigua, but it's certainly not Dogpatch with surf and sunscreen either. As inviting as the area is in the summer, the real time to come is after Labor Day, when the temperature cools a bit and the prices go from moderate to real bargains.
Once, the Panhandle Coast was sparsely developed between Pensacola and Panama City. Plenty of people wish it still were. But there are now at least five different worlds just in the 35 miles from Fort Walton Beach, the first part of the area to be developed, and Seaside, the designer-label fantasyland that's still aborning.
Fort Walton Beach and Destin have taken to calling themselves the Emerald Coast. With its flag-lined main street, busy harbor, tourist attractions like the Gulfarium -- the area's answer to Sea World -- and accommodations ranging from modest cottages and motels to pricey condominium towers, Fort Walton Beach has a feel somewhere between a medium-sized Southern town and an old-line Florida retirement and vacation community.
But the real boom area over the past decade has been Destin itself, which has grown from a modest fishing village to a major resort community. The town signs still bill Destin as the World's Luckiest Fishing Village, and Destin's 10-mile distance from the 100-foot depths of the Gulf has made it a fishing mecca for decades, from the 1,200-foot Okaloosa Pier in town to the ample fleet of fishing boats that take anglers into the Gulf. There are at least 14 charter boats and six party boats available for visitors.
But over the past 15 years, Destin has had an explosion of building that has created a row of condominiums, cottages and motels that stretch out along the beach and sprawl around the harbor. And though Destin's main drag along Route 98 isn't nearing the level of Panama City, which must hold the world record for souvenir shops and beachware emporiums per square inch, it sometimes seems to be heading there with a collection of kiddie parks, water slides, dinosaur putt-putt golf, and T-shirt shops to warm the heart of any 11-year-old. But then Destin is partly lost-in-space Margaritaville, partly Miami-like condo corridor, and partly the world of Southern tacky in which only the scenery changes from Myrtle Beach, S.C., to Branson, Mo.
What saves the place is that the beaches, fishing and food are so good you can take or leave the strip. There are plenty of first-rate restaurants like the Back Porch, an unpretentious cedar-shingled eatery with a screened porch that juts out over the Gulf where you can eat burgers, amberjack sandwiches or skewered mahi-mahi; seafood restaurants like AJ's, Harry T's and Captain Dave's on the Gulf and the harbor, or the Hatteras Cafe. There are also surprises like Louisiana Lagniappe, which has excellent Cajun food. But the quintessential Destin eating experience is to go to the marina in the late afternoon when the fishing ships come in and buy your red snapper, triggerfish or grouper -- there are more than 20 species of edible fish available each season -- as soon as it comes off the boat and take it home and cook it.
If Destin can have a comfortably dogeared Southern feel, things are a bit more esthetically correct to the east at Sandestin, which is the country-club South of Southern Living magazine. A sprawling, immaculately cared-for tennis, golf and beach resort, Sandestin has the feel of South Carolina's Hilton Head or Kiawah Island and some of the other well-manicured, upscale, Southern beachfront resorts. The Market at Sandestin offers stores like Benetton, Resortworks and Taylor Cruise International. Even the ice cream shop is a tony Icehaus. Still, like almost everything in the area, prices are not out of sight. The lowest one-bedroom condomiums go for about $1,000 a week in the summer and $550 in the fall. Hotel rooms start at $119 a day in the summer and $69 in the fall. There are bike rentals, water skiing and a full range of supervised activities for children, and the Elephant Walk Restaurant is highly recommended.
East of Sandestin on State Highway 30A, which dips down to the Gulf and then runs along it, the pretension level drops back toward zero. This is an area of weathered cedar homes on stilts, new low-rise condominiums and faux Cape Cod cottages that has the quiet, lost-in-the-ozone feel of a classic getaway. You can see old boys from Opelika with 12-packs sitting under the shade of the carport, but visitors tend to be suburbanites from such cities as Birmingham and Dallas who rent houses or condominiums by the week in areas like Santa Rosa Beach or Blue Mountain Beach. For food, you can't beat Goatfeathers, near Santa Rosa Beach, which has one of the all-time great steamed fish platters and wonderful fried pickles upstairs and a fresh fish market downstairs that will steam your shrimp for you at no extra charge.
A little farther down the coast is Grayton Beach, which is half Jimmy Buffett and half Flannery O'Connor, a totally unexpected slice of Southern eccentricity plopped down along one of the most beautiful stretches of beaches that's been designated as a state park. Grayton Beach is one of the oldest tourist spots along the beach, with a collection of homey cottages with screened porches that the same families have owned or rented each summer for decades, plus a few newer homes that are generally rented by the same people every year. But the highlight is Patrones of Grayton Beach, an artists' colony and makeshift zoo that has one of the great sno-cone stands in America and one of the strangest bed and breakfasts anywhere.
Patrones, on Highway 283 into town, is an informal jumble of 150 banana trees and a dozen or so wooden booths turned into galleries and shops that has the look of a barnyard that's gone upmarket. It has 11 galleries and shops, the Dream Cafe, the Patrones Bed and Brunch (Grayton is laid back enough that brunch seems to make more sense than breakfast), pontoon and canoe rental, and the amazing menagerie that Gene Florence, who started the whole thing, has accumulated over time. There are two peacocks and two peahens, three varieties of pheasants, plus horses, goats, various varieties of fowl and a Vietnamese pot-bellied pig. In the middle of all this is the bed and brunch, owned by B. J. Totten. The exterior isn't much, but inside the units have a sleek modern decor and the top unit has a wonderful thatched palmetto leaf ceiling on the porch. The brunch is coffee, juice and muffins at the Dream Cafe, which presents live music a few nights a week. And the best part of all might be the sno-cone stand, which offers 53 varieties of sno-cones, with the juices displayed in a gorgeous every-color-of-the rainbow array of glass decanters and the ice dispensed from an ancient sno-cone machine that serves up elegant thin slivers of snow-like ice.
The Dream Cafe is wonderful for informal eating, and Cafe Mama in what used to be the town's general store is also recommended. But the real place to eat in Grayton Beach is Criolla's, which is often cited as one of the top restaurants in Florida and deservedly so.
Started by an emigre from Louisiana, Criolla's combines the food of the Caribbean and South Louisiana with Spanish sauces and flavors.
The setting has a cool Caribbean feel, and from the paella, to the Haitian food to the creole red snapper and the amazing Key lime cheesecake, Criolla's is really something special.
If you want to splurge for one big meal (entrees range from $15.95 to $23.95), this is definitely the place.
And then for those previously impervious to cultural whiplash there's Seaside, which trades in Flannery O'Connor for Architectural Digest. Eighty acres of picket fences, widows' walks, front porches, tin roofs, graceful balconies and beachfront pavilions, Seaside plunks bits of Cape Cod, Nantucket, Charleston and Savannah in the middle of the Florida Panhandle. The result is every Atlantan's idea of the South reborn -- cooler, newer, more seamless and refined than the Yankees ever dreamed of. Forget hoop skirts. If Scarlett O'Hara came back to life, she'd run a designer iced tea and Key lime pie emporium overlooking the beach here.
Seaside is as relentlessly tasteful as anyplace on the planet, from its brick-paved, car-free streets, to the dazzling two-story skylighted gourmet grocery and delicatessen called the Modica Market, to the Arabian bazaars of shops and booths, to Bud and Alley's, the beachside restaurant, which ranks among the best in the area. For kids, there's Camp Seaside, which offers tennis, yoga, basketball and bike trips to Patrones.
For adults, there are film festivals, croquet, Swedish massage, sailing and wine tastings. Summer rentals start at $105 for the motor court, and weekly cottage rental runs from $749 to $2,860. In the fall they drop to a low of $595 and a high of $2,265.
Seaside may strike more than a few people as the beachfront version of Harry Connick Jr. -- tasteful virtuosity without soul -- but even the cynics are likely to be dazzled by it. And if it's too much, it's only a five-minute drive to the goats and sno-cones back in the real world at Patrones.
 
 
 
PLACES TO STAY, PLACES TO EAT
Accommodations
 Destin and Fort Walton Beach offer more than 10,000 rooms ranging from hotels and motels to condominiums and private cottages. For complete listings call the Emerald Coast Tourist Development Council, (800) 322-3319.
At the budget end, there are many places like the Best Rest Inn, 402 Highway 98 East, (800) 874-0470, or the Seaview Cottages, 316 Highway 98, (904) 837-6211, in Destin, or the Benchmark Inn, 573 Santa Rosa Boulevard, (800) 238-8686, or the Econo Lodge, 100 Miracle Strip Parkway, (800) 325-6343, in Fort Walton Beach where rooms are available for less than $70 a night.
At the higher end, one of the most popular places to stay in Destin is the Henderson Park Inn, (904) 837-2434, 2700 Scenic Beach Highway 98, bordering Henderson Park, which has 20 large Gulf-front suites and 18 efficiency suites. Summer rates range from $165 a night to $210.
Another good way to find a place to stay is to check with some of the large realty companies that offer hotels, houses and condominiums to suit almost any taste. Abbott Realty, (800) 336-4853 has access to most of the large hotels and condominiums in Destin and Fort Walton Beach. Dune Allen Realty, (800) 423-7433, in Santa Rosa Beach, has an excellent supply of rental properties, particularly houses, on Highway 30A along the Gulf.
The Patrones Bed and Brunch, on Route 283, Grayton Beach, Fla. 32459, can be reached at (904) 231-1606. Studio apartments are $85 a night, $75 for additional nights.
For information on accommodations and attractions in Sandestin call (800) 277-0800.
For information on accommodations in Seaside, on County Road 30A between Grayton State Park and Seagrove Beach, call (904) 231-1320.
 
Dining Out
 The Back Porch, 1740 Highway 98 East, Destin, (904) 837-2022, is a budget choice. Try the chargrilled amberjack sandwich for $4.99 or a two-course dinner for one, $10.99.
Captain Dave's on the Gulf, 3796 Highway 98 East, (904) 837-2627, Captain Dave's on the Harbor, 314A Highway 98 East, (904) 837-6357, and AJ's Seafood and Oyster House, 116 Highway 98 East, (904) 837-1913, are some of the more reliable seafood restaurants in Destin, with meals running around $25 for two.
Elephant Walk, 5500 Highway 98 East, (904) 267-4800), in Sandestin, is a sleek restaurant overlooking the Gulf. The crab cake appetizer ($8.25) is particularly good. Dinner for two about $50, without wine.
Goatfeathers, at Santa Rosa Beach on Highway 30A, (904) 267-3342, is a somewhat moderately priced seafood restaurant with a pleasant outdoor deck. Dinner for two about $60 with wine.
Criolla's, at Route 283 and Highway 30A, (904) 267-1267, may be the best restaurant in the Panhandle, with offerings including a conch fritters appetizer ($6.50) and Creole red snapper entree ($20.95). Dinner for two with wine about $70.
Bud & Alley's, on Highway 30A at Seaside, (904) 231-5900, changes its menu monthly. Staple main courses are coastal crabcakes meuniere ($19.95) and grilled lamp chops ($24.95). Dinner for two with wine about $60.
A popular hangout is Frank LeBleau's Cajun Kitchen on Highway 98 near Santa Rosa Beach, (904) 267-3724), where a full breakfast is $2.75. Dinner for two under $20.

ALMOST PERFECT, by Alice Adams. (Knopf, $23.) Social and business pressures drive emotions in this painful, funny novel about a young woman on the rise who loves a crazy man.
ANGELS & INSECTS: Two Novellas, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $21.) Two long novellas, and very clever ones, in which insect life is an analogue of Victorian society and literary immortality is compared to the real thing.
CAPE OF STORMS: The First Life of Adamastor, by Andre Brink. (Simon & Schuster, $16.) Grave and tragic can be expected in a fable of the first interracial contact in South Africa; Mr. Brink, a longtime opponent of his country's policies, makes it diverting and witty as well. Miraculous!
CRUELTY AND SILENCE: War, Tyranny, Uprising, and the Arab World, by Kanan Makiya. (Norton, $22.95.) The cruelty is that of the Saddam Hussein regime in the author's native Iraq; the silence, that of the Arab intellectuals who condone or assist it.
CUERVO TALES, by Robert Roper. (Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.) Ten interlinked stories that follow a burned-out survivor of the luminous, excessive 1960's into the downer decades that followed.
DENYING THE HOLOCAUST: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, by Deborah E. Lipstadt. (Free Press, $22.95.) A historian untangles the perverse and ingenious arguments of those who say there was no Holocaust.
DRUMS ALONG THE CONGO: On the Trail of Mokele-Mbembe, the Last Living Dinosaur, by Rory Nugent. (Houghton Mifflin, cloth, $21.95; paper, $10.95.) And was it found? Well, something was, and the trip was loads of fun.
GAME OVER: How Nintendo Zapped an American Industry, Captured Your Dollars, and Enslaved Your Children, by David Sheff. (Random House, $25.) A nuts-and-bolts history of the world-bestriding Japanese video game colossus.
A MOMENT OF WAR: A Memoir of the Spanish Civil War, by Laurie Lee. (New Press, $17.95.) An English poet and memoirist's bleak, metaphorical monument to his ragged brigade of international volunteers, in a plain, understated style that fits both the subject and the era.
PICASSO AND DORA: A Personal Memoir, by James Lord. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) Life at the heart of the post-1945 artistic enterprise: what a genius, his mistress and a shrewd memoirist did and said to and about one another.
SEPARATE ROOMS, by Pier Vittorio Tondelli. (Serpent's Tail, paper, $14.99.) An Italian novel of imperfect love and urgent grief, by a young writer who died of AIDS in 1991.
TSVETAEVA, by Viktoria Schweitzer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) The life and apocalyptic times (1892-1941) of a great Russian poet, a woman whom no revolution could contain.
UNITED STATES: Essays 1952-1992, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $37.50.) In 40 years of essays and articles, the author expounds on sex, politics, literature, himself and other phenomena.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: Government, Up Close and Populist

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis, a senior editor at The New Republic, is the author of "Liar's Poker" and other books about business.

 BODY:

NOT FOR SALE AT ANY PRICE
How We Can Save America for Our Children.
By Ross Perot.
158 pp. New York:
Hyperion. Paper, $5.95.
 
THE WISH FOR KINGS
Democracy at Bay.
By Lewis H. Lapham.
213 pp. New York:
Grove Press. $22. 
 ROSS PEROT'S new book is a neat pastiche of his recent speeches that breaks down a bit messily into two parts, a quiet part with bar graphs and pie charts and a noisy part with lots of words written in block print LIKE THIS. The first and longer section of "Not for Sale at Any Price: How We Can Save America for Our Children" consists of Mr. Perot's economic plan. The most striking thing about it is how much less brave, honest and refreshing it seems than his early pronunciamentos: it looks a lot like the budget being hammered out now on Capitol Hill. The main revenue raisers are a gas tax, an increase in the top income tax rate to 33 percent, an increase in the tax on rich recipients of Social Security, an increase in the cigarette tax and a restriction on home mortgage deductions. The main spending reductions are in military spending ($40 billion), lower interest payments ($145 billion) and an unexplained 10 percent across-the-board cut in Government services ($73 billion).
Of course, if Mr. Perot now seems unoriginal it is only because he has been so brilliantly successful; his plan hasn't changed so much as the world around it has, and for that we owe him thanks. But by most calculations he's now meant to vanish. The role of third parties "has not been to win or govern, but to agitate, educate, generate new ideas and supply the dynamic element in our political life," wrote the historian Richard Hofstadter in his newly relevant 1955 classic, "The Age of Reform." "When a third party's demands become popular enough, they are appropriated by one or both of the major parties and the third party disappears. Third parties are like bees: once they have stung, they die."
The bee has stung and yet he lives. I can think of at least two possible reasons why. The first is that perceptions have not caught up to reality, thanks in part to Mr. Perot's verbal smoke screen. His opponents may have conveniently acquired his fiscal concerns, but he has conveniently learned some of their accounting skills. Although he has no health care plan, for example, he subtracts $141 billion from his budget in the name of "health care cost containment." He claims to be able to raise $21 billion by taxing foreign corporations, a number widely ridiculed when it was trotted out during the 1992 campaign by Bill Clinton. The bar chart on page 99 shows the budget deficit under the Perot plan becoming a surplus by 1998, but it is based on outdated deficit projections. The (highly credible) Congressional Budget Office has revised its numbers, and Mr. Perot's are now off by several hundred billion dollars.
But it is also possible that Mr. Perot's appeal always had less to do with his economic plan than with other things, especially his gift for tapping into free-floating popular resentments. The parts of "Not for Sale at Any Price" that have nothing to do with the budget deficit have to do mainly with whipping up hatred toward Washington insiders. One chapter on Washington politics bears the highly misleading title "Good People, Bad System." This disguise -- "I'm not here to point fingers" -- is as thin as the forced smile Mr. Perot wears when he goes on the attack. The gist of Mr. Perot's message is that for our system to work we need only to put a scrupulous businessman in charge of it: after all, "we live in the greatest country in the history of man." In other words, Good System, Bad People.
"Between 1980 and 1991," he writes in one characteristic passage, "158 former Federal officials left office to become registered foreign agents.
"Take a look at the list below; it's like looking at a list of AWOL soldiers who turned up fighting for the enemy. This is the reason that two million high-paying factory jobs were shipped to Asia during the 1980's.
* 25 White House officials
* 65 executive agency officials
* 50 Congressional staff members
* 10 members of the House of Representatives
* 8 senators.
THIS IS ECONOMIC TREASON."
Now one can think up many reasons for the decline of American manufacturing: a low savings rate, the Harvard Business School, an ignorant work force, sheer laziness. But on any reasonable list, lobbying by Americans on behalf of foreigners is so far down that it's hardly worth mentioning. Put another way, you could purge the Federal Government of ethical problems and still not make a dent in our standard of living. Mr. Perot concedes as much with the paucity of evidence he offers to the contrary. The misconduct of Washington insiders is real enough. But perhaps the main consequence of the popular indignation it arouses is the distraction from addressing society's larger problems.
In a ringing endorsement of Mr. Perot's governing sentiment, Lewis H. Lapham, the editor of Harper's Magazine, writes in "The Wish for Kings" that "most of the country's present trouble follows from the blind arrogance of too many people in power and the apathy and lack of objection on the part of too many people out of power." That the populist tendency to personalize events that are largely impersonal has reached the fashionable New York dinner party circuit reveals just how far we've drifted toward Ross Perot's world view. About Mr. Perot himself -- or, as he is referred to, "H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire adopting the unlikely pose of a rural populist" -- and most everything else, Mr. Lapham is disdainful. But in the personal animus he bears Washingtonians there is a clue to Mr. Perot's appeal. A few passages will serve to convey the flavor of the whole:
"For a period of about 18 months in 1985 and 1986 I never once traveled to Washington (whether on the Metroliner or a plane) without finding myself seated next to an expectant contractor with whom I could discuss the prices paid for access and connection in the form of a campaign contribution or a legal fee. The gentlemen understood that they were on the road to court. None of them first thought of themselves as democrats or of the United States as a democracy."
And: "Over the course of the last 20 years, and across the span of an extensive acquaintance among the people who enjoy most of the country's advantages -- bond salesmen and politicians, as well as publishers, corporate vice presidents, novelists, lawyers, English professors and under secretaries of state -- I've noticed that most of the respondents fear and despise both the theory and the practice of democracy."
And: "Although I have spent the better part of 20 years in and around the New York literary bazaars, I have come across only a small number of people who can talk about any particular book at convincing length, and I don't think that I have met more than two or three writers who know much about the specific weights and measures of economics, medicine, history, law, finance, physics or human anatomy."
Every sentence is too long by a third and arched to the breaking point. ("Human anatomy"? "The specific weights and measures of economics"?) But the clash of style and content does generate a certain frisson -- think of Jeremiah as played by David Niven in black tie. Mr. Lapham co-opts his readers the same way that Mr. Perot co-opts his followers, by encouraging them to feel superior.
There is no attempt to persuade with reason. One either enjoys Lewis Lapham's many contradictions and shares Lewis Lapham's many prejudices, or one doesn't. When he writes, "From the point of view of most functionaires whom I've known in Washington, the shift to monarchy would require nothing more difficult than a change of costume," one can titter appreciatively or wonder what on earth he's talking about, since the functionaires most offensive to him exist either to get re-elected or to help others get re-elected.
THE logic at work here is the logic of snobbery: what matters is not what is said but who is saying it, and, perhaps, how many subordinate clauses he can afford to employ as hod carriers. But this is interesting. Snobbery is a technique for defending one's (presumably threatened) turf. Nothing more irritates the snob, because nothing is more threatening, than social ambition in others. And what irritates Lewis Lapham most of all is, ludicrously, the airs put on by Washington insiders. "I can admire Washington for its trees, for its monuments and some of its stately public buildings, but I have trouble with the stately inhabitants," he writes. "So few of them know how to laugh at their own pretension, and so many of them mistake themselves for statues."
So there it is: the poor bastards in Washington have for the last 20 years made their hand-over-hand climb up the drainpipe of American success only to reach the top ledge and find the editor of Harper's waiting to stomp on their fingertips and send them plummeting. I wouldn't care to push the point too far, but perhaps Lewis Lapham's odd compulsion to quash Washington pretensions, which in my view are far less robust than those in New York or Los Angeles, is the boutique version of supermarket Perot-mania. That is to say, the journalist who casts himself as an upper-class observer and the followers of the billionaire who casts himself as a common man reflect the same national anxiety, brought on by a collective collapse in status. If so, then I've got Lewis Lapham all wrong. Truly, he is a man of the people.
Or is it THE PEOPLE?

The New York Times
