SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2007 words

HEADLINE: A Hospital's New Site Stirs Opposition

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
UP and down the western edge of mid-Manhattan, St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center searched for a place to put its new building. It finally settled on a site on Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, in what looked like a parking lot but turned out to be a hornet's nest.
That is because the site, directly across from the Worldwide Plaza office and apartment complex, is in Broadway's backyard, just a few steps west of the Gershwin, Circle in the Square, Ambassador and Eugene O'Neill Theaters. 
 And it is clear what the theater community does not want in its backyard: a 12-story hospital with 250 beds and a busy emergency room, plus ambulances whooping outside during performance hours. An unusual alliance of Broadway leaders is waging a forceful battle against the St. Clare's plan, even though a hospital would be permitted on the site as a matter of right under zoning rules.
"It's a real land-use tragedy," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the land-use committee of Community Board 5. "There are no villains. There's not necessarily a right answer."
The story of St. Clare's search for a new home -- it is now in a badly outdated jumble of buildings between 51st and 52d Streets, Ninth and 10th Avenues -- speaks of the hurdles facing any institution looking for a usable and affordable development site, even a parking lot on the far West Side, even in what ought to be a buyer's market.
It also illustrates the chance circumstances by which major real estate decisions are made. Had the city not planned to build a shaft at 10th Avenue and 48th Street to the future Water Tunnel No. 3, the hospital might have been able to buy that parcel from the Rudin family.
Had the commercial market not collapsed, the Eighth Avenue site might not have been available at all, as the developers Ian Woodner and William Zeckendorf Jr. once contemplated an office tower there, designed by Pei Cobb Freed & Partners.
As it happened, the tower was never built. Mr. Woodner died in 1990 and his estate turned the deed over to the Chase Manhattan Bank last August, in lieu of foreclosure.
Enter St. Clare's, which is under contract to buy the 35,000 square foot site from Chase for up to $17 million, depending on the closing date.
Should St. Clare's receive approval from the State Hospital Review and Planning Council by year's end, it might begin building in the second half of 1994 and finish in late 1996 or early 1997.
"It's just a perfect spot," said Richard N. Yezzo, president of the hospital. "It's affordable. There is certainly enough space. It's vacant. A hospital is as-of-right. It fronts on an avenue. It's close enough that we're not abandoning Clinton. Transportation is perfect for staff and patients."
Broadway takes a much different view.
"That site is not a good site," said Jack L. Goldstein, special assistant to the president of the Actors' Equity Association. "It's not good for the theater district for a hospital to be there and it's not good for a hospital to be there, in terms of the provision of health care."
Opponents include the three major theater owners -- the Shubert Organization, Nederlander Organization and Jujamcyn Theaters -- as well as the Theater Development Fund and the Mayor's Midtown Citizens Committee. They question the wisdom of placing a hospital in an entertainment district, insisting that the site offers far better opportunities for theater-related uses. Traffic and noise are also major concerns.
"It is our strong belief that placing a hospital on this site is no more appropriate than it would be to place it on Broadway and 45th Street," said Robert W. Callely, managing director of the Theater Development Fund, which is well known for the TKTS booth it operates in Duffy Square.
"The congestion on all three streets around the site is already at a peak," Mr. Callely said, "with 49th and 50th Streets being major crosstown bus and taxi arteries. There is already a fire house located one block away."
THE site may be in Broadway's backyard but is also literally at the front door of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, whose office is in Worldwide Plaza. The law firm does not share the theater community's concern.
"We think it would be better for the neighborhood and the community to have the hospital there than to have the parking lot," said Samuel C. Butler, the presiding partner.
Opponents do not relish the prospect of battle with a hospital that has long links to the theater community, which is committed to the treatment of AIDS and which is sponsored by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese. "I'd rather be almost anywhere else than fighting this issue," Mr. Goldstein said.
However, he said: "If we don't begin to ask questions related to the health of this industry in a very forceful fashion, they're not going to be asked. And we greatly fear that an irreplaceable cultural and economic institution will disappear."
Mr. Yezzo, too, sees the matter in life-and-death terms. "There's a primary desire to be a good neighbor," he said, "but we cannot abandon our commitment to the patients we serve. If this doesn't happen now, it will be very difficult to continue that commitment."
How did St. Clare's get to this point?
First, it determined that it would take too long and cost too much to renovate its existing buildings. To stage the construction work, about 60 percent of the hospital would have to be closed for six to eight months, Mr. Yezzo said, "which would not allow us to continue our base of operations."
Searching for a new location, Mr. Yezzo said, the hospital looked for a site of at least 35,000 square feet, zoned to permit a hospital with some 300,000 square feet of space as a matter of right. It could not be so remote as to jeopardize the safety of patients and staff. And there could be no housing on the site.
In 1991, a site survey was compiled by the Williams Real Estate Company. Although institutions do not usually reveal development sites they have rejected, St. Clare's search is detailed in an application to the state Health Department.
Among the discarded possibilities were Olympia & York's development site at Ninth Avenue and 31st Street; the Y.M.C.A.'s William Sloane House, a former 1,400-room residence hall at 34th Street and Ninth Avenue; an assemblage at Broadway and 56th Street owned by the Zeckendorfs, and the former John Jay College building on 10th Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets.
"They were either too expensive, too large, too far west or unavailable," Mr. Yezzo said.
There was, however, a promising property on 10th Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets: a 47,000-square-foot parking lot owned by the Rudin family. The price was tentatively set at $10.5 million.
"We would have liked to do a deal with the hospital," Lewis Rudin said. "It's a good location for that hospital, a better location than Eighth Avenue. It's less congested."
There was a hitch -- a hitch about 45 feet wide and 700 feet deep, as deep as the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue is high.
CITY engineers identified the Rudins' lot as a good spot for a riser shaft from the third water tunnel. "They look for places that would displace the fewest businesses and homes," said Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the city's Environmental Protection Department, which is building the tunnel. "Parking lots tend to fit that description very well."
Shafts are situated every mile or so above the tunnel, to bring the water up through clusters of 48-inch pipes. In the case of the 48th Street shaft, Mr. Michaels said, construction could occur any time between 1997 and 2001. If an owner will not sell a needed property, he said, the city will condemn it.
With that, St. Clare's turned to the Eighth Avenue site, an L-shaped parking lot wrapping around St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church and the Wally's & Joseph's restaurant.
As recently as mid-1990, the site was being considered for an office tower with anywhere from 700,000 to 1 million square feet of space. But the site, together with other properties owned by the Woodner estate, was taken back by Chase last year. In December, St. Clare's signed a purchase contract.
The new hospital, designed by Taylor Clark Architects, would be financed by a $181 million bond issue by the New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency. Its ground floor would be bisected by a north-south driveway, keeping the entrance to the emergency room off the surrounding streets.
St. Clare's applied to the state in December for a "certificate of need" that would authorize the project. No hearing has been scheduled. In assessing the need for the new St. Clare's, the state review panel would look at siting "in the broad sense," said William Gormley, of the Health Department, but not whether it should be on, say, 10th Avenue as opposed to Eighth Avenue.
A lawyer for the hospital, Shelly S. Friedman of Brown & Wood, said an environmental consultant was being selected to study the traffic conditions. As for noise from ambulances, he said, "people who understand hospital policy will discover that ambulances shut off their sirens as they approach hospitals."
Community Board 5, whose district includes the Eighth Avenue site, has not yet taken a position on the project, said its chairman, Nicholas Fish. Neither has Community Board 4, immediately to the west, within whose boundaries St. Clare's now operates. But a committee of that board has identified alternative sites from Ninth to 12th Avenue.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan favors the granting of a certificate. "I strongly support the need to rebuild St. Clare's," she said in a letter to community leaders. Moreover, she said, "neither my office nor any agency of city government has the power to compel a change in the hospital's planned location."
However, her office has set up a working group through which the hospital and its critics may be able to address design, streetfront uses and other issues.
But that misses the point, the critics say. "Even if we had the best and most interesting architecture, and control over ambulances and doctors' parking, it still wouldn't be an appropriate use for that land," said Lee Silver, corporate relations director for the Shubert Organization, which owns the Ambassador Theater, on the same block.
The Mayor's Midtown Citizens Committee declared its opposition to the project in a March 9 meeting. Among those who took part were representatives of the New York Times Company, New York Telephone, the League of American Theaters and Producers, Park Tower Realty, Madison Square Garden, Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, St. Luke's Lutheran Church and the Landmark and Sardi's restaurants.
"MANY years have been spent to rehabilitate and preserve the theater district and to further enhance it with theater-related uses," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the committee and of the Shubert Organization. "The hospital would be antithetical to this purpose and would create further disruption in an already traffic-congested area."
The theater industry's "blue sky" vision for the Eighth Avenue site, Mr. Silver said, would be a mixed residential and commercial building, with space for rehearsal studios, music studios, offices for scenic designers, or costume and wig shops.
"I'm absolutely confounded about why that site was chosen," said Paul Libin, producing director of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns the Eugene O'Neill Theater, across 49th Street from the hospital site. He said St. Clare's ought to rebuild on a site closer to the community it serves in Clinton. "That seems to be more appropriate because that's where the hospital is now," Mr. Libin said.
But St. Clare's is committed to the Eighth Avenue site. "Because of that contract, we're pledged to move forthwith," Mr. Yezzo said.
"I'm neither being stubborn nor pig-headed," he said. "I fail to see any basis for objection to a hospital in that area. Nine hundred well-paid employees are going to be working right there. How could that be bad for business?"

HEADLINE: A Woman's Ordeal Helps Her Become A Better Pastor

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
FOR the Rev. Alice O'Donovan, being open about her sexual orientation has been like letting a genie out of a bottle. "The genie never goes back in the bottle," she said. "You can't ever take it back."
Five years ago, Ms. O'Donovan became the first openly gay person to be ordained a United Church of Christ minister in Connecticut. She paid a price for her honesty, she said, but her struggle for acceptance has deepened her spirituality and made her a more compassionate pastor. 
 And at a time when gay and lesbian rights are being debated in many mainstream churches and in the military, the 47-year-old woman, who is divorced and the mother of three children, has found acceptance among the members of a small country church, the First Congregational Church of South Windham.
"I had to learn to be very clear about the distinction between God's love and people's judgment, because people's judgment is sometimes pretty ferocious," she said as she described one of the benefits of her openness. "God's love is all-embracing. That's what makes it worth the doing."
The white clapboard church, which dates from 1902, is on a sleepy residential street just off Route 32 between Norwich and Willimantic. Sixty-two people belong to the congregation, part of the United Church of Christ, and about 40 attend Sunday services, said Ms. O'Donovan, who became pastor a year ago. She was honest about her sexual orientation with members of the church's search committee, who interviewed the candidates for pastor. But since it was not an issue for them, they decided not to make a point of telling the congregation, Ms. O'Donovan said. Since her hiring, she has been telling members one at a time about her relationship with Kathleen Crewdson, her partner of nearly 13 years.
The reactions have varied. Some people were unconcerned while others have taken longer to adjust. "Sometimes they have been polite up front and surprised and distressed afterward but have been able to work that through," Ms. O'Donovan said.
The church had been without a pastor for 13 months and Ms. O'Donovan, who worked on a dairy farm before she began her seminary studies, impressed the five-member search committee with her enthusiasm.
"Without a minister, the membership tends to fade away and not tend to business," said Helen Card, a member of the church since the 1940's and chairwoman of the committee. "She's full of energy. We heard her preach, and she's dynamic. She doesn't whisper up there."
The church sought a pastor who would be at ease not only with its members, 37 percent of whom are retired, but also with the rest of South Windham's community -- the library, the fire department and the grange. Ms. O'Donovan's relationship with another woman, and the fact that the church is conservative, did not stop the church from calling her to the pulpit.
"Being a staid New England group, maybe some do have reservations," Mrs. Card said, "but they support Alice regardless because of her personality and activity."
 
Uncertain Ordination
 As far as she is concerned, Ms. O'Donovan said, she could not have asked for a better first year in South Windham. She said that she is happier and more relaxed than she was five years ago, when her ordination was more uncertain than most because she shares a longstanding relationship with a woman rather than a man.
A second ordeal followed, during her first pastorate at a church in Vermont. Her openness about her sexual orientation brought criticism from many of the members and some stopped attending services, she said. Tensions worsened until she finally decided to leave.
Now, Ms. O'Donovan is eagerly involved in the work of leading a congregation. In her office one afternoon, she wore khaki slacks, brown sandals and the cleric's band of white beneath the collar of her light blue shirt. Her interest in rural ministry grew from her upbringing in rural areas of New York State and Massachusetts and her informal ways seem in keeping with South Windham's quiet, turn-of-the-century houses and country roads.
Being a lesbian pastor is no different from being a heterosexual pastor, Ms. O'Donovan said, except that the rejection she suffered at the Vermont church has left her wary and more afraid of being condemned or disliked. "I try not to let it put me on the defensive," she said. "That's the temptation. But coming out of that painful experience, it takes time to quit looking over my shoulder."
 
Buried Orientation
 Ms. O'Donovan grew up in the United Church of Christ but converted to Catholicism when she was in her 20's. She attended the University of Massachusetts and after her marriage became a full-time mother. For many years, her sexual orientation was buried.
In 1982 she was divorced. She and her children, who are 19, 20 and 21, live with Ms. Crewdson, a massage therapist, in Tolland. The women share a covenant union, described by Ms. O'Donovan as a commitment before God and the community of faithful that was celebrated in 1984 in a service at the Storrs Congregational Church.
The couple have known each other for 23 years. Their sexual orientation became public when the church they belonged to learned of their relationship and refused to recommend Ms. O'Donovan for a scholarship to Hartford Seminary. That "threw us out of the closet," she said. "We decided to turn that liability into an asset and to be fully open."
She completed her studies at Hartford Seminary and graduated in the spring of 1988 from Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass. As far as she knows, Ms. O'Donovan said, she is still the only openly gay woman to be ordained in the state. The United Church of Christ, formed in 1961 by the merger of the Evangelical and Reformed Church with Congregational Christian Churches, is the only mainstream Protestant denomination that ordains openly gay and lesbian clergy.
 
Some Positive Changes
 Although gays and lesbians are still not accepted in much of mainstream religious life, some positive changes have taken place in the five years since her ordination, Ms. O'Donovan said. "I don't feel so lonely because I may be the only one who has gone through the ordination process. There are more lesbian and gay clergy out there and we're there for each other in some important ways."
Some churches in Connecticut are taking steps toward welcoming openly homosexual members through what is called the Open and Affirming process, by which some United Church of Christ congregations becomes sensitive to gay and lesbian issues. Seven of 273 United Church of Christ congregations in Connecticut have Open and Affirming status, Ms. O'Donovan said, and about 12 more are addressing the issue in sermons, workshops and discussions.
Ms. O'Donovan draws support from lay and ordained members of the United Church Coalition for Lesbian-Gay Concerns, an organization established 10 years ago in the state to insure that lesbian, gay and bisexual Christians are able to participate fully in their churches. She tries to raise awareness of homophobia and other lay and lesbian issues through the articles she writes and the workshops she leads.
 
'Justice Preacher'
 But her sermons express equality for all. Calling herself a "justice preacher," Ms. O'Donovan reaches beyond gay and lesbian issues and exhorts her congregation to reach out to all who are different because of economic situation, skin color, accent, sex or age.
Susan Thomas is a member of the board of deacons, who are responsible for the spiritual life and worship of the church. "I didn't know anyone who was homosexual before," she said. "It has really broadened my horizons and helped me to become more aware of their issues, of how they are discriminated against and victimized. I learned more about her struggles and it made me a lot more sensitive."
Many members have turned to their new pastor during personal crises and have found her a strong support, Mrs. Thomas said.
Other members report positive changes. The Sunday school has grown, more people are attending church and there is a new organist and choir director. In addition, the church is joining with two other congregations in Franklin and Columbia to help a family from Bosnia resettle in the area.
 
'Trust Their Love and Respect'
 Asked what her congregation's reaction would be upon seeing their pastor's story in print, Ms. O'Donovan sighed and said: "I don't know. That's the risk. People may ask questions or have concerns but fundamentally I trust their love and respect."
Ms. O'Donovan said these are the best years of her life. But she said she would not be the good pastor she is today if she had not endured pain that left her with more compassion for other people and their pain. She said she cares more about being a good pastor than about being a lesbian pastor.
And as she left the church and walked down the driveway, she summed up her dreams. "I hope I can do some good for my church. There was this Jewish man who was walking along in Judea. He said, 'Repent.' We're still doing it."

LENGTH: 1109 words

HEADLINE: Your Home: Roommate Law;
Staying On If a Tenant Doesn't

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
TEN years ago, New York State enacted a "roommate law," acknowledging the rise of nontraditional living arrangements. The measure gives tenants the right to bring in a nonfamily member without first gaining the consent of the landlord. Reasons can range from financial to personal. And hundreds of such roommates moved in.
Today, a growing number of these individuals are facing a follow-up issue. Under what circumstances, they ask, may they also have the right to stay on should the tenant move out or die? 
 The issue is of critical importance in New York City because thousands of roommates moved into low-cost, rent-regulated apartments. Many were gay partners. And their concerns about succession have been made all the more significant in the AIDS crisis.
These particular roommates are also keen to press the issue because in 1989 the New York State Court of Appeals affirmed the right of a gay partner to be deemed a family member for the purposes of succession in a rent-controlled apartment.
The case, Braschi v. Stahl Associates, further prompted the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency that administers rent regulation, to broaden its definition of a "family-type" relationship for succession in any rent-regulated apartment.
But even these changes left unanswered questions concerning individual situations that did not neatly conform to either the Braschi decision or the modified regulations.
These are the ones that have since landed in court. And the growing body of law resulting from the decisions can now provide anyone who originally moved in as a roommate -- and never became a co-tenant with full tenant rights -- with a better idea of what it takes to qualify.
Warren A. Estis, who practices landlord-tenant law in New York City, noted that many roommates never became co-tenants because landlords refused them the option. "It was against their economic interests," he said. "If they did so they would have to exhaust another layer of tenant to win a vacancy increase. And if the original tenant moved out the cycle could begin all over again. Landlords would lose control."
So what should a roommate do? Robert A. Jacobs, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in landlord-tenant issues, noted that to qualify as a family member for succession purposes the roommates needed to prove that they lived in the apartment for at least two years with the tenant before the tenant's departure.
The apartment must also qualify as a primary residence for both tenant and roommate -- defined as the address given on a driving license, for voting or income tax purposes, among other criteria. A crucial element is that there must have been a nontraditional or traditional family relationship between the two during the two-year period.
Exceptions include the disabled and the elderly. In both instances the required duration of the combined living arrangements is reduced to a year.
The other exception is for married couples. A spouse has an automatic right of succession even if the marriage lasted only for the final few months of the tenant's life, added Joseph Burden, another Manhattan lawyer specializing in landlord-tenant matters.
In all other instances, even if the roommate can readily prove an intimate relationship with the tenant, any right of succession may be denied if the relationship in the apartment lasted less than two years.
Consider the 1993 case of Allerton Associates v. Shannon, which involved Barbara Thomas and her male companion, identified in the records only as "Shannon." He contended that he qualified as a family member because the two had lived as a couple in the apartment and had shared household expenses. Even so, the court denied the companion any claim to the apartment -- the tenant having moved out after the relationship fell apart -- because they had lived there together for only 10 months.
IN a related case a year earlier -- Park Holding Company v. Power -- the roommate, James Power, was also denied succession rights. The problem was that his five-year relationship with Jay Bernstein, the tenant, had ended 10 years earlier.
Though the two men had stayed on in the spacious two-bedroom apartment (with terrace) on the Upper East Side as roommates they no longer commingled their finances or showed any other sign of a familial relationship. It was not enough, said the court, that they had once been involved, or that this relationship had taken place in the apartment for more than two years. It was the most recent years that counted.
What if a tenant and a roommate can prove a personal relationship even though the tenant was married to someone else during the relationship?
In Lepar Realty Corporation v. Griffin, a 1991 case, Larry Rhodes, a roommate who lived for six years in an apartment with the tenant, Deborah Griffin, contended that they had lived as a family, even having a child together. It did not matter that Mrs. Griffin had been married at the time to another person, the court ruled, since the two clearly had a long-term, family type of relationship while occupying the apartment.
IN proving such a relationship, lawyers say, the little things count. They include such gestures as having the roommate named as executor or a beneficiary in a will, sending out joint Christmas cards or going to parties or on vacation together. Proving physical intimacy, Mr. Burden noted, is not normally required.
Moreover, without any outward signs of life as a couple, declarations of a sexual relationship may be insufficient. Early this year, in ANF Company v. Cruz, Ana Arteaga, a roommate in a one-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights, failed in her bid to retain the rent-controlled apartment even though she insisted that she and the tenant, Manuel Cruz, had lived there as "husband and wife." They could not prove they had ever entertained, combined their finances or done anything else as a couple.
Finally, Mr. Estis raises the case of the Lincoln Guild Housing Corporation v. Stuckelman as having implications concerning occupancy rights of a roommate to a co-op apartment.
The Stuckelman case revolved around whether the tenant-shareholder's granddaughter could remain in the apartment after her grandmother moved to a nursing home.
Normally a co-op board has approval powers over occupancy. Yet in the Stuckelman case, Mr. Estis said, if the shareholder's granddaughter had been able to prove she was a roommate rather than a subtenant staying beyond the lease period (the status confirmed by documentary evidence), she would have won the right to stay on in the apartment rather than being evicted by the board.

HEADLINE: Florio's on a Bill-Signing Blitz; Whitman's Off to a Quiet Start

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IN June, New Jersey voters picked the two major party candidates for governor and then turned their thoughts to vacations, air-conditioners and the resurgence of the Yankees.
That left Gov. Jim Florio, the incumbent Democrat, and Christine Todd Whitman, his Republican opponent, the task of keeping themselves in the public eye and expanding their base of supporters -- all without spending too much of the money they will need for their television campaigns after Labor Day. 
 The state's public financing law effectively limits each candidate to a total expenditure of $5.9 million, which will have to finance time on New York and Philadelphia television stations, the first and fourth most expensive markets in the country.
Last week Mrs. Whitman reported that she had raised $515,000, a long way from the $2 million or so she will need to get the $3.9 million in matching funds from the taxpayers. Mr. Florio already has about $1.6 million in pocket. As a result, Mrs. Whitman has been spending a considerable amount of her limited campaign time this summer at fund-raisers.
Mrs. Whitman has also been talking with small groups of voters, listening to their views and preparing for what by all accounts will be a bruising battle in the fall. But she has not devoted much time or energy to the kind of public campaign that draws crowds and generates headlines. Mr. Florio's campaign staff has suggested that she has been "hiding" from the press and the public.
Meanwhile, Mr. Florio has been taking maximum advantage of his office to obtain press coverage, traveling the state to sign bills that in nonelection years would be signed at his desk, and personally releasing reports that would normally be dropped off without fanfare in the offices of the State House press. He has also appeared at a variety of photo opportunities, like the laying of artificial reefs in the surf off Avalon and the announcement of a new business-academic partnership in Newark.
The bill signings tend to take place in communities that stand to benefit from the new laws.
On July 1, for example, the Governor attended the swearing-in of Bret Schundler, Jersey City's Republican Mayor, and signed a bill distributing $77 million from taxes levied on power-generating plants. Mr. Florio told the 1,000 people gathered for the event that Jersey City would receive $3.3 million of the total, leaving the impression that it was like a personal gift.
Neil Upmeyer, the director of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues, a nonpartisan public interest group in Princeton, described Mrs. Whitman's summer in these terms:
"Christie has been on vacation like the rest of us, and I would suggest that that's a fundamental flaw in her campaign. She apparently has the perspective that she can rely on the good will out there for her and the ill will over taxes with regard to Florio to see her through to the fall when the campaign heats up.
"Florio is out there trying to dominate the news every day. By doing so, he is able to portray her as not having a well-thought-out platform and strategy about how she would run state government. When she is not there, it chips away at her credibility, and it could be very damaging if it continues over an extended period."
Carl Golden, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman, insists that she has been busier than her critics say. And the candidate did put in one long day on July 21, making more than a dozen campaign stops in a few counties that won considerable press coverage. But the increased campaign schedule had hardly begun when Mrs. Whitman and her family left for Idaho on July 23 for a weeklong vacation.
 
A Stop at a Gun Shop
 Mrs. Whitman has not matched the Governor's success in focusing attention on specific campaign issues, like the environment, education, housing, jobs or crime. Her best-known campaign stop was an unplanned visit in June to a gun shop while she was in Jersey City.
According to an account in The Jersey Journal, the only newspaper to cover her visit, Mrs. Whitman said that the state's ban on the sale or possession of semiautomatic assault weapons "should be cleaned up a bit" and that some weapons should not be included in the law.
She later said she was referring to .22-caliber guns used primarily for target shooting, and during a television interview called the gun ban "a lousy piece of legislation." The Florio campaign seized the opportunity to attack her on one of the very few initiatives that has won the Governor high marks with the public.
Mr. Florio went to a firing range with some state troopers who demolished watermelons with .22-caliber assault weapons for the press. And his campaign aides accused Mrs. Whitman of pandering to the National Rifle Association, which is ready to spend $1 million to defeat Mr. Florio.
Mrs. Whitman also stirred a brief but intense storm of criticism when she announced that she was hiring Larry McCarthy, the Washington-based media consultant who produced the Willie Horton campaign commercial during the 1988 Presidential campaign. The ad attacked Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, the Democratic candidate, as being soft on crime and focused on Willie Horton, a black convicted murderer who was on a weekend furlough from a Massachusetts prison when he fled and later attacked a white couple in Maryland.
Mr. McCarthy resigned the next day, but by then civil rights leaders had accused Mrs. Whitman of insensitivity.
 
Concern About the Economy
 Commenting on Mrs. Whitman's campaign to date, Mr. Golden, her spokesman, said, "We can't match the Governor's ability to travel around the state handing out checks." He added that Mrs. Whitman has consistently called upon Mr. Florio to explain his decision to push a $2.8 billion tax program through the Legislature in 1990 at a time when the state was heading into a recession.
"One thing that three recent newspaper polls show," Mr. Golden said, "is that the debate will be about the economy. The polls showed that a majority of people are concerned about the economy and the future, but when she challenges the Governor to explain why he did what he did, he says, 'Let me tell you about guns.' "
Jim Andrews, Mr. Florio's campaign manager, agreed that "bread and butter issues" like the economy and taxes will dominate the fall debate, but he said Mrs. Whitman's still unspecified intentions about how she would amend the assault weapon ban and her failure to respond to repeated challenges from the Florio campaign to reveal her own economic program demonstrate that she has no well-grounded policies.
"She hasn't a clue," Mr. Andrews said, using a phrase that appears in Florio campaign releases and is the message the campaign will be seeking to plant in the minds of voters during the fall campaign.
Mrs. Whitman has announced the formation of a "Council for Economic Recovery" and charged it with finding a strategy for rebuilding the state economy. The deadline for the report is Nov. 2, a date so late in the campaign that Florio aides have said it is a ploy to shield her from answering specific questions about her economic program until after the election. Mrs. Whitman has said she will discuss specifics being worked on by the advisers during the campaign.
 
Representative May Visit
 In the fall, in addition to television advertising, stepped-up press coverage and public debates, the campaigns will attract political stars from both major parties. But the Florio campaign would rather not see one Democrat who has indicated he may visit the state in the coming months: Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee and its Subcommitte on Oversight and Investigations.
Mr. Florio was the chairman of two subcommittees on energy and commerce in the 1980's under Mr. Dingell, and former committee aides say the two men disagreed often, principally on environmental issues, and developed an intense dislike for each other.
Mr. Dingell has announced he intends to look into the refinancing of New Jersey Turnpike bonds. Federal prosecutors are already examining allegations that bond dealers were steering business to a company owned in part by Joseph Salema, Mr. Florio's chief of staff, who resigned when news of the investigation broke.
Mr. Dingell has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is also investigating the bond transactions, to broaden its inquiry to include bond lawyers, financial advisers and consultants, and has said he may hold public hearings in New Jersey.
The Michigan Democrat's interest in the investigation has made him a potential wild card in the Governor's race. Mr. Upmeyer said that the animus between the Representative and the Governor is well known and that if Mr. Dingell were to hold hearings in the state before Election Day it could refocus public attention on the bond refinancing flap and hurt Mr. Florio's re-election chances.

HEADLINE: Churches Face Ravages of Age And Neglect

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
THREE years ago at St. Columba's Roman Catholic Church, a fixture in Newark's South Ward for close to a century, the congregation was dismayed when water started running down the inside walls on rainy Sundays. When the leaks were investigated, the parishioners discovered that the building needed extensive roof repairs and interior restoration work.
Now, after the completion of more than $200,000 in repairs, St. Columba's is watertight once more. 
 St. Columba's is not the only historic house of worship afflicted with dripping water and falling plaster. New Jersey's churches are ailing. Many, constructed during the church-building boom that coincided with the expansion of New Jersey cities and towns in the late 19th century, are about 100 years old. The effects of aging have often been aggravated by neglect, caused by factors ranging from straitened circumstances to inexperienced leadership.
Changes in the fortunes of many congregations are taking their toll on church buildings. In cities, once-vigorous parishes have dwindled as members have died or moved away. In rural areas and suburbs, established denominations like Episcopalians, Presbyterians and Methodists have declined in membership, and demographic changes have made some present-day congregations less prosperous than their predecessors.
 
'Always Tension' Between Two Demands
 Sometimes, even when the money is there, priorities change. Church leaders may decide that the church's mission is best served by focusing on programs and outreach activities rather than building restoration.
"There is always tension between the time, money and energy required for the ministry versus the time, money and energy needed for renovation," said the Rev. Tracy Lind, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Paterson.
The problems start with aging. "For the first 50 or 60 years, churches do not need much beyond regular maintenance," said D. Scott Imhoff, projects manager for United Contractors, a construction company that specializes in church restorations.
J. Randall Cotton, director of the Philadelphia Historic Preservation Corporation, which has provided technical assistance to congregations of some landmark churches in southern New Jersey, said 100 years was "the normal lifetime" of common church building materials like slate and metal work. "The effects of pollution are also showing up now," he said.
Mr. Cotton's observations were borne out by the Rev. Daniel Danik, pastor of Sacred Heart Church, a Roman Catholic church in Bloomfield, who said Sacred Heart's 103-year-old steeple had never needed repairs before the major renovation that was finished in June.
At St. Paul's in Paterson, the oak floorboards of the parish house have taken a pounding for almost a century, and Ms. Lind said that the time has come for their restoration or replacement.
 
'Neglected for a Generation'
 Neglect worsens the problems of aging structures. "Some of these churches have been neglected for a generation or two," said A. Robert Jaeger, co-director of Partners for Sacred Places, a Philadelphia organization that helps congregations save their historic religious buildings.
Some neglect is a byproduct of congregational change. One hundred years may be a short time in the life of a massive stone building, but it is a long time in the life of a city neighborhood.
The Prospect Street Presbyterian Church in Trenton was built in 1875 and once housed the largest Presbyterian congregation in that city. "The congregation had a fruitful ministry in the neighborhood," said the Rev. Lorrie Rowland-Skinner, urban mission associate for the New Brunswick Presbytery.
But as the area's population changed, the newer residents did not join the historic congregation, and it eventually dwindled. The roof developed leaks, and the church's life, both structural and institutional, was threatened.
Demographic shifts have also affected older churches in other cities. "Virtually all the churches in downtown Camden have the same problem," Mr. Cotton said.
Neglect can also be a sin of oversight. "Very rarely do people pay attention to the outside of the church," Mr. Imhoff said. The contractor added that hairline cracks and other seemingly small problems usually go unnoticed. Eventually the water that seeps in through those cracks can turn old mortar to dust, or can rot once-sturdy trusses.
Inexperienced church leadership can also breed neglect. Committees responsible for buildings and grounds may change as new members are elected and maintenance and repair information is not passed on.
Cost-conscious councils also sometimes vote to award repair contracts to contractors who submit low bids, regardless of whether they have experience repairing historic structures. The result can be haphazard repairs.
"All mortar is not the same; all bricks are not the same," Mr. Imhoff said.
The contractor remembered working on one northern New Jersey church whose original soft mortar was later repaired with a much harder substance. The incompatible mortar did not bond properly, water seeped into the masonry and the church's congregation paid for the earlier economy with expensive restoration work.
Financing repairs to historic churches takes more than faith and bake sales. Small and medium-size congregations with big structural problems are often forced to look beyond their members for money.
Banks are of little help to religious institutions, Mr. Jaeger said, because churches are considered poor credit risks. Often, steeples are stabilized and foundations are shored up with a combination of congregational, community and state funds.
In New Jersey, restoration money is available through the New Jersey Historic Trust. Financed by a 1987 bond act, the trust provides matching grants for work on structures that have been designated or are eligible to be designated as historic places.
Harriette C. Hawkins, executive director of the trust, said that in some cases, the grants matched money already spent on restoration. The average state grant is $200,000 to $300,000, she said.
When the 235-year-old Friends Meetinghouse in Randolph needed extensive restoration, the association that owns the building sought money from several sources. Members of the association contributed to the fund-raising effort, as did the local Kiwanis Club and a private family foundation in the area. A new fire-control system was donated by a contractor.
The association also obtained a $23,000 matching grant from the New Jersey Historic Trust. To date, the cost of the painstaking restoration has been $100,000. The restoration is almost complete, although, Dr. Margaret Stenneck, president of the Meetinghouse Association, said, "Preservation goes on forever."
In recent years, St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Paterson has undergone roof repair, rewiring, heating-system repair, the rebuilding of a parapet wall and the restoration of its organ. Members of the congregation conducted what Ms. Lind described as "a minor capital campaign" to help finance work on the 94-year-old church. Additional money was secured by borrowing against the church's endowment and obtaining a grant from the Episcopal Diocese of Newark.
Further restoration is ahead. Ms. Lind and the St. Paul's vestry are working with Mr. Imhoff on plans for restoration and maintenance and are seeking additional sources of money.
 
Calling in Consultants
 Organizations like Partners for Sacred Places and the Philadelphia Historic Preservation Corporation can help congregations find sources of money, plan fund-raising campaigns and establish priorities when a restoration project threatens to become unwieldy. Some congregations with huge restoration projects use professional fund-raisers.
"There are an increasing number of good consultants who specialize in capital campaigns," said Mr. Cotton, who added that such consultants do not actually raise money, but suggest ways of augmenting the effort and provide support materials.
Some congregations are simply too financially weak to repair their debilitated structures. The Prospect Street Church in Trenton needs extensive repairs, but its congregation is too small to raise the money. The New Brunswick Presbytery will retain the old building, but the present congregation will dissolve on Aug. 1.
 
Hopes of Saving Building
 Ms. Rowland-Skinner said that officials of the Presbytery hope that the building could be saved. Within the next year, essential repairs, financed by the Presbytery, will take place, while the parent body explores ways of paying for additional work. Ms. Rowland-Skinner said the church might become a community center or perhaps even house a new congregation that would be more representative of the neighborhood's population.
The one factor crucial to the survival of historic churches is community involvement, Mr. Cotton said. "Successful congregations show that their buildings are a community asset," he said.
Both Mr. Jaeger and Mr. Cotton said that a church like St. Paul's in Paterson, with its shelter, soup kitchen and other outreach programs, touched people far beyond its congregation. According to the experts, the more people who view a church as a community asset, the more people will have an interest in its restoration.
With local chapters of the American Civil Liberties Union, a crisis ministry and the Council of Churches housed at the Prospect Street Church, the structure may be a good candidate for a new lease on life.
Given the problems and expense of restoring and maintaining old buildings, some people say it might seem more reasonable for congregations to abandon their cavernous spaces, build simpler structures and spend the money saved on outreach activities. Ms. Lind, Mr. Jaeger and Ms. Rowland-Skinner all say there is a genuine need for the big old churches, especially in the inner cities.
"Churches are the institutions that have not left the cities," Ms. Lind said. "We have to keep out buildings in good shape for our programs."
Aside from programs, historic churches also provide a measure of spiritual refreshment in the midst of a parched place. "Beauty attracts people," Ms. Lind said, "and in a place like Paterson, we need places of historic beauty and history."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Power Struggle: Central Banks Fight The Tape

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IT was classic Bundesbank. The independent, proud and powerful German central bank was, in the words of one French banker, "determined not to be pushed around by anybody, least of all the markets."
The Buba decision, to do only a bit to cut German interest rates, pushed the latest European currency crisis to a fever pitch just as most of the important people on the Continent were planning to begin their traditional August vacations. Some traders hoped the governments and central bankers would capitulate this weekend to avoid disturbing their holidays. 
 An ocean away, the fight seems odd. France has low inflation and a trade surplus, hardly the traditional characteristics of a country whose currency is about to be devalued. But the currency traders have decided that the French franc must be devalued against the German mark.
The traders have sold every franc they can find, and are, as they say on Wall Street, "talking their books" by telling everyone who will listen that the franc is sure to collapse.
The French and Germans fear, and some others hope, that Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism will collapse. Having had the pound forced out last fall -- at a huge cost to the Bank of England and similar profits to currency traders -- many in Britain would love to see a similar fate befall the haughty French.
In this country, free markets tend to get more respect than Government officials, but that is not true in much of Europe, where the central bankers want to show the uppity currency speculators just who is the real boss. And the central banks rightly believe fundamentals like inflation are on their side.
Unfortunately for the central banks, the game is slanted in favor of the speculators. If the franc is devalued, their profits will be huge. But since there is no chance the franc will soar, a victory for the central banks means the speculators risk losing a lot less than they hope to win. That is one reason so many are betting against the franc.
All this seems so unnecessary. The French economy would unquestionably benefit now from lower interest rates, but to say this in Europe now brings accusations of short-term thinking. In the long run, it is said, Europe must unify its economies to compete effectively against the United States and Japan. And defending the franc now is needed to keep the European Monetary System from disintegrating. There are reasonable German domestic reasons not to lower interest rates too much, and other Europeans will have to endure the pain.
But why should they? The goal of European economic unity is a good one, but recession and Germany's botched reunification have made the Continent's economies diverge. The issue should not be whether the speculators or the central banks have more power, but what policies are needed to restore growth.
Whoever wins the currency fight, that will remain the big question for Europe's policymakers. They will need to act, partly by cutting interest rates, even if the Bundesbank doesn't want to help.

HEADLINE: This Man Wants to Bury You

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
Off in this city's industrial wasteland sits an unmarked building of corrugated steel, perpetually locked. Now and then, a wide door rises, a black Chevrolet Suburban truck backs in, and a whiff of formaldehyde escapes before the entry clanks shut. Here, 15 times a day, more than 5,000 times a year, the residents of Houston come to be embalmed.
In any other business, Service Corporation International would call this site its regional processing and distribution center. Remains flow in from households and hospitals around the city, in trucks large enough for two cots. Twin walk-in coolers accommodate the center's backlog. Once embalmed -- or prepped, as they say -- the remains are delivered to the company's 15 funeral homes in the Houston area. 
 By then, the dispatch desk at the central garage, with 13 hearses and 10 limousines, has assigned a funeral driver. On his way to the car, he takes the appropriate steel nameplates from a pegboard. Possibly a cursive "Waltrip" for a morning run to that funeral home, a bold "Geo. H. Lewis & Sons" in capital letters for the afternoon, one replacing the other in a slot on a side window. On the job, he identifies himself as an employee of one home or the other.
As far as the mourners ever know, they are dealing with a local funeral home as personal, familiar and unchanging as the neighborhood church. In fact, they are dealing with the world's largest funeral home and cemetery chain by far.
Approaching $1 billion in annual sales, S.C.I. handles 1 in every 11 funerals nationally at its 662 homes in 39 states. Manhattan's venerable Frank E. Campbell and Riverside Memorial chapels are among its 35 homes in the New York area. S.C.I. also owns 62 crematories, 44 flower shops and 174 cemeteries, providing deathbed-to-grave service.
Of the nation's 21,000 homes it doesn't yet own, S.C.I. has its eye on more than 4,000. The company has dozens of homes in Canada, and the purchase of Australia's largest chain won official approval last month. Candidates for the company's next foreign invasion include Britain, France, Mexico, Hong Kong and Taiwan.
 
The Cluster Approach
 Guided by Robert L. Waltrip, its founder, chairman and chief executive, S.C.I. has quietly revolutionized funeral merchandising and production.
The company assembles groups of homes with deep local roots in demographically correct turf. It then introduces centralized purchasing, training, finance, transportation and embalming to an extent the industry has never before known. At independent funeral homes, employees and hearses usually sit idle, waiting for the call. S.C.I., clustering from 2 to 51 homes in a region, keeps staff and equipment consistently busy.
The company has also built scores of funeral homes on its cemeteries, erasing the line that long separated the funeral director's staid persuasion from the plot salesman's real estate hucksterism.
S.C.I.'s growth has brought opposition from proudly independent funeral homes and consumer groups that want the company to share the savings from its efficiencies. The company, publicly traded, achieved a pretax profit margin of 18 percent in 1992, at least half again as much as the industry average -- enough to give Mr. Waltrip $4 million in compensation.
S.C.I. has succeeded by standing the chain concept -- perfected by restaurants, retailers and hotels -- on its head. Instead of using a common name to vouch for consistency, its funeral homes keep the local names that promise distinction.
A hamburger chain has much the simpler task. The same relentless efficiencies, the same standardization that have won the chains so many hungry, hurried customers, would, if presented so baldly, offend most patrons of a funeral home. Almost nobody wants a McFuneral.
Least of all in New York City, a nation of ethnic and economic enclaves, each with its own funeral homes. Nowhere else is S.C.I.'s invisibility more visible.
Under their own names, Campbell, the leading chiefly Christian home, on Manhattan's East Side, and Riverside, the leading Jewish home, on the West Side, proclaim their identities in bold lettering on sidewalk canopies and awnings. Plaques inside preserve the memory of their founders. Those carried through Campbell's doors have included Rudolph Valentino, Frank Costello, Judy Garland, John Lennon and Malcolm Forbes. Through Riverside's, Isaac Bashevis Singer and Leonard Bernstein.
At each home, Service Corporation International stays as anonymous as its very name. The only fleeting signs of its presence are fingernail-size lapel pins, with the company's linked initials, worn by regional executives. The company's New York operations have centralized purchasing, marketing and hearse service, but not embalming. The traffic's too bad.
 
Scratching the Surface
 Most S.C.I. executives -- even the vice president who has managed a McDonald's and toured Burger U. -- resist comparisons to mass marketers. But not Mr. Waltrip. Now 62, he started out 40 years ago with a single funeral home inherited from his family in Houston.
"The hamburger business used to be solely a Mom-and-Pop hamburger stand," he said, in the slow drawl of someone who knew that the other executives gathered around to talk strategy would hear him out, even when he sounded like a country music tape played at half-speed.
"You used to sit down at the table. Mom would serve it to you. Dad's back there cooking it. Now you go to McDonald's or Burger King and everybody's in a uniform. All the cooking is computerized and all the order-taking is computerized. They're all trained to say the same things to you.
"There is nothing amazing about trying to bring that to an industry that never had that before. And 90 percent still don't have it. But we have just started to scratch the surface."
To plan acquisitions or new homes, executives consult with the team in the demographic room. There, an NEC Multisync 4FG computer monitor displays neighborhood-by-neighborhood data on incomes, shopping preferences, ethnic groups, religion and age. And, most important, actual and predicted death rates.
Once the company has targeted an area, it tries to buy the premier home. Its acquisitions tend to come with client families (known as repeat customers) who have been delivering up their members for generations.
Often, the owners of the home initiate the talks. But even when they don't, S.C.I.'s starting approach is always friendly, especially since the same clans have often owned these homes since their founding. "We try to be very, very diplomatic," said W. Blair Waltrip, the chairman's son and an executive vice president. He has a finance degree, not a funeral director's license, and the ways of a Wall Street merger baron.
The younger Waltrip's first visit to a funeral home owner can seem like a mission of compassion -- for the complications of passing the business on to children, the cost of complying with regulations and all the other work, work, work. If, by the end of a second visit, the funeral director shows no desire to have S.C.I. lighten the burdens, then Mr. Waltrip might mention that he has also called on that home's leading competitor.
Still no luck? "On the third contact we tell them we have property zoned and we are seriously considering building a funeral home," Blair Waltrip said. That might be on a cemetery that S.C.I. already owns, giving the new home a claim on everyone who has a plot. Targeting elderly plotholders has helped the company gather contracts for $1.3 billion in funeral arrangements, provoking rivals to demand tighter regulations.
"Not that we are competing with you," Blair Waltrip continued, as if addressing a funeral home owner who was being unreasonable. "But we are interested in expanding."
Sometimes, he explained, "that will motivate somebody to think more seriously about becoming affiliated with our company."
After the acquisition comes the makeover. For $25,000, S.C.I. can install new carpeting, lighting, furniture and wallpaper, buying most items in bulk from manufacturers. The former owners, or their children and assistants, are usually asked to stick around, most often as managers but sometimes merely to maintain ties to churches and clubs.
The new owners find ways to raise the average sale at least 5 percent, usually more. Major credit cards are accepted (and S.C.I. is thinking about issuing its own). The company also takes special care to freshen up the casket room, with market research and casket fashions coming into play.
"It's getting to be more and more of a science," said John J. Roefaro, S.C.I.'s marketing chief for the New York region, as the sun penetrating his office at the Campbell home glinted off his chunky gold jewelry.
Funeral homes make their biggest money on caskets, industry analysts say. They typically mark them up two-and-a-half to three times, figures that S.C.I. does not dispute.
In training sessions, with employees playing the roles of funeral directors and customers, Mr. Roefaro recommends the understated approach. "I do not want anyone to feel this is a high-pressure sales organization," he said. "We're not selling autos."
He strode into Campbell's selection room -- or, rather, rooms -- to demonstrate S.C.I.'s state of the art. "If there were no financial concerns raised, the funeral director would begin here," he said, halting at the entrance. On a wide carpeted ledge encircling the room was a procession of rare and antique caskets. Under stage-quality track lighting, not the slightest dust speck or scratch darkened their sheen.
 
The Top of the Line
 For $85,000, a family could choose a seamless, cast bronze model from 1929, with a glass dome to keep viewers from making their farewells too personal. "We search the country for these," Mr. Roefaro said.
He lingered. Then, shifting into a side room, he said that mahogany, the most popular finish for Campbell's clientele, could go as low as $6,295. "There is less wood used in the construction," he said with a shrug in the lower-cost casket's direction. "A very, very basic design. It's not as massive," he added, as a $13,700 mahogany casket nearby began to pull him away.
That extra expense brings beefy cornices, a gracefully sculpted lid and Mr. Roefaro's full respect. "Much more massive, a lot more," he said, his voice dropping several notes.
Lesser woods are crowded into a back room, on skeletal, wheeled bases. A birch casket with no railings, just notches in the side, for $5,295. Or poplar, at $2,995. With bronze hardware, however flimsy? "Probably not, probably just made to look that way," he said. "Probably steel."
In the farthest corner sat a narrow, boxy casket in a grayish blue embossed fabric. Mr. Roefaro let a sign in the coffin do the talking. "Cloth Covered Flakeboard," it said. "Non-protective. $1,295."
S.C.I. executives are discussing new ways to lure poorer families. "We want to have a Macy's type of operation, but we want to have a Wal-Mart too," Robert Waltrip said.
His son suggests that S.C.I. could build some large, new homes that would advertise their prices, perhaps as low as $1,795 complete.
Once inside the homes, customers would learn the virtues of a $4,000 funeral, the industry's average. "Pricing or advertising is basically a means to get people to come to our facility," Blair Waltrip said, adding that he is testing this approach in St. Louis. "Then by explaining the options, more times than not they buy up to our current average."
 
Industry Opposition
 Regulators say that S.C.I. has scrupulously complied with price disclosure and worker safety codes. The company has settled two antitrust cases by selling several homes. Now it is fighting a proposed Federal Trade Commission rule banning funeral homes from charging handling fees that virtually prohibit customers from buying caskets elsewhere.
S.C.I.'s growth has aroused the strongest opposition from rival chains and the independent homes that dominate the trade groups. Robert Waltrip, feeling slighted by the National Funeral Directors Association, halted company dues payments for several months last year.
Critics, at the American Association of Retired Persons and even within the industry, say that the funeral buyer should see some of S.C.I.'s savings. "Who should benefit?" said John Eirkson, executive director of the Pennsylvania Funeral Directors Association. "The stockholder or the consumer?"
Mr. Eirkson derides S.C.I. as "a multinational conglomerate," noting that state laws have kept the company from buying more than a single home in his state and others ("That's a shame."). In the next breath, however, he mentions owning a few hundred shares of S.C.I. himself.
Rival chains are raising S.C.I.'s costs, adding to its already heavy debts, by bidding up funeral home prices. Executives of the Loewen Group, based near Vancouver but the second-largest owner of homes in the United States, boast that funeral directors fearing heavy-handed interlopers often sell to them.
But S.C.I. is still more than twice Loewen's size. Robert Waltrip says that his company even owns Vancouver's prime funeral homes and cemeteries, burying the competition, or at least the competition's family, at one of its sites.
With him, nobody else's graveyard will ever have a chance. Just inside the entrance to S.C.I.'s Memorial Oaks Cemetery in Houston lies a low brick wall. In the center, a bronze plaque says "Waltrip." All his funeral arrangements are made and paid for.
 
 
 
A GUARANTEED CUSTOMER BASE
 PUBLICLY traded since 1969, Service Corporation International remains a lot like the small family businesses it so voraciously buys.
W. Blair Waltrip, an executive vice president and the 39-year-old son of the company's founder, is the very apparent heir. He grew up next to a funeral home, used the parking lot as his playground and pursued his career in the family business. "He's never done but one job since he got out of college," grinned his father, Robert, who has no plans for retiring.
Robert Waltrip's son-in-law runs an investment management unit. His mother, a director emeritus, receives all the rewards of a current director, amounting to $42,000 and 1,500 S.C.I. shares last year.
To memorialize the living and the dead, Mr. Waltrip last year opened the tax-exempt American Funeral Service Museum in Houston. The Funerals of the Famous gallery has evidence, from an S.C.I. home in Memphis, that Elvis is dead.
The several funerary settings include a 1920's embalming room, complete with shelves of colorful fluids, among them Decker Laboratories Blood Solvent in yellow and Pierce VX Cavity Chemical in orange. Behind a bronze bust of Robert Waltrip in the entrance hall, a chiseled inscription hails "his monumental and ongoing contributions to defining the funeral service industry." Admission $5, or $3 for children under 12 and adults over 54.
Mr. Waltrip, however, had to bring in an outsider a few years ago to salvage his business. To become fully integrated, S.C.I. had bought or developed funeral insurance and casket companies. Insurance proved to be unfamiliar, and casket sales floundered because few funeral directors would order from a competitor.
L. William Heiligbrot, who, as a brave Texas Commerce banker, had extended S.C.I. its first loan, became S.C.I.'s president in 1990. He unloaded the faltering businesses and dozens of small, isolated funeral homes. Even now, when Blair or Robert Waltrip trot out lofty goals for earnings growth or foreign empire-building, Mr. Heiligbrot hedges and cautions.
Mr. Heiligbrot is very much a part of the S.C.I. team, a burly, former college football player like the chairman. In pay, he has become a part of the family as well, with compensation of more than $3 million last year. The elder Waltrip received more than $4 million -- an amount pegged to the company's size and performance, he said -- and his son, $1.6 million.
Other advantages of S.C.I. family life include the Gulfstream III jet. For business trips, the jet sometimes swings by to pick up Mr. Waltrip from his 40,000-acre Colorado ranch, twice the size of Manhattan.
Since the turnaround, the S.C.I. clan has earned its keep, many analysts say. Profits since 1988 have risen nearly four-fold to $86 million last year, and to $52 million for the first half of this year.
But woe to anyone who would question how S.C.I. keeps its books. Early this year, after Ernst & Young balked at the accounting for advance sales of funeral services, S.C.I. turned to a more cooperative Coopers & Lybrand. Coopers had no comment but Mr. Waltrip did: "I still don't understand why Ernst & Young got their nose out of joint, with the exception of the fact that they were not rehired."
The accounting flap caused just a momentary pause in the advance of S.C.I. stock from a low of $8.50 in 1989 to $23.825 on Friday, just off its $24 high. Mr. Waltrip is never shy about flogging his shares, or anything else. "People that don't buy our stock just don't like money," he said, shaking his head in wonderment. "It's the greatest buy I've ever seen. People are always going to die."

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
A Man With Many Ideas for Addicting Americans

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
If Thomas J. Kalinske were a video game character, he would rack up more points than Sonic the Hedgehog. Mr. Kalinske, president and chief executive officer of Sega of America Inc. of Redwood City, Calif., a subsidiary of Sega Enterprises Ltd. of Japan, joined the toymaker Mattel as a product manager in 1973 and rose to president of the company in 1985.
When he took the control stick at Sega of America in 1990, the video game machine and software company lagged far behind Nintendo with annual sales of $125 million. This year's sales are "just under a billion," he said, and Sega's Genesis machine is outselling Nintendo's counterpart by two to one. 
 The game has only just begun: In the next year, Sega of America plans to release a "virtual reality" helmet, an interactive cable TV channel and other new technologies. This week, it is expected to introduce cartridge and CD-ROM versions of "Jurassic Park," a game based on the movie.
And don't forget the competition, notably from a newcomer, the 3DO Company, and Atari, both of which are developing advanced game systems.
Question: You've said "Jurassic Park" is just one of at least eight titles of which you expect to sell a million copies each. At $54.99 per copy, this game business isn't kids' stuff, is it?
Answer: Last year we did $450 million worldwide on one game, Sonic 2. That's more than any hit movie, more than any other entertainment property. It's a very compelling form of entertainment. We believe we have a very good shot at offering more entertainment per dollar spent, per hour spent, than movies or television. In essence we see them as our competition. You'll see, you'll want to spend more time on "Jurassic Park," the video game, than in seeing "Jurassic Park," the movie.
Q: Sega clobbered Nintendo by being first to move to 16-bit games from 8-bit games. Do you fear 3DO doing the same to you with 32-bit game machines?
A: The arcade side of our business has been doing 32-bit software for four years now, so we have a fairly extensive library of 32-bit games. We also know more about 32-bit hardware than just about anybody. I could do a 32-bit hardware system like that. [Snaps fingers.] The problem is, it's too expensive right now. The real engineering challenge is getting that cost down to where it's a mass-market product. I could do one today for $100 less than 3DO, but I'm not interested in that. I'm not interested in $200 less. It's got to be a substantially lower-priced unit.
Q: You don't think people will pay $700 for a 3DO game machine?
A: That's our view. Maybe we're wrong, but we think it's a niche product at that price. We've done a fair amount of research on it. VCRs had to cross the $300 price barrier before they became mass-market products. We're also somewhat skeptical of the technology itself. Frankly we don't think it's good enough. So I guarantee you that whatever we do, we'll be better than what they're currently doing, and it will be less money.
Q: In the meantime, you've already come out with Sega CD. You're developing Sega VR, a virtual reality device that looks really cool, and next year there will be the Sega Channel, for interactive cable TV. Aren't you afraid that at some point the kids of America . . .
A: That's my nightmare! One day they say, "That's it, no more."
Q: Could that happen?
A: Clearly they will if we don't keep re-inventing ourselves each year. Virtual reality we've shown already. There's special software for it. It's absolutely addictive. You put this helmet on, and . . .
Q: Is addiction good?
A: It is for us. Seriously, there hasn't been enough research done, but there's a fair amount of research that correlates video game playing and higher grades. Kids often get interested in computers through this door of video games. I think that's really positive.
Q: Are your own children deeply involved in playing Sega games?
A: No, they're a little young. Actually 70 percent of our Genesis players are over 12 years old. We really are not a kid business anymore; we're a teen-age and adult business. Eighty percent of our CD-ROM players are over 18. There are a lot of grown men playing CD-ROM. We think we'll sell 800,000 to a million Sega CD systems this year. If your seasonality is 80 percent of sales in November-December, our current sales would support that.

HEADLINE: Center-Court Star at Center Stage

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN

 BODY:
DRESSED in jeans, a black jacket and recycled shoes, Martina Navratilova floated up the escalator into the hot, white light of the television cameras, some kind of blond, casual goddess rising from the sea.
Smiling but moving as fast as one of her groundstrokes, she blistered through the tony, largely gay crowd waiting breathlessly to see her in the upper reaches of Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. A few mumbled hellos and she was gone, tucked safely away inside one of those rooms reserved for stars like her at times like these. 
 It seemed her miniature fox terrier, K.D. (Killer Dog) had become agitated by all the lights and noise and people gathered at the Paramount for A Lesbian and Gay Tribute to Martina, a fund-raising event sponsored by the Gay Games IV and Cultural Festival, an Olympic-style sporting and cultural event that will be held around New York City next June. This was announced by Ms. Navratilova's handlers-for-the-night, identified by the I'm-Very-Serious looks they wore chiseled on their faces. Ms. Navratilova also needed a moment to recover from the crush.
THE photographers grumbled. Some people who had paid money to be there grumbled. But Marge Sherwin did not grumble. She trembled. After years of admiring Ms. Navratilova as much for her honesty about being a lesbian as for her tennis game, and after a hellish two-and-a-half-hour commute from her home on the East End of Long Island to attend this tribute, Marge Sherwin had found herself and her camera right in Ms. Navratilova's path.
Did she see her?
"Yes! Yes!"
Did she get a picture?
"Oh yes, yes, yes," Ms. Sherwin squealed. "My heart is going madly."
Initially closed-mouthed, then quietly open about her homosexuality, Martina Navratilova has grown increasingly vocal about being a lesbian and active in the gay-rights movement. She spoke at the April gay-rights rally in Washington. She joined the American Civil Liberties Union in a lawsuit against an anti-gay-rights measure in Colorado and vowed to move out of Aspen if the measure was not overturned. Her name adorns a recent fund-raising mailing from the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. She has become the gay-rights poster child of the 1990's.
"Dear Martina," reads the response card bearing her picture. "You can count on me to come to the side of gay men and lesbians who need support in this critical civil rights battle."
Ms. Sherwin said, "Because she's been so honest about her life style, she's given us all a little boost."
But being the darling of the gay-rights movement is a time-consuming diversion for a 37-year-old athlete still slugging it out in the girlish world of women's professional tennis (she is currently ranked No. 4 in the world).
"I say no a lot," she said. But "I've got to practice what I preach and this feels right."
Ms. Navratilova's leadership role is especially pleasing to lesbians fighting to become more prominent within the movement.
"We've been doing grunt work forever, stuffing envelopes and other things," said Vivian Shapiro, a co-chairwoman of the Legacy Fund, a lesbian advocacy group in New York.
"The wives of the gay-rights movement," said Lys Marigold, the other co-chairwoman.
Ms. Shapiro said: "There's never been any sense that lesbians have a strong economic base," "We want to say we're here and we want to make an impact, economically."
Ms. Navratilova's own economic impact is as big as Boris Becker's serve. Although she says her sexuality has cost her untold millions in potential endorsements, her face means big bucks in the gay community. Ms. Navratilova's presence on Wednesday helped raise more than $250,000 for Gay Games IV. A private tennis lesson with her raised $30,000 alone during a rambunctious auction.
Emerging from the secluded room without her dog but with the Olympic swimmer Bruce Hayes, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and Billie Jean King, a mentor, Ms. Navratilova faced the crowd. She is smaller than she seems on television, with softer features and a smile that -- surprise -- is not at all strained. She is wry and funny and apparently, a lesbian sex symbol. "She's hot," observed one woman in the crowd.
Ms. Navratilova said she liked the concept of the Gay Games, which are open to everyone, and hoped they would move society toward acceptance of homosexuals. She said, "Sports is a wonderful way to bridge differences between people." She said athletes were not as homophobic as people might think, at least not female athletes.
"I don't know what it's like in the N.F.L. or the N.H.L.," she said. "I know a hockey coach, and he says there are no gay men playing hockey."
"Please," she said, rolling her eyes. "Wake up and smell the coffee."
Laughter.
"It's like, 'Don't ask, don't tell.' They have that in the N.H.L., too."
Laughter.
"The media thinks that if you're a female athlete you're automatically gay. And if you're a male athlete, then obviously you're straight. I happen to be gay, but 90 percent of the women on tour are not."
Murmurs of assent.
Someone asked if Ms. Navratilova was seeing anyone. The room erupted in catcalls and whoops, and several women screamed out, "I'm available" and "I'm single."
"Can I answer that?" said Ms. King, laughing, but she did not answer.
"Let's just say I'm having a wonderful time in Atlanta, playing and getting to know people," Ms. Navratilova said, referring to her stint with the Atlanta Thunder of World Team Tennis.
Later Wednesday, Ms. Navratilova was praised over a $225-a-plate dinner.
"One thing I love about Martina is she demands acceptance on equal terms for all of us," Ms. King said. "Not tolerance, but acceptance. Because she is comfortable in her own skin, she helps all of us be more comfortable in ours."
When it was finally her time to speak, Ms. Navratilova said: "When I get all these accolades for being true to myself, I say, 'Who else would I be?' I can't be Chris Evert."
