HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
From Acura, a Third-Generation Integra

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
HONDA's Acura Division has come a long way in the seven short years since it arrived on these shores as the leader in what has since become a Japanese rush to produce luxury automobiles.
First, there was the Legend sedan, followed by an elegant coupe. Then came the entry-level Integra, the Vigor sports sedan and the spectacular all-aluminum NSX sports car. And a new network of dealers was set up to distance the nameplate from Honda's reputation for cheap little cars. 
 But through it all, something else was happening. While the division was establishing itself, Honda also was moving up the scale. The Accord came and went as America's best-selling car, and Honda wound up with pricetags that were often higher than those on competing Acura models.
Acura's Integra is a case in point, and the top-of-the-line GS-R sports coupe is a prime example, with a $19,440 sticker that is thousands less than the price of a fancy Honda Prelude.
Still, Acura's products and dealers achieved an impressive reputation for quality, finishing as "best overall car line" for the past three years in the vehicle-performance study conducted by J.D. Power & Associates. The California consulting firm based its results on surveys that measured driver satisfaction after three years of ownership.
One way that Acura did that was through constant improvement, and the Integra is a good example of that, too. For 1994, the line of coupes and sedans is all new -- again. It is Integra's third generation in seven years, and that is an amazing feat in a business whose products frequently have lifespans of a decade or more.
Both four-door and hatchback can be had in three trim levels, RS, LS and GS-R, with prices starting at $14,670. The tester was a white GS-R sports coupe like those that went on sale in early July. The GS-R sedan will move into the showrooms in September, and Acura expects it to boost sales by appealing to drivers who want practicality with their zip.
There is no question that the GS-R is aimed at the sporty crowd. The molded 15-inch aluminum wheels are equipped with high-performance tires, and the car has a full complement of blackout trim. And the hatch, which yawns wide over a 13.3-cubic foot cargo area, carries a spoiler across the rear.
Up front, tiny round headlamps nestle in the soft vinyl nose, and they are of the "projector-beam" type that use internal lenses to flood the road with increased light.
The tester's swoopy curves were interrupted only when the power sunroof was opened, with the glass panel sliding back outside the car, thus allowing considerably more headroom than if it needed its own pocket within the roof.
Inside, the dark gray interior of vinyl and cloth featured comfortable buckets up front, split by a console holding the short-throw shifter for the five-speed stick -- the only transmission available in the GS-R. There is surprising legroom in the rear, and the seatbacks fold down to create more space under the hatch.
Seat controls are manual, although they include lumbar adjustments, and there are other thoughtful touches, too: a dead pedal for the driver's left foot, dual cup-holders and a toll-change bin to the left of the four-spoke steering wheel. Air-conditioning, with an environmentally friendly refrigerant, is standard on all LS and GS-R models.
The tilt wheel houses an air bag, and a second bag is mounted in the top of the dash on the passenger's side, its position leaving room for a small glove box underneath. Antilock brakes also are standard, and side-intrusion beams in the doors -- accompanied by side-impact cushions in the door panels -- pad out the safety equipment.
But it is the four-cylinder VTEC engine that makes the GS-R coupe special. In loose (not to say wobbly) translation, VTEC stands for Variable Valve Timing and Lift Electronic Control, and the system changes the way the valves work to achieve maximum torque and power throughout the engine's range of revs.
While all '94 Integras have a 1.8-liter powerplant, the GS-R's free-breathing system boosts horsepower to 170 from the lesser cars' 142. Zero-to-60 acceleration takes only 6.5 seconds, and top speed is about 140.
That's quick, but then Integra demands that. Don't blink or you're liable to miss the next generation.

HEADLINE: It's Alive;
How Clinton's Economic Strategy Ended Up Looking Like Bush's

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON'S plan for reviving the economy, embodied in his budget proposals, is squeaking through Congress. Even so, the President in one important sense has lost the battle. Like a general forced to call off a cavalry charge, he has given up his original strategy.
Instead, President Clinton is proclaiming the same hard-nosed economic propositions that George Bush and Ronald Reagan proclaimed as their guiding principle. The irony is that Mr. Clinton, like his Republican predecessors, has locked himself into an economic theory that works in the imagination but perhaps not in practice. 
 The theory, in its baldest terms, is this: A shrinking budget deficit means the Government needs to borrow less. Less Government borrowing makes more money available for the public to borrow from the limited pool of lendable funds. To lure the borrowers, lenders lower interest rates. And as the newly lent money is spent, the economy booms.
That sequence of events has never actually happened in America. Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush preached a smaller deficit and then added to it. And when the deficit did fall in the late 1980's, interest rates remained high. But in a nation obsessed with shrinking the deficit, lowering interest rates through deficit reduction has become the only acceptable economic policy. And Mr. Clinton has become an adherent.
"It is surprising to see, when you step back, how broad the consensus is on this key logic of economic policy," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
A competing thesis briefly challenged the logic of reviving the economy mainly through deficit reduction and lower interest rates. During the election campaign, President Clinton argued that the way to faster growth would be a shot of Government spending, on public works, among other things. The new spending would even raise the deficit, but once the economy was back on track, deficit cutting would kick in.
Many prominent economists, among them several Nobel laureates, endorsed this view. But they fell into silence by March, when Congress -- particularly Congressional Republicans -- said no to the President's spending proposals.
Nowhere has deficit reduction been embraced more militantly than in the budget debate. Virtually no one in either party any longer challenges the proposition that deficit reduction will eventually be good for the economy, and now Congress appears to be producing a bill that would make a substantial dent in the deficit.
In the short run, however, the economy has been despairingly weak, expanding in the second quarter at an annual rate of only 1.6 percent, the Commerce Department reported last week.
During the Bush Administration, such reports drew scorn from Democrats. Now Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, says: "It takes time for the American economy to react to lower rates." And Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich adds: "I would be surprised if 1994 brought a buoyant recovery; the payoff will come after next year."
Various explanations are offered for the grip that deficit reduction has on the national imagination. Some surveys suggest that many Americans, suffering from hard times, view Government spending as wasteful and unhelpful in improving their lives. Ross Perot sounds this theme, and his solution -- slash spending, and with it the deficit -- has been influential.
Then there have been the endless Presidential promises, not least from Mr. Reagan, to cut the deficit, only to have it mushroom. "When you keep saying that you are going to cut the deficit, and you never do, that gets a little like Vietnam," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University. "Once people in office get committed to cutting the deficit, and they fail, they find that they can't back out of the struggle. They can no longer explain that maybe the deficit might not be such a problem after all."
Whatever the dynamics, the current Clinton remedy is a set of tax increases and spending cuts that would make the deficit progressively smaller than it otherwise would have been. By 1998 the deficit would be $200 billion rather than the $360 billion currently projected by the Congressional Budget Office. The President's conflict with Congress is not over this goal, only over how to reach it, with the President putting the emphasis on more taxes and the Republicans preferring more spending cuts.
The version that emerged last week gave the President much less than he had sought in energy taxes, but also less than Republicans had sought in Medicare cuts.
Whatever the outcome, lower interest rates from deficit reduction -- even if that formula works -- guarantee that the economy will regain its vigor only very gradually. That raises the possibility that slow economic growth and high unemployment are what many Americans might really prefer, without quite admitting it, even to themselves.
Evidence of this preference is not hard to find. The President himself has gone from his campaign promise of more jobs in a hurry to a more specific promise of 8.3 million new jobs in his first term. That sounds like a lot, but 8.3 million breaks down to an average of fewer than 180,000 new jobs a month. Many labor economists say at least 200,000 are needed to shrink the unemployment rate from its current 7 percent level.
Then there is inflation. Wall Street executives, often speaking for customers, argue that holding down inflation is more important than rapid job creation. Rapid inflation, in this view, disrupts stock and bond markets, and the disruption hurts the economy. The Federal Reserve pushes this case, arguing that rapid economic growth puts too much money in people's pockets. They go on buying sprees, shortages develop and prices rise.
"The ideal economic policy results in only moderate economic growth," said Henry Kaufman, a Wall Street economist.
It takes great gobs of borrowing and spending to make the economy jump vigorously enough to dispel the sense of hardship that prevails today. Low rates alone can't make that happen. Various studies have shown that people are reluctant to borrow and spend if they lack the income to repay the debt. Similarly, corporate executives frequently say that low rates are only one factor in their decision making. An appliance company, for example, won't invest $10 million to expand a factory and hire 100 workers if its executives lack confidence that there will be customers for all the extra stoves and refrigerators.
This year the weak economy and the promise of future deficit reduction have made rates fall even while the deficit remains high. And the low rates have helped the economy. Car and truck sales have risen in response to lower rates for vehicle loans, and so have sales of machinery and equipment to companies. "Only housing has not come around yet, which is a bit puzzling, given falling mortgage rates," said Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "But we expect it to come around soon, and that will make the economy rise."
Still, Administration officials say they are not relying entirely on lower rates through deficit reduction -- recognizing, as everyone does, that the immediate result of less Government spending will be to dampen growth. Already, officials are talking about softening that blow -- perhaps by delaying some of the deficit reductions that were adopted in the first place to rescue the economy.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Down From the Self-Esteem High

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
CAN student achievement in math, science and other academic subjects be increased if teachers boost the self-esteem of their pupils?
For years conventional wisdom has said yes: more self-confidence will help all students, but particularly girls, members of minority groups and, increasingly, gay and lesbian youth who see their sense of self diminished by an indifferent public school system. 
 But the self-esteem movement that began with such high expectations in the 1980's is running aground. Teachers in many public schools are praising student accomplishments so indiscriminately that such praise has become meaningless. The result, some education analysts warn, is that true achievement is losing out to mediocrity.
"In some instances, you accept work you shouldn't accept because there is the fear that the kids will not feel good," said Elzeria Barnes, a science teacher in middle school and high school in Westchester.
Other teachers are more blunt. "It's a crock," said a middle-school teacher in Albuquerque, N.M., who asked not to be identified. "It has lessened the appeal of hard work among students."
Some teachers have applauded students simply for turning in homework. Others accept work that even students know is lacking, which can have the opposite effect on a child's self-worth.
The push to increase self-esteem has also helped sustain the trend toward grade inflation. In one Albuquerque middle school, teachers tried to start a new academic honor society, using as the cutoff for membership a 3.5 grade-point average on a 4.0 scale. They found that two-thirds of the school's 600 students were eligible -- about half of them in special education.
So they raised the average to 3.8, but that excluded the very students -- hard workers who spent long hours studying -- the teachers wanted to acknowledge. One flabbergasted teacher who was involved in organizing the program said the grade inflation was a direct result of the school's self-esteem program.
"We all believe in self-esteem," said the teacher, who asked not to be identified because the experience so divided the teachers. "Where we disagree is how to give students self-esteem and at what price." The honor society idea was eventually scrapped.
 
Where It Works
 The idea appears to work where it is based on test results. In Detroit, four all-black public academies were established two years ago and the teachers were told that part of their mission was to bolster students' self-esteem. The staff stresses the relationship between self-confidence and exemplary achievement, between self-esteem and hard work, which city school officials say has led to stronger student performances on the Michigan Educational Assessment Program and the California Achievement Test.
The Detroit schools achieved this through more than just fuzzy feel-good praise. If a student receives a D on an essay because of grammatical and spelling errors, for instance, the teacher returns the paper, with encouragement that the student can do better. The students also are taught respect; they are expected to be quiet when another teacher or administrator enters the classroom. Expectations are an important component, says Dr. Rebie Kingston, director of the office of guidance for Detroit Public Schools.
"Expectations play a great role in self-esteem," Ms. Kingston said. And teachers must make the connection that students' self-worth rises in relation to legitimate achievement based on goals just a bit higher than their reach but attainable through hard work.
Many educators often confused praise with encouragement. "Where teachers often go astray is, the praise is not congruent with the effort the child is putting forth," said Carole Kennedy, principal at the New Haven Elementary School in Columbia, Mo. "If you have a little boy who reads his lesson and then the teacher lavishes praise upon him, that doesn't mean anything to the little boy, who says, 'Gee, that wasn't hard. Does she think I'm not smart?' "
Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, agrees. "You can't simply achieve self-esteem by using the label or by rewarding any effort regardless of its quality or merit," he said, adding that one without the other "frankly does acknowledge mediocrity."
Some experts say teachers, battered by public criticism and working for little money given their responsibilities, lack self-esteem themselves and are in a poor position to give students something they themselves lack. "Children are not fooled all of the time," said Lilian G. Katz, a University of Illinois professor of early childhood education, who has written on the topic of self-esteem in schools. To pretend that all children are created equal in academic, artistic or athletic ability is to undermine them later in life. Instead, Professor Katz said, "Learning to deal with setbacks and maintaining the persistence and optimism necessary for a childhood's long and gradual road to mastery are the real foundations of lasting self-esteem."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Ukrainian Could Envy Russia's Economy

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
IF the economy in Russia seems wobbly and fraught with the seeds of social and political unrest, consider neighboring Ukraine.
Ukraine's fledgling currency, the coupon, has collapsed against the dollar and the ruble as the central bank's printing presses keep rolling at full speed. Progress toward privatizing industry is less likely than a year ago. Hyperinflation devours workers' salaries and capital is in full flight. Barter and corruption dominate what is left of trading, which could be further hurt by Russia's action last week on the ruble. In other words, economic reform, even of a tepid kind, is unknown in the second most populous republic of the old Soviet Union. 
 Last week, Russia's economy was traumatized when the central bank tried to quickly take old ruble notes out of circulation, only to have President Boris N. Yeltsin extend the time allowed and lighten the limit on how much could be exchanged for new notes. But such ups and downs in making the ruble convertible at least show that Russia is on a road to establishing faith among international lenders; indeed, the International Monetary Fund handed it $1.5 billion last month and the World Bank approved a $660 million loan to its oil industry.
By contrast, the only help either lending institution has been able to justify for Ukraine is a $27 million World Bank loan to help the Treasury here to get its statistics right. So retrograde is Ukraine on questions of reform that some economists reckon it resembles a little Soviet Union. Even the imagery remains secure, with statues of Lenin standing upright in the cities.
None of this would be so important if the stakes were not so high. An unstable Ukraine, with 52 million people, having inherited the world's third largest nuclear arsenal, and situated on Russia's border, worries many policy planners in the West. Somewhat belatedly, they have begun to understand that Washington's concentration on Russia and the comparative lack of attention to Ukraine have heightened paranoid feelings in Kiev.
This is especially so since Ukrainian nationalists, who instinctively distrust the Russians, say Russia has been trying to weaken what was its richest province, with the ultimate aim of reclaiming it. The welcome given to Col. Gen. Konstantin Morozov, Ukraine's Defense Minister, when he visited the Pentagon last week was intended to send a more understanding signal to Ukraine.
Even as this is happening, however, Ukrainians are showing more and more disgust with their economic plight. On the main highway near the tire factory at Bila Tserkva, an industrial city about 40 miles south of Kiev, skilled workers are reduced to hawking their company's tires in an effort to keep their families afloat. And the story of the tire factory, depleted of raw materials because it can't afford the prices that its Russian suppliers are demanding, is not unusual in a country where national output fell 16 percent last year.
"The factory can't pay us a proper wage," said Victor Tarianov, a 33-year-old engineer, as he dragged two new radial tires to the road to sell to passing drivers. "So they allow some of the workers to buy the tires cheaply at 24,000 coupons (about $8), a little less than half the state price. And we sell them out here for 45,000 coupons." Bitterly, he added: "You've heard the term social explosion? Well, the factory tries to stop a social explosion by allowing us to sell their tires. If I didn't sell the tires I wouldn't be able to buy meat or clothes for the children. But soon there will be chaos here."
In Kiev, Valentina Smiyam, a 35-year-old mother of two children who works as a superintendent for an apartment block, joined the 8 A.M. line at her local bakery, full of foreboding. "People have become like dogs," she said. "Recently I was in third position in the line to buy some sunflower oil. After the shop opened, the crowd burst into the shop and I was 33d in the line. I was about to cry and then the men started fighting in the shop. I said, I don't want this oil. I'll just go home."
Mrs. Smiyam's husband is a plumber, but she said the family would still have to live on bread and milk if not for the vegetables from her mother's small plot at a collectivized farm an hour's tram ride away.
Some politicians acknowledge that the outlook is grim indeed. "In the near future we expect a lot of factories will have to close and then we'll have a critical mass which can become an explosion," said Edward I. Gurvits, chairman of the Council of People's Deputies of Odessa. One problem is the inability of President Leonid M. Kravchuk and Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma -- who, to complicate matters, are locked in a power struggle -- to make any decisions.
 
Official Greed
 For the moment, the leaders in Kiev, most of them former Communist bosses with a new nationalist stripe, act as though the domestic woes barely exist. In fact many profit from the way things are. An estimated 25 percent of the 450 members of Parliament are managers of industrial and manufacturing enterprises. Thus, they pushed through a provision that makes it more difficult, not less, for outside investors to buy into enterprises the managers hope to acquire on the cheap.
Corruption is rife. For example, Ukraine's pharmaceutical plants are on their knees, and major cancer operations at one hospital here are being done without anesthetics. But health officials are reported to have embezzled appropriations worth millions of dollars.
The crunch may well come next winter, when Russia is to raise the price of oil to Ukraine to world standards. The Ukrainians, who depend on Russian oil, already owe Moscow more than $2 billion for subsidized oil, Western bankers say. So there is little incentive for Russia to delay the increase, especially since Ukrainian bureaucrats enriched themselves last year by selling cheap Russian oil at world prices on the world market.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Conservatives Struggle For Something to Say

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ON a chilly morning here last January, leading conservatives announced "Empower America," an organization created to begin plotting the resurgence of a Republican Party that seemed in tatters.
Since then, two of the group's leaders and possible Republican Presidential candidates, William J. Bennett and Jack F. Kemp, have articulated strikingly different visions of what their party should stand for. While Mr. Bennett preaches about a crisis of values in America, Mr. Kemp argues that the party's future lies in proposals for economic growth. 
 "Bennett and Kemp are stumbling over each other in a clash of monumental egos who don't agree on fundamental tactics or principles," said Richard N. Bond, the last chairman of the Republican National Committee under President George Bush.
Such could be said for the Republican Party itself. It is hardly a testament to their own cohesiveness when Republicans proudly declare that President Clinton has been more successful than any Republican in unifying their party.
As evidence of a comeback, party leaders point to their victories since November: The elections to the Senate of Paul Coverdell in Georgia and Kay Bailey Hutchison in Texas and Richard J. Riordan's election as mayor of Los Angeles. Another positive sign is that as the White House blunders have piled up, so have donations to conservative groups.
But the Republicans' delight masks a sobering reality. They are so divided and so lacking in leadership that many Republicans fear they are in no position to advance a captivating, or even convincing, argument of why voters should turn to their party. Their profile is largely that of the Anti-Party, which specializes in filibusters such as the ultimately unsuccessful effort last week to threaten national service legislation, one of Mr. Clinton's most popular proposals during the campaign.
"With every Clinton initiative, we're against it even before he announces it," said Mayor William J. Althaus of York, Pa. "We're not going to win any elections or do anything until we get some programs that we're for."
In contrast to 1976, the last time the Republicans lost the White House, there is no Ronald Reagan to rebuild the party. Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, has become the de facto spokesman but he is limited because he serves in Congress, where his only real power is in opposing the Democratic majorities.
And while Haley Barbour, the Republican chairman, is attractive on television, he has never served in elective office and does not command the stature to single-handedly set Republicans on a new course.
The most powerful alternative voice to Mr. Clinton, it turns out, is not a Republican, but Ross Perot, as even Mr. Kemp recognizes. Mr. Perot, he said, "seems to be the one who's more on the proposing side than the opposing side on issues like government reform and budget reform."
There is nothing like the Kemp-Roth tax reduction plan that Republicans coalesced around in 1978; the Republicans' budget alternative this year was not viewed as credible and would not have come any closer to curbing the deficit.
William E. Brock, who as the party's chairman helped rescue the Republicans in the post-Watergate period, likens the party to a political Tower of Babel; there are, he said, "a great many voices speaking in different tongues."
The voices are those of would-be Presidents (or as Mr. Bond puts it, "a bunch of unemployed Cabinet secretaries") including Mr. Kemp, a former Housing and Urban Development Secretary, and Mr. Bennett, a former Education Secretary.
Mr. Kemp dismissed Mr. Bond's criticism as "sour grapes," saying any differences he had with Mr. Bennett came from "early growing pains" in their organization.
Mr. Bennett put the party's challenge this way: "The Republican Party does not become sanctified for the Democratic Party's errors. We have a great opportunity. But what we need is a point of view. There has to be a consensus on three or four big pieces of the puzzle -- like education, welfare, crime and spending."
What should the Republicans be proposing? Senator Phil Gramm of Texas seems to want the party to stick to the anti-tax and anti-spending message of Ronald Reagan. But others, like Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, say that the party must develop welfare and crime and education programs modeled after those of the states. Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, is still waging a cultural war against abortion and homosexual rights.
While such debate may be healthy, Republicans have had little success finding common ground.
 
Repositioning the 'Party of Ideas'
 Mr. Barbour, the Republican chairman, recently announced that the party would establish a semi-independent group called the National Policy Forum to hold issue-oriented town meetings to determine how the "party of ideas" can best position itself. While the forum is intended to be independent from traditional party thinking and win over Mr. Perot's supporters, the risk is that it will only highlight the divisions.
The answers for the Republican Party may not be in survey data, either. Polls show that even those who identify themselves as Republicans are far more sharply divided than Democrats on critical issues like abortion and national health insurance.
Not all Republicans, of course, are pessimists. Some plead for patience, noting that the party is still recovering from Mr. Bush's defeat. Richard Viguerie, who runs conservative direct-mail organizations, says they are more profitable now than they have been in 12 years and he is downright enthusiastic. "Our opponent is out there self-destructing almost hourly, so it would be foolish for us to clutter up the airwaves with a different message right now," Mr. Viguerie said. "This is working beautifully."
But former Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, chairman of the Conference for a Republican Majority, one of many new groups seeking to help Republicans find themselves, has little confidence in a party without a message.
Asked about the future of the Republican Party, Mr. Frenzel replied, "I've heard there used to be one."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Regardless of the Budget, the 103d Is No Gridlock Congress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TUESDAY the House stopped fighting about flood relief and passed a $3 billion measure, raised to $4.7 billion in a Senate committee Friday. Thursday House and Senate conferees broke their deadlock on how to put the Government into the student loan business. Friday Senate Republicans gave up their filibuster against the national service bill, which the House had passed Wednesday.
This legislative barrage was conducted while other sets of negotiators fought over the tax increases and spending cuts in the budget-reconciliation bill, the crucial test for the first part of this Congressional session. None of those other successes made the budget measure any easier. It will still take every bit of muscle and arm-twisting the White House and Democratic leaders can muster to pass the half-trillion-dollar deficit reduction before Congress leaves for vacation next weekend. 
 But the pace of other activity made it clear that however the budget war comes out, the 103d Congress is already a powerful legislative engine.
The student loan and national service bills are particularly significant reflections of a fast-starting Congress. While the ideas involved in each have been around for some time, neither had made major legislative progress until they were introduced this spring.
In that respect, they were quite different from two earlier victories for President Clinton and the Democrats. The first major bill passed, the family leave bill, had been vetoed twice by President George Bush. The "motor voter" bill to ease registration requirements had been vetoed once, and neither required any legislative skills beyond persuading Senate Republicans to stop talking and vote.
 
Candidate Clinton's Promise
 The national service bill, designed to encourage volunteerism and create a corps of volunteers who would get living allowances and up to $10,000 in education grants, was a promise Candidate Clinton made. Nothing else he has urged on Congress reflects the mainstream hopes of the Democratic Leadership Council forces he assembled for victory. Even so, writing a new bill and making the modest compromises necessary to win the handful of Republican votes to break a filibuster was no small accomplishment. As Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, noted somewhat ruefully Friday, the Democrats were more unified than the Republicans.
Except for those Republicans who wanted to deny President Clinton a real victory, the national service bill had no natural enemies. The student loan bill did, in the banks and the Student National Mortgage Association, or Sallie Mae. As part of the overall reconciliation bill, it gained some shelter.
But it was still a hard-fought conference. Representative William D. Ford of Michigan, the chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, wanted a complete shift to direct Government loans after four years.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, his Senate counterpart, might have preferred that result personally. But he insisted on keeping the Senate approach, which left the existing federally guaranteed bank loans in place as a fallback. Republican senators like James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas wanted that approach, and Mr. Kennedy persuaded the Clinton Administration that their help would be needed on other issues down the road. Some other tough issues have very uncertain futures. Well-organized opposition, dissent among supporters and a diminishing sense of urgency about abortion rights make the Freedom of Choice Act look unlikely to pass. The Senate's decision to take public financing out of the campaign finance bill has dimmed the measure's difficult future in the House. Labor's big hope, a bill banning permanent hiring of replacements for strikers, faces a certain Senate filibuster.
 
Ahead on the Calendar
 There are other projects on the horizon, such as rewriting the Occupational Safety and Health Act and the financing formulas in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, where regional and economic divisions will make it hard for the Democrats to seize the opportunity presented by the unaccustomed presence of a President disinclined to veto.
After the budget, the next tough issues are the North American Free Trade Agreement and health care. President Clinton, who has hardly dealt with Congressional Republicans at all, will find Republican backing available, and essential, on the trade measure. Health care will also need Republican help. An easier measure may be his proposal to alter the procedures on claiming political asylum. Republicans like the idea but worry that it gives immigrants too many protections. It could be the first test of Mr. Clinton's bipartisan skills.

HEADLINE: Reagan Curse on Clinton

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
It isn't all Bill Clinton's fault. Not by a long way.
The President's protracted, messy effort to push his economic program through Congress, still hung up short of success this weekend, is taken in some Washington circles and by many rank-and-file voters as evidence of ineptitude if not incompetence. There is no doubt that the White House has made its share of mistakes in this campaign, on which the very definition of the Clinton Administration may turn. 
 Even as Congressional budget negotiators took the weekend off, the President and his staff continued today to campaign for his economic program. [Page 28.]
But to understand why it has been so hard for Mr. Clinton to achieve his goals, and why he will achieve only some of them even if Congress, as expected, gives grudging and narrow approval to some kind of budget package next week, one has to hark back to the Presidency of Ronald Reagan and the political atmosphere he created. It is still with us, and it makes Mr. Clinton look like Sisyphus on a bad day.
 
Failures of Government
 Playing on the failures of American Government in the 1960's and 1970's, and the difficulties those failures had created or proved unable to correct, Mr. Reagan successfully argued that government itself was the problem. Most Federal programs were bad; taxes were bad; spending was bad.
That notion -- a departure from the thinking of other recent American conservatives, like Richard M. Nixon, and many conservatives in Europe, where taxes are higher -- continues to exert a hold over a broad section of the American electorate.
As a result, politicians are terrified to wear the awful label, "tax and spend," however much their constituents need government money for health care or roads.
"We have reached a point when people sense that the time has arrived for another period of at least moderate government activism," said a moderate Republican senator. "There are unmet needs. People want problems solved. But they remain deeply skeptical about the capacity of any government to do the job, and they want the deficit reduced, too. Now."
In a sense, what Mr. Clinton and the negotiators on Capitol Hill have been trying to do is work their way out of that dilemma. They have been trying to patch together majority support for enough new taxes to give the public enough deficit reduction without cutting existing social services too much, and set up a few pilot programs like the proposed National Service Corps.
 
Electoral Weakness
 The President has tried to counter "tax and spend" with "fairness" and with a more concerted effort to explain himself. It is not working very well, so the Administration finds itself in the unenviable position of a company with an aging product line and inadequate cash flow to finance research and development. In fact, the agenda the President is undertaking is an enormous one, probably the most ambitious since that of Lyndon B. Johnson.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, a conservative Democrat who gives Mr. Clinton mixed reviews on both ideological and operational grounds, nevertheless asserts that "he is aiming higher than anyone we've had in the White House in decades."
He is doing so, furthermore, from a position of basic electoral weakness. Whereas Johnson won by a landslide in 1964 and benefited from the sense of national crisis created by the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, Mr. Clinton fell far short of a majority of the popular vote last November. That has hurt him.
 
The Treatment
 So has the very fact that the Democrats have been out of the White House since 1980 and have held it for only four years since 1968. The Clinton Administration, a member of the Cabinet said recently, has "suffered greatly from a lack of experienced technicians who can get things done on the Hill and elsewhere."
One of the Texans who came to Washington with Johnson pointed the other day to two other differences that he deemed important.
For one thing, he said, Johnson in the early, productive years of his Presidency had a kind of gravitas, a sense of political weight, that Mr. Clinton has found hard to project. Like many other Democrats, the former Johnson aide complained about Mr. Clinton's prolixity, his difficulty in focusing for long on any one issue and his seeming inability to find good nominees for crucial jobs without stumbling first.
The Texan also recalled that Johnson knew Congress as well as anyone in his generation, having served as Senate majority leader, and worked skillfully and successfully with both Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill. Trading, bluffing, demanding, cajoling, Johnson applied what came to be known as The Treatment. It was hard to resist.
But those techniques may no longer apply. Party discipline on Capitol Hill has weakened severely in the last three decades; even the Republican opposition in the present Senate, which has been remarkably unified, has failed to sustain some filibuster efforts.
It is the special-interest groups, the talk shows and the fund-raisers who exert the most powerful leverage over senators and representatives today, not the party apparatus or the Congressional leadership or the White House or even the President. Cable television and fax machines and phone banks have changed almost everything in Congress.
 
Distractions on Economy
 When Mr. Clinton came back from the summit meeting in Tokyo, where he had done well, he hoped he could segue directly into his domestic economic package. Foreign policy success and domestic economic strength, he has long argued, go hand in hand. But he was distracted almost at once by the need to settle the question of homosexuals in the military, by the death of his friend and staff member, Vincent W. Foster Jr., and by the threatened indictment of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
The President is desperate to get the budget package passed, with a credible amount of deficit reduction built in. Failure would be ruinous for him and for his party.
But once that is done, how long it has taken him to do it and how many votes he wins by will not matter so much. What will count in the Congressional elections next year and in the Presidential race in 1996 is whether this and subsequent economic measures create jobs and speed the recovery.
That, after all, is what Mr. Clinton spent 1992 insisting he could and would do and George Bush could not or would not.

HEADLINE: Citing Chains, Eeyore's Books Calls It Quits

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Eeyore's, a mainstay in the world of children's books in Manhattan, has closed its doors, a victim of difficult economic times and changing fashions in retail bookselling, its owner said yesterday.
Joel Fram, who founded Eeyore's Books for Children two decades ago, said he closed one of his stores, on Broadway near West 79th Street, on Tuesday, after having closed the other branch, on East 83d Street, in June. 
 For longtime customers, whose children visited the stores for readings by authors or to browse on their way home from school, the closings marked the end of an era. For Mr. Fram, it marked the end of a long career as a bookseller in New York City.
"I think I really did create something that really contributed to the neighborhood," Mr. Fram said. "A lot of kids would come and treat it as a way station on the way home from school. And a lot of people treated it as a resource for children's books. They practically treated it as a sort of public library."
 
Competition From Chains
 The stores -- named for the donkey character in "Winnie the Pooh" -- stocked more than 20,000 titles by hundreds of children's authors, from Maurice Sendak to Judy Blume. At one time, the owner said, Eeyore's was the only bookstore in Manhattan geared specifically to children.
Mr. Fram said, however, that in recent years, an economic slump, coupled with the proliferation of bookstore chains, has made it increasingly difficult for smaller booksellers to survive. He said the opening in April of a Barnes & Noble "superstore" -- a block-long store offering 225,000 books, including a large children's section -- on Broadway three blocks from his Upper West Side store was the final straw.
"The big chains, particularly Barnes & Noble, are opening up massive stores and sending shockwaves through the business," Mr. Fram said. "It's not just me and it's not just New York; its all over the country."
The closings put the 18 employees of the two stores out of work. Mr. Fram, who lives in Pennsylvania, said he hoped to find a buyer for the stores' name and inventories, and that he was pursuing a number of "different projects" for himself.

HEADLINE: Europe's Currency Crisis Presents U.S. With a Hard Choice

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
While a collapse of the European Monetary System would probably give American exports a boost, Europe's latest currency crisis presents the Clinton Administration with a difficult decision on whether to intervene to help prop up the French franc, monetary experts said today.
A breakdown of the so-called exchange rate mechanism could also eventually unleash inflationary pressures throughout Europe. And the United States hardly wants to be seen as benefiting from or abetting the troubles of its allies. 
 If the monetary system does break up, France and half a dozen other European Community nations would be free to stimulate their economies. Keeping their currencies within the bounds imposed by the system has required them to keep their interest rates at levels that have restricted economic growth, contributing to Western Europe's lingering recession, said John Williamson, a former International Monetary Fund official who is now a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics.
Freed from that system, European nations would be free to lower the rates.
 
Benefit for the U.S.
 The resulting economic growth would allow American companies to sell more goods in Europe, he said, adding, "In the short run, there is no doubt that European policies will be more expansionary if it falls apart, and that will be helpful to the U.S."
Olin L. Wethington, who was Assistant Treasury Secretary for International Affairs in the Bush Administration, also emphasized that the monetary system effectively limits American exports.
"The real cost to the United States in the present situation is the failure of the European economies to grow, to recover," he said.
Robert A. White, a senior vice president and foreign exchange trading manager at Standard Chartered Bank in Los Angeles, said that foreign companies might also be more willing to invest and trade more in the United States if the demise of the monetary system made the European market appear less stable.
But Mr. Williamson cautioned that to avoid offending the Europeans, the United States could not afford to be perceived as encouraging the currency turmoil there. A collapse of the monetary system could reawaken inflation in Europe, gradually undermining economies there and eventually hurting the prospects for American exports.
 
No Obvious Intervention
 Mr. White said that he had seen no obvious sign of market intervention in the crisis this week by the Federal Reserve, but he noted that the agency might be discreetly trading currencies using money supplied by European central banks.
European countries quietly encouraged the United States to intervene last fall to help preserve the monetary system, but the Bush Administration refused to do so. The British pound subsequently pulled out of the monetary system and London cut interest rates.
So far, there has been no official public request that the Clinton Administration intervene to prop up the French franc -- though experts say such requests are usually made discreetly through private channels -- and the Administration has been cautious in its statements.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said on Thursday night that the United States was watching the European currency markets closely but felt that they were a European concern. The Federal Reserve declined today to comment on the issue.
Another factor the Administration must weigh in deciding whether or not to buy francs to support its current level on currency markets is whether such action can be effective at anything less than a prohibitive cost.
Mr. Wethington said that the decision not to give assistance last year was based on an assessment that the United States could not have made a difference.
"There's simply too much currency sloshing around in international markets to have an effect, absent changes in domestic monetary or fiscal policies," said Mr. Wethington, who is now a partner at Steptoe and Johnson, an international law firm with a large Washington office.

HEADLINE: Reluctant Giant: Germany Balks at Leading Europeans to Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 31

 BODY:
Germany's shoulders, it turns out, are not as broad as either the Germans or their neighbors thought they were.
Ever since the unification of Germany in 1990, supporters of European unity, Germans most of all, have been telling themselves that Germany would lead the way. Built on the idea of Franco-German reconciliation, this unified Europe would forge a strategic and economic partnership with the United States, with the powerful German economy pulling the rest of Europe to prosperity. 
 There were fears, of course, fears that 78 million Germans would dominate their neighbors economically, monopolize trade with the formerly Communist countries to the east and throw their weight around in ways uncomfortably reminiscent of the past.
But if Germany dominates Europe today, it is by its unexpected weaknesses rather than by its strength.
This weekend, the European Monetary System that was to lead to a common European currency by the end of the decade was in turmoil because Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, acted in accordance with its national charter instead of meeting European expectations. [Ministers of the European Community gathered in an emergency session in Brussels to seek a way out. Page 16.]
 
Preserving Mark's 'Stability'
 The crisis flared on Thursday after the Bundesbank adhered to the letter of its charter, which requires it to preserve the "stability" of the German mark against inflation. The charter does not provide any room for tolerating a little bit of inflation to help the French franc, the British pound or any other European currency. The French had hoped the Bundesbank would agree to lower German interest rates, which would indirectly bolster the franc.
Instead, the bank declined to reduce its key short-term interest rate, and plunged the franc into a crisis. The Bundesbank's president, 67-year-old Dr. Helmut Schlesinger, described the situation as a "dilemma."
Politically, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his Government regard the alliance with France as the political core of European unity. But the Bundesbank, which is legally independent of the Government, was, like many other European national institutions, being called upon to bear more weight than it was ever designed to carry.
The crucial overload came from the Treaty on European Union that was agreed to by the leaders of the 12 member nations of the European Community in the Dutch city of Maastricht in December 1991. The treaty laid down a path to a common European currency as early as 1997, and committed the community to the goal of a common foreign policy as well.
 
A Surprising Hesitancy
 Second thoughts have since abounded all over Europe, but Germany has been the main scapegoat for what has gone wrong. And for all the fears of Germany throwing its weight around, it has been the hesitancy and reluctance of Mr. Kohl and his Government to assert leadership that has most often surprised their European and American allies.
The great sobering experience for the Germans was the unexpectedly huge social and economic cost of absorbing East Germany, which threw the German economy into an inflationary cycle and led the Bundesbank to impose the high interest rates that have been choking the rest of Europe for two years.
The high interest rates make it more costly to borrow, and thus reduce spending, which helps contain inflation. But those high rates also make the mark strong against other currencies, because they attract investors.
And that creates problems for the rest of the community, because many currencies are linked through the European Monetary System and its exchange rate mechanism. The mechanism requires the nine currencies to fluctuate within narrow ranges, and when the mark is kept strong by high German interest rates, other nations are required to keep their rates higher than they would like in order to keep their currencies within bounds.
Germany's political system was not designed to make crucial strategic or military decisions, which were left to the United States and the NATO alliance, and it has not been able to solve this economic riddle, or some political ones.
 
Prometheus Bound
 After unification, Germany had the biggest standing army in Western Europe, but -- far from being a military colossus -- it seemed more like Prometheus bound. Germany declared itself unable to send troops to the Persian Gulf, to the war-torn Balkans, or anywhere else beyond its borders because the Constitution of 1949 barred it from any military action abroad.
Germany's one attempt to throw its political weight around, just after the Maastricht treaty was signed, backfired disastrously. Believing that recognizing the independence of Croatia and Slovenia in late 1992 would deter Serbia from attacking them, Germany railroaded its allies into going along in the name of the common foreign policy they had just agreed to in the treaty.
Many now blame premature recognition of Bosnia and Herzegovina for inciting Serbian attacks there, and say the Germans bear special responsibility for the tragedy. When Secretary of State Warren Christopher pointed the finger at Germany again, in June, German diplomats reacted with strong protests.
But the fact remained that, whatever Germany might or might not have done to lead its European partners into a mess in the Balkans, it was unable to do much to help them get out of it.
 
Devaluation an Embarrassment
 At the Bundesbank, Dr. Schlesinger and other leading officials have always argued that if matching Germany's high interest rates was undesirable or too painful for neighboring countries, all they had to do when speculators started attacking their currencies was realign their values against the mark.
But for every other currency but the mark, "realignment" means "devaluation," which is very definitely embarrassing to people like Prime Minister John Major of Britain or Prime Minister Edouard Balladur and President Francois Mitterrand of France.
As for the Germans, many have no idea what devaluation means. The mark has not been devalued against other European currencies since the European Monetary System was established in 1979.
The underlying problem is that Europe's economies run on very different cycles. Britain was deep in recession when Germany was booming three years ago. France kept booming long after Germany sunk into recession. Now France is plunging deeper while Germany hopes it has bottomed out. Britain, which was able to cut interest rates after leaving the exchange rate mechanism, has been able to stimulate its economy and has started to emerge from recession.
Tying currencies tightly together when national economies are far apart simply does not work, yet that was the aim of the European Monetary System. As the weekend crisis proves, a united Europe is still a long way off.
And though it was the last thing the Germans say they wanted, Germany's special national problems and interests have probably made monetary union and the Maastricht treaty itself a dead letter for the rest of this century.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: Vatican Watershed -- A special report.;
Papal Birth-Control Letter Retains Its Grip

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Twenty-five years after Pope Paul VI put a jolting halt to expectations that the Roman Catholic Church might ease its opposition to artificial birth control, only 1 out of 10 American Catholics agree with the church's position. But the Pope's 1968 encyclical and the furor it created continue to polarize the American church.
Though birth control is seldom the subject of much serious debate among lay people in the 58-million-member Catholic Church, the effects of the initial debate linger like a low-grade fever, flaring up in areas that have little to do with sexual morality. To this day, they shape everything from Catholic views on other issues to the selection of bishops and other leaders. 
 The encyclical, "Humanae Vitae" ("Of Human Life"), was issued on July 29, 1968 -- a time of turmoil around the world, a moment of street battles at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago and just between the student uprising in Paris and the Warsaw Pact's invasion of Czechoslovakia. Today its critics and defenders are very much in evidence.
 
Effects Still Argued
 At conferences observing the encyclical's anniversary, like one attended by 1,400 people, including 14 bishops, in Omaha last week, the defenders are calling it prophetic: they say it accurately predicted that modern societies would slip into promiscuity and exploitation if contraception severed sexual activity from reproduction.
Critics reply that "Humanae Vitae" has itself contributed to the breakdown of sexual norms by undermining the church's credibility on questions of sexual morality in general, especially among young people.
A strong defender of the encyclical, Pope John Paul II, has made the condemnation of contraception a pillar of his papacy. He will visit Denver for an international gathering of Catholic youth Aug. 12 to 15, and it will be uncharacteristic if he makes no reference to his views.
Today, Catholics are as likely to use contraception as other Americans -- and to do so with a good conscience.
In a 1992 poll, 8 out of 10 Catholics said they disagreed with the statement that "Using artificial means of birth control is wrong." And 9 out of 10 told a New York Times poll in 1987 that "someone who practices artificial birth control can still be a good Catholic."
 
Issue of Credibility
 The changes are not limited to contraception. The Rev. Andrew M. Greeley has written of "the catastrophic collapse of the old Catholic sexual ethic" -- for example, more Catholics than Protestants now say that premarital sex is "not wrong at all" (44 percent to 35 percent, according to a poll by the National Opinion Research Center). And he says that because of "Humanae Vitae," papal authority has suffered, and so has Catholics' loyalty to the church: attendance at Mass and financial contributions both fell sharply after 1968.
Other critics, like Bishop Kenneth Untener of Saginaw, Mich., say the church's position on birth control has corroded its credibility with women and lay people. "Those who teach and preach have felt less confident in attempting to provide guidance in sexual matters," he wrote in a recent issue of the journal Commonweal. "Lay people are increasingly suspicious of the willingness of the hierarchy to listen to them on important matters."
The Rev. Richard A. McCormick, a leading Jesuit scholar in medical ethics who teaches at the University of Notre Dame, said he worried that the American church was "getting some very mediocre and unimaginative episcopal leaders" because the Vatican was using the birth-control teaching as a litmus test for choosing new bishops.
Defenders of the encyclical, encouraged by support from Pope John Paul II, say it is high time the church appointed bishops who outspokenly support the church's official teaching.
The defenders believe that the exclusion of critics like the Rev. Charles E. Curran, who lost his professorship at Catholic University because of dissenting views on contraception and other sexual questions, is if anything all too rare. They say the increasing numbers of abortions, out-of-wedlock births and cohabiting unmarried couples all seem to confirm the warnings of Pope Paul.
Yet over all, supporters and critics of "Humanae Vitae" are in agreement about many of the changes in Catholic life in its wake.
The two sides differ mainly in whether they blame the encyclical itself or the public rejection of it by leading theologians, combined with many bishops' low profile on the issue.
This fall, Pope John Paul is expected to issue a long-delayed encyclical on moral reasoning that will bolster his predecessor's declaration, either explicitly or implicitly.
 
The Issuing
Letter Set Tone On Contraception
 "No papal teaching document has ever caused such an earthquake in the church as the encyclical 'Humanae Vitae,' " wrote the Rev. Bernard Haring, one of Catholicism's foremost moral theologians, shortly after the encyclical was issued in 1968.
The controversial nub of Pope Paul's conclusions are in a few paragraphs among general reflections on marriage, sex, parenthood and morality. There is an "inseparable connection," the Pope declared in those passages, between the reproductive purpose of sexual intercourse and the emotional, physical and psychological aspects that express a couple's love.
Therefore, the argument continued, not just did the marriage as a whole have to be open to bringing new life into the world but so did each sexual act. Deliberately blocking the possibility of procreation violated the act's meaning, which the current Pope usually expresses as "total reciprocal self-giving."
 
New Questions in 60's
 For much of the 20th century, opposition to contraception has been an identifying mark of the Catholic Church. "We grew up thinking it was wrong and that could never be changed," recalled Patty Crowley, a Chicagoan who, with her husband, led the Christian Family Movement, an organization of Catholic couples that grew rapidly in the 1950's.
New questions about the church's position were raised in the early 1960's when the birth control pill was introduced. But it was the Second Vatican Council that by altering many church attitudes and practices between 1962 and 1965 created an atmosphere in which revision of the ban on contraception became thinkable.
By 1964, American Catholics began to read reports that some theologians approved of the use of the pill. Church officials disagreed, but their statements only warmed the debate.
The Second Vatican Council did not settle the matter. It approved a statement on marriage that emphasized the role of sex in expressing the love of spouses and their right to limit the size of their families by moral methods of birth control.
But what methods were moral? At the bidding of Pope Paul VI, that question was handed to a special advisory commission on family and population problems originally established by Pope John XXIII. Pope Paul enlarged the commission, adding bishops, medical experts, theologians and even three married couples, including the Crowleys, by then the international leaders of the Christian Family Movement.
Along with extensive theological arguments, the commission examined the results of a survey the Crowleys had made of couples in their movement. Many of them had tried to practice "rhythm," the one method of birth control the church accepted, abstaining from intercourse during the wife's fertile days.
 
Leaning Toward Change
 "Our input was crucial," said Ms. Crowley, now an 80-year-old widow who helps maintain Deborah's Place, a shelter for homeless women in Chicago. "We took couples that were trying to do what the church said, and some of the letters were just heartbreaking -- traveling salesmen and people out to sea coming home at the wrong time."
By the summer of 1966, an overwhelming majority of the Pope's commission, including many who had been advocates of prohibiting contraception, reached the conclusion that a change in church teaching was justified. When their report to the Pope was leaked to the press in March 1967, it became front-page news.
While Paul VI was agonizing, many Catholics were already making up their minds. By the mid-60's, only 14 percent of Catholics supported laws that forbade offering birth control information -- down from 45 percent in 1936. In 1964, not quite half the Catholics told pollsters that they would like to see the church accept contraceptives; a year later 63 percent favored a change.
When "Humanae Vitae" finally appeared, reflecting the position of a minority on the Pope's commission rather than the majority, the response was explosive. "We got a call from the press in the middle of the night," recalled Ms. Crowley. It was the morning of July 29 in Rome. "We just said we didn't believe it."
Father Curran mounted a public protest, composing a statement criticizing the encyclical that was signed by over 600 Catholic scholars. Many of the world's best-known theologians signed it or a similar European statement.
"We never even had a letter from Rome," said Ms. Crowley, who along with her husband had left their children to work on the papal commission. "I guess I'm a bit bitter about it."
 
In Practice
Few of the Young Tackle the Issue
 Twenty-five years after the encyclical, younger Catholics appear to take contraception as much for granted as Ms. Crowley's generation once took for granted the church's condemnation.
The encyclical's supporters are probably right in complaining that few younger Catholics have read "Humanae Vitae" or grappled with the moral arguments that it reflects.
Consider Joanie Collupy, who is just the kind of Catholic that Pope John Paul II wants to reach through his coming visit to the church's "World Youth Day '93" in Denver.
A 1991 graduate of St. Joseph College in West Hartford, Conn., Ms. Collupy spent two years working with teen-agers at a government health clinic in Alaska -- and providing them with information about birth control.
Hoping to devote herself to church service, Ms. Collupy is starting graduate studies in theology at the University of Dayton in September.
But until she read a recent newspaper editorial, Ms. Collupy said, she had never even seen the name of the papal document condemning contraception. "I'd heard of it and knew the church was against birth control, although a lot of priests would tell people simply to do what they thought best," she said.
 
Not a Leading Issue
 A priest who works extensively with young adults was asked how often they ask about birth control; he replied on the condition that his name not be used. "In 23 years of talking to people prior to marriage," he said, "the issue of contraception has never come up from them. It is absolutely amazing. Not once."
John Fontana, a layman who works with young adults for Old St. Patrick's Catholic Church in Chicago, said that for them, all that counts about the encyclical is that it left "a public relations image of the church and sexuality that is fairly negative."
"We are now dealing with the children of the people who wrestled with this as young adults in 1968," he said. "That was the first major segment of the Catholic population who were college educated and could engage theologians in real discussions of sexual morality."
But after the encyclical and a few years of fierce debate, "it just petered out," he said, and young people "are simply not going to the church" to ask about sexual issues.
"They are looking for people with psychological credentials rather than religious ones," he went on. "If the psychological credentials are there, a bridge to religious meaning can be built. If you're a parent or teacher and you're ambivalent about an issue, it isn't easy to pass it on with clarity."
 
The Resurgence
Pope Says Issue Is Not Debatable
 For some years after 1968, the papal condemnation of contraception appeared to have so little effect on the tide of Catholic opinion and conduct that many people thought that in time the Vatican would quietly abandon its position. That impression ended in 1978 with the election of Pope John Paul II.
From the start John Paul has been an ardent defender of "Humanae Vitae." He insisted that Catholics should abide by it and in 1987 declared that its teaching "does not belong to the category of matter open to free discussion among theologians."
Encouraged by the Pope, supporters of "Humanae Vitae" have rallied. They have published fresh philosophical and theological defenses of the encyclical. They have found platforms in new study centers and international conferences financed by conservative Catholic groups like Opus Dei and the Knights of Columbus.
Prof. Janet E. Smith is the author of "Humanae Vitae: A Generation After" (Catholic University of America Press, 1991), the latest major English-language entry into the debate. An associate professor of philosophy at the University of Dallas, Professor Smith said her interest in the topic began after she had left the church as a college student in the late 60's and early 70's.
She came back after gradually deciding that the church's opposition to abortion was right. Teaching at the University of Notre Dame, she found very few people who supported the church's teaching on sexuality and almost no one who taught it.
"I decided to bite the bullet," she said in an interview last week, "and found students receptive. I also had friends getting married and reporting satisfaction with natural family planning." Now, she went on, she is "interested in stemming the kinds of sexual madness that society is embarked upon."
 
Seeing Momentum
 Professor Smith and other defenders of the church's ban on contraception believe that they have regained the momentum in the debate.
"Instead of doing their own homework," she said, "the dissenters simply dismiss the traditionalists and the Pope as members of the flat-earth society."
Many defenders of "Humanae Vitae" draw additional strength from their conviction that its ban on contraception is infallible doctrine, not because Pope Paul said so but because it expressed something universally taught by the church before controversy broke out in the 60's.
A vast majority of Catholic ethicists reject this view, as well as the encyclical's teaching on contraception. "If you talked to 10 moralists, it would be three in support at most, seven against or evasive," acknowledged one defender, Msgr. William B. Smith, a professor of moral theology at the New York archdiocese's St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers.
Those critics remain unpersuaded by the encyclical's basis -- the principle that the dual meaning of sex, uniting the couple and reproducing human life, must be somehow respected not only in the totality of a married life but in each act of intercourse.
In addition, many couples find the Pope's talk of "total self-giving" or condemnations of contraceptive sex as "degrading" or "anti-life" to be far from the realities of married life, where they say that love has to cope with clashing work schedules, sick children and everyday exhaustion.
But both sides in the debate complain that for bishops, priests, and lay people, the division over contraception has created an unhealthy discrepancy between public declarations and private beliefs.
Monsignor Smith said that he found many of the theological dissenters "dishonest" for not acknowledging the radical effect of their focus on overall intentions and consequences rather than individual acts. This approach to morality, he said, could justify not only premarital and homosexual sex but almost any deed historically considered sinful.
As for insisting on the church's official teaching when dealing with Catholic couples, "there's a great deal of tiptoeing," he said; many priests "are not all that sure that the institution really means what it says."
Bishop Untener said that the only answer was "honest and open discussion."
Monsignor Smith called for "education," adding, "you don't accomplish much out of fear or threats."
While the bishop's "open discussion" would make room for dissenting views, the monsignor's "education" would not.
"We're just not going anywhere on this," Ms. Crowley said.
 
 
Short History of Encyclicals
 Popes have made formal declara tions since ancient times, but only in the 18th century did these begin to take the form of encyclicals, pastoral let ters written (or "circulated," the root idea of the Latin term) to the whole church.
With increasing frequency since the mid-19th century, Popes have issuedencyclicals to address both questions of doctrine and political or social de velopments.
Pope Leo XIII, for example, criti cized the treatment of industrial work ers in "Rerum Novarum" in 1891. Pope John XXIII took up questions of world peace and social welfare in "Ma ter et Magistra" in 1961. Two years ago, Pope John Paul II wrote about the religious and economic lessons of the collapse of Communism in "Centessi mus Annus."
With a few exceptions, the official texts of encyclicals are in Latin, al though they may be drafted in other languages. Their titles come from the first few words of the text.
Not everything in encyclicals is con sidered equally binding on Catholics, who have quite commonly interpreted and applied them with very different emphases. While acknowledging that positions taken in papal encyclicals have been eventually set aside or re vised, church officials warn that Cath olics should not ignore them in the meantime.

HEADLINE: CLINTON APPROVES A PLAN ON BOSNIA

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
President Clinton gave his final approval today to a plan for using air strikes to help protect the Bosnian Muslims, Administration officials said.
The United States has called for a NATO meeting in Brussels on Monday to discuss the proposal. The President's decision means that despite recent progress in negotiations on partitioning Bosnia, Washington is determined to press ahead with planning for air attacks to safeguard Muslim civilians and protect aid deliveries. 
 The Administration believes that the threat of air strikes is needed to press the Serbs to negotiate in good faith and to reassure the Bosnian Muslims that they will be left with a viable, if small, territory that will not merely exist at the sufferance of their enemies, the officials said.
 
Serbian Victory Seems Near
 Deteriorating conditions in Sarajevo and other Muslims areas, as well as intelligence projections that the Serbs are on the edge of a complete victory, have also prompted the Administration to move forward with its plan.
Mr. Clinton discussed the plan at a White House meeting this morning with his top aides. Secretary of State Warren Christopher; Anthony Lake, the national security adviser; Defense Secretary Les Aspin, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, attended the half-hour session.
The meeting was described by one Government official as a final review of a plan that had been the subject of high-level interdepartment deliberations. Even before today's meeting, Washington began alerting its allies that it intended to press its new initiative formally.
Mr. Clinton sent letters on Friday to heads of state and to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations explaining the importance of safeguarding Sarajevo and suggesting the need to expand the use of force to protect of Muslim civilians as well as United Nations peacekeepers.
 
Call for a NATO Meeting
 To further explain the Administration's thinking, Mr. Christopher spoke by telephone today with Western foreign ministers and underscored the need for a NATO meeting on military and economic measures to reverse the deterioriating situation in Bosnia.
Mr. Christopher plans to proceed with his plans to travel to the Middle East. The Administration has chosen Stephen Oxman, the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, and Reginald Bartholomew, Washington's representative at the current Bosnia talks in Geneva, to represent the United States at the NATO meeting.
The Administration's effort to promote a settlement in Bosnia does not depend entirely on military threats. Officials say they are determined to keep economic sanctions on the Serbs until it is clear that they are prepared to respect whatever new boundaries are decided in a partition of Bosnia and to stop their attacks on the Muslims.
In addition, senior Administration officials say Washington may need to apply economic sanctions to the Croats if they do not respect the terms of a peace settlement. The shelling of Spanish peacekeeping troops on Friday occurred in an area where Croatian forces have been active, although the United Nations says it has been unable to identify the culprits.
 
'Strangulation' of Sarajevo
 A senior Western official said that the United States had made headway in meetings with its British and French allies on the plan for broad use of air power, but that allied officials continued to have some reservations.
But that was before the Clinton Administration put its prestige behind the plan by contacting heads of state and calling for a NATO meeting.
While Administration officials say they are proposing the use of force to prevent the "strangulation" of Sarajevo and other Muslim enclaves, they have yet to spell out publicly the details of their military plan.
As a result, it is not clear whether Washington is prepared to begin attacks to stop any shelling of the Muslim enclaves, as some senior Administration officials have suggested, or is planning some lesser form of protection. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat, for example, has urged that a weapons-free area be established around Sarajevo and that United Nations troops interpose themselves in this zone. But it is not clear whether the United States and its allies are prepared to go that far.
 
Preparations for Air Strikes
 While the allies discuss how to protect the Muslims, NATO and the United Nations are pressing ahead with preparations to use air strikes to protect United Nations peacekeepers.
Spotters, radar equipment, laser designators and communications equipment are being moved into Bosnia to establish a command and control arrangement for calling in air strikes. American, British, French and Dutch warplanes are deployed in Italy for this purpose, and the United States and France have aircraft carriers in the Adriatic.
Though this network is being established at this point only to protect the peacekeepers, it would provides a basis for the United Nations to extend its protection to civilians as well if allied nations agree to the Clinton Administration plan.
