HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Flinching Over Washington's Hand in State Wallets

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, July 30

 BODY:
As Governor of Arkansas, President Clinton was just as generous as other state and local officials in ridiculing the Federal Government's practice of sticking its long arm into their affairs, particularly when it came to how they spent their money.
So it was no surprise when Mr. Clinton, speaking by satellite to the National Conference of State Legislatures gathered here, sought to reassure his former colleagues. "The evidence is clear, at least based on my personal experience," he said, "that Federal money goes farther, does more good, has a bigger impact, if we stop trying to micromanage it and overregulate it, and instead let it be spent where the people and the problems are." 
 But while Mr. Clinton's comments drew applause, many state officials said they were still suspicious of him and his budget bill. Their fear is that while the President and the Democratic Congress sound sympathetic, they are more interested in unveiling new programs that are bound to squeeze state and local budgets and only intensify the strains that have developed between Washington and local governments.
Paul D. Schauer, a Republican State Representative from Colorado, told his colleagues at the meeting here, "I'm sure all of you have horror stories of New England communities monitoring for contaminants that can only be found in pineapples in the fields of Hawaii."
No one laughed.
Each new proposal from President Clinton and the Congress, whether controlling the deficit, overhauling the health care and welfare systems or curbing illegal immigration, draws more resentment from local governments. They fear that they will be forced to foot the bill, often for regulations that make no sense in their states.
 
'Ongoing Tug of War'
 At issue are the growing number of cases when the Federal Government imposes costly regulations on state and local governments without providing money to pay for them. Local officials have carped for years about requirements threatening their "fiscal sovereignty," but their concerns have only escalated with the new Administration at a time when many jurisdictions are scraping for money for basics like police protection and sanitation.
Recent studies have found that as much as 60 percent of state budgets is often devoted to programs that are in part required by the Federal Government.
"This plays havoc on all our state budgets," said Wayne Goode, a Democratic state senator from Missouri. "It's an ongoing tug of war. We're told, 'If you don't do this, we'll take away your Federal highway funds.' That's the biggest threat."
Harry A. Green, the executive director of a Tennessee agency that handles governmental relations, was more blunt: "This whole process has become mean, nasty and brutish. It just shifts the burden from Washington."
To prove that they are not just crying political wolf, several states are drafting legislation this year to challenge Congressional efforts to impose requirements, or at least to make it easier for states to win exemptions from them. And some members of Congress are pressing for measures that would give states relief from such requirements, or at least require Congress and Federal agencies to assess how much financial burden new laws would place on them.
To draw public interest in the requirements, the United States Conference of Mayors has announced plans for a National Unfunded Mandates Day in September.
 
Wide Agreement
 The subject was also a big topic here, with legislators complaining about requirements for everything from clean water regulations to Medicaid to enforcing the new disabilities law. In a survey of 590 legislators at the conference, 90 percent agreed that requirements without accompanying financing provisions were making it increasingly difficult to balance state budgets.
The mandate issue is viewed as so severe that the National Conference of State Legislatures now publishes a booklet of several pages, the "Mandate Watch List," almost monthly to "alert readers to particularly threatening legislation under active consideration."
One example cited by the conference was language in Federal budget legislation that would affect how states regulate and tax telecommunications companies. The conference warned its members in a memorandum that "at least 32 states would be directly affected at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars."
After explaining to state legislators here that they were fortunate that the deficit reduction plan no longer contains a tax on all forms of energy (though it is expected to contain billions of dollars of new costs to state and local governments), Christopher Zimmerman, chief economist for the National Conference of State Legislators, warned that the worst may be yet to come. "They didn't do a lot of things we most feared," he said. "But hold your breath and keep your fingers crossed for health care reform."
 
Sympathy From Dole
 In a sign that the states are being heard, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, told the group, "There is a bipartisan sense now that we've got to slow down, that we're unloading part of our burden on the states."
Arthur Hamilton, who is president of the conference of legislatures and the House Democratic leader in Arizona, seemed heartened by the comments of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole, saying "people used to just laugh at us" when they complained about mandates.
Yet it was not clear whether the President and Mr. Dole were just using the issue to win applause from the legislators. Mr. Dole, for one, was most critical of the newly passed "motor voter" bill intended to ease voter registration. He warned the legislators that "you're picking up the tab -- we ought to fund the mandate or we shouldn't do it in the first place."
But it is no secret that Mr. Dole had long opposed the legislation, which is widely believed to lead to the registration of more Democrats, so his comments appeared to be as much a criticism of the legislation itself.
Since they are no strangers to political reality, several state legislators said they did not expect the onslaught of unfinanced requirements to stop coming their way anytime soon. They said, though, that they hope their opposition will at least slow the practice.
In the meantime, most states will probably try to do what they have done for years: pass on part of the burden to local jurisdictions.
"You bash up and you pass the buck down," said Alan Rosenthal, director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "That's how it works."

HEADLINE: Lawyers Unsure of Effects of Paring Altman Charges

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
As the criminal trial of Robert A. Altman enters its final, critical phase this week, lawyers familiar with the case are divided over how to interpret the significance of a decision by a New York State Supreme Court judge to dismiss half the charges against Mr. Altman.
Some say the ruling weakened, if not gutted, the Government's case. The decision was made on Thursday by Judge John A. K. Bradley, who threw out four charges, including an important bribery count. 
 "It can't help the prosecution in any manner that I can see," said Ronald P. Fischetti, a criminal defense lawyer who is a close friend of Gustave H. Newman, the leader of Mr. Altman's defense team.
Others say the action may turn out to be a blessing in disguise for a prosecution that they say has often appeared to take a scattershot approach during the four-month trial.
And still others say both the defense and prosecution may feel uneasy about the decision because the judge's actions in the case have been inconsistent.
No lawyers involved in the case would comment publicly, in keeping with Judge Bradley's request last week that prosecutors and defense lawyers refrain from speaking to the press until after the jury reaches a verdict.
 
Central Accusation Remains
 Mr. Altman, 46, now faces four charges, including the central accusation that he systematically engaged in a scheme to defraud regulators about the role of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International in the acquisition and management of First American Bankshares Inc., once Washington's largest bank holding company.
Prosecutors say Mr. Altman and Clark M. Clifford, Mr. Altman's former law partner and mentor, were aware that a group of Middle Eastern investors they represented were merely front men for B.C.C.I. when they purchased First American in 1981.
Mr. Clifford, 86, was indicted with Mr. Altman over a year ago. But after heart surgery in early March, Mr. Clifford, a former Secretary of Defense, was deemed too ill to stand trial. Both men have denied the accusations and contend that they were duped by the investors.
Testimony concluded in the case last week, and closing arguments will begin Wednesday. If convicted on the remaining charges, Mr. Altman would face a maximum prison term of 16 years and could be fined up to $20,000.
Aside from establishing the connections linking B.C.C.I., the investors and Mr. Altman, a large chunk of the prosecution's case has focused on the sensational details of the deal Mr. Altman and Mr. Clifford had with B.C.C.I. to purchase First American stock, shares that were bought in 1986 and 1987 at no risk with loans from B.C.C.I.
 
$9.8 Million Profit
 In 1988, roughly 20 months after the stocks were initially purchased, some shares were sold at a 300 percent profit, producing a pretax profit of $9.8 million for the two men. B.C.C.I., prosecutors charge, bought those shares.
Judge Bradley's decision to throw out the bribery charge makes it highly likely that when lawyers for both sides meet on Monday to argue what should be included in the judge's instructions to the jury, Mr. Newman will press hard for an instruction to disregard all testimony about the stock deal.
Mr. Newman's closing argument, scheduled for Wednesday, could also reflect the fact that a financial payoff from B.C.C.I. is no longer part of the government's case against his client. Mr. Newman may argue that the lack of an economic incentive to participate in a scheme to commit fraud legitimates his client's claim that he was fooled by the investors and B.C.C.I.
But other lawyers noted that a substantial part of the indictment remained intact and that evidence presented about Mr. Altman's stock dealings might remain part of the record.
"The judge will have to instruct them that no charge of bribery will be submitted to them, but the testimony may be admissible for a different purpose," said Otto G. Obermaier, a former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who is now a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
 
Avenue Left Open
 The fact that three false-filing counts are left in the indictment may provide that avenue. Those are filings, signed by Mr. Altman, with the New York State Banking Department for the years 1988, 1989 and 1990; among other things, the filings list his name as a shareholder in First American.
The lawyers who argue that Judge Bradley's ruling may turn out to be favorable for the prosecution say that by limiting the case, the Judge has forced Assistant District Attorney John W. Moscow, the lead prosecutor, to adopt a more focused approach, correcting what those lawyers say has been a major weakness.
Widely seen as a brilliant investigator, Mr. Moscow has spent years tracking and uncovering B.C.C.I.'s fraudulent activities. But in the courtroom, Mr. Moscow's vast knowledge about B.C.C.I. and its ties to Mr. Altman has at times proved to be more of a hindrance to the prosecution than a help, the lawyers add.
In effect, Judge Bradley's ruling will place legal blinders on Mr. Moscow when he sums up the prosecution's case on Thursday or Friday.
These lawyers also point out that by throwing out four counts of the indictment, Judge Bradley may also have simplified his task of what to instruct the jury about the case.
But nerves are on edge about the Judge and his upcoming rulings, partly because of what has happened thus far.
Before the trial began in late March, Judge Bradley commented that based on grand jury transcripts, "the evidence of guilt is overwhelming." Since then he has become much more circumspect.
Thursday's decision came as an extreme surprise to a number of lawyers. Based on rulings by the New York State Court of Appeals, they said, decisions about whether prosecutors have met the burden of proof should, in most cases, be left to the jury.

HEADLINE: Senate Confirms Mondale as Envoy to Japan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The Senate has approved former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to be the United States Ambassador to Japan.
By voice vote, the Senate confirmed Mr. Mondale and more than a dozen others for senior diplomatic posts on Friday. 
 The Senate also approved James J. Blanchard, the former Governor of Michigan, to be Ambassador to Canada, and Stuart E. Eizenstat, a policy adviser in the Carter Administration, to be the United States representative to the European Community.
Also confirmed were Robin Lynn Raphel, counselor for political affairs at the United States Embassy in India, for the new State Department post of Assistant Secretary for South Asian Affairs.
Other ambassadorial appointments approved were Thomas J. Dodd of Washington for Uruguay, Jeffrey Davidow of Virginia for Venezuela, Alan H. Flanigan of Virginia for El Salvador, John Maisto of Pennsylvania for Nicaragua and Donald C. Johnson of Texas for Mongolia.
Other nominations confirmed were those of Richard M. Moose of Virginia for Undersecretary of State for Management, Mary M. Raiser of Washington for White House chief of protocol and David L. Aaron of New York for United States representative to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Says Chinese Economy Rivals Japan's

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency says China's economy is bubbling -- indeed, close to overheating -- with a gross domestic product of $2.35 trillion, matching Japan's and growing at 13 percent a year.
In an annual report to Congress presented today, Martin Petersen, the C.I.A.'s top East Asia analyst, said reforms instituted over the last 14 years have sharply improved living standards in China, and allowed free domestic markets to flourish. They have created "a modern economic power," the third-largest economy in the world, after those of the United States and Japan. 
 Among the modern aspects of the Chinese economy is inflation, which reached 16 percent in China's cities last winter. Another is a huge trade surplus with the United States, which Mr. Petersen said could reach $24 billion or more this year.
Last year, American exports to China rose 19 percent to $7.5 billion. But American imports of Chinese goods, particularly textiles, shoes and toys, rose 35 percent to $25.7 billion, for a record American trade deficit of $18.2 billion. Japan did better in the Chinese market, boosting sales to about $12 billion and buying about $17 billion worth of Chinese goods.
The strongest trend in the Chinese economy reported by the C.I.A. was a 160 percent increase in foreign investment -- almost all of it from Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan. Despite their longstanding political and cultural enmity with China, those three countries were responsible for more than 85 percent of the $11 billion in foreign investment in China in 1992, the analyst said.
Economic reform has come to China in a trial-and-error approach, which the official described as "crossing a river by feeling for the stones." Among the firm footings the economy has found, he said, are these: Industrial output grew 22 percent last year, the number of companies nearly doubled, and investment in fixed assets grew about 38 percent.
The slipperiest stone remains inflation. The 16 percent rate is "shocking to a leadership that has always feared inflation," Mr. Petersen said. "While the economic expansion is good news for Beijing -- creating new job opportunities for many Chinese and adding to Beijing's clout as an emerging economic power -- it is threatening to spiral out of control."
Three weeks ago, Beijing began trying to cool the economy by halting the construction of new development zones and ordering government banks to recall dubious loans, the analyst said.

HEADLINE: Budget Talks Take a Breather, but Clinton Presses On

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Hung up on odds and ends, Congressional budget negotiators took the weekend off, but President Clinton and his staff continued today to try to drum up support for his economic program.
Mr. Clinton invited a group of tourists at the White House into the Rose Garden about 8:30 this morning and delivered a campaign-style speech in which he insisted that his program was essential for economic recovery and would pose little burden to middle-income Americans. 
 On Capitol Hill today, Congressional staff technicians churned out one computer spread sheet after another showing how much revenue various proposals would raise and how much other proposals would cost. At this stage, every dime is important, and money taken from one program must be found in another.
Downtown, two dozen Administration officials gathered in what they call the war room on the first floor of the Old Executive Office Building next door to the White House and placed telephone calls around the country to promote the program and to try to line up votes in Congress for it.
 
Plan for Thursday Vote
 The Democratic Congressional leaders who are putting together the final package, an amalgam of deficit-reduction bills passed in May by the House of Representatives and last month by the Senate, broke Friday night, saying they had resolved all the main issues and needed only to tie up loose ends before signing a final agreement on Monday.
Plans now are for a final vote in the House next Thursday and in the Senate late Thursday or Friday. The prevailing view in the Capitol is that the measure will become law. But at best it will be a cliffhanger, and no one can say where the necessary votes will come from. All the Republicans in the House and Senate plan to vote against it.
The bill passed the House in the first round by six votes, 219 to 213. Since then, several representatives who voted for it have expressed second thoughts, and one, W. J. (Billy) Tauzin of Louisiana, has said he definitely plans to vote "no" next week.
In the Senate, the bill passed originally on the strength of Vice President Al Gore's tie-breaking vote. This week, three Senators who were in favor then, David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, have expressed reservations.
 
Clinton's Pitch
 In his speech today, Mr. Clinton said: "Unless the Congress acts on this budget, we cannot remove the uncertainty that exists in the economy. We cannot continue to bring interest rates down, and we cannot possibly move on to the other challenges that await us."
He stressed that 80 percent of the new tax revenue would come from people earning more than $200,000 a year and that "no working family earning less than $180,000 will pay a penny more in income taxes."
The only extra tax on the middle class, he said, would be "less than a dime a day" for gasoline.
The White House announced that Mr. Clinton would deliver a speech on the budget on television Tuesday night.
Traveling in North Carolina today, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, responded to the President by issuing a statement. "The White House fog machine is on full blast," it asserted. "No matter how hard the President tries, he can't make this tax-heavy package look good."
The negotiators have agreed to raise the top tax rate, now 31 percent, to 36 percent for individuals with taxable incomes between $115,000 and $250,000 and couples with taxable incomes between $140,000 and $250,000. The rate for taxpayers with taxable incomes above $250,000 would be 39.6 percent.
Taxable income is the amount left after deductions and personal exemptions are subtracted. A taxable income of $140,000 is the equivalent of an adjusted gross income of about $180,000, and a taxable income of $250,000 usually means the taxpayer has a total income above $300,000.
 
Agreement on Gas Tax
 The negotiators have also agreed to add 4.3 cents a gallon to the current 14.1-cent Federal gasoline tax. According to the World Almanac, the average driver drove 12,858 miles last year. At 20 miles to the gallon, such a driver would pay an additional $27.60 a year in gasoline taxes.
Other key provisions that have been settled would lower military spending and limit the explosive growth in spending for Medicare.
The issues still unresolved include tax deductions and credits for businesses, the precise size of the Medicare limits and the effective date for the higher income taxes.
The legislators also have not decided exactly how much the total deficit reduction would be, although the figure is almost certain to be between $490 billion and $500 billion over five years, making it the largest such package ever enacted.
This seems like small potatoes in a $7 trillion, five-year budget accord, but the political stakes are so high and passions are running so deep that decimal points can cause snags.
The White House has continued to put the best face on the prospects. From the war room, Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman, the officer in charge, said it was his understanding that reaching a final agreement was "just a matter of checking with the conferees and making sure they are prepared to sign, rather than any substantial differences."
Lawrence F. O'Donnell Jr., the chief of staff of the Senate Finance Committee, agreed that basically only tinkering remained to be done. "We may have to take small amounts from here or there that are in the spirit of what we've already agreed to but are not technically what we've agreed to," he said.
 
Tensions Rising
 After days of sitting around conference tables in small rooms in the Capitol, nerves have begun to fray.
Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the chairman of the Budget Committee, seemed about out of patience. "Every time you turn around," he said, somebody's shoving a note under the door saying they've got to have another $200 million for this or $400 million for that. And then somebody comes in and says the revenue estimate is $1.5 billion different from what it was yesterday. I've had it."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "STILL ON THE TABLE"
 
A few of the items that the budget negotiators have not resolved:
 
Small Business. To encourage investment in new equipment, the House bill would allow small businesses to deduct up to $25,000 each year in equipment purchases, up from the current $10,000. The Senate bill put the figure at $20,500. To save money, the conferees would like to reduce the maximum deduction to $17,500, but the Clinton Administration prefers a higher number.
 
Research and Development. The tax credit businesses were allowed to offset research and development costs expired June 30, 1992, because its extension was part of a much larger tax bill that President George Bush vetoed. The House bill would extend the credit permanently and make it retroactive to July 1, 1992. This was a Clinton campaign promise. The Senate bill would allow the credit for one year beginning July 1, 1993, but would not make it retroactive.
 
Meals and Entertainment. Both the House and Senate would reduce the deductible portion of business meals and entertainment costs to 50 percent from the current 80 percent. But the lobbying on this issue has been fierce, and the negotiators are considering a figure of perhaps 60 percent or 70 percent in the hope of picking up a few votes for the final version of the bill from wavering lawmakers.

Medicare. The House bill would restrict the exploding growth of Medicare spending by cutting $50 billion from its budget over the next five years. The Senate voted for a $58 billion cut. The final figure will probably be in between.
 
Effective Date. Under the House bill, the higher income-tax rates on upper-income taxpayers would take effect Jan. 1, 1993. The Senate made the effective date July 1, meaning that the income-tax increase this year would be only half as high. The conferees tentatively agreed to set the date at March 1, but now they are considering going back to Jan. 1 to generate a few billion dollars more in revenue.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Skirted Own Rules on Military Contracts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The Pentagon is skirting its own rules by farming out military contracts to other Federal agencies, a practice that frequently avoids competitive bidding and drives up costs, Pentagon officials have acknowledged.
The Pentagon routed at least $6.3 billion in military work to other agencies in 1990 and 1991, according to an audit by the Pentagon's inspector general that was obtained by The Associated Press. 
 In one case, the Defense Department used the Tennessee Valley Authority for $18 million in spending for highly classified submarine-detection research, Pentagon auditors said. The auditors determined that the T.V.A., the electric utility serving seven Southern states, lacked "adequate security clearances" for such a contract.
As testimony opened before a Senate government management subcommittee, Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who heads the panel, said the T.V.A. took a fee to pass on the contract to the Pentagon's preferred contractor, ESG Inc., which actually performed the work.
When auditors intervened, Mr. Levin said, Pentagon officials used bookkeeping sleight of hand to redirect the money to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which channeled it back to the T.V.A., which passed it on once more to ESG.
The inspectors general of the Defense Department confirmed Mr. Levin's findings and said steps were being taken to correct the situation.
The Air Force also went through the T.V.A. for a truck, walkie-talkies with headsets and boom microphones, designing a machine-gun range and clearing trees and underbrush at a cost of $1 million, said Derek J. Vander Schaaf, the Pentagon's deputy inspector general.
At another agency, the Pentagon incurred $11 million in unnecessary costs by having the Energy Department oversee $100 million in research projects on hazardous waste and computer systems, an audit found. The Pentagon should have issued the contracts itself, it concluded.
The audits do not assert any violation of Federal law, although a Senate subcommittee plans to review the cases.
"We identified hundreds of cases" where the Defense Department could have handled work, but shipped it out to other parts of the Government instead, Mr. Vander Schaaf testified.
The reason for going to other agencies is that it is "a means to circumvent procurement regulations," he said, "and expeditiously obtain goods and services from contractors."
The Federal Economy Act requires a determination that going to another agency is cheaper than direct acquisition. But Mr. Vander Schaaf said that farming out the work to another agency frequently costs more.
Mr. Levin said, "What we have here is a widespread practice by Federal agencies of breaking rules and violating important checks in the procurement system."
The practice of routing work to other agencies frequently has been used at the end of the fiscal year as departments scramble to spend unused money that otherwise would revert to the Treasury.
Two Pentagon audits show how the Defense Department conducts the practice year-around, invoking the Economy Act that allows one Federal agency to use or borrow the expertise of another in certain circumstances.
"D.O.D. managers were unaware" how much they had spent until auditors added it up, according to one audit report, which calculated the total cost of routing work to other agencies at $6.3 billion for 1990 and 1991.
The audits indicate additional costs from the practice. For example, the Pentagon paid $1 million to the T.V.A. for handling the submarine detection program, documents show.
And when the Pentagon routed the work through the Energy Department's Oak Ridge, Tenn., installation, auditors concluded that the practice had added $11.6 million to the final bill. They found "multiple tiers of subcontractors, which in turn added three or four tiers of indirect costs for administering the projects."
Federal regulations generally require that contracts be advertised for competitive bidding.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
War Room General Plots Fight on Economic Turf

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
In the middle of chaos, with computer printers humming, phones ringing nonstop and five television monitors blaring, Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman calmly surveyed the Administration's war room as he planned the next forays in the protracted battle to push the President's budget package through Congress.
Mr. Altman has been hunkered down in this overstuffed room for the past three weeks, ever since the White House asked him to run the war room operations. The 30 people he oversees are responsible for developing and executing a strategy to nudge or straight-arm (whatever it takes) President Clinton's $500 billion deficit-reduction plan through Congress. 
 Mr. Altman was chosen for the task because he knows politics, is an expert on economics and has been over more than a few waterfalls before, in business and in Government.
"We're down to the two-minute warning," Mr. Altman said as he took a break that was sandwiched between calls to Congressmen. He sat behind one of the two large U-shaped tables that hug the walls of the office, an ornate, 19th-century room in the Old Executive Office Building. "This is one of the crucial moments in the early history of this Administration."
To his right, Marla Romash, a senior aide to Vice President Al Gore, was coordinating television appearances, radio interviews and speeches by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and other Administration officials. Across the room, Rahm Emanuel, a political aide, and Gene Sperling, an economic aide, were feverishly planning a rapid response to a Republican report charging that the President's package would clobber small businesses. The second-in-command of all this activity is Ricki Seidman, the deputy communications director.
 
On the Line of Scrimmage
 With the Administration squaring off against the Republicans day after day over the budget, Mr. Altman is playing middle linebacker, directing the defense and getting in the hardest hits by accusing the Republicans of hypocrisy and worse. Although his face is not as well known as the face of Mr. Bentsen or Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, Mr. Altman is becoming one of the Administration's most prominent -- and partisan -- economic spokesmen.
A sample, from a CNN interview: "I don't think we adequately anticipated the cynicism of the other side, both of Republicans themselves and a variety of right-wing groups going out and saying to middle-income Americans, you're going to pay enormous new taxes under this plan, when in fact under the Senate bill the average family earning $40,000 is going to pay one dollar a week of higher taxes under this plan."
For good measure, he added, "There have been gross distortions."
Mr. Altman's new role could be a dry run for him to move on to bigger things. Within the Administration, it is assumed that Mr. Bentsen, who is 72, will not remain Treasury Secretary for eight years. At the age of 47, Mr. Altman is one of the favorites, if not the favorite, to succeed him.
For Mr. Altman, politicking for Mr. Clinton is old hat -- he was a year ahead of Mr. Clinton at Georgetown University, but he worked hard in Mr. Clinton's unsuccessful race to be president of the school's student council. ("It was clear even back then that he had considerable political gifts," Mr. Altman now says.)
 
Millionaire Populist
 The image Mr. Altman projects can seem somewhat at odds with his populist message. He was a millionaire investment banker during the go-go 1980's. He owns a ranch in Jackson Hole, Wyo., where he ropes and brands calves during vacations. He walks with the self-confident swagger common among bluebloods.
But his life is a real Horatio Alger story. His father died when he was 10, and his mother supported him on a librarian's salary in Boston. As he grew up seeing his mother's efforts to help poor children, he was drawn toward Democratic politics, he said. In graduate school at the University of Chicago, he had so little money that he cooked for his roommates and they paid for his food in return.
As an investment banker, Mr. Altman put in long hours, often working past midnight. Perhaps that experience helps Mr. Altman feel at home in the frenzied war room -- sometimes called the rec room, for reconciliation room -- by its inhabitants. The war room's purpose is not just to get the President's budget approved, but, with an eye to the elections of 1994 and 1996, to convince Americans that the budget will bring them economic benefits, like lower interest rates.
"Secretary Bentsen has a wonderful line -- we not only want to enact President Clinton's budget, but we want to enact it with the American people," Mr. Altman said. (He talks almost fawningly about Mr. Bentsen: "I think the term 'class act' was invented for him." "My job is to do what he would like me to do.") In the past few months, with Mr. Bentsen working overtime lobbying on Capitol Hill, Mr. Altman has handled many of the administrative chores of running the Treasury.
 
Barbs From G.O.P.
 But Republicans do not give Mr. Altman high marks. They mock the war room's work, ridiculing assertions like the one that Mr. Clinton's program will help create eight million jobs. They say those jobs will be created even without his program.
G. William Hoagland, the Republican staff director for the Senate Budget Committee, said in an interview: "Roger Altman might be a great Deputy Treasury Secretary, he might have made millions on Wall Street, but in terms of communicating effectively, most of the stuff he has put out has been pure unadulterated junk. Maybe he has a difficult plan to defend, but he's certainly not doing a good job defending it."
Just as Mr. Clinton spent his life training to be President, Mr. Altman seems to have spent his life training to be Treasury Secretary. While studying for an M.B.A. at the University of Chicago in 1968, he worked in Indiana, organizing volunteers for Senator Robert F. Kennedy's Presidential campaign.
In 1969, he joined Lehman Brothers; five years later, he became its youngest general partner, specializing in mergers. He campaigned for Jimmy Carter in 1976, worked on the transition team and became Assistant Treasury Secretary for domestic finance.
In that post, he was the point man on the New York City and Chrysler bailouts. That meant he spent much of his early 30's twisting arms, getting union leaders to accept wage freezes and bankers to accept slower repayments. Only after he extracted such concessions did the Government come through with the loan guarantees needed to avoid bankruptcy.
In the Chrysler talks, many company officials feared that he was driving too hard a bargain with the banks and that the banks might push the company into bankruptcy rather than accept Mr. Altman's demands. But he finally got Chrysler's 400 banks to agree not to call in their loans for at least four years. "At the time I thought it was too tough," said Robert S. Miller, a retired Chrysler vice chairman. "But that four-year standstill gave us the breathing room we needed to survive."
Mr. Altman rejoined Lehman Brothers in 1981, but in 1985, after American Express acquired Lehman, he joined a new investment banking firm, the Blackstone Group. He was Blackstone's vice chairman and ran its worldwide mergers and acquisition business.
"He is a fiscal conservative," said Peter G. Peterson, a former Commerce Secretary and chairman of the Blackstone Group, "who believes the nation is investment-starved. But on social issues, he is certainly a progressive. It's probably accurate to call Roger a policy wonk."

HEADLINE: Trying Serial Murder: Where to Begin?

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Of all the questions surrounding the case of Joel Rifkin, who is accused of killing 17 women, the first quandary prosecutors must resolve is this: Who will get the first crack at convicting him?
Legal experts say the case is a jurisdictional morass involving nine counties in the New York region, since the authorities have said Mr. Rifkin killed most of the women in Manhattan and dumped their bodies in rivers and woods in a wide area from eastern Suffolk County to northern Putnam County. The state police are coordinating the murder investigations, but a month after Mr. Rifkin's arrest, a squadron of prosecutors is still trying to resolve where he will be tried and in what order to bring the cases. 
 Prosecutors say they want to make sure that the first case tried is the strongest, since an acquittal in the first trial could weaken all the other cases. It is also important that they gain more than one conviction, they say, to make it virtually certain that Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, will never be paroled.
 
Lure of Praise and Publicity
 And, of course, the prosecutor who wins the first case against Mr. Rifkin will reap the greatest windfall of praise and publicity. While none will say so publicly, the prosecutors themselves admit that they are extremely reluctant to yield authority in high-profile cases in which a conviction is certain to burnish their reputations.
"Jurisdictional problems in this case are so unusual that they are almost guaranteed to create ego rivalries over a high-profile serial murder case," said Laura A. Brevetti, a former Federal and state prosecutor. "The question is sure to be which D.A. is going to get the most honor and publicity, and everybody wants it."
James B. Jacobs, director of the the Center for Research and Justice at New York University's School of Law, said Mr. Rifkin's case illuminates internal disputes that often arise from the country's decentralized law-enforcement system.
"This case raises extraordinary jurisdictional questions, and there is no institutional mechanism in the state's criminal justice system to resolve them except through negotiations among the prosecutors themselves," Mr. Jacobs said. "With such an abundance of crime, it seems almost humorous for law-enforcement people to be fighting for business."
 
More Than One Trial Urged
 But James M. Catterson, the Suffolk County District Attorney, said, "When you have 17 dead, that fact cries for more than one indictment and trial."
Prosecutors and their aides from the affected counties -- Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Orange and Putnam -- said that while no agreement had been reached, the schedule of trials would probably be based on who has the strongest evidence.
Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, said that his office and several others were prepared to try Mr. Rifkin but that one or two of the prosecutors were delaying decisions because the trials could be complicated and might strain the resources of their staffs.
"I don't know what will happen down the road, but so far there has not been any rivalries over who will prosecute first," he insisted.
Under state criminal procedure law, a murder case can be prosecuted in a county where the killing occurred or where a body is found.
 
Corpse in Trunk, Police Say
 Mr. Rifkin was arrested by the state police in Mineola in Nassau County on June 28 after a car chase that began when troopers tried to pull him over for a routine traffic violation. They said they found the corpse of a Manhattan woman, Tiffany Bresciani, 22, under a tarpaulin in the back of Mr. Rifkin's truck.
State police officials said that on the day of his arrest, Mr. Rifkin admitted strangling Ms. Bresciani and 16 other women, many of whom had arrest records for prostitution. The officials say they found evidence in Mr. Rifkin's home in East Meadow, L.I., tying him to an 18th murder.
The statements by Mr. Rifkin, state police officials said, led to the recovery of 14 bodies in the nine counties, but they have been stymied in their search for four bodies.
Indicted in Nassau County on July 13th in the murder of Ms. Bresciani, Mr. Rifkin pleaded not guilty and is being held without bail in the Nassau County Jail. He has not been indicted in any other killings.
 
Admissions Not Recorded
 His lawyer, Robert Sale, said he expected that the first trial would be held in Nassau County because the prosecutors assert that Mr. Rifkin can be directly implicated in Ms. Bresciani's death through the finding of her body in his truck. All of Mr. Rifkin's admissions, police authorities said, were made to investigators without being written or recorded on video or audio tape, and prosecutors expect that Mr. Sale will try to suppress the statements as evidence.
Last week, most of the prosecutors rejected a proposal by Mr. Sale for the nine counties to consolidate their cases and to hold a single trial in one county on all charges.
Mr. Dillon and Mr. Catterson said state law precluded a joint trial covering indictments in several counties.
Mr. Sale, however, maintained that the district attorneys had the discretionary authority for a combined trial. He said that prosecutors, whom he declined to identify, had told him that the Manhattan, Nassau and Suffolk offices "did not want to abdicate their cases."
Three bodies were found in Manhattan, two in Suffolk County and one in Nassau County.
 
Cost of Multiple Trials
 Mr. Sale said that a single trial would save the state hundreds of thousands of dollars in court costs and that multiple trials would place "an impossible economic burden" on Mr. Rifkin and his family.
The lawyer said that in addition to Nassau County, he expected that prosecutors from at least four more counties would seek indictments.
Although the prosecutors have declined a joint trial, Mr. Sale said the office of Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau might prosecute Mr. Rifkin at a single trial for four murders committed in that borough. Nancy Ryan, chief of the trial division in the Manhattan office, said no decision had been reached.
An insanity plea for Mr. Rifkin was being considered, Mr. Sale noted. To be acquitted under such a plea, the defense would have to prove that at the time of each murder, Mr. Rifkin was suffering from a mental disease or defect and failed to know or appreciate that the criminal act was morally wrong.
 
'Son of Sam' Similar
 The last major serial murder case in the region with overlapping jurisdictions occurred in 1978 with the arrest of David R. Berkowitz, who called himself "Son of Sam." He pleaded guilty to nighttime forays in which he used a .44-caliber gun to slay six young women and wound six women and men in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.
Mr. Berkowitz pleaded guilty to all charges at a single session in Brooklyn at which State Supreme Court justices from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx separately heard his pleas. He was sentenced to 25 years to life, the maximum term that could then be imposed for multiple murders, making him eligible for parole consideration after 25 years.
The law has since been changed and Mr. Rifkin, if convicted, could be sentenced to consecutive minimum terms of 25 years, eliminating any hope of parole.
Ms. Brevetti, the former head of the Federal Organized Crime Strike Force for the Eastern District of the state, was an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn when prosecutors wrangled over jurisdictional rights to try Mr. Berkowitz. "Behind the scenes, there were a lot of meetings and a lot of screaming and yelling," Ms. Brevetti, who is now a defense lawyer, recalled.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mr. October Is Now A Man For All Seasons

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARMEL, Calif.

 BODY:
On a Saturday in June 1977, Martinez Jackson, a tailor in Wyncote, Pa., just outside of Philadelphia, received a phone call from his son, Reggie, in Boston, and it was clear that his son was terribly upset. Martinez Jackson had raised Reggie pretty much alone, after he and his wife had divorced when the boy was 6. He raised him on Greenwood Avenue in Wyncote, the block where all the blacks in town lived.
At the time of the call, Reggie Jackson was 31, an outfielder with the New York Yankees, and it came after a game against the Red Sox. Reggie had always said that his father is the most important influence in his life and he talked often to his father, at that point in 1977, over the 10 years of his major league baseball career. 
 Most times, the calls were pleasant, even thrilling. "I just popped two today, Dad," Reggie might say. "Oh, you did?" his father might reply. "That's great! Just great!" But as Reggie Jackson remembered that call in June 1977, there was a different feeling. That afternoon he had had another clash with his manager, Billy Martin, in the dugout after Martin accused Jackson of loafing after a ball in right field, and Jackson denied it. They almost came to blows.
 
What Dad Believed
 "I'm having trouble with the manager, Dad," said Reggie. He told him how Martin had got into his face and how Reggie said don't get too close, you're only 150 pounds and you're 50 years old and that, said Reggie, is when he "went off." Other players had to pull them apart.
"Forget the manager," Martinez Jackson told Reggie. "Remember, son, you're still a colored boy. And the man in the office is payin' you good money. Just go back and hit the ball over the wall."
By "just a colored boy," Martinez Jackson, the tailor, meant that Jackson should not consider himself, as Reggie interpreted it, "a big shot." "You got to appreciate what you got," said his father. "You're making $600,000 a year. You're putting food on the table, you got money in your pocket, you've been given a chance to be somebody. Go with dignity. Just do your job."
This afternoon, Reginald Martinez Jackson, who went back and hit the ball over the wall, the way his father had suggested, will be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. Martinez Jackson, age 90, will be in attendance, an honored guest of the inductee. Jackson's father, an old Negro League player who never got a chance at the big leagues because of segregation, wasn't telling him, as Jackson heard it, to shuffle for the Man. And Reggie Jackson never did that. He took pride in having attended college -- Arizona State, where he remains 16 credits short of a degree in biology -- and took pride in being a new generation of black American, one not afraid to speak his mind, regardless of consequences.
Reggie Jackson hit 563 balls over the wall in his 21-year major league career, sixth on the career list; only Hank Aaron, Babe Ruth, Willie Mays, Frank Robinson and Harmon Killebrew had hit more. And Jackson did it with as much style and drama as anyone who has ever played. No one has ever moved about a ball field with as much obvious delight or seeming need to be in the spotlight, to virtually lasso it if necessary. It appeared that Reggie Jackson, 6 feet tall, 215 pounds and broadchested as a rooster, his eyes behind dark glasses and a roll to his stride, luxuriated as the chants of "Reg-gie!" "Reg-gie!" washed over him.
He was called Mr. October for his exploits in the World Series, where his lifetime batting average in 27 games in five Series is .357, nearly 100 points higher than his regular-season lifetime average. His Series slugging average of .755 is the best ever. And he hit 10 homers in the Series, at a rate of about once every 10 at-bats, the second-best percentage ever.
In one of the most stirring nights in baseball history, Jackson, against the Dodgers in Yankee Stadium on Oct. 18, 1977, ripped three straight homers, each one on the first pitch, and when he ran past first baseman Steve Garvey on the last one, Garvey, he later told Jackson, applauded into his glove.
 
Loves His Nickname
 "Mr. October," he said recently, drawing out the name. "It's the best, better than Say Hey Kid or the Mick. The Yankee Clipper -- what's that? I'm not talking about them as ballplayers -- they were great -- but this is nicknames. You know which one I liked a lot? The Galloping Ghost -- Red Grange. You can just picture that. Like you can Mr. October."
It was said by an Oakland teammate, pitcher Darold Knowles, "There isn't enough mustard in the world to cover Reggie Jackson," hot dog supreme. And of course Reggie himself made that never-to-be-forgotten reference to being "the straw that stirred the drink" for the Yankees, and rhapsodized about the "magnitude of me."
 
Bottom Line: He Produced
 He preened, he could be overbearing, he hyperbolized in word and deed, and he seemed at times not to have an unaffected bone in his body. He might casually break appointments, but, above all, for a ballplayer, he produced, and produced often when it was desperately needed. And in the end you wondered whether the shimmering ego was, in amateur psychology, just a coverup for a basic insecurity that perhaps none of us, maybe not even the subject himself, might understand, or acknowledge. From here, it looks like a combination of talent and the inner demons driving him to succeed.
"We won 11 division titles, 6 American League pennants, were in 5 World Series and won 3 of them," said Jackson. "And I hit in the big slot in all of those.
"I can't say I relished those moments under pressure -- at least, not at the moment -- but I succeeded in them. I rose to the occasion. I knew what to do, how to control it. I mean, Michael Jordan doesn't want to have to score 20 points in the last quarter to win. It is nerve-racking. But you have to adjust to the clutch, do what you have to do -- that's what they're paying you for. And the first thing is to make sure you're mind wasn't cluttered."
This was said one day last week as Jackson sat at the kitchen table of his handsome, secluded five-bedroom house on a hill here. From the picture window, one could see out past the tall Monterey pine trees to, down below, the edge of town and then out to the spectacular ocean sparkling in the afternoon sun. But Jackson, now 47, still looked powerful in T-shirt -- he works out in a gym for two hours, five days a week -- blue jeans and hiking boots. A sprig of gray hair curled up from under a felt Yankee cap, which covered a retreating hairline and shadowed the salting of gray in his dark mustache.
 
Just You and the Ball
 And slowly he began to transport himself, to a ball field, with 60,000 people waiting eagerly to see what he would do next.
"Yeah, you gotta get everything out of your mind except that ball the pitcher's got in his hand, and you're thinking of getting the barrel of the bat in the pay zone -- on time!" he said. He raised his right arm and extended it, with the five fingers at the end representing the enemy, the opposing pitcher. His left fist at his side was a proxy of him at the plate, grasping his black bat:
"Get yourself together, you tell yourself. You got the pine tar on your hands. You mash down your helmet. You fix your glasses. You shift your body so your shirt's fitting right, not hugging you. You plant your feet in the dirt, and make sure there's no stones. Your hitting gloves are on right. There can be no excuses, like some guys. 'Oh, something got in my eye.' Or, 'My gloves slipped.' C'mon, man, you didn't do it -- that's all! Ah, but now he's gotta throw. Now I'm in charge. He gotta be out there with it." Now Jackson is talking swifter, dropping verbs like a street kid in the 'hood. "He right there! He right there! Close your eyes and listen and you know who's up. Pow!" Jackson smacked his left fist into his right hand. "That's how I felt up there."
Of course, it wasn't all glory. Jackson holds the record for most strikeouts in a major league career, 2,597 -- far outdistancing the second-place man, Willie Stargell, who had only 1,936.
"I remember I went by Babe Ruth, breezin,' " said Jackson, about Ruth's 1,330, which was the record once upon a time. "And then I went by Mickey Mantle, who once held the record." It was at 1,710. "Mickey told me, 'Reggie, when you passed me it was one of the happiest days of my life.' "
He shrugged. "Yeah, I have lapped a few guys," he said, with a little smile. "Sure, it's a little bit embarrassing owning the all-time strikeout record, but not a lot. Remember, in order for you to strike out that much, they have to have confidence to put you in the lineup."
 
You Can Look It Up
 Striking out was only one of the darts thrown at Jackson. Some said he was a detriment as a fielder, and that his arm was strong but erratic. "The putdowns about my fielding began with Martin, he was the one who began saying it and others picked up," said Jackson. "I thought of myself as a complete player, an intelligent player, who knew how to run the bases and hit the cutoff man.
"But I don't want to have to defend myself as a ballplayer," he said. "All I have to do now is throw them the book and say, 'Look it up: Reggie Jackson, Hall of Famer.'
"You make the Baseball Hall of Fame, it's different from anything else in sports. You become a national resource." Perhaps he meant national treasure, but resource might be right, that you can still take sustenance from the magnitude of Reggie, still feel you can count on him when you need him in the bottom of the ninth.
After retiring from baseball, going back to Oakland in 1987 as a kind of encore, for he had begun his career with the A's in 1967, he now has two jobs -- or two titles, to be sure. He is "adviser to the president" of the Upper Deck Company, a firm that makes baseball cards and is the sponsor of old-timers games. And Jackson is the "special adviser to the managing general partner and principal owner of the Yankees," one George Steinbrenner.
 
Not Much Travel
 When the appointment with the Yankees was made in the spring, Jackson said he would help evaluate talent. How would he do that? Oh, he said, he'd check out statistics and look over guidebooks. When it was asked whether he'd look over talent first-hand, he said, well, sure.
"I get to New York maybe one week a month, and talk with Gene Michael," said Jackson, referring to the Yankee general manager. "But I'm checking out the young guys in the minor league system."
How often does he make trips?
"Not as often as I'd like."
How often has he been to their minor league teams so far?
"Well, once, to Columbus for three days."
 
$6 Million in Cars
 Jackson seems as interested in his antique automobile collection as he is anything else. He has 94 cars, including a plum 1955 Chevrolet Bel Air in mint condition with license plates "R M JAX 44" -- 44 being his Yankee number -- that he was driving swiftly through Carmel traffic, the exhaust pipes gunning, the '50s music station loud and him bouncing to the beat of "Great Balls of Fire" with his baseball cap turned catcher-style. He keeps most of his cars covered in plastic in a warehouse in Carmel. He says his collection might be worth $6 million. He lives alone, having married once, in his rookie season, and then was soon divorced. He does have one child, a 2 1/2-year old daughter, Kimberley, who lives with her mother in southern California and whose picture is on a shelf in his bedroom.
Jackson seems to have handled the millions he made from baseball with care. He once said that he could always talk with George Steinbrenner because Steinbrenner was a businessman, like him, but he could never really talk with Billy Martin. "Martin," said Jackson, "was just a baseball manager."
Steinbrenner, meanwhile, courted Jackson in 1977 to play for the Yankees, let him go as a free agent in 1981 -- "the biggest mistake I ever made," Steinbrenner has said. About the controversy over whether Steinbrenner should move from Yankee Stadium, Jackson said, "Why not? It's an economic decision." It sounded like he was shilling for the Boss. After all, Willie Randolph, Jackson's former teammate with the Yankees, and now a working assistant general manager for them, said moving Yankee Stadium from the Bronx would be a terrible thing, given the history of the Stadium. "Willie's from New York," said Jackson. "It means more to him in that regard."
At Old-Timers Day at Yankee Stadium, Jackson remembers talking with Randolph and saying, "You must feel great to have the job you do now, where people look up to you -- a black man making it on the administrative level." And Randolph told Jackson that that was right.
 
Race the Key Factor
 Jackson indeed sees himself on that level, although surely going at his own pace. Like the baseball world, it seems, the business world comes to Reggie Jackson, not the other way around. If his role appears more public relations than hard-core, hands-on, full-time business, well, it's a trade-off, his name and image for his title.
Jackson takes pride in his image and his language, having worked at speaking "with eloquence and style," as his father had advised him from his youth.
"In the end, race remains the most important factor in my life," Jackson said. "The sensitivity to it. When I was younger, a kid in Wyncote, I just took it for granted that I was a second-class citizen. You were made to feel that way. But when I got older, I got mad about about it, but couldn't always say something. Like there were cliques on the Yankees, and they loved it when people said things about me that they couldn't say themselves, or wouldn't say to my face. That I was self-centered or had a massive ego.
"And I felt I was misunderstood about that straw stirring the drink remark. I mean, I came to the Yankees after they'd just lost the Series in four straight to Cincinnati. And I said they had great players like Munson and Guidry and Piniella and Chambliss, but I said I was the last ingredient that could win the championship. The straw that stirs the drink. When it was printed, everyone went nuts."
But the fact is, the Yankees won the championship the next two seasons.
"Then I remember the time on the team bus when Mickey Rivers and I were needling each other and I told him I had a high I.Q. and he said, 'Reggie, you can't even spell I.Q.' And it was funny, but I hated that it was another black man who was saying it in front of some of those other guys. They got a big laugh out of it. I laughed, too. Ha. Ha. But I knew why they were laughing."
On balance, though, Reggie Jackson's memories are sweet. He reached the pinnacle of his profession with a star quality shared by few others and has a plaque in the Hall of Fame to prove it. If he was too absorbed in Reggie Jackson for some tastes, it wasn't too much for his. And still isn't.

HEADLINE: The Trouble With Drug Testing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mr. Lipman brushes aside the objections of "critics" who say workplace drug tests are "intrusive and prone to error." 
 I am one such critic. In 1990, my employer, Motorola Inc., initiated a random without-cause testing program of its United States employees. With the aid of the Civil Liberties Union, a fellow employee and I challenged the policy in the Massachusetts courts. In November 1992, the Massachusetts Superior Court ruled that the company's policy violates the state's privacy act because it "mandates urinalysis without respect to the nature of an employee's duties." Our case is under appeal. Other cases challenging employer drug testing are pending here and in other states.
When companies claim the right to conduct chemical tests on their employees' urine, blood, hair or other bodily fluids and tissues, they are using the drug problem to camouflage a seizure of power over their workers' attitudes. Docile submission to employer drug tests has become the loyalty oath of the 1990's. Who dares refuse when to do so means unemployment and worse -- the stigma of presumed guilt?
We have these crusades from time to time in America in which the public and private sectors collude to rid the nation of witches, or spies -- or now, it seems, noncompliant workers. If we are lucky, this crusade will follow the pattern of its predecessors -- a few years of hysteria after which we look back with chagrin and wonder what came over us.
Meanwhile, what becomes of those who do not believe employers should have search powers that so greatly exceed those we grant to our police? What becomes of those who do not look upon their fellow workers and fellow citizens as criminal suspects? They -- we -- are in for a few bad years.
 
JAMES A. WEBSTER
Clinton, Mass., July 23

HEADLINE: In America;
Looking For Work

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Scott Scanlon was blunt, and it was enough to make you shudder. "When people talk about economic recovery," he said, "people tend to think that means more jobs. There's not going to be a recovery in jobs."
Mr. Scanlon is chairman of Hunt-Scanlon Publishing in Greenwich, Conn. It publishes a newsletter, Executive Search Review, aimed at senior-level executives who are looking for work. Some have been looking for two or three years. For many, the search is hopeless. The jobs are gone. 
 Constance D'Agosta of Whitestone, Queens, was once a vice president for human resources at a company that was the target of a hostile takeover. She joined the job search in 1989 and what she encountered was frightening. "For every job on my level," she said, "500 to 1,000 people were applying."
Ms. D'Agosta turned to consultant work and now counsels others who are unemployed. "What I am seeing is incredibly emotional," she said. "The pain, the anguish, the trauma. People are hurting. It's almost like a death in the family."
It is difficult to overstate the importance of a job to most Americans. It is both a financial and an emotional linchpin. But no matter what results from the frantic budget maneuvering in Washington, the employment outlook is poor.
Even companies that are doing well are downsizing. Procter & Gamble, which is enjoying record earnings, announced last week that it will eliminate 13,000 jobs.
John Cammidge, director of employee relations for Bank of America, is among those who call the phenomenon "right-sizing." It's a cold term for a cold procedure. In many cases, employees who have been with major firms for 10, 15, 20 years or longer are being hustled out the door. Referring to one aspect of the changes at Bank of America, Mr. Cammidge said, "We needed to shed people to meet customer flow."
"Realistically," said Mr. Scanlon, "companies just don't need all the people they've had in the past."
"It's very scary," said Bill Belknap of Ridgewood, N.J., a former executive who now does consulting projects. "American companies are really learning to do it smarter, and that means with fewer people."
No one disputes the trend. Companies struggling through a weak economy are pushing profits up by pushing employees out. Very few good new jobs are being created to replace the ones that are being lost. All types of workers are affected, from gung-ho men and women at the highest levels of the corporate hierarchy to kids fresh out of high school and college.
Which leads to a question. How do you sustain a fragile economic recovery while decent jobs are hemorrhaging? Who will be spending the money to power the recovery, especially at a time when the Government is raising taxes and restraining its own spending in an effort to reduce the deficit? And what will be the effect of additional taxes to finance health care reforms?
"There is nothing to suggest that we'll have any significant expansion of the economy," said Markley Roberts, an economist with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s department of economic research. "The stimulus originally proposed by Clinton was not as big as we had hoped but that's been ground down. There's damned little left."
The Federal Government is contributing to the assault on jobs. On Friday the Senate Armed Services Committee endorsed the recommendation of the base-closing commission to shut down 130 military installations and to scale back operations at another 45. Not only will Federal jobs be lost, but also the jobs of thousands of civilians whose work depends on the existence of the installations.
Earlier in the week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced plans to eliminate 2,000 jobs as it reduces the scale of the space station.
Not nearly enough attention is being paid to the nation's employment problems. There is general agreement that the budget deficit needs to be reduced and Government spending brought under control. But as the fervor for deficit reduction has grown, serious talk about Government investment and other strategies to stimulate employment has faded.
The real issue is jobs. Any attempt at economic recovery is threatened by the millions of Americans who are unemployed, and the millions more who are underemployed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: JULY 25-31;
Dollar Libre: Cuba Tries Tourism And Cash in Crisis

BYLINE: By Howard W. French

 BODY:
With the neatly twinned announcements last week that Cuba will soon allow its citizens to possess dollars for the first time since its Communist revolution while encouraging Cuban-Americans to visit in large numbers, the Government of Fidel Castro is effectively announcing the grave dimensions of its economic crisis.
Mr. Castro's gamble is aimed at attracting more, desperately needed foreign dollars and capturing those already in circulation by enabling Cubans to shop stores previously reserved for foreigners. 
 If the country does draw a large influx of exiles, a major part of the strategy, experts say there will be plenty of other surprises as well.
"The big question is what will Aunt Luisa say when her wealthy relatives start showing up and telling her how awful things are," said Jorge Dominguez, a Harvard specialist on Cuba. "My guess is that it won't take her long to start agreeing."

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD;
America's Schools Are Not Alone

BYLINE: By Veronica Byrd

 BODY:
MANY problems facing your school board, it turns out, are far from unique. A group of 24 university presidents, chancellors and rectors from around the world gathered recently at New York University to compare notes -- and commiserate -- on common difficulties facing public-school education.
Among the concerns of school officials in Russia, Syria, Nigeria, Greece, India and elsewhere, according to the participants, were chronic overcrowding, a lack of economic resources, a decline in student literacy, the negative impact of television, decreasing popularity of science and a decline in social and family values. 
 The university leaders also voiced the need for their own institutions to work more closely than they have with elementary, junior and high schools in preparing students for college or vocational study. "Perhaps we've been too concerned with looking inward," said Sir Claus Moser, Warden of Wadham College at Oxford University. Sir Claus said he was particularly discouraged by the inability of students to understand the social sciences and technology.
New York University's president, L. Jay Oliva, agreed. "Higher education has an enormous stake in the 'product' of our elementary and secondary schools," he said. "There must be constant interaction between these schools and higher education if the crisis in public education is going to be solved."
Stanislav P. Merkuriev, rector of St. Petersburg University, said he believed that all universities -- not just teacher's colleges -- should take greater responsibility in the training of public-school teachers, in part by making general education courses more readily available.

HEADLINE: Belly Dancing Is Out!

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
CALL IT the curriculum of ambition. In its serious incarnation at schools for continuing education, it is "Introduction to Parallel Computing." In its not-so-serious incarnation, it is "How to Make Money Selling at Fairs, Festivals & Flea Markets."
Throughout the economic slowdown, with its large number of white-collar professionals newly unemployed or fearful of layoffs, enrollment in continuing education courses has continued to inch up. 
 And the trend seems to be away from the not-so-serious to the serious. "Belly dancing was very popular five years ago, and now it isn't," said Beth Greer, who owns three Learning Annex franchises in California. "The hottest thing now is career stuff."
Enrollment has risen steadily, if not dramatically, at more than 370 colleges and universities that offer continuing education courses. Most of these courses are three months long and cost anywhere from several hundred dollars to several thousand. Enrollment has also risen, if more erratically, at scores of unaccredited adult "learning centers," where the courses are shorter, as few as two evenings, and less expensive, often less than $50.
Students continue to see the value of these courses, which follow college but do not typically lead to an advanced degree. Yet continuing education has changed considerably in recent years.
To keep enrollment up, schools all over the country have given students what they want: more business-oriented classes, especially those known as career development, meaning getting or keeping a job or striking out on your own as an entrepreneur.
 
Avoiding the Frivolous
 And there is a shift away from what could be considered frivolous courses, like tours of notable houses or tennis for credit.
The approach seems to be working. According to the most recent statistics released by the United States Department of Education, 1992 enrollment of part-time students, who are mostly in continuing education classes, rose about 1 percent, to 6.3 million, from the previous year, and increased 12 percent from five years earlier.
The shift in curriculum is noticeable just from thumbing through course catalogues. At the University of Washington in Seattle, for example, there is not a single recreational or culinary class.
"When I took this job 10 years ago," said Richard L. Lorenzen, the university's vice provost for continuing education, "I felt it was my job to get rid of the wine-tasting, the pop psychology, the kayaking and all that stuff." He added, "Our students are not taking the insurance class on certified employee benefits for a lark."
Instead, there is a great emphasis at the University of Washington on 35 new "certificate" programs, which vary in length from 5 to 11 months and whose cost of several thousand dollars is often borne by employers. They range in field from actuarial science (statistical computation of insurance risks) to fund-raising management (writing grant applications and wheedling donations out of corporations) to software engineering (writing computer programs).
"Master's degrees and Ph.D.'s will always have their place," Mr. Lorenzen said. "But because of the information deluge today, some people in the future may prefer to deal with knowledge in digestible chunks a few months at a time, rather than take two years off for an M.A. and six years or more for a Ph.D."
The University of California at Los Angeles offers possibly the world's largest continuing education program, with more than 4,500 courses and more than 90,000 students enrolled annually. But the huge, 216-page summer catalogue devotes only two pages to sports, where once recreational classes would have gone on for many pages.
These days, U.C.L.A. officials are proud of the "Hospitality/ Food Service Management" program designed to train professional chefs, wine stewards, caterers and facilities managers for the ailing hotel industry in southern California.
Michael E. Stone, a spokesman for U.C.L.A. Extension, said: "One of our continuing-education specialists had a hunch that despite the high vacancy rate for hotels, there was a shortage of trained personnel. His hunch was right and we developed one of our most successful programs."
At the Learning Annex in New York, which started out as a meeting place for singles, one of the hottest classes is not "Steal the Man You Want From the Arms of Another Woman" but "Start Your Own Import/ Export Business (Full or Part-Time)."
"What we have always offered is education but also entertainment," said Harry Javer, director of the Learning Annex in New York, one of six such adult-education schools owned by local franchisees. "The recession froze entertainment dollars, so we had to start offering more education."
At the Learning Annexes in San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Diego, all owned by Ms. Greer and her husband, Stephen Seligman, many of the more light-hearted courses like belly dancing have faded away. However, both the New York and California Learning Annexes still have a heavy dose of what they call "edutainment," like "Power Shmoozing -- How to Network for Business and Social Success," in Los Angeles, and "Yes! You Can Find Your Soul Mate . . . Even in San Francisco."
"The buzzwords for us are love and money," said Mr. Seligman. "We know we're going to succeed with both in our classes."
To Joseph F. Donaldson, this return to career basics has a familiar ring. An associate professor of adult education at the University of Missouri at Columbia, Professor Donaldson has studied continuing education's history.
In the early 1800's at Cambridge University in England, dons taught "extramural studies," the forerunner of continuing education, which was designed to teach basic reading and writing skills to the working class.
 
American Copies
 Around that time, Rutgers University in New Jersey and later the University of Chicago copied the English model, offering classes to both college graduates and the general public.
Up until the 1970's and early 80's, most courses in continuing education were career-oriented, Mr. Donaldson said. But with the energy crisis and the resulting fiscal strain on universities, there was pressure to fill classrooms after 5 P.M. to spread out the operating costs of the university with less rigorous courses.
Continuing education is largely financed by student tuition rather than subsidized from regular operations. "There is some temptation for continuing education to be viewed as a cash cow," Mr. Donaldson said. "Popular classes that fill the seats obviously help, but there really is not that great a return on investment." Ann M. Pflaum, a dean of continuing education at the University of Minnesota, added: "It's true that we are the entrepreneurial part of the university, but we're not being turned into a profit center."
