HEADLINE: The Fight Over National Standards

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
When former President George Bush pushed for national student standards in math, science, history and other academic subjects and new ways to assess student progress in meeting those standards, there was a ground swell of support. When President Bill Clinton proposed Federal legislation in April to create councils to oversee the work on standards and assessments, many more applauded.
After all, who could argue against setting standards for students that specifically outline what they should know in each subject area at each grade level? And who could oppose exams that better measure student progress toward those standards, abandoning the old multiple-choice tests that research shows are biased against girls and minorities and substituting new assessments that require students to do more writing and demonstrate an ability to think? 
 But as work continues on both standards and assessments, concerns are mounting that the projects in tandem will ultimately spawn a national curriculum -- at once dreaded and criticized by educators, analysts and parents.
Never mind that math is the only subject for which national standards have already been written and that new national student assessments are still being debate and designed, years from actual use. All this worry is being vented even as some, like former Education Secretary Terrel H. Bell, say the country already has a de facto national curriculum, dictated by textbooks and college-entrance exams like the Scholastic Assessment Exam and the American College Test.
None of this eases the minds of critics, however, who have launched an increasingly rancorous opposition in the past year over what they say are the real evils of a national curriculum.
Following the unveiling of President Clinton's legislation, the National Center for Fair & Open Test, a Boston watchdog group, warned about the effects that it said such a curriculum coulkd have on student assessments. In June, the American Educational Research Association sponsored a conference that embodies its concern in the title: "The Hidden Consequences of a National Curriculum." Many of the conferees warned of the dire consequences a federally prescribed framework would have on public schools. And journals of various education associations have published article upon article making much the same case. The sour reactions reflect a host of worries such as the prospect of a loss of local control over schools, a tradition as old as the country. Critics also worry that the national curriculum would hinder innovation in the classroom, as educators would teach to the new standards to make sure their students meet them. Acquiring knowledge and passing tests, they point out, are not necessarily the same thing.
Over time, others fear, a national curriculum could well mimick those found in Great Britain, France, Germany and Japan, models where students in each of those countries study the same subjects from the same textbooks in the same grades, sometimes even on the same days. Such a development, they argue, would wring local and regional flavor from curriculums. And there is concern that the writing of standards is progressing so quickly - and some critics assert without much thought to consequences - that no one can say with certainly that American schools won't ultimately be saddled with a European-style curriculum, which would be less than ideal given the rigidity of national curriculums.
"We need to be more contemplative about these changes as we approach them and get off the notion that something must be done immediately," said George E. Stroufe, director of governmental and professional liason for the American Educational Research Association. Based on studies of other country's national curriculums, Mr. Stroufe says that national "standards and assessments do narrow the curriculum with detrimental effects."
Fueling a good deal of the worry, however, is simple confusion. The public, both sides of the national curriculum debate acknowledge, has been ill served by the education community and public officials who have debated the issues without giving the words "standards" and "assessments" a clear context.
But those devising new standards and assessments say all the hand-wringing is for naught. "Basically, there is no reason to worry," said Lauren Resnick, a University of Professor education professor and co-chairman of the National Standards Project, a group overseeing the writing of national standards. "If you're vision of a national curriculum is one modeled after the French, then there's no need to worry. We aren't headed toward that."
If anything, Ms. Resnick says, a national curriculum might resemble the Norweigian model, a loosely constructed framework of academic standards that local schools work toward meeting with minimal interference from the Federal Government.
The stage was unwittingly built for this acrimonious debate in 1989, when the nation's governors set forth six national education goals later backed by President Bush. By the year 2000, according to the goals, all American youngsters should arrive at school ready to learn; students must exibit proficiency in math, science, history and other subjects, and they must lead the world in math and science. Schools must be free of violence and drugs, and all Americans must be literate and possess the skill to compete in a global economy by the end of the decade.
 By the time the goals were written and endorsed by President Bush and the 50 governors, most states had already initiated efforts to stregthen curriculums. But governor's designation of areas of acedemic achievement in which American students should lead the world by 2000, according to some supporters, provided key elements that had been missing in American education and gave the Federal Government a role as advisor to the states.
 In the wake of the enunciation of these national goals, however, as test after test indicated that American students were still lagging behind their peers in other countries, the persistent cries from the public and the business community through much of the early 1980's that even tougher standards were necessary became even louder. A consequence began building that, for all the education improvements attempted by states, the Federal Governments should step in to provise a national framework.
 President Clinton's "Educate America" legislation is aimed at giving states guidelines to devise their own curriculums. But Opponents believe the legislation contains a number of potential evils.
 "A national curriculum is something that is so nebulous!" said Karthyrn Whitfill, president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, the umbrella group for seven million parents who belong to P.T.A. groups. "We would be very wary to jump on this bandwagon." The parents' group doesn't just stop at worrying about a national framework for what students should know at each grade level; it opposes the notion of national standards and assessments altogether. "Some school districts might adopt the standards and their students would reach to meet them, while others would not be able to," said Mrs. Whitfill, a parent in Pasadena, Tex. "We are so wary of national standards and assessments. There are more questions than answers now."
 Other critics say the introduction of national standards and assessments would lead to a national curricilum that would underscore yet again the disparities between affluent schools and poor ones. Educators point to the math standards as an example. Those and a companion set of standards for teachers require the expensive retraining of teachers and the wider use of computers and calculators, whose prices, despite recent declines, represent a hefty investment even for well-financed school systems. Critics envision a scenario in which wealthier schools would muster the resources to buy the necessary equipment, leaving behind children in poor schools.
For different reasons, some states are fretting about the so-called "nationalization" of education. In California, which has pioneered in writing standards and assessments for students, some members of the Association of California School Administrators worry that the national effort may undermine the five-year effort by the state's education department to overhaul California public education. What if, asks Davis Campbell, executive director of the state administrators' group, the national standards and assessments do not square with those either already in place or soon to be introduced in California?
"If they are different from what we've done in our state," he said, "we are going to be a little more reluctant to talk about it."
Although Mr. Campbell said the association supported the notion of standards and assessments, "we do get nervous when we talk about it at a national level. You get so far away from children and the classroom. When you go to the national level, that's about as far as you can get from the classroom."
There is evidence to support both sides of the debate, but there is more evidence in America and abroad (with the notable exception of Britain, where teachers are angry over a new national curriculum; page 17) that national standards and assessments need not strip local school systems of control or introduce all the other problems outlined by critics.
In a handful of states like California, Kentucky, South Carolina and Vermont, legislators and educators have designed and introduced new standards and assessments in recent years that have not handcuffed teachers or students to rigid statewide curriculums.
The California experience, for example, is a microcosm of the national debate. In 1983 the state introduced academic standards for all its students, and in the last school year introduced the first component of a new assessment program called the California Learning Assessment Program.
But when state education officials proposed an overhaul of the student testing system, they ran into vociferous opposition from teachers, administrators and parents. The fears in California mirrored those now debated across the country: that new assessments, coupled with the existing state standards, will stifle teacher innovation in the classroom because teachers will feel compelled to teach to the new assessments so that they, their students and their school system do not look bad compared with other state school districts.
State officials, however, successfully defused the concern through a widespread public relations campaign, conducting meetings both for teachers and the public on what the new assessments would mean and how they would be better than the standardized exams.
Dale Carlson, director of California's new assessment program, said that once the state held its meetings, "the criticism from the experts and the professional community of teachers dissipated quite quickly."
In the 1992-93 school year, California introduced the first component of the new assessments, testing students in all grade levels on reading, writing and math. Early reviews have been positive. Educators say the new tests do a much better job of gauging student progress on state standards. The fears are virtually gone, too, that the tests will lead to creation of a statewide curriculum of stultifying sameness.
"We're actually very enthusiastic about the move away from assessments that have driven curriculum instruction for years," said Stephen Peck, assistant superintendent of the Los Gatos Union Elementary School District, near San Jose.
Although he is aware of the danger of teaching to the new standards and assessments, Mr. Peck asserts that "if the new assessments are models of good instruction, I'd much rather have a teacher teach to this new test than teach to multiple-choice tests," which formerly measured California students' progress.
Indeed, there is little evidence historically to suggest that national standards and assessments lead to a numbing sameness of curriculum. At the turn of the century, for example, there were growing concerns about the country's ability to keep up with competitors. The worries helped give birth to the Smith-Hughes Act of 1917, which called for a vocational education curriculum in the nation's public schools.
What the act did was give public schools a framework for a job and vocational training curriculum. What it did not do, experts said, was create a uniformity that squelched local school initiative.
Another so-called "nationalization" of public school curriculum occurred in 1958, with passage of the National Defense Education Act. The act proposed an invigoration of public school curriculum with an emphasis on math and science. Though work on the legislation had begun before the 1957 launching of the Sputnik space satellite by the Soviet Union, that event accelerated its completion.
What the National Defense Education Act did for local schools was give them an impetus to improve existing programs. And like the earlier vocational legislation, it stopped short of imposing "Big Brother" oversight by the Federal Government.
There is, education experts say, a strategic purpose to Federal intervention in public education. But that purpose is not to correct any cyclical lag in the national well-being. "If, indeed, the national interest is being threatened by the rise of new economic powers along the Pacific Rim or by yet another transformation in the nature of work or by a sagging economy," asked Herbert M. Kliebard, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, "is the answer to create a national curriculum specifically designed to shore up the weaknesses in American education?"
NOT LIKELY, Mr. Kliebard said. "When there is a real or perceived crisis, there's a tendency in the United States to focus on education. But I don't think that a national curriculum, national standards or anything like that will have any effect on our economic position in the world."
The debate is likely to go on for some time. But the end result undoubtedly will be some sort of national framework. And though there is the potential for the Federal Government to take a "Big Brother" approach in its role, the best guess seems to be that this will not occur. One reason is the role states have already begun playing in devising new standards and curriculums and testing methods. A second reason lies with the local school districts: They are likely to battle any real threat of Federal infringement. Finally, there seems to be no inclination in the Clinton Administration toward that kind of control.
But there does seem to be a consensus developing toward creating national guidelines, or a national curriculum and assessments, that will help public schools better prepare students for a changing and demanding world. And who could argue with that?

HEADLINE: Fishing Countries Split on Harvest

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 30

 BODY:
Rival fishing nations grimly acknowledged this week that their fleets have thinned out stocks of the world's edible marine fish to levels unimaginable only a few years ago, and that only coordinated conservation and management steps will restore them.
 But at the conclusion of three weeks of talks here, a core negotiating group of 70 governments remained far apart on the central problem: how to reconcile the time-honored freedom to harvest the sea with the biological consequences of overfishing. It is a notion that went largely unnoticed until catch rates worldwide began declining sharply about four years ago. 
There has been broad agreement in principle on the nature of conservation measures that need to be taken," said Satya N. Nandan, a diplomat from Fiji overseeing the talks, the first phase of a yearlong United Nations fisheries conference. "But because there are competing national interests, the issues are very delicate, and the process is difficult and naturally slow."
 The negotiations, one of a series of follow-up conferences on environmental problems mandated by the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, represent the first effort to regulate global fishing since the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea, which ended in 1982.
 
Three Nations Balk
 As the conference moved toward adjournment, the high stakes in the struggle for dwindling numbers of fish were reflected in an increasingly tense dispute between Russia and several other nations in the Sea of Okhotsk, a formerly rich fishing ground off Russia's east coast, where unregulated fishing appears to have brought stocks of pollock to the verge of collapse.
 On June 15, Russian officials halted pollock fishing within their 200-mile-wide territorial zone in the sea, and called on Japan, Poland, South Korea and China to join in a three-year moratorium in the Okhotsk "peanut hole," a 35-by-300-mile area formed by the converging boundaries of Russian waters.
 But Poland, South Korea and China refused, saying there was no convincing evidence that the stock was in peril, and announced this week that instead they would reduce their fishing activities in that area by 25 percent.
 Russian officials in New York responded that Moscow was prepared to take "all necessary measures" under international law to halt the fishing, which diplomats said could entail stopping or seizing foreign trawlers and assessing captains for damages.
 On Wednesday, the United States announced in a joint statement with Russia released at the United Nations that it would support steps to enforce the Okhotsk moratorium, which it said was in line with efforts by the two countries to save endangered pollock stocks in another area, the Bering Sea.
 "It's a very tense situation, and time is running out," a United States official said.
 
Threat Seen to Law of Sea
 Mr. Nandan said he was worried that an accumulation of similar disputes could threaten the Law of the Sea, which he said "contributes to the peaceful use of 70 percent of the earth's surface."
 The fisheries negotiations involve 60 "like-minded" coastal countries led by Canada, Iceland, Argentina, Chile, Peru and New Zealand, whose economies are bound up with fisheries within the 200-mile territorial limits, and 10 so-called distant-water countries like China, Russia, Japan and the United States whose fleets include more advanced, long-range vessels.
 A paper drawn up by Mr. Nandan as the basis for future talks focuses on proposed guidelines that would be used by regional groups worldwide to begin restoring endangered populations of two key categories of fish: "straddling stocks" like cod, pollock and orange roughy, which swim back and forth between territorial waters and the high seas, and highly migratory species like tuna and billfish.
 Representatives of more than 50 private groups attending the conference as observers expressed concern that while major issues and possible solutions had been clearly defined, there were no corresponding signs of the requisite political will.
 "There is little evidence that any common commitment exists to adopt legally binding obligations at the global level that will inform and guide regional, national and local action," said Malika Naqasima of the Fiji Women and Fisheries network, who addressed the conference on Friday on behalf of many of the groups.

HEADLINE: Market Research and Product Image

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHEN Reynald Swift, president of Longines-Wittnauer Watch Company in New Rochelle, needed a marketing strategy to create a new image for an old product, he got in touch with B.A.I., a market-research and consulting concern originally called Behavioral Analysis Inc., based in Tarrytown.
"I had worked with them before," Mr. Swift said. "When I was at Arm & Hammer, they helped us develop new products. "I like the thoughtful, creative approach they take, and that's what we needed. Our goal was to strengthen the Wittnauer name and to give it its own identity as a separate brand of watch, which was not as simple as it sounds because for over the last 100 years, Wittnauer has never had its own image; it has always been linked as a companion to the Longines lines." 
 When Mr. Swift was asked why he gave the Wittnauer assignment to a market-research company instead of an advertising agency, he replied: "Strategy. I knew a lot of thought and time had to be spent in developing marketing strategy, which was the vital keystone on which the entire project rested."
The marketing strategy that B.A.I. created for Wittnauer called for reviving the image of Albert Wittnauer, the founder, a Swiss-born watchmaker who emigrated to the United States and started the company in 1885.
 
Ideas Evaluated
 Now, more than 100 years later, Albert Wittnauer, working at his watchmaker's table with his eyeshade, is once again the company spokesman. His image appears in all the print, television and radio advertisements, stressing that the quality craftsmanship of yesteryear is still the hallmark of Wittnauer watches.
The idea was developed, said Kathleen Knight, president of B.A.I., after months of researching the watch industry, which included interviews with consumers, followed by meetings at which the data were examined from many perspectives in order to generate ideas leading to an evaluation of the most promising approaches.
"The objective of our focus groups is to find which new ideas have the greatest potential," Ms. Knight said. "For example, the members of one group included the creative director of an advertising agency, a 30-year-old woman and an older man, both consumers who buy watches, representatives from Longines and two of us from B.A.I. We feel that outside people bring a fresh perspective to the work of our project teams. Sessions are held at off-site locations, and, finally, after all the data are reviewed and evaluated, we come away with a clear assessment of the idea that has the greatest potential."
Mr. Swift said that using Albert Wittnauer as a character identified with the tradition and old-fashioned value of the watch company proved so successful in test markets that this fall the campaign will be extended to 25 percent of the nation.
 
Aided by Computerization
 The growth of B.A.I., Ms. Knight said, parallels the growth of market research as an industry.
"Twenty-five years ago, when Richard Reiser started our company in the basement of his Scarsdale home, market research was a relatively new concept," Ms. Knight said. "Results were laboriously tabulated by hand, but as the computer industry began to grow, so did the market-research industry. The computer made it possible."
Mr. Reiser, 63, has been in Europe meeting with clients, Ms. Knight said. "He studied anthropology and sociology before he became a part-time researcher in order to raise money for graduate school," she said. "He planned to get an advanced degree in sociology, but he was so fascinated by the market-research process he switched from sociology and eventually became the market research manager at Grey Advertising before he started B.A.I."
She added: "We specialize in financial-service companies. A typical assignment that we just finished was an international study held in six countries for our client, a major credit-card company, who wanted a study made of the use of direct mail as measuring how effective it was as a medium to get people to buy financial services products, such as insurance, through the mail using credit cards."
 
A Link to Politics
 What was especially interesting, she continued, "were the similarities we found in the buying habits of peer groups: young people in all six countries, which included Japan and Great Britain, tended to be more trusting in buying things sight unseen by mail."
"On the other hand," she said, "retired executives in Japan and Britain and the United States also had a lot in common in that all of them were reluctant to buy financial-services products through the mail from someone they did not know."
Ms. Knight, who is 51, said she got interested in market research by working on political campaigns.
"When I was in college, I did survey work for the campaign of Congressman Thomas B. Curtis, in St. Louis County, where I lived," she said. "I found the procedure so fascinating that after I graduated from college I took a job directing the work of focus teams for a market-research firm in St. Louis. In 1975, I joined B.A.I. as operations manager. By then the firm had outgrown its base, and our offices were in an apartment in White Plains."
Her first project for B.A.I., Ms. Knight said, was testing the effectiveness of baking soda in septic tanks.
"The client was Arm & Hammer, and the test was done in Memphis. The product not only proved to be extremely effective in septic tanks, but we also uncovered a host of other cleaning uses for it."
 
Two Views of the Recession
 By 1985, B.A.I. had 15 employees and moved into a Victorian mansion in Irvington. Ms. Knight became the president.
"At the end of that year our volume was $1.5 million," she said. "We knew we weren't growing as fast as we should be, but we didn't know why. So we did what we were advising our clients to do: we hired an outside management consultant, who was literally a shrink for the business. He advised us to be less hierarchal and to decentralize management. That, he said, would make us quicker to respond to opportunities and customer requirements. He also suggested we hire someone else, someone on the partner level, as research director. We hired someone we had worked with as a customer, and in five years we had doubled our revenues."
Last year, despite the recession, B.A.I. generated $7 million in sales.
In speaking about the recession's effect on the business, Ms. Knight said: "It's a two-edged sword. We do get a lot of repeat business because, I feel, in the highly competitive world of new-product development -- where the failure rate is 90 percent -- a near miss is a big loss, bigger still during a recession. But on the other hand, there are fewer new products being introduced, and during a recession it is harder to grow new clients."
And, she added, as companies merge and cut back, although there is new business to be had as in-house research departments vanish, there is also increased competition. "What's happening is that a cottage industry has sprung up as the market researchers who headed those in-house departments try to grow their own companies."

HEADLINE: Placing the Hudson Valley in Perspective

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

 BODY:
THE Hudson River Valley has long been known locally for the richness of its cultural past. But interest in the historical significance of the area is no longer confined to the region. This summer 25 college and university professors from throughout the country gathered at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie to study the national importance of an area that has produced great writers and painters and ultimately produced one of the first visions of a national culture for a fledgling America.
"The Hudson River Valley is the nation's first self-consciously esthetic zone -- the first literal stretch of landscape that was elevated into a symbol of national identity and aspiration," said Dr. H. Daniel Peck, a professor of English at Vassar College. Dr. Peck was the director of a summer institute, called Hudson River Valley Images and Texts, which studied the region. 
 The institute, convened for the first time this year, was sponsored by the American Culture Program at Vassar College and supported by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. The program ran from mid-June to mid-July and drew professors from universities as far away as California, Nevada and Wyoming.
The participants focused on the region in the 19th century, examining the art and literature that emerged side by side during that period. From that they drew a picture of a particularly American sensibility, one based on the valley but symbolic of the emerging country as a whole. For instance, they studied the work of the artist Thomas Cole, one of America's first great landscape painters, and compared his images of the Hudson River Valley with those described in Washington Irving's famous story "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow."
 
New American Vision
 "When Rip van Winkle goes into the woods for his 20-year sleep, Irving describes the wood in great detail," Dr. Peck said. "In a painting by Thomas Cole, you can see some very clear analogies in terms of what the landscape means, the moral and esthetic meanings for that generation of a forest or glen or a meadow."
Comparing the two genres side by side, Dr. Peck said, one could see not only how the European perspective informed the works but also how the new American vision breaks away and begins to define itself independently.
Those participating in the summer institute were given access to Vassar's Elias Lyman Magoon collection of Hudson River School paintings, which can be seen by the public when the college opens its new Art Center in November.
The Hudson River School is considered the first American native school of landscape painting, and the Vassar collection includes the work of such notable artists as Cole, Frederic E. Church, Asher B. Durand and Sanford Gifford.
The Hudson River Valley that these artists and writers depicted was a hub of economic activity in the 19th century, Dr. Peck said. When the Erie Canal was completed in 1824, the Hudson River became an important gateway to the Great Lakes and was central to the development of American commerce.
 
Field Trips Offered
 Not only did the area reflect America's economic modernization but also its cultural diversity. Several ethnic groups met in the Hudson Valley: the Dutch who had been in the area since the 17th century, the Yankee population from New England, Connecticut and Massachusetts and the indigenous American Indians. Further, slavery still existed in New York at the beginning of the century, and by the 1820's there was a free black population.
"You have a region that demonstrates some of the cultural richness of the new United States," said Dr. Scott Casper, a historian from the University of Nevada at Reno.
As part of the summer program, the professors took several field trips to put their studies of the region into a visual as well as historical context. They visited Olana, Church's home near Hudson in Columbia County, and Sunnyside, Washington Irving's home in Irvington. The participants also took a riverboat trip on the Hudson and visited Kaaterskill Falls, a once popular tourist destination near Haines Falls in Greene County. Their study of 19th-century artists also took them to the Albany Institute of History and Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New-York Historical Society, both in Manhattan.
 
Weekly Themes
 Several participants said that spending time on the river and in the area had enhanced their appreciation and understanding of the works they were studying.
"I had never thought much about the geography of the region," said Dr. Casper, the historian from the University of Nevada. "By looking at the river itself, by looking at the ways people shaped the land, I got a much better sense of this very real region and the paintings and writings that deal with it. If you don't actually see and experience the region, you think about the writings very differently."
The institute had a different theme each week. The first week, the professors studied the Dutch and English Colonial periods before the Revolutionary War. The focus was on material culture, examining furnishings and portrait paintings of early Dutch landholders. The second week covered the emergence of American literature and American landscape art in the 1820's.
Next, professors explored the cultural meanings of tourism in the early 19th century. This was a period of growing urbanization in America and a time when people who had the money to get out of the cities did so, Dr. Peck said. The Catskills were one of the first tourist destinations and were representative of emerging modern life. An entire session was spent talking about the Catskill Mountain House, a famous resort at that time near the Kaaterskill Falls. The building has since burned down, but the professors visited the site of the resort.
In the final week, they studied the literature of James Fenimore Cooper and the paintings of Cole. In the work of both are warnings about America's emerging imperialism and moral emptiness, Dr. Peck said.
"We really did prove to ourselves through the course of our study that the Hudson River Valley provided a paradigm for a national culture," Dr. Peck said. "That was immensely gratifying on the intellectual side. On the human side of it, there was a real richness in the kind of bonding that took place among the scholarly community. It was an extraordinary experience that left everyone feeling rewarded."

HEADLINE: Japan's Moment, and Ours

BYLINE: By James Fallows; James Fallows, Washington editor of The Atlantic Monthly, is author of a forthcoming book about Asia, "Looking at the Sun."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
By the time an ill George Bush collapsed into Kiichi Miyazawa's lap in Tokyo 18 months ago, it was easy to imagine that Mr. Bush and his Republican Government might be out of power soon. It was hard for anyone to foresee that Mr. Miyazawa's Liberal Democratic Party would be headed the same way. Yet two months of political turmoil have apparently insured that the insurgent Morihiro Hosokawa will become Japan's first non-L.D.P. prime minister since 1955.
Where the turmoil will finally lead turns on whether Japan can do anything about the fundamental oddity of its postwar regime: the combination of a very strong Government and very weak political control. 
 The Japanese Government famously intervenes at countless levels of society, applying formal and informal controls to everything from bank-lending policy to the number of non-Japanese teachers allowed in universities and schools. Yet there is virtually no feedback loop allowing the public to register its views about the Government's behavior.
Prime ministers come and go with no detectable impact on the country's policies. The consequential decisions are made and carried out by well-trained and often nationalist bureaucrats in the major ministries -- Finance, Education, Construction, Transportation, International Trade.
At a gross level, this system has clearly won popular assent. One inch below the surface of public grumbling about tiny houses, inflated prices and corrupt politics is widespread recognition that Japan's strategy has worked. It has made the country powerful, and although living standards are modest they keep going up.
But many groups feel that they have been shortchanged for the sake of national growth. These include urban consumers, women in general and students forced into a conformist mold. Japan's brand of political gridlock has kept the standard of living artificially low, generating chronic trade and savings surpluses. America's kind of gridlock has of course done the reverse.
A transformation of Japanese politics that created a feedback loop, giving the public more say about the country's priorities, might not solve all economic conflicts or turn Japan into a Western-style democracy. But a more democratic Japan would certainly be easier for the rest of the world to deal with. How can we tell whether it's on the way? Here are three rules of thumb while following the news from Japan:
1. Smile when you say "reformer." The American press has largely portrayed many anti-L.D.P. politicians as "reformers" or "young Turks." This may be a plausible description of Mr. Hosokawa himself, who started the challenge to the Liberal Democrats last year. But most members of his coalition could more realistically be called "disgruntled party hacks."
One of the most prominent, Tsutomu Hata, now declares himself shocked, just shocked to find that an "iron triangle" of bureaucrats, industries and corrupt politicians runs Japan. During his long years with the L.D.P., Mr. Hata pooh-poohed the idea that the economy was controlled in any way. In the late 1980's, he memorably opposed letting foreign beef into Japan because, he claimed, the average Japanese citizen's "unique" intestinal tract could not handle it. Ichiro Ozawa, another leading "rebel," is a veteran L.D.P. power broker who recently jumped ship.
Some of Japan's new politicians have pushed real reform plans. For example, Yoshio Terasawa of Mr. Hosokawa's New Party has proposed removing Finance Ministry regulations that now make the Tokyo Stock Exchange a rigged market.
Japanese history is full of people who radically changed their roles with changing times; think of Emperor Hirohito's emergence as a meek biologist after World War II. By acting as if this really were a coalition of reformers, the outside world might make reform more likely. But let's not fool ourselves about who these people are.
2. Don't hold your breath. American commentators often wonder how Japan can be called a success when most Japanese live so poorly. The answer is that its industries have succeeded largely because of the constraints on consumers.
For decades, the nation's resources have been channeled away from individuals and toward industrial investment, which in turn produces more output than Japan's strapped consumers can buy. This structurally depressed demand is the single biggest reason for Japan's huge and chronic trade surplus. A Japan with real political competition would have a harder time imposing these limits on its people -- which is why any step away from the L.D.P. monopoly is ultimately good news.
But it may not be good news any time soon. The big loser in this month's election was the anti-business Japan Socialist Party, not the L.D.P. Conservatives in a broad, pro-business sense control more of the Diet than before. The seven anti-L.D.P. parties that have formed a coalition to select a prime minister agree on very little. Their new Government's main goal will be to enact changes in the gerrymandered electoral system and then call new elections, in hopes of making real inroads against the Liberal Democrats.
It could be many years before a strong elected leadership can get the upper hand on the bureaucrats. The trick for the outside world is to keep two time scales in mind at once. In the long run, it can allow itself to hope for a less lopsided, less export-driven structure in Japan. But in the short run, it should gird for even fiercer competition from Japanese industries, since, Mr. Hosokawa aside, there is no sign yet of a shift in national emphasis.
Americans should also recall how often they have overestimated the chance of deep political change in Japan. A U.S. magazine published a special issue on how affluence, youth culture, the women's movement and international awareness were transforming Japan. The magazine was Life, and the issue was published in 1964.
3. Face the terror of the empty page. For 40 years, U.S. policy toward Japan has often been frustrating and complicated -- but it has been conceptually easy, since the central point was so clear. The main goal was to keep Japan from "going Communist" or siding with the Soviets, and the first step toward doing so was to prop up the Liberal Democratic Party.
The party, for all its foibles, was committed to a military relationship with the U.S., while its main opponent, the Socialists, threatened to kick American soldiers out. As recently as last year, officials describing President Bush's trip to Tokyo said that one purpose was to show support for the L.D.P.
Now the U.S. enjoys a luxury it has not had in half a century: near-total freedom to rethink relations with Japan. There is no possibility that Japan will go Communist, and no Soviet bloc for it to join. The fledgling emergence of mainstream alternatives to the L.D.P. reduces the air of fragility in U.S.-Japan relations -- the fear that if anything changed, Japan would have to choose between the leftists and a new militarist regime.
In theory, the Clinton Administration could use this moment, while Japan is otherwise engaged, to re-think ways of maximizing American interests in Asia. Most countries in the region would prefer that the U.S. maintain its military presence. Surely America can use this and other forms of leverage for better-balanced economic relations, starting with Japan. Conceiving a policy from scratch is more troublesome than continuing on autopilot. But it is far more valuable in the long run, and there will never be a better chance.

HEADLINE: Two Conflicts Between Historic Preservation and Develpment

BYLINE: by LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
THE debate over the preservation of historic buildings and the contemporary pressure to develop is heating up at two sites on Long Island.
In the Village of Huntington, a farmhouse dating from 1830 has become a source of dispute between Huntington Hospital and residents. The hospital, which owns the vacant house, is seeking approval from the Town Board to move it so that a parking lot can be built on the site. But residents oppose the move, saying they want to save the town's historic character. 
 In the Village of Amityville a vacated Gothic house built before the Civil War is also in jeopardy. The house is in disrepair, and its new owners, who want to develop the site, question whether it can be saved.
The Huntington farmhouse, known as the Adams House, after the family that lived there for many years, is on the National and State Registers of Historic Places and has been designated a national and local landmark. Because of that, Town Board approval is required to move, alter or demolish it.
In contrast, the Baldwin-Hilbert House in Amityville, named for the two families who occupied it from 1840 to recently, has no state or Federal restrictions. The historian of the Town of Oyster Bay, Dorothy Horton McGee, said that an application for landmark status was made in 1977, but that the process was never completed.
"We're not sure what happened," she said, "but the landmark designation was never made."
 
5 Partners Buy House
 The house, a sprawling white structure on Merrick Road in West Amityville, was bought by five partners last year under the name of the Tollgate Land Improvement Company. The name comes from the original tollgate house that once stood on the site.
The lawyer for the Hilbert family estate, Richard Handler, said the house dated from 1830 or 1840 and was owned and inhabited by the Baldwin family until 1930, when it was sold to Kenneth Hilbert, a veterinarian.
Mr. Handler, a former president of the Amityville Historical Society, said the property was especially significant historically because it stood on the dividing line between New York City and Suffolk before Nassau became a separate county
South Turnpike, now known as Merrick Road, was built in the colonial era, and maps from 1820 show the tollhouse was on the site, Mr. Handler said. One wall of the tollhouse was kept as part of the house.
When Nassau became a county in 1899, the property became the border between the two counties. Although the house is in Nassau and under the jurisdiction of the Town of Oyster Bay, it is served by an Amityville post office and is in the Amityville school district, which is in Suffolk.
The house, Mr. Handler said, "is one of the last best examples of Gothic architecture that was modernized in the 1880's to give it a Victorian flavor."
"But it was a sad story of an elderly couple with a beautiful old home and too many problems keeping it," he added. "The property outlived its usefulness, and the Hilberts became victims of a tax system gone wild, with all their finances going to pay the taxes and the property falling into disrepair."
If restored, Mr. Handler said, the house "would be a magnificent example of a Gothic Revival Victorian structure. But it may not be economically feasible, and the new owners may be forced to demolish the house."
One partner, Jerry O'Neill, said the new owners were studying how to use the two-and-a half-acre site, which includes commercial and residential zoning. "We would like to keep the house as part of any project," Mr. O'Neill said, "but won't know if it's feasible until we investigate further."
One option is a condominium project for the elderly, in which the house might be restored as an administration or recreation building, Mr. O'Neill said, adding that the proposal would require a zoning amendment by the Oyster Bay Town Board allowing higher-density housing.
Another partner is Mr. Hilbert's son Stuart, who grew up in the house and who owns a garden center next to it. He said many of his customers had declared that they would chain themselves to the building if anyone tried to demolish it.
Mr. Handler said people in Amityville had a great historic consciousness and wanted to maintain the historic flavor of the town. "The owners of the property are sensitive to the needs of the residents," he said. "But they are also business people and must face economic realities."
The saltbox farmhouse in Huntington Village, on Park Avenue adjacent to the front lawn of the hospital, is also significant as an example of late-19th-century settlement architecture, said the town historian, Rufus Langhans. Its features include clapboard sheathing, frieze windows, a central chimney and small-pane windows. The house is one of two in the village that exhibits unusual four-bay plans, Mr. Langhans said.
When the last owner died, three years ago, the Hospital bought the house from the estate, with the idea of demolishing it and building a parking lot. But its landmark status prevented demolition, Mr. Langhans said, and the hospital recently applied to the Town Board to move it to a site half a mile away in the historic district.
A spokeswoman for the hospital, Helen Dudkewic, said by moving the house the hospital could add 72 badly needed parking spots. The hospital now has 717 parking spaces.
"We are a community-based hospital and are sensitive to the concerns of the residents," Ms. Dudkewic said. "We think this plan offers a solution that allows us to preserve the house and to meet a need of the hospital."
Mr. Langhans said the fate of the Adams House had become an emotional issue for many residents. "We are interested in protecting the historic flavor of this town," he said. "When we look at the historic value of the house, the site is as important as the house itself."
He said there was also concern that part of the house would be destroyed in a move, adding: "There are clearly other options for the hospital, including a multilevel parking lot or using an existing lot several blocks away and providing shuttle service. We don't want to have our historic district taken over by pavement."
The chairman of the Huntington Historical Preservation Commission, Raymond S. O'Riordan, said the house preceded the hospital by 87 years and should not pose any threat to the existence and viability of the hospital.
"Being sworn to uphold Huntington's laws concerning how to best conserve, protect and perpetuate our town's wonderful historic heritage," he said, "the Historic Commission had no choice but to officially oppose this danger-ridden plan to relocate the Adams House."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gothic house, above, built before Civil War in Amityville, and a farmhouse built in 1830 in the Village of Huntington. (Photographs by Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By Bill Sharp

 BODY:

ENVIRONMENTALISM
SHOWDOWN AT OPAL CREEK
The Battle for
America's Last Wilderness.
By David Seideman.
Carroll & Graf, $22.95. 
 A lifelong Oregon logger, Tom Hirons, puts the quandary of preserving ancient forest simply: "The question is, can man extract what he needs without ruining it?" Mr. Hirons has spent many of his recent years opposing preservation, fighting an environmental group led by his longtime close friend George Atiyeh. In "Showdown at Opal Creek," David Seideman, a reporter for Time magazine, brings the divergent pressures of economic and environmental issues down to a personal level through the lives of these two passionate people, driven apart by the old-growth controversy. Do we preserve the last stands of massive old-growth forests, home to species like the spotted owl, or do we cut them down, losing an ecosystem but keeping loggers employed at least a little while longer? Mr. Seideman provides abundant information about the forestry industry and the Government that regulates it. He tells anecdotes galore about the people around Opal Creek, Ore. Where the author slips is in leaning occasionally toward his own passion for preservation. The strength of this work is not trumpeting the "right" cause, but portraying the pain felt by people torn between worthy causes.

HEADLINE: President Stands By Investing in America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Administration strongly agrees with your July 26 editorial that the President's proposed investments in our people, businesses and communities are, like his deficit reduction plan, essential to long-term economic and job growth. 
 We also agree that these investments are critical to make his program fundamentally different from President Bush's 1990 budget agreement. There are other important contrasts -- most notably, the economic and spending forecasts we have used, as well as the specific spending cuts the President has proposed.
As to the investments contained in the budget reconciliation bill nearing final approval in Congress:
* The House-passed bill retained the key investments in the President's plan -- the earned income tax credit, empowerment zones, hunger-relief measures, immunization, family preservation and incentives for business investment.
* The Senate-passed bill contains some of these investments.
* While the result will be a compromise, the President has insisted on keeping a good portion of the investments in the conference agreement.
The greater part of the President's proposed investments are contained in his five-year plan for discretionary spending. These are in areas like education, infrastructure, nutrition, environment, housing, defense conversion and law enforcement. They are paid for by savings in low-priority or wasteful discretionary spending.
In the appropriations process for fiscal year 1994 very tight budget caps at first left practically no room for our investments. Yet Congress, working with the Administration, is making enough spending cuts beyond those originally proposed by the President to provide room for close to 60 percent of those investments.
The outlook for 1995-98, is even better -- despite the freeze Congress has imposed on all discretionary spending. If Congress adopts only our proposed spending cuts for those years, there will be room, on average, for nearly two-thirds of the President's investments. With further cuts there will be room for even more of the investments.
Republicans are opposing every one of these investments to protect the wealthy from paying even $1 in higher taxes to contribute to deficit reduction. They prefer the status quo to any serious effort to confront our social and economic problems.
But the President is specifying areas of public and private investment to reverse economic decline and restart growth. He is also focusing Congress on making choices between old spending and new priorities, so that we increase investment without mindlessly increasing the size of government.
 
LEON E. PANETTA
Director
Office of Management and Budget
Washington, July 28, 1993

HEADLINE: Still Solid, G.O.P. Opposition To Clinton May Soon Soften

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Toward the end of this week, all 219 Republican members of Congress will line up against President Clinton's budget bill. It may be the last time they are this united in the 103d Congress.
A posture of relentless opposition has served the Republicans well when it is focused on big issues, like the budget plan's tax increases, or even the economic stimulus bill. Buttressed by sincere economic beliefs, it reassures their natural supporters and scores political points with swing voters. 
 "To the degree that people think we are opposing bad ideas out of principle, I think it helps us a lot," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the deputy leader of the 175 House Republicans. He said support for Republicans on the tax issue had turned up sharply.
"We're finally talking about an issue that is a defining issue for the Republican Party," said one of the most partisan of the 44 Senate Republicans, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, "and that is tax and spend."
 
'Guardians of Gridlock'?
 But unanimous House votes on many bills and frequent Senate filibusters bother some party moderates, and even some conservatives who fear that they have not made their case well. Opposition to the national service bill based on its "fine print" failed to justify itself, said Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, who helped kill the party's filibuster against the measure.
Not everyone agrees. When Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, calls Republicans "guardians of gridlock," Mr. Gramm replies that the Democrats think that "gridlock is the lock on the smokehouse door" and that they want to get at the pork hanging there. And Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, the third-ranking House Republican, said, "Long term, I think people will realize gridlock might have saved them from what looks like an impending economic disaster."
But even Mr. Gingrich said that his party had not done well enough in explaining its frequent opposition. "If people believe it is being done for petty reasons, then it's bad," he said. "They want Washington to work."
And Senator William S. Cohen of Maine, who joined Mr. Hatfield in ending last week's delaying action on the national service bill, said, "I think the filibuster ought to be used selectively, on the very biggest-ticket items."
Concern over appearing obstructionist, which was manifested day after day last week when Republican senators stared up at the press gallery and demanded that reporters not call their filibuster a filibuster, is only one reason why the seemingly unremitting Republican rejection of Clinton Administration proposals is likely to end.
Perhaps the most important other reason is a shifting legislative agenda. If the North American Free Trade Agreement comes before Congress in the fall, Mr. Clinton can expect "his strongest support is going to come from Republicans, not only because we believe in it, but because we are willing to support the Administration when it is right," said a Senate moderate, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island.
Mr. Gingrich cited the President's proposal to toughen procedures for aliens trying to gain political asylum. He said that he and the party's Senate leaders, Bob Dole of Kansas and Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, had agreed "to do everything we can to pass his new immigration legislation."
Another reason Republicans will be tempted to abandon purity of ideology, and even political advantage, is the prospect of helping to shape national policy. Representative Jim Leach of Iowa insisted that a basically conservative party like his had no "choice but to be unified against tax increases of the magnitude that Clinton has proposed."
But, he said, if Republicans are not part of the action, "then all negotiations take place between the far left and the moderate left," and the result is worse for the country than if Republicans took part.
Universally, Republicans say it was Mr. Clinton's decision to exclude them, not their decision to stay away.
Representative Sherwood Boehlert from the Finger Lakes region in New York, one of three Republicans who voted for the economic stimulus bill, said, "If Republicans had been brought into the process early, no question that the majority would have opted out, but a lot of Republicans might have looked with favor on a package that was developed in consultation with them."
Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri said that if unified Senate Republicans and a few Democrats defeated the reconciliation bill this week, then "we have to sit down in good faith with members of the Administration and try to work out something in good faith."
 
Wary of a Trap
 Some Senate Republicans reject that idea as a trap that would beguile them into supporting tax increases. But Mr. Leach said Republicans were involved then a capital gains tax cut "would be on the table." And Mr. Chafee said, "The final solution will have to have some taxes." He added, "If you're going to go through the mine field, it's better to go through together."
Some Republicans spurn collaboration, and argue that opposition on major issues is sufficient, so long as Republicans "have an intellectually responsible alternative," as Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio put it.
Mr. Kasich, who offered an alternative budget in the House last spring, foresees a similar response on health. Other Republicans, like Mr. Cohen and Mr. Chafee, would prefer to work with the Clinton Administration, depending, of course, on what it proposes.
Republicans say they have opposed Mr. Clinton out of principle, not to score points. Mr. Danforth said, "This is not a plot, with Republicans sitting around trying to do in the President."
An NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll released last week showed that 64 percent of the public said Republicans opposed the President's economic plan not because they had an alternative but "for political reasons."
The survey of 1,006 adults, taken by Peter Hart and Bob Teeter last week, showed that 48 percent of the public said Mr. Clinton was more serious about reducing the deficit than were the Republicans, while 34 percent said the Republicans were more serious. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Boren Changes His Mind
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, the conservative Democrat whose mercurial support has given President Clinton's budget package its one-vote edge in the Senate, changed his mind today and declared himself unshakeably against the measure.
"If we're going to ask the taxpayers to pay $250 billion more in taxes, we need to be able to look them in the eye and honestly say we've cut all the spending we can," Mr. Boren said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "I don't think we have."
Vice President Al Gore, appearing with Mr. Boren, said, "We haven't counted on Senator Boren for quite some time."

HEADLINE: EUROPE'S CURRENCY CRISIS;
Tokyo Hectic In Response To Europe

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, August 2

 BODY:
A desultory morning of currency trading exploded here early today after European governments mounted another attempt to rescue the European Monetary System, with the German mark soaring in value amid extremely nervous speculation.
Foreign exchange traders used to quiet Monday mornings here said that initially the market had been slow and edgy as the monetary officials met in Brussels in an effort to calm the latest currency crisis. But shortly after news services flashed word that several European currencies would be permitted to fluctuate in a wider band of values, furious bidding began. 
 The chief beneficiary of the activity was the German mark, which had risen sharply most of last week. The dollar fell to a low of 1.7240 marks at mid-morning here, down from 1.742 marks in New York late Friday. In late afternoon trading, the the dollar rebounded to 1.7310 marks.
 
 
Mark Rises Against Franc
 Against the French franc, the focus of most trading last week, the mark rose to 3.4850 francs early today here, compared with 3.4292 francs in late trading on Friday.
The dollar slipped slightly against the yen in late trading here, dropping to 104.55 yen from 104.65 yen in New York late Friday.
"Everything broke loose as soon as the news flashed from Europe," said Laurent Depus of Chase Manhattan Bank in Tokyo. "It was very hectic. But it was short-term flows, not customers taking big positions."
Mr. Depus and several other traders added that, at least initially, there were no indications of central bank intervention in the market.
But by late morning the Bank of Japan was said to be intervening to buy dollars in an attempt to brake the yen's steep rise. The yen now trading at its highest levels of the postwar era and, some economists warn, could slow Japan's economic recovery.
 "Frankly, most traders are a bit confused about the real implications of the new move," said Kazutera Tanaka, head of currency trading at the Bank of Tokyo. "A lot of speculators are watching. It's very nervous and turnover is not huge."
Japanese stocks moved lower today. With an hour left in session trading, the the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 79.91 points, or nearly four-tenths of a percent, at 20,300.23.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Europe's Currency Crisis
European Community officials agreed to let their currencies fluctuate by as much as 15 percent -- a far wider margin than was allowed for the last 14 years -- in an effort to save the remnants of the European Monetary System. Finance ministers and central bankers said the measure was temporary and would not nullify plans to achieve a common European currency. [Page A1.]
Japanese currency trading exploded into frenzied activity after word of the new plan to save the European Monetary System. The German mark soared in value in trading. [D8.] 
 The European move is a severe political blow to France, but many experts think that is just what the nation's faltering economy needs.[D8.]
Influential financier George Soros denied that he took part in last week's selloff of the French franc but declined to describe his current role in the currency market. [D1.]
Individual investors should not try to profit from the crisis in Europe, professionals advise. [D8.]
 
The Economy
A hot August and an early frost may cause more damage to Midwest farmers than recent flooding. [A1.]
Some Republicans in Congress are concerned about their growing reputation as "guardians of gridlock."[A1.]
General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are walking a tightrope as they report big profits and negotiate new union contracts. [D1.]
Many malls are rushing to join the movement to ban smoking in public places. [A1.]
 
Companies
The chairman and most of the board members of Louisiana Blue Cross and Blue Shield have been forced to resign by the state's Insurance Commission. [A1.]
Bethlehem Steel promised steelworkers a seat on its board and better pensions to avoid a strike. The accord also entitles the union to take control of assets if the company defaults on its promises. [D1.]
Microsoft has hired a small team of supercomputer engineers to help create a class of computing devices that will control future digital television sets and other consumer appliances. [D1.]
I.B.M. and Dell are moving to carve out distinctive niches in the market for personal computers. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
The ever-expanding film and television industry is proving a bright spot in an otherwise gloomy California economy. [D1.]
Spanish-language broadcasters have begun a lobbying effort that, if successful, could unleash millions of dollars of financing to radio station owners. [D6.]
The Bobbsey Twins may finally make it to television and film through an agreement between Paramount Publishing and New York Production Partners. [D6.]
Barry Diller would face big hurdles in building a new network. Bill Carter: Television. [D6.]
General Mills promotes a cereal "made to eat with your fingers." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

Europe's problems may be good news for some international bond traders. Jonathan Fuerbringer: Credit Markets. [D5.]
Golfers invent more devices than the players of any other sport. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]
Zebra Technologies finds a "perplexing" downside in its prosperity. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: EUROPE'S CURRENCY CRISIS;
Financier Denies Role In the Currency Crisis

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
While European ministers struggled in Brussels to save the European Monetary System, George Soros lounged by the pool at his Southampton, L.I., home yesterday, portraying himself as an elder statesman among foreign exchange traders and not a speculator out to make another huge profit from a currency crisis.
"Exactly because I don't want to drive the markets crazy, I am not going to say what I am doing," Mr. Soros said in a telephone interview. 
 For years he has been a hugely successful money manager and investor, but the $1 billion that he reportedly made in just a few days in September by betting against the British pound has turned him into a guru -- and his investments are mimicked across the world.
Mr. Soros insisted that whatever he had been doing -- if anything -- during the latest crisis for the European Monetary System, he did not start doing it until last Friday at noon, New York time. So he had not made any money speculating that the French franc, the victim currency this time, would continue to fall in value. Since Friday noon, he noted, the value of the franc has hardly moved up or down against other currencies.
"I am a great believer in Europe and in having the system, and participants ought to care about preserving the system and not just making a profit for themselves," said Mr. Soros, who grew up in Hungary.
 
Planning to Stay on L.I.
 The 62-year-old financier had told Le Figaro, the French daily, early last week that he had refrained from speculating against the franc because he did not want to destroy the European Monetary System. And with currency traders driving down the value of the franc on Thursday, Mr. Soros went that evening to his Long Island home. He plans to remain there into this week, trying, he said, to be an elder statesman rather than a trader.
"There has to be a modification of the European Monetary System," Mr. Soros said, referring to the system that ties the value of nine European currencies to one another, with the German mark as the dominant one. "Either there has to be a floating of the currencies or a readjustment of the exchange rates or a broadening of the band" in which each currency can rise or fall.
After hours of deliberation, European finance ministers and central bankers, meeting in Brussels, announced last night that they had agreed to broaden the band. Mr. Soros said he was not impressed.
"The wider band will help the French to lower interest rates, but if they don't lower interest rates now, they will have the worst of all possible worlds, which means currency instability and continued recession," Mr. Soros said.
The British, in fact, lowered rates and devalued the pound last September, after currency traders began to sell pounds in huge amounts, betting that the British currency could not keep pace with the mark, mainly because the Germans resisted lowering interest rates to make their own currency less attractive vis-a-vis the pound. Speculating with huge sums in that selloff, Mr. Soros came away a huge winner.
 
Further Abstention Unneeded
 Until noon last Friday, Mr. Soros and the operations he directs, the Soros Fund Management and the Quantum Fund, had carefully refrained from trying to duplicate the feat. But in a statement issued then in New York, he said that further abstention would be futile because the European Monetary System had been broken by the German failure to concern itself with the needs of its European partners.
Did that answer mean that Mr. Soros had traded since Friday noon or had not? "No comment," he said yesterday.
Did he think that being so influential a trader, he should withdraw from currency markets during crises that threatened the European Community?
"It is my business to trade, it is my role, it is my professional activity," Mr. Soros replied. "I could not carry on managing a fund if I did not take positions in stocks, bonds and currencies. So I took a position in Newmont mines and look what happened."
The Newmont episode, coming in April -- seven months after his success with the British pound -- made Mr. Soros very acquainted with his new influence. He bought a stake in Newmont Mining, mainly a gold-mining company, and that produced a rally in the price of gold and gold-mining stocks. Also in April he became involved in a British real estate venture, and that set off a rally in British real estate stocks.
Then in June, a Soros letter in The Times of London said the German mark was bound to fall, and it did just that for a while.
Although the Europeans came up with a different solution last night, Mr. Soros said he would prefer for the mark to float, thus helping the Germans through their own economic difficulties as they try to unify the economy of the former East Germany with that of the West.
"I think it is the German mark that should float and not the other currencies," Mr. Soros said, adding that if the mark floated it would probably go up and then come down, "very much as the dollar did during the Reagan Administration."

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
Entrepreneurs Pave Path For the Next Generation

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
A thriving population of black entrepreneurs prospering in business has been a dream since the days of Booker T. Washington. These hopes, however, have been a dream deferred.
But for some successful entrepreneurs, the dream remains alive, and a few have taken it upon themselves to guide the young. 
 "The next generation should be the generation of entrepreneurs," said Frank Savage, one of the success stories. Mr. Savage is chairman of the Equitable Capital Management Corporation and former head of Freedom National Bank, a black-owned institution that was closed by regulators in 1990.
He said black businessmen are urgently needed as role models. One who fits that mold is Michael Vann, a part owner of the Shark Bar at 307 Amsterdam Avenue. The establishment combines excellent recorded music, soul food and a laid-back appearance, and has attracted celebrities like Denzel Washington, Naomi Campbell and Michael Jordan.
 
The Entrepreneur's Path

Normally, it is not a breakfast spot. But the other morning, more than a dozen teen-age guests devoured heaping plates of pancakes. These youths had all been convicted of serious crimes, but because of their age they had been placed on probation rather than sent to prison.
Trying to offer a different path, Mr. Vann preached the promise of entrepreneurship, saying it had worked for him. "I could never be satisfied until I became my own boss," he said.
The son of a steelworker and a legal secretary in Gary, Ind., Mr. Vann, 35, began several steps ahead of most of those in his audience, and was able to build a successful career in fashion and restaurants. Celebrity contacts he had built as a maitre d'hotel at B. Smith's Restaurant in midtown Manhattan helped persuade the two initial owners of the Shark Bar to bring him in as a partner.
To some in the audience, it all sounded like life on another planet. "You're making it sound like it was easy," said one teen-ager. "But black people don't have no opportunities. We live in projects and ghettos."
Mr. Vann repeatedly said he planned to put his money where his mouth was. He told one probationer, an artist, that he might pay him to design a T-shirt logo for Soul to Go, his takeout division. He told all the teen-agers he would welcome them in an apprenticeship program that he hoped to build once he began Soul to Go franchise outlets.
This struck a responsive chord. "I want to work legitimately," said another teen-ager. "I'll do anything."
 
Changing Attitudes
 Vernon Manley, assistant commissioner of New York City's probation department, said this sort of statement is the beginning of the miracle he seeks. "When they get turned onto an idea," he said, "it can change the whole direction of their lives."
Entrepreneurship as a life-changing idea is the mission of Steve Mariotti, founder and president of the six-year-old National Foundation for Teaching Entrepreneurship, a nonprofit organization based in Manhattan. The foundation, which has a $2.5 million annual budget, grew out of his experiences as a special education teacher in the South Bronx.
He said his average student had a deplorable academic record, little athletic ability and an empty social life. Accordingly, most saw themselves at the bottom of every totem pole. "That's a very brutal way to think of yourself," Mr. Mariotti said.
His idea was for them to forget how they ranked with other people, and instead to think of other people as a potential market to whom they might sell things.
"Their sense of self grew dramatically," he said. "The actual sentence structures in the human psyche begins to change when you view yourself as an entrepreneur."
Mr. Mariotti's program, which now reaches 2,500 high-school-age young people a year in eight cities, involves teaching basics like the definition of marking up prices and elementary record-keeping. But the most eye-opening exercise, he said, is when each student is given small amounts of money -- a first installment of $50 and a second of $75 -- with which to start a business.
Most buy flea-market goods or other trinkets from wholesalers they have visited as a class. About 15 percent are able to maintain their businesses over the long term. Success stories in the Bronx include Josephine Reneau, who made $28,000 selling lingerie; Mike Freeman, who sold $17,000 of electronic equipment, and John Emmanuel, who posted sales of $200 a week selling cologne.
Mr. Mariotti suggests that many disadvantaged youths have the talent for success. An ability to deal with stress and ambiguity, the staples of many of their lives, he said, is also the key to business survival.
"Nobody at Goldman, Sachs will have gone through what they've gone through in the past year," he said.
But business is far from easy, particularly for novitiates. Edward T. Lewis, chairman of Essence Communications, one of the nation's largest black-owned enterprises, warned that only those with unusual perseverance and vision would make it truly big as entrepreneurs.
"It's not about fancy cars or clothes or things like that," he said. "It's about serving a need in the marketplace that is not being served at the moment."
Some aspirants hardly make it past the front door. Mr. Vann said that one probationer he hired for an entry-level job showed up for work erratically, then offered glib excuses to try to cover for his mistakes. He dismissed him.
By contrast, several years ago Mr. Vann hired Andre Smith, who he knew had been imprisoned for a year on drug charges. Starting as a busboy, Mr. Smith, 28, is now a chief steward, with assistant manager most likely to be his next title. Ultimately, Mr. Vann wants his protege to become an owner of one of his soul food franchises.
That thought seems to sit well with Mr. Smith. "I wouldn't mind being my own boss," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Vann, left, an owner of the Shark Bar at 307 Amsterdam Avenue, preaches the promise of entrepreneurship. With him was Andre Smith, whom he hired as a busboy. Mr. Smith, who had been imprisoned for a year on drug charges, is now chief steward and likely to become assistant manager. (Debra DiPeso for The New York Times)
