HEADLINE: After 13 Years of a Vicious War, Liberians Dare to Hope for Peace

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Virtually all shooting between Liberia's warring factions reportedly ended today as a peace accord brokered by the United Nations took effect.
"All sides seem to be respecting the cease-fire," said John Adda, the deputy field commander of a regional peacekeeping operation. "I think everyone is fed up with fighting." 
 Charles Taylor, the leader of one of the main factions, was quoted on a radio broadcast as telling his troops to return to their homes.
 
'The War Is Over'
 "Some of you were shoeshine boys, carpenters and farmers," he said. "We ask you to return to your towns and villages and begin to rebuild your lives. The war is over."
The civil war, which has cost nearly 150,000 lives, began in December 1989 when Mr. Taylor's forces attacked the military dictatorship of President Samuel K. Doe, who was killed in September 1990. As the guerrilla movement grew and split into rival factions, the widespread violence brought military intervention by neighboring West African countries.
Diplomats and relief workers here acknowledge that it is too soon to tell if the truce will lead to lasting peace. But for the first time since the war began, almost all the principals seem to be genuinely groping for a comprehensive political solution, largely because of the growing role of the United Nations.
Until recently, the 16-member Economic Community of West African States was virtually the sole mediator. Troops from Nigeria, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Gambia have been in Liberia since August 1990 trying to impose a truce.
But Mr. Taylor has insisted that these forces were not neutral, and he recently accused Nigeria's President, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, of trying to assassinate him.
At the same time, Mr. Taylor has refused to recognize the interim Government set up by the West Africans and led by Amos Sawyer.
There was a widespread belief that only if the Western powers, particularly the United States, turned their full attention toward Liberia would the country be put back together again.
But in a diplomatic breakthrough, the three main factions -- Mr. Taylor's rebel group, the National Patriotic Liberation Front; Mr. Sawyer's interim Government, and the United Liberation Movement, loosely allied to the army set up by President Doe -- signed a peace pact on July 25.
The key differences this time, during negotiations in Geneva, came from pressure from the Organization of African Unity and an agreement by the United Nations to play a far greater role in forging a settlement.
Under the terms of the accord, the three main factions are to be disarmed by a reconsituted West African peacekeeping force, which United Nations officials say will include troops from Egypt, Zimbabwe and Tanzania. Perhaps most significant, the disarmament will be supervised by 200 to 300 United Nations monitors.
The agreement also calls for elections to be held in February.
Some African political authorities emphasized that the new atmosphere was based more on exhaustion than on any real entente.
 
Skepticism and Hope
 In this view, the constant shelling of Mr. Taylor's headquarters in Gbarnga, the massacre last month of nearly 600 unarmed civilians and the crippling of the economy all have finally forced the militias' leaders to accept at least a short-term accommodation.
Although Mr. Taylor has reneged on cease-fires several times, there was an almost palpable sense of relief here.
In a speech broadcast tonight, Mr. Sawyer said he was confident that the accord would "pave the way to the restoration of peace and the beginning of democracy in our society."
"Let us think positively," he added.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 4, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A headline on Monday about a cease-fire in Liberia misstated the length of the civil war there. The war began about three and a half years ago, not 13.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Haiti's Man of Destiny Awaiting His Hour

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
For most of the 22 months since he was ousted from Haiti's presidency in a military coup, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide has been something of a celebrity in Washington, running his government-in-exile from rented Georgetown apartments and lecturing audiences about the urgent need to free his troubled country.
Now, after arduous negotiations with the same military leaders who toppled him, the frail, soft-spoken Catholic priest is poised to go home. And the nagging question for the Clinton Administration as Father Aristide prepares his return 13 weeks from now is whether he will be able to make the transition from martyr to statesman. 
 It is one thing to show up at parties in Hollywood and to be feted as a champion of democracy on Capitol Hill, and quite another to rebuild a country devastated by brutal military rule and economic sanctions. Such a transition would be difficult for any politician.
 
No Ordinary Politician
 But Father Aristide is not an ordinary politician. He was expelled by his religious order for, among other things, "a glorifying of class struggle." He is an iconoclast who sees himself a missionary of God and views the world through the lens of liberation theology.
"I feel confident, very confident," he said Friday in an interview in his one-bedroom apartment in Georgetown, describing his pending return to Haiti as an act of love, not one of sacrifice. "It's not a question of being willing to become a martyr, nothing like that. It's a question of sharing love, giving your life for love the way Jesus did."
The 40-year-old Father Aristide tends to arouse passionate support and passionate opposition.
Among Haitians who elected him President with an overwhleming majority in December 1990, he is a beatific visionary, a brave leader who knows eight languages, writes poetry and composes hymns on his guitar and is willing to risk his life for his people.
For his political opponents, mostly in the military and the upper classes, he is a demagogue with messianic visions and some of the same thuggish tendencies of the military junta that overthrew him.
The Clinton Administration, which has spearheaded the campaign to reinstate Father Aristide, appears to regard him as a volatile chemical that needs to be handled with care.
When President Clinton summoned Father Aristide to the White House last month, the meeting was half lecture, half pep talk. Two weeks before, Father Aristide had signed a compromise agreement in New York with the military commanders who had ousted him, and Mr. Clinton wanted to impress upon him the importance of becoming presidential.
"The President emphasized that Aristide had to be a figure who spoke about reconciliation and healing and rebuilding," a senior Administration official said. "He told him how important it was to make the transition from president-in-exile to President."
Mr. Clinton was said to have been heartened when Father Aristide, who once called capitalism a mortal sin, preached forgiveness rather than vengeance later that day at a meeting in Miami.
"Haiti must be reconstructed by its sons and daughters," Father Aristide told 180 Haitian businessmen, many of them his political enemies. During a standing ovation at the end of his speech, Father Aristide embraced Raymond Roi, a onetime foe who heads Haiti's Chamber of Commerce, as the crowd burst into a rendition of the country's national anthem.
"Aristide is acting very responsibly and very constructively," said Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's deputy national security adviser. Michael Barnes, a former Democratic Congressman from Maryland who is Father Aristide's lawyer, said Mr. Clinton had told him at a dinner on Wednesday night that Father Aristide "is a good man who's trying to help his people."'
 
Learning Experience For Clinton's Team
 That sort of praise is a far cry from the Clinton Administration's introduction to Father Aristide.
A classified Central Intelligence Agency psychological profile prepared after his ouster in September 1991 portrayed a man prone to severe mood swings. The report suggested that he suffered from depression and may have had nervous breakdowns, and it concluded that he was capable of saying one thing one day and the reverse the next without being aware of any inconsistency, said senior officials familiar with its contents.
The conclusions of this assessment were presented to the Clinton team during the transition. But while Mr. Clinton's top aides say they at first found the C.I.A. analysis troubling, they quickly decided that the fact that Father Aristide was Haiti's first democratically elected President was more important than a psychological profile that was dated and based largely on secondhand reporting.
"It is a caricature of Aristide," a senior Adminsitration official said. "Even people who have doubts about him acknowledge that his experiences of the last few years have been sobering, and that he's grown."
In the interview, Father Aristide vehemently denied that he had had a nervous breakdown, had suffered from depression or was taking medication, although he added that the C.I.A. assessment of his mental state did not come as a surprise.
"When you don't like someone, it's natural to say bad things about him," he said. "I'm like a man following Jesus, and Jesus was a God, and they said he was crazy and they even killed him because they couldn't understand how he said he was a God. If they could say that about him, who am I?"
Asked about the introduction to his autobiography, which says he "sometimes succumbs briefly to depression," Father Aristide dismissed the statement. And although a flattering profile in a book on Haiti by Amy Wilentz, a journalist and personal friend, refers to a series of "nervous prostrations," he said: "No, no, she didn't mean that. She was just trying to explain how someone can be open to listening to the audience and be in communion with their suffering."
One senior Administration official who has come to know him well said the C.I.A. was biased against him because of his leftist views.
"There's ideological overlay on some of the official analysis," he said. "In any case, it was decided that that it was not our responsibility to pass judgment on his mental health and that there was nothing so disturbing as to override our very strong conviction that he had to return to Haiti as soon as possible."
 
A Frustrating Time For Highest Officials
 The process of restoring Father Aristide to power has been fraught with frustration for the American and United Nations officials who deal with him. Father Aristide's predilection for consulting with each member of his inner circle of up to 40 advisers, a tendency often described as indecision, has been a recurrent source of exasperation.
On July 2, the fifth day of torturous negotiations on Governors Island in New York Harbor on a compromise accord to restore Father Aristide to power, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations told him he was getting a very good deal, officials familiar with the conversation say. Father Aristide replied that yes, he was examining the accord very carefully. "Don't examine it, just sign it," Mr. Boutros-Ghali is reported to have replied.
Shortly after midnight that night, Lawrence E. Pezzullo, the American special envoy to the talks, was so distressed by Father Aristide's indecision that he called Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, and asked him to intervene directly.
But Father Aristide was asleep, and his aides would not wake him. The normally easygoing Mr. Lake spent the next three hours trying to convince Mr. Barnes that the moment must be seized and the document signed.
"Tony stressed we are working together to restore democracy and bring him back to Haiti, and if we lose this moment we may fail," a senior Administration official said. "The message was fairly firmly put."
For another nail-biting day, Father Aristide did not budge. Mr. Lake had the unfortunate task of telling an impatient Mr. Clinton at an early Saturday morning meeting that Father Aristide had not signed, even though the military leader who had ousted him was poised to do so.
Mr. Clinton was so eager for good news that he twice interrupted his golf game for a status report on the negotiations, so frustrated that he stayed awake that night until he received word that Father Aristide had finally signed.
 
Some Annoyance At Accord's Terms
 Father Aristide and his supporters said they felt that at the eleventh hour they were being pushed into unacceptable concessions to the military rulers. Particularly galling to them was that Father Aristide, the target of two assassination attempts in Haiti, had to agree to allow members of the ruling high command to stay in the army, as long as they took posts outside Haiti. Only Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who was appointed by Father Aristide as commander in chief but then overthrew him, must retire under the accord.
"We were astounded to learn early Saturday morning that this is what they meant by the 'resignation and departure of the high command,' " Mr. Barnes said. "We never understood that they could remain in the army."
In the interview, Father Aristide acknowledged his frustration with the accord but said, "I signed it, and I will keep my word."
Father Aristide appears to have shed much of his suspicion of the United States since the days when cables from the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince labeled him a "radical firebrand." The suspicion was inflamed by the Bush Administration's tacit support for Marc Bazin, a well-heeled former World Bank official, in the 1990 election.
 
'Love' for Clinton Partly Reciprocated
 The Haitian leader said in the interview that he "loves" Mr. Clinton, remarking that during a phone conversation one day with the President he realized that "there was a kind of deep human vibration" in him. "I felt that he really understood the reality," Father Aristide said.
He referred to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Lake and Mr. Christopher as "my friends," but was less enthusiastic about Mr. Pezzullo, a hard-driving negotiator who has lost his temper with Father Aristide many times in an effort to broker a deal. "As a psychologist, I understand the differences in people," he said when asked whether Mr. Pezzullo had pressed him too hard.
Father Aristide has invited Mr. Clinton to visit Haiti after democracy is restored. That is suppposed to happen on Oct. 30, after a new Prime Minister takes office. The United Nations oil and arms embargo is to be suspended, and the Government's financial assets unfrozen. American troops will be deployed to professionalize the army and build military housing, and French and Canadian police trainers are to create an independent police force.
Father Aristide once said in a 1990 interview, "Above all, we must not accept money from abroad," but he now lauds the promise by the United Nations of a program of more than $1 billion in aid over the next five years.
One of the difficulties in trying to assess Father Aristide is that he has been on the interview-and-lecture circuit so long that he seems to have packaged answers for every question.
"Haiti looks like a broken glass, and it is my responsiblity to put the pieces together, and of course I cannot do it alone," he said, repeating the same image that a senior White House official said had impressed Mr. Clinton in their meeting last month.
 
An Improvement On Human Rights
 The Clinton Administration regards Father Aristide's record in the seven months he served as President as mixed. He followed what American offficials of both Administrations saw as a relatively responsible economic policy, reduced the public payroll and abolished the jobs of the rural sheriffs who ruled the countryside with impunity.
The main criticism lodged against him is his own less-than-perfect human rights record, including speeches that have been interpreted as condoning the practice of "necklacing" political opponents with burning tires. But independent human rights experts insist that his transgressions were mild compared with the tyranny that preceded and followed him.
"While Aristide's record is far from perfect, it's obscene to compare it to the mass murder, torture, arbitrary detention by the military in the two years since the coup," said Kenneth Roth, executive director of the New York-based Human Rights Watch.
Clinton Administration officials quietly express concern that if foreign military and police trainers do not begin their work soon, the military may try to sabotage Father Aristide's return.
When he is asked about how he plans to govern, Father Aristide's answers are long on spirituality and short on data. Although he is making his way through a stack of books on Haiti's economy, in the interview he offered no concrete proposals on how he intended to rebuild the country after his return.
His supporters say that what he lacks in hands-on experience he makes up in the strength of his character.
"There is no other leader who has impressed me as much as Aristide," said Representative Major Owens, a Brooklyn Democrat who serves as an unofficial adviser to the Haitian leader. "He has compassion and unquestioning integrity, and I know he will have the wisdom to seek experienced people to rebuild his country."
Even if he does return at the end of October and gradually reasserts his authority over the military, as envisioned in the Governors Island agreement, Father Aristide will not have very long to prove himself again. His term expires 27 months later, and he cannot run again until five years after that.

Europe's Currency Crisis
The French franc sank more than 2 percent and European governments were left wondering what remained of their monetary system and their plans to create a single currency by the end of the century. [Page A1.] Currency traders bought German marks and Japanese yen, pushing weaker currencies down and sending the dollar to a new record low against the yen. [D17.]

NEW YORK CITY
 
NEW FIGHT OVER PATIENT
A new legal fight over the release of a mentally ill homeless man who has menaced and frightened residents of the Upper West Side for years was joined yesterday as New York State officials moved to detain him at a psychiatric hospital for up to six more months to allow time to find him a suitable home. B3.
 
BODIES IDENTIFIED; 4TH VICTIM FOUND
A woman and her two children who were shot to death and dumped at the edge of the East River over the weekend were finally identified, and when the police searched their home in Connecticut they made another chilling discovery -- the body of the woman's husband, wrapped in a blanket in the garage. B2.
 
WHERE EVERY SECTION IS ROMANCE
They did it to Laundromats. They did it to health clubs. Was it really so long before New Yorkers would turn the mega-bookstore into a meeting place for the unattached? The block-long new Barnes & Noble on Broadway near 83d Street has become, in the words of one patron, "the ultimate safe-sex place." B3.

The former American Savings Bank, a neglected neo-Classical temple on Union Square in Manhattan, was bought yesterday by the House of Blues of Cambridge, Mass., which plans to convert the building into one in a national chain of restaurants and blues bars. B3.

HEADLINE: Ukrainian Steel Mill Seeks Growth in U.S. Market

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARIUPOL, Ukraine

 BODY:
From sleek European-designed offices, Sergei A. Taruta, works long hours trying to insure that the towering Stalin-era steel mill outside his window is a winner and not a loser in the industrial shakeout under way across the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Taruta, the deputy foreign sales director at Azovstal, one of the old union's largest steel plants, thinks he has found part of the solution: selling steel plate and slabs to the United States. 
 This year, Azovstal will send 40,000 tons of steel plate to America, a small amount, but Mr. Taruta is confident it will jump to 200,000 tons next year.
 
A Niche Market
 The decision by the International Trade Commission in Washington last week that most of the steel plate from Europe and Latin America is subject to anti-dumping duties continues to give Ukraine, a new exporter to the United States, a niche for carefully calibrated sales. This is because while duties on the steel plate of the kind that Ukraine makes were upheld, Ukraine as a newcomer to the American market, is not affected by the ruling.
"We'll increase exports to the United States but at the same time we're trying to be reasonable in not disturbing the internal market of the United States," said Mr. Taruta, who by now is well schooled in the sensitivites of American steel manufacturers. "We plan to be very careful."
The export of steel to the United States from Ukraine, the world's fourth-largest steel producer, became possible last year when Ukraine was granted, along with the Commonwealth of Independent States, most-favored-nation status by Washington. The decision meant duty charges on Ukrainian steel dropped from 23 percent to 6.5 percent.
Thus, on Azovstal steel priced at about $280 a ton the duties are now about $17 a ton instead of $67, according to Michael Ratzker, a senior trader for Metallia Ltd., a London-based international steel-trading company and one of Azovstal's main foreign customers.
Ukraine's prices are competitive with some East European countries, like Poland and Romania, but these countries have had to stop shipping steel to the United States because of anti-dumping measures, Mr. Ratzker said.
"Azov produces good quality plate, they are competitive price-wise and they don't have these anti-dumping measures and if carefully handled can avoid them," Mr. Ratzker said, whose company is also shipping Ukrainian steel to the Far East. Two or three other Ukrainian mills and two mills in Russia were exporting to the United States, Mr. Ratzker said.
The suavely attired, 38-year-old Mr. Taruta and his offices with remote controlled shades and black leather chairs are intended to send a signal to foreign buyers that Azovstal is serious about acting in the modern and competitive world beyond the old Soviet perimeters. But Mr. Taruta's problem lies with the rust-colored, badly polluting plant that sits immediately outside his smart, air-conditioned office suite.
With an antiquated, enormously overstaffed plant situated in an economically precarious country in an era of declining steel consumption, the transition for Azovtal will be extremely difficult.
Last year's production of seven million tons of steel will drop to four million tons this year, because of crippling coal strikes in the nearby Donbas region in June and shortages of available iron ore, Mr. Taruta said.
 
'They're Complacent'
 Still, Mr. Taruta and some Western steel experts believe that Azovstal has a better chance of survival than most of the 10 steel works in Ukraine, a heavily industrialized republic that produced about 40 percent of the Soviet Union's steel needs.
"Not that many mills in this country are willing to change," said Karl McKeever, an American metallurgist who inspects the quality of Ukrainian steel for foreign buyers. "They're complacent and they've been making to Russian specifications forever. Azovstal does much better."
Mr. McKeever said that like the steel mills across the former Soviet Union, Azovstal still operated open-hearth furnaces. He said most of the plant's newest equipment, dating from the 1960's, was of old technology even then. But even with these handicaps, Azovstal had proved adaptable by producing steel for export that met international specifications rather than the Russian specifications, Mr. McKeever said.
Concepts of productivity have not yet arrived at Azovstal. When asked how many man-hours it took to produce a ton of steel -- compared, for example, with the three man-hours a ton at the Burns Harbor plant of Bethlehem Steel -- Mr. Taruta looked blank. "We don't have this one; we don't have the methods to calculate," he said.
There are 25,000 workers at the plant, about 10,000 of whom are involved in such nonsteel activities as running the plant's huge hospital, holiday houses, shops and stadium, according to Mr. Taruta.
 
New Laws
 And while the plant has attained certain amount of freedom from the central Government in Kiev, there are new laws that are most unhelpful, he said. "I would like to see a new politics and new economics in Ukraine so we could improve the situation. The laws that have been adopted do not contribute to the well-being of the economy."
The Government, which is dominated by former Communists, requires Ukrainian enterprises to convert half the hard currency it earns abroad into coupons, the new and virtually worthless Ukrainian currency. This requirement, according to Ukrainian and Western businessmen, has led to large-scale capital flight with most of the dollars that are earned abroad staying abroad.
The newest part of the Azovstal plant is the metal-cutting shop built in 1973 that stretches for about a mile. About 1,800 workers are assigned to the shop but in July, shortly after the coal miners' strike, the shop was virtually idle and only a handful of workers could be seen operating the vast expanse of machinery.
"We're working at one-third capacity," a foreman said. "Maintenance is suffering because of lack of money and specialists." But the situation was better, he said, than at Mariupol's other steel mill, a 120-year-old plant he described as "hardly ever working."
Mr. Taruta said he knew Azovstal, with its good access to world markets because of its location on the Sea of Azov, which leads into the Black Sea, was working against the odds. "Ukraine doesn't need so many steelworks because they do a lot of harm to the environment; they can't produce the competitive product and the market will not allow their existence," he said. "More than half the enterprises will have to close."
About his own plant, he said, "I'm a pessimistic optimist."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Macy Pessimistic on July After Hitting June Goals

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company reported yesterday that its financial performance in June met the goals outlined to creditors as part of its continued operation under bankruptcy court protection. But the retailer warned that July's official results would probably fall short of its targets because of "declining consumer confidence in its primary markets."
As a result, Macy's said in its monthly report to the United States Bankruptcy Court, it is "approaching the fall season very cautiously." 
 In June, before deductions for interest payments, taxes and certain noncash expenses such as depreciation, Macy's earned $12.2 million, compared with a similarly measured loss of $7.4 million in June 1992. After allowing for those taxes and expenses, the retailer lost $40.8 million in June, compared with a loss of $64.7 million in the same month last year.
All told, monthly sales rose 3.1 percent from June 1992 and the comparable-store sales, excluding the effect of stores that have been closed, increased 1.5 percent.
 
Fifth Month on Target
 June was the fifth consecutive month that it hit its financial targets. But July, the final month in its 1993 fiscal year, is likely to break that string, the company cautioned.
The roots of that pessimism can be seen in the details of June sales. While the company saw some sales strength in Florida, Texas and Georgia, results were only slightly stronger in Northern California, and remained depressed in the Northeast, the heart of its market.
July results were also likely to suffer by comparison with last year's numbers, the company said, because of a change in strategy for its annual preseason sale, a two-week event that has helped raise July sales in the past. This year, as part of a shift away from special sales events, the company scaled back the scope of that sale and, thus, the impact it should have on the month's figures.
The forecast of a weaker July did not seem to unsettle the market for Macy's publicly traded junk bonds. According to M. J. Whitman & Company, a specialist in bankrupt securities, the bonds were priced at 36 1/2 cents on the dollar of face value, about where they had been all last week, and volume was very light.

HEADLINE: Cuban Dissident, in the U.S., Says Embargo Is a Mistake

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 29

 BODY:
In ardently spoken five-minute bursts, Cuba's most prominent political dissident often finds himself railing these days against the disaster he says is looming over his country.
But rather than attacking the Government of Fidel Castro, a target of his criticism for more than two decades, the dissident, Elisardo Sanchez Santa Cruz, has spent much of his time during a rare visit to the United States reproaching Washington for what he sees as its immutable determination to isolate his country through a 30-year-old economic embargo. 
 With Cuba facing its worst economic and political crisis since President Castro's revolution in 1959, Mr. Sanchez says, it is time for Washington to expand its long-frozen ties with Cuba to better influence events there.
"Cuba is like a volcano waiting to explode," said Mr. Sanchez, who repeatedly used similarly dark images in an interview in the Miami offices of an exiled friend and colleague in the country's human rights movement.
"If the United States policy is not less simplistic and more farsighted, when the explosion comes you can multiply the turmoil that you have seen in Haiti by 100 to get an idea of what things will be like there."
Touring the United States, Europe and Caribbean countries, Mr. Sanchez has sought to convince all who will listen that a violent tragedy could unfold in Cuba if the economy is encouraged to unravel while Mr. Castro, 66, clings to power.
"We are only 90 miles away from you, and whatever happens in Cuba will have serious national security consequences for the United States," he said. "It is time to realize that by maintaining open hostility, the United States is helping Castro. The external enemy is the best friend of the totalitarian dictator."
Mr. Sanchez said the United States should encourage change in Cuba just as it does in China, through commercial ties and expanded contacts between citizens, while continuing to apply diplomatic pressure for observing human rights and for political changes.
In Miami, where opposition to Mr. Castro among Cuban-American exiles often edges toward hatred, many have received Mr. Sanchez's message with suspicion. Some ask why it is that the 49-year-old dissident is only now receiving an exit visa from his Government five years after applying for one.
Having spent nearly 9 of the last 12 years in Cuban jails and suffered a severe beating in December by police agents who raided his home in Havana because of his outspokenness, Mr. Sanchez treats such suspicion with calm disdain.
 
Currency Plan Criticized
 "The Government has its agenda and I have my own, which consists of seeking greater international support for human rights in my country and helping contribute to a peaceful transition," he said. "It is important for people in both countries to understand that whatever actions I take are independent of any Government."
As if to prove his independence, Mr. Sanchez harshly criticized plans announced by Cuba recently to legalize the possession of dollars for ordinary citizens and encourage visits to the island by Cuban-Americans.
"Anything that reduces the totalitarianism of the state is for the good," he said. "But the Government is not doing any of this out of a desire to change the system. Rather it is looking desperately for funds to finance its system of repression."
When asked why, given his suspicion of Havana's motives, he opposed American sanctions against his country, Mr. Sanchez said: "The embargo against Cuba is not the cause of the country's problems. They result from three decades of neo-Stalinist policies, and this is what will cause Castro's downfall."
"The boxer who fights in a rigid style is more easily beaten," he said. "Change is coming to Cuba, and if Washington could learn to be more flexible, its opponent would fall of his own accord."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Cuba is like a volcano waiting to explode," said Elisardo Sanchez Santa Cruz, left, Cuba's most prominent political dissident, shown outside a Miami cafe. "If the United States policy is not less simplistic and more farsighted, when the explosion comes you can multiply the turmoil that you have seen in Haiti by 100 to get an idea of what things will be like there." With him was Omar Castro, owner of the cafe. (Tom Salyer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Shorter-Term Treasury Issues Slip

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Yields on short- and intermediate-term Treasury issues edged higher yesterday, while the 30-year bond's yield slipped, as traders reacted to a reduction in the Government's borrowing plans and hints of new inflation.
The Treasury Department said yesterday that its estimated borrowing needs in the third quarter would total $58.3 billion, considerably less than the $90 billion to $95 billion it estimated on May 3. 
 That news, in advance of tomorrow's announcement of the details of the Treasury's quarterly refunding of 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities, caused some traders to reconsider their strategies. The refunding will be held next week.
 
 
Treasury's Needs
 "A lot of people are starting to cut back their estimates of what the Treasury needs to raise in the refunding," said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. in New York.
Mr. Ricchiuto said that in particular, traders were anticipating that fewer 30-year bonds would be sold by the Government than previously expected. The anticipated lower supply pushed the price of the long bond up 4/32 of a point, while its yield slipped to 6.55 percent, from 6.56 percent on Friday.
But prices of shorter-term Treasury issues slipped and their yields rose on concerns that inflation might re-emerge. Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities Inc. in New York, said an increase in the Commodity Research Bureau index, a measure of commodity-price inflation, in addition to some positive economic news, set off fears that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates to curb inflation.
The index was up 3.66 points, to 222.92, with most of the commodities measured higher for the day, Mr. Levenson said.
Inflation erodes the value of existing bonds, which pay fixed rates of return.
In a separate report, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its purchasing managers' index, which measures the strength of the manufacturing economy, rose to 49.5 percent in July, a slight improvement from 48.3 percent in June.
Signs of economic strength, traders worry, may clear the way for the Fed to raise interest rates because there would be less concern that the move would send the economy back into recession.
"That all gives you a fear factor," Mr. Levenson added. And traders took that as an excuse to sell shorter-term Treasury securities.
Prices of short-term Treasuries fell 2/32 to 6/32 of a point, while intermediate-term issues dropped 5/32 to 7/32 of a point.
The Treasury's weekly auction sold $12.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.1 percent, the same as last week. It sold $12.3 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.25 percent, up from 3.24 percent last week.
"There wasn't any surprise in the result," Mr. Levenson said.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.05 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills also rose three basis points, to 3.21 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills rose four basis points, to 3.42 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 3.25 percent, up from 3.07 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 101 22/32, up 1/32 from Friday. The average yield to maturity was 5.76 percent, down from 5.78 percent Friday.
Following are the results of the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Lawyer Sets Insanity Plea In L.I. Case

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 2

 BODY:
In a move that came as no surprise to prosecutors, the lawyer for Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper suspected of killing 17 women, said today that he planned to use an insanity defense based on several psychiatric examinations of his client that occurred in July.
Robert Sale, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, declined to discuss the doctors' findings or any other details of Mr. Rifkin's mental condition, but he said that the evaluations "confirm the propriety and efficacy of such a defense." Mr. Sale added that he was not conceding that Mr. Rifkin had committed any of the murders and that the insanity defense was one of a number of arguments he would be using. 
 Under New York State law, the insanity defense requires that Mr. Sale prove two points. First, he must show that his client suffers from a mental disease or defect. And second, he must convince the jury that because of this ailment, Mr. Rifkin lacked the capacity to know what he was doing or to recognize that it was wrong.
Asked about Mr. Sale's announcement, Ed Grilli, a spokesman for the Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, who is most likely to prosecute the first case, said, "We're optimistic that we'll be able to prove our case beyond a reasonable doubt."
 
Raising a Possibility
 David Rosenhan, a professor of law and psychology at Stanford Law School, was extremely skeptical that such a defense would work, though he said Mr. Sale had few other options.
"It's something that any responsible defense attorney must raise as a possibility," Professor Rosenhan said. But he added that the facts of the case, as he understood them from newspaper reports, led him to believe that Mr. Rifkin was not a strong candidate for such a defense.
"One gets the impression of a set of murders that occurred with tremendous mindfulness," he said. "This is someone who knew what he was doing and carefully planned it out. None of this seems to match the the current criteria for the insanity defense."
Mr. Rifkin's only hope is that the "prosecution doesn't do its homework," Professor Rosenhan said.
The use of the insanity defense all but guarantees that the case will involve psychiatrists testifying for both sides, and that the trials, assuming there is more than one, may add up to thousands of dollars in bills for expert witnesses.
 
More Psychiatric Tests
 As required by New York State law, Mr. Sale said he would formally notify the prosecution of his plans to use the insanity defense at the next hearing on or about Aug. 16, so that the prosecutors can schedule their own psychiatric evaluations of Mr. Rifkin. In the meantime, Mr. Sale is continuing to arrange for psychiatric examinations of his client.
Mr. Sale used the insanity defense once before successfully in a case in which another client, Mate Ivanov, killed his wife, three children and dog with a bayonet.
The lawyer said that when a defendant is found not guilty by reason of insanity, he is institutionalized until a panel of psychiatrists rule that it is appropriate for him to be released.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rebound as Dow Gains 21.52

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The stock market rebounded yesterday from Friday's slump, as worldwide expectations grew that the European currency crisis would lead to lower interest rates in Europe -- a move that would probably mean a long-term improvement in export markets for American companies.
Also cited by analysts as reasons for yesterday's gains were the recovery in 30-year Treasury bonds, favorable data from the National Association of Purchasing Managers and general anticipation that President Clinton's deficit-reduction proposals would be passed by Congress this week. As a result, the mood on Wall Street was generally upbeat and all of the major market indicators advanced. 
 "The global environment has taken a positive step in terms of less confusion and a clear direction toward an international economic recovery," Steven Resnick, senior investment strategist for Cowen & Company, said. "So investors were more inclined to buy stocks than to sell them."
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 21.52 points to close at 3,560.99, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks increased 2.02 points, to 450.15, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.96 points, to 707.66. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate, with 230.4 million shares changing hands and advancing stocks outpacing decliners by a ratio of about 3 to 2.
The gain in the American markets mirrored advances throughout the day in most other foreign markets. Investors overseas seemed to share the same perception that a breakdown in Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism would push down interest rates there and thereby stimulate economic growth on the continent.
Automotive issues were strong yesterday on the New York exchange, spurred by a favorable article in Barron's magazine and a report from General Motors of a 9.9 percent sales increase in the mid-July period. This brought the overall automobile industry gain for that period to 11.7 percent.
All of the Big Three auto makers were on the Big Board's 10 Most Active list yesterday. G.M., the second most active, was up 1 1/8, to 48 3/4; Chrysler, the third most active, was up 1/2, to 43 3/4; and Ford Motor, the seventh most active, was up 1 3/4, to 54 1/2.
Another gainer on the most active list was the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, up 1 5/8, to 49 1/8, after rising 1 7/8 in the previous trading session. The company is likely to be a major beneficiary of a Congressional staff decision last Friday to remove or cut fees on secondary market buyers of student loans that might have been imposed under the proposed new plan to replace the current guaranteed student loan program.
Merck & Company, which announced last week the acquisition of Medco Containment Services, was the most active stock and inched up 1/8, to 30 3/4. Bristol-Myers Squibb, one of two more drug stocks on the list, fell 7/8, to 53 3/4; Johnson & Johnson, the other, rose 7/8, to 37 3/8.
Some of the housing-related stocks on the New York exchange were propped up by low interest rates and the affordability of homes. Centex, a home builder, advanced 1 1/4, to 37 1/4, while Shaw Industries, a carpet manufacturer, rose 7/8, to 39 5/8.
Similarly, multiline insurance companies have been participating in an upward cycle and some stocks in this category yesterday gave evidence of that activity. Chubb moved up 5/8, to 92 1/8, and Aetna gained 1/2, to 58 7/8.
There was also strength among large-capitalization stocks with good earnings momentum. Traders mentioned Motorola, up 3 3/4, to 94 3/8, and the American International Group, up 2 1/8, to 94, as among the companies that performed well yesterday.

HEADLINE: True Recovery In 3 Regions

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Only the Mountain, Midwest and Southern regions of the country have truly recovered from the recession, according to an analysis released yesterday by the Conference Board, a New York-based corporate-sponsored research organization.
Its latest quarterly analysis showed that since the 1991 national economic recovery began, regional economies had performed differently. 
 The Mountain, West North Central and three Southern regions have not only recovered, but most have also far exceeded their pre-recession peaks, the board said. Those areas tend to be lower-cost areas, where manufacturing jobs are growing despite the national decline.
Other regional economies -- in particular the Middle Atlantic, New England and Pacific regions -- remain in a slump, the organization said.
In the Northeast and on the West Coast, business and population migration trends -- from California to the Mountain region and from the Northeast to the Southeast -- are a major force shifting economic activity and growth, it added.
The Conference Board bases its findings on its newly developed regional performance indexes. For each region, the barometer indicates the direction and growth of gross regional product. It is a statistical blend of five economic indicators: housing permits, employment, consumer confidence, retail sales and help-wanted advertising.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Despite Drop, Gold Prices Are Expected to Go Higher

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices retreated slightly yesterday, after hitting their highest levels in nearly three years in early trading. Many dealers said they expected prices to go even higher.
Many investors have been turning to gold as a safe haven in reaction to the turmoil in the European Monetary System. Early yesterday, finance ministers of the European Community agreed to allow weaker currencies in the system to fluctuate within a much wider range than in the past. 
 "Currency instability is one more factor weighing in gold's favor," one gold dealer said.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery slipped $1.10 an ounce, to $405.90, after trading as high as $409. The most active gold contract, for December delivery, traded as high as $414 an ounce, its highest level since September 1990. It later dipped on profit taking to close at $410.20, down $1.10 from Friday's close.
 
 
Other Precious Metals gain
 Other precious metals advanced. Platinum for October delivery closed up $4.20 an ounce at $423.10 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, its highest in two and a half years. Silver for September delivery on the Comex closed at a three-and-a-half-year high of $5.458 an ounce, up 5 cents.
Analysts say the end of stable exchange rates in Europe through the Exchange Rate Mechanism should allow interest rates to fall, reducing the cost of maintaining inventories of gold. It is also expected to rekindle economic growth, which could lead to a resurgence of inflation -- all favorable for gold.
Political factors are also lending support. "From the E.R.M. mess to Clinton in Bosnia, it can only mean one thing -- higher metal prices," one dealer said.
Ever since the gold rally started in March, American investment funds have been driving gold higher through buying of futures and options. Dealers say the funds' next target will be to push gold through $420 and possibly $440 an ounce, even though prices might temporarily fall below $400 before moving higher.
"Gold has followed a clear pattern," a dealer said. "Rallies of $10 or $15, pullback and consolidation, then a fresh surge."
On other commodity markets, soybean prices shot up amid concerns that an early frost in the fall might curtail the harvest.
Many Midwestern crops have already been heavily damaged by relentless rains this spring and summer that delayed planting and development.
"Crops will mature anywhere from 10 to 25 days later than normal," said Paul Handler, a meteorologist for Atlas Forecasts, at a weekend conference in Denver. He said the later the crop, the more vulnerable it was to frost damage.
The National Weather Service predicted cooler than normal temperatures for the nation's midsection in the next 30 days, possibly presaging a frost.
 
 
'Even a Call for Rain'
 "There was even a call for rain to a certain degree in Iowa that wasn't expected," Mark Cermak of Prudential Securities said of the long-range forecast.
The cooler, wetter weather also prevents soybeans from producing as much oil, a factor that lifted soybean oil futures.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans for August delivery rose 19 cents, to $7.0425 a bushel, and August soybean oil rallied near the daily limit, closing 0.96 cent higher at 24.17 cents a pound. September corn advanced 4.25 cents, to $2.40 a bushel, and September wheat firmed 3.75 cents, to $3.0775 a bushel.
After the close of trading, state crop reports indicated that 45 percent of the soybean crop was in either good or excellent condition, up from 40 percent the previous week.
Elsewhere, energy futures posted modest gains. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for September delivery firmed 9 cents, to $17.97 a barrel; September unleaded gasoline edged up 0.01 cent, to 52.17 cents a gallon, and September heating oil rose 0.37 cent, to 51.18 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Outlook: Still Tepid

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The outlook for the nation's manufacturing sector improved only slightly in July, according to an influential survey of purchasing managers released yesterday.
The National Association of Purchasing Management in Tempe, Ariz., reported its monthly index of economic activity was 49.5 percent in July, compared with 48.3 percent in June. Under its method, any rating below 50 percent suggests that manufacturing contracted, even though numbers above 44.5 percent may indicate overall economic improvement. 
 The closely watched index is culled from the opinions of 300 executives who buy the supplies for their corporations. From its vantage point, the manufacturing sector is still in the doldrums.
If economic activity continues at its current tepid pace, the association predicts, gross domestic product will grow 2.8 percent in real terms in 1993, compared with 3.1 percent last year. Even that would not be possible were it not for strong showings in the first three months this year.
 
Just 'Treading Water'
 "Manufacturing has just managed to tread water during the last few months," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business management committee and the purchasing manager for Pitney Bowes. "There's nothing in this report to change that picture dramatically."
He and others focused instead on the pickup in new orders, none of which involved exports. "What makes that impressive," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist with Merrill Lynch, "is that our domestic economy is strong enough to make up for some of the weakness" abroad.
At first glance, commodity prices were another bright spot, with more purchasing managers reporting higher prices than lower prices.
But economists and analysts said that the price increases were concentrated in three industries -- steel, semiconductors and agricultural products -- and were not likely to stick. Steel prices are already slipping after a trade ruling last week lifted many tariffs on imported steel. Semiconductor prices may also retreat once the Intel Corporation corrects the temporary shortages that have developed over its new Pentium chip. And firmer agricultural prices are less a byproduct of improved fundamentals than of Midwest floods.
 
Composite of 5 Indicators
 The purchasing index is actually a composite of five indicators, four of which flashed stronger signals last month. Purchasing managers in general reported that orders were up, supplies took longer to arrive, inventories were lower and production was higher in July than in June.
The one big piece of contradictory evidence was employment, which managers said was unchanged or falling. Only three of 20 industries in the survey reported otherwise.
Backlogs also appeared to be slipping, despite the jump in new orders, which Mr. Bretz called "the biggest surprise."
Sid A. Brown, a purchasing manager for a James River Paper Company plant in North Portland, Ore., attributed much of the inertia in his own industry to the Clinton Administration's not having promptly detailed the rules for industrial use of Federal land. "When you are sitting in the Northwest where a lot of raw material is paper, there's a lot of concern in this area," he said.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Surges for Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Spending on construction projects jumped 1.2 percent in June, the best showing this year, but analysts said today that the important residential sector was still not responding as it should to the lowest interest rates in two decades.
The Commerce Department report released today showed that spending on all types of construction rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $460.1 billion, an increase of $5.5 billion from May. 
 The advance was led by the biggest increase in Government spending in more than a year, a gain of 3.6 percent. That reflected a huge 9.3 percent rise in outlays for highways and streets. Private construction was up as well, reflecting strength in the residential sector, but by a much more modest three-tenths of a percent.
The overall increase was the biggest since a 1.3 percent rise last December. Spending rose 1.1 percent in May after posting two months of weak showings.
 
 
Low Rates Not Enough
 The Clinton Administration is counting on strength in sectors of the economy like construction that are sensitive to interest rates to offset the economic drag from the higher taxes and cutbacks in Government spending that are part of its huge deficit reduction plan. But economists say they have been disappointed that single-family construction has not picked up more than it has, given interest rates that are at their lowest level since the early 1970's.
In June, residential construction advanced nine-tenths of a percent with single-family construction up five-tenths of a percent and multifamily building rising 2.9 percent.
So far this year, the overall economy, as measured by the gross domestic product, has risen at the disappointing rates of seven-tenths of a percent in the first three months of the year and 1.6 percent in the recent April-June quarter.
 
 
Flood Rebuilding Ahead
 David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill Inc. of Lexington, Mass., said that the Midwest floods should eventually add to construction spending as flood-damaged structures were replaced but that the floods would likely depress activity until it was dry enough for rebuilding to begin.
The 3.6 percent increase in public construction lifted that category to an annual spending rate of $125.6 billion. It was the biggest one-month increase since a 4.8 percent rise in May 1992 and was led by a 9.3 percent rise in spending on highways and streets.
Nonresidential spending, which came in at an annual rate of $89.5 billion, dropped 1.3 percent in June, reflecting widespread weakness. Spending on industrial projects was down 3.5 percent, office building outlays were off 3.8 percent, and hotel and motel construction fell by 6.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Layoff Law Impact Is Almost Nil

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Four years and millions of layoffs after Congress enacted the plant closing law of 1988, which required many companies that chopped 50 or more jobs to give their workers 60 days' notice, the law seems to have had virtually no impact.
While few people took literally the Democrats' assertions that the law was a great victory for America's working men and women -- or President Ronald Reagan's warning that it was the "the most anti-competitive, anti-employee, anti-business pieces of legislation to come along in a long time" -- many Americans expected that laid-off workers would have the time to look for new jobs or retrain, and that communities affected would have the time to seek new businesses. 
 But things did not turn out that way. Take the case of Veronica A. Fox, a sewing machine operator at the Pennshire raincoat plant in Portage, Pa., for 30 years. She was notified just hours before her job was eliminated on Jan. 22; a week later, the management posted a curt handbill that read: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank you for giving us many years of loyalty and to wish you the best success in your retirement or new endeavors."
 
No Severance or Vacation Pay
 Within a couple of weeks, all 79 workers at the plant were gone, with no severance and no vacation pay. Pennshire has declined to comment on the layoffs; the workers and Cambria County, Pa., have filed suit.
As it happens, the fraction of workers who get more than a month's formal notice is no higher than before the law passed, said John Addison and McKinley Blackburn, labor economists at the University of South Carolina who conducted a broad study of the law's impact. "We find no effect whatsoever," Professor Addison said, after analyzing the Government's biennial survey on displaced workers.
Why has the law fallen short of its goals? Too many loopholes, too many exceptions and virtually no enforcement, its critics say. The law applies only to companies with 100 or more employees and to layoffs where more than a third of the work force at a particular operation is involved. It also exempts distressed companies that are trying to find buyers or fresh funds or are facing unforeseeable circumstances like natural disasters.
Entire industries, including shrinking ones, are not covered because of the exclusions. The country's 22,000 clothing factories, for example, employ an average of 52 workers each.
 
For Some Workers, Less Notice
 The labor economists' study found that 8.2 percent of laid-off workers received a month's notice or more since 1988; in the five years before the law, 8.6 percent said they received such notice. Slightly more than half the workers whose jobs were eliminated -- 51.4 percent -- reported that they had received no notice, a modest increase from the 47.5 percent in the five years that preceded the law.
The results were even more stark than those of a fairly downbeat report released in February by the General Accounting Office. The report, limited to 11 states, found a small increase in the proportion of employers who gave advance notice.
"Many workers who are permanently laid off aren't part of a large-scale layoff," said Ronald Ehrenberg, an economist at Cornell University. "Many are laid off from small firms or firms exempted from WARN," as the planting closing act is known, an acronym for the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act. "The other problem," he said, "is that there's no enforcement."
 
Loopholes for Companies
 Julie H. Hurwitz, the executive director of the National Lawyers' Guild/Maurice and Jane Sugar Law Center for Economic and Social Justice in Detroit, a national clearinghouse for WARN cases, said, "Experience and time have proven to the benefit of those who choose to ignore the law or to take advantage of its various loopholes."
Many companies give workers advance warning, often years ahead. Among those that have done so are Kroger, General Motors, I.B.M. and Procter & Gamble. But many other companies have provided little or no notice. The St. Johnsbury Trucking Company, of Holliston, Mass., for example, one of biggest trucking companies in the Northeast, recently laid off more than 4,000 workers the day before it filed for bankruptcy.
"On June 14, people came to work and, by the end of their shift, the company was closed," said Frank A. Braman, a senior software specialist with 24 years' experience at St. Johnsbury, who has been kept on to wind down the company's computer operations. "The employees received virtually no notice, no severance pay, no vacation or sick pay. Management said, 'The company's closed, you're done, goodbye.' "
Executives at St. Johnsbury said the company was exempt under a provision that permits a faltering company to avoid giving notice if it undermines its ability to raise funds or find a buyer.
And there is the case of the Acuson Corporation, a manufacturer of diagnostic ultrasound equipment, which is based in Mountain View, Calif. As sales for medical equipment weakened at home and abroad, the company laid off 250 employees, mostly production workers. "We gave no notice," said David Ringler, the director of corporate communications. But, in contrast to St. Johnsbury, the company said it gave workers three months' severance pay and extended their health insurance for five months.
 
A Scaled-Down Bill
 The original legislation, sponsored by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, and Representative William D. Ford, Democrat of Michigan, was much more far-reaching than the version that passed. It called for six months' notice and applied to layoffs of 25 workers or more and to any company, regardless of size.
"The law that was passed included so many exceptions that it covers only a small portion of layoffs, perhaps 10 percent," said Jim Benn, the executive director of the Federation for Industrial Retention and Renewal, a Chicago-based network of community groups that opposes plant shutdowns. Indeed, the General Accounting Office found that half the mass layoffs involving more than 50 employees were not covered.
Even though Emery Worldwide cut 1,000 workers in 1991, said William L. Tomko, a former Emery driver with more than 10 years on the job in Pittsburgh, "we are the only terminal nationally that could file a suit under the WARN because the company had reduced the worker level under 50 at most terminals."
"Roughly six months after we were released," he added, "150 workers at the Dayton hub were terminated. They couldn't file a WARN suit because they did not represent one-third of the work force at that hub."
Another problem is that no agency, including the Department of Labor, has the authority or resources to enforce the law. So fewer than 125 cases have been initiated, and those settled, Ms. Hurwitz said, "you can count them on one hand."
 
A Bid to Toughen the Law
 An effort to toughen the law is under way, with Mr. Metzenbaum and Mr. Ford preparing amendments much closer to the original legislation, their staffs said.
"Extending amount of notice automatically gives us a field to organize an alternative to a shutdown," said Mr. Benn of the Federation for Industrial Retention and Renewal. "Now it's legitimate because of WARN for Government to assume some kind of stewardship for the economic base of the community."
Markley Roberts, who tracks plant closings and large layoffs for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said: "We'd like to see more workers covered, we'd like to see more notice given, we'd like some enforcement beyond civil lawsuits. That's an expensive, cumbersome and totally ineffective way of enforcing the law.
"We're calling for enforcement by the Labor Department. We also think there ought to be a lot more information given to workers, unions and local communities about the existence of the law."
But most businesses have opposed any widening of the law.
"We believe the current law is adequate," said Peter Eide, the manager of human resources law and policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington, one of the business groups that fought against the 1988 law.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Molitor Gets Chance This Time Around

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
The last time the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays were so close to each other and played a meaningful series this late in the season was in 1985. They played two series in September that season, the first one in New York, the second in Toronto that ended the season and made the Blue Jays American League East champions. The New York series made Dave Winfeld Mr. May.
Paul Molitor was not a part of those games. He spent September mired in the depths of the division, wallowing with the rest of the Milwaukee Brewers up to 31 games behind the leaders. Baseball economics, however, have conspired to make Molitor a part of the confrontation that began at Yankee Stadium last night. 
 "With so many games to go, you don't want to overmagnify it," the Blue Jays' designated hitter and sometimes first baseman said, noting that this is early August and when the four-game series is over Thursday, the Yankees and the Blue Jays will still have to play more than 50 games each.
"But," he added, "it's a chance for them to make a statement, and slow us down a little bit. I'm sure it will be a good atmosphere. It hasn't been this way for a while."
It was this way in September 1985. The Blue Jays arrived at Yankee Stadium for a four-game series two and a half games ahead of the Yankees and promptly lost the first game. But the Blue Jays had their way with the Yankees the rest of the series. The turn of events was too much for George Steinbrenner.
In the eighth inning of the third game, Steinbrenner plopped down in the press box next to a reporter and reeled off a series of negative batting statistics he had instructed his public relations department to compile. Winfield, in the owner's view, was one of the major culprits.
"Where is Reggie Jackson?" Steinbrenner asked. "We need a Mr. October or a Mr. September. Winfield is Mr. May."
Steinbrenner spent Winfield's entire 10 years with the Yankees speaking ill of him. Bud Selig never said a bad word about Molitor.
"Our relationship was strained, particularly immediately following the change," Molitor said, discussing his departure from Milwaukee, where he had spent his entire 15-year career and developed an unusually close relationship with Selig, the Brewers' owner. "But I went to see him in his office when we were there and then we met again in Baltimore the day before the All-Star Game. It's back to where I'm comfortable seeing him. We can talk about things again -- why I left, why they didn't keep me. We have a pretty good understanding of what happened."
Molitor and Selig became victims of the growing controversy over the major leagues' small-market and large-market clubs. The small-market clubs say they can't compete financially with the large-market clubs and point to players like Molitor as examples. The Blue Jays offered Molitor $13 million for three years. Selig wouldn't even offer himself that kind of deal.
"I believe that he would like to have kept me in Milwaukee," Molitor said. "But I also respect the position he's in as a small-market owner. He couldn't meet what the market said one of his players was worth. I told him I would've stayed for less than I got here, but the difference was too great."
So instead of being in last place or in a position to help the Brewers avoid last place, Molitor came to New York in first place with the Blue Jays. He has had much to do with getting them there.
He is hitting .324, among the top six averages in the league; is leading the league in runs scored with 85 and multi-hit games with 41, and is trailing only his teammate, John Olerud, in hits with 135. And at an age that in 19 days will become 37, he has contributed 17 stolen bases in 20 attempts to a team that with Rickey Henderson joining the relay team has three of the top seven base stealers in the league.
"You make a transition like this," Molitor said, "and naturally there is going to be some pressure. But my expectations of the city, my teammates and the franchise all have been surpassed. I feel very good about my choice. I'm having some fun."
Molitor, however, knows better than most that this season's races have a sober side, a dark side, some would say. As much a veteran of baseball's bargaining table as he is of baseball fields, Molitor is a member of the Players Association's executive subcommittee and will participate in negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement.
With talk of a possible players' strike next month, the contenders for division championships have to wonder whether they will play for the league pennants and World Series championship. In other words, the Blue Jays and the Yankees could be playing this series for nothing. The best time of the baseball year could be eclipsed by matters of revenue sharing, revenue participation and salary caps.
"The compensation system can be looked at, but a salary cap doesn't have to be the answer," Molitor said. "As an industry, baseball generates enough revenue to compensate the players. Radical changes aren't necessary. Putting a cap on salaries just gives money back to the teams that give up money to the small markets from their local revenue."
The fight over revenue, though, is for another time. This week it's the fight for first place.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Small-Screen Feud, Majors' Big Picture

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Imagine this: the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds are playing a crucial pennant-race game (all I said was imagine, all right?) at Shea Stadium, but neither team lets the other broadcast the game back to their home cities.
All that -- and much, much more! -- is possible if a quiet time bomb within the National League isn't defused. 
 Our zany baseball story of the day began last year when five small-market teams gave notice that the 1956 National League TV agreement was kaput as of 1994. The pact provides the reciprocal framework that allows teams to air each other's games and establishes financial arrangements among them.
If reciprocity goes the way of Ladies' Day, the potential for chaos is immense. Maybe the Dodgers and the Padres won't air each other's games, or the Cubs and Astros will prohibit each other's broadcasts.
Perhaps the Padres will only find friendly broadcast relations with its four compatriots in this affair, the Pirates, Astros, Expos and the Marlins. Two others, the Reds and the Cardinals, are sympathetic to the cause.
"Chaos is possible, but I prefer to look at it constructively, that people of good faith can come to an agreement," said Claude Brochu, the Expos' president, who added that the 37-year-old TV agreement needs a total overhaul.
"I'd hope that this doesn't happen," said Brent Shyer, broadcasting director of the Dodgers. "We want to have something that works out so we have an agreement, but a lot of dialogue has to take place."
Even more tantalizing than the chaos that may be engendered is the political message of the agreement's abrogation, a message of revenue-sharing.
The league agreement calls for each team to contribute 25 percent of its local cable TV revenues into a shared pool. The dissident teams want more local cable money shared. They also want to divvy up money from local over-the-air broadcasts for the first time.
(An oddity of this contretemps is that the wealthy Dodgers currently have no cable deal, while the discount Padres do. Thus, the Dodgers now reap monetary benefit from the Padres' cable cash.)
This issue is part of the small market versus big market battle being waged in baseball, although the Marlins and Cardinals don't qualify as small markets. The small markets contend that they can't compete, that they can't sign the biggest stars, unless they get a chunk of the wealthier markets' revenues.
To the small markets, and to Dick Ravitch, the owners' labor negotiator, baseball can't thrive without an all-encompassing revenue-sharing mechanism that creates labor peace and economic stability.
Coincidentally, Ravitch will try to gain approval of his revenue-sharing proposal during owners' meetings next week in Sheboygan, Wis. If he succeeds there, he will then have to persuade the ever-suspicious players union.
It is possible that the revenue cravings of the dissident National League teams will be sated via Ravitch's plan. But if owners nix it, the National Leaguers' cash yen will remain a ticklish issue, at best.
"What we're proposing dovetails with what Dick Ravitch is working on," said Brochu.
Bill Giles, owner of the Phillies and a member of the major league broadcast committee, said: "My position is there should be increased revenue sharing, but I'm not in favor if just television. All elements should be shared."
(Well, that's one vote for Ravitch.)
There is one more facet of this tempest: superstations. Most clubs are fed up with the geographic influence of the Braves and Cubs through their WTBS and WGN superstations, which are beamed to cable systems around the country.
The National League agreement could not foresee the superstation phenomenon. The agreement described into which geographical areas teams could broadcast into, and does not have provisions for a Chicago station being seen everywhere.
Brochu was cagey about what the dissidents want regarding superstations, but one could imagine they'd like to scale back their spheres of influence. Said Brochu: "Rather than call it a superstation issue, it's more of a geographical invasion issue."
And upon what spaceships did the aliens land, monsieur?

HEADLINE: Meal Tax to Aid Miami's Homeless

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Metropolitan Miami will soon begin imposing a 1 percent tax on restaurant meals to finance programs for the homeless, an action that experts on homelessness say breaks new ground but that the tourist industry opposes.
The move is a response to a Federal court order that Miami provide help for its homeless. 
 The tax, which was unanimously approved last week by the Dade County Commission and goes into effect on Oct. 1, is intended to underwrite medical treatment and job training programs for homeless people, and to build low-cost housing and temporary shelters.
The new effort will be run largely by a not-for-profit corporation made up of representatives of the private sector and religious and advocacy groups, as well as the homeless themselves.
 
Turnabout in Attitudes
 "This is an impressive, innovative, first-of-a-kind program," said Mayor James Scheibel of St. Paul, the head of the United States Conference of Mayors task force on hunger and homelessness. "Miami is addressing the causes of homelessness instead of passing anti-homeless legislation. We need services and affordable housing for the homeless, and when you look at the Federal budget, the money is obviously not all going to come from Washington."
Dade County's decision to levy the tax is a turnabout in attitudes toward the homeless, stemming from last November, when a Federal judge ordered the Miami to create "safe zones," where the homeless could eat, sleep, bathe and cook without fear of arrest.
The ruling said Miami's "custom and practice of driving the homeless from public places" was unconstitutional. In his ruling, Judge C. Clyde Atkins of Federal District Court strongly criticized Miami's policy of "arresting the homeless for harmless, involuntary, life-sustaining acts" in the city's streets and parks.
The order has been stayed pending appeal, but it has prompted the county and city authorities to adopt its alternatives to establishing arrest-free zones for the homeless.
"This is a much more humane and reasonable choice," said Paul Johnson, director of Camillus House, the city's best-known shelter. "I think our leaders have finally gotten the message that government must step up and accept its responsibility."
Under the county ordinance, all restaurants that serve alcoholic beverages and have annual sales of $400,000 or more will be required to collect the tax from their customers. The county commission estimates that the new tax will generate about $7.5 million in revenue in its first year.
 
County Spends $7 Million
 In contrast, Dade County, with about 6,000 to 10,000 homeless people, spends about $7 million a year on the homeless, including about $5 million in grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and Miami spends about $400,000, officials say.
The budget of Camillus House is about $4 million a year, Brother Johnson said. New York City, with a homeless population estimated at 90,000 by advocacy groups, spends an estimated $500 million a year on them, city officials said.
The restaurant tax has been criticized by some civic tax abatement groups, as well as by community organizations concerned that the three new 500-bed shelters in the plan will be built in their neighborhoods. But the loudest complaints have come from restaurant owners, who say their business, squeezed by a flat economy, will suffer unduly.
"We oppose this all the way, not because we're not empathetic to the needs of the homeless but because it is totally discriminatory and irrational to have only restaurant patrons pay for this," said Manny Mighdoll, executive vice president of the Florida Restaurant Association. "One percent doesn't sound like a lot, but this is going to have a negative impact not just on fine dining restaurants but also on the bulk of family and neighborhood places."
As of the end of 1992, there were slightly more than 6,700 licensed restaurants in Dade County, about half of which are authorized to serve alcohol, Mr. Mighdoll estimated.
Only "a few sandwich places" are likely to be exempted from the tax, he said, adding that retirees and other "people on fixed incomes who eat in restaurants out of necessity" will also be affected.
 
Some Fear Government Plans
 Other residents who opposed the tax when the county commission held hearings last month say they also fear an expansion of government programs will swell the population of the homeless here. If the new programs succeed, they contend, the homeless will flock here and overwhelm the effort, dooming it to failure.
When asked how the police would deal with homeless people who do not wish to participate in the program but who also refuse to leave, Alex Penelas, who is chairman of the county commission's committee on housing and homelessness, admitted bafflement. "What that means from an enforcement point of view, I don't know," he said.
As envisioned by the task force that drafted the new policy, the initial phase of the plan would place the homeless in shelters for up to 30 days, where they would receive free lodging, food and medical care. They would then go into a wide array of treatment and training programs that would include job training, addiction treatment and mental health counseling.
That second phase would last six to nine months, or longer if necessary.
In the final phase of the program, expected to be in place within three years, homeless people would be placed in low-cost housing provided by not-for-profit corporations and, it is hoped, they eventually would be able to fend for themselves.
