HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BILL: A Fading Call to Arms;
Clinton Wins a Crucial Fight on the Deficit, But Some of the Sense of Mission Is Lost

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton took office with three goals for the economy. He wanted to reduce the annual budget deficit, stimulate the economy to create jobs and redirect the priorities of the Government.
In his speech to a joint session of Congress last February laying out his economic program, the President called for tough choices and shared sacrifices, for fundamental changes that he said would make the tax system fairer and direct Government spending to the programs where it would do the most good. "Our nation needs a new direction," he declared. 
 If Congress approves the legislative compromise that House and Senate negotiators struck today -- a probability but by no means a sure bet -- then the President will have achieved the first of his goals, reducing the annual Federal deficit. This is a serious, credible, mostly gimmick-free bill that should make the deficit significantly lower over the next five years than it otherwise would be, saving the country billions of dollars in interest payments on the national debt.
But the President's two other goals -- stimulating the economy and changing priorities -- have fallen by the wayside, at least for the time being. And with them, to some extent, has gone the dream, the vision, the call to arms.
 
Memories of Bush
 For one reason or another, Mr. Clinton has failed to overcome the inertia of the established political system. The bill Congress will vote on later this week bears a striking resemblance to the budget agreement that President George Bush and Congress struck in 1990.
On economic stimulus, the President's $30 billion, two-year spending plan died in Congress last spring. It was killed by a Republican filibuster. But many if not most Democrats were unenthusiastic. It simply seemed illogical to many to throw more money at the same kinds of projects the Government had been spending billions on for years at the same time that Congress and the President were straining to lower the budget deficit.
As for changing priorities, the deficit-reduction measure would reverse the tax trend of the Reagan years, when taxes on the wealthy went down and those on others went up. But spending directions would be changed only sightly. The bill falls short of what the Administration wanted in terms of tax help for the working poor, investment incentives for businesses, additional money for food stamps, tax breaks for companies in poor neighborhoods and funds for childhood immunization and family support.
 
How New a Course?
 The military budget would be cut sharply, and some of that money would be spent for education, nutrition and other areas that got short shrift in the Republican years. But the ambitious new programs Mr. Clinton advocated in his election campaign for new roads and bridges, communications and information networks and environmental technology are nowhere to be found. If the nation is on a new course, it is hardly perceptible.
Gene Sperling, a top economic adviser to the President, said that deficit reduction had to come first and that the other priorities would be met later.
"All of the things Bill Clinton talked about in the campaign as far as investing in people are still in line to happen," Mr. Sperling said in an interview. "By taking control of the deficit, he has kept control of his agenda."
Maybe so. But it is hard to escape the parallels between this budget measure and the one Mr. Bush signed three years ago. Like that agreement, the new measure would lower the deficit from what it would otherwise be by nearly $500 billion over five years. As was the case then, this would be accomplished largely through increased income taxes on the wealthy, a modest rise in the gasoline tax, reduced military spending and limits on the growth of Medicare spending through lower rates for doctors and hospitals.
 
Attractive in the Abstract
 The same, familiar path was taken because it is the easiest way politically to get from here to there and because the route was mapped by essentially the same Democratic Congress that traveled it in 1990.
It is the way, perhaps the only way, to take a bite out of the deficit without affecting the vast majority of Americans. All that middle-income working Americans would be asked to pay in the name of deficit reduction is a few more dollars a year for gasoline at a time when the price at the pump, adjusted for inflation, is the lowest in decades.
Shared sacrifice sounds attractive in the abstract. In the specific, it is viewed as bad politics.
Ronald Reagan changed the core of American politics with his pain-free approach to paying for Government, and Mr. Bush followed in the same vein. Now, as the columnist Michael Kinsley has written, Mr. Clinton has "bought into the central lie of American politics -- that our problems can be solved without asking anything of the middle class."
 
Promises and Setbacks
 Mr. Clinton was elected on the campaign promise to cut the taxes of the middle class. Of course, he reneged and actually proposed an across-the-board energy tax that not only would have raised more than $70 billion over five years but also would have had some benefits in terms of conservation and the environment.
When Congress eviscerated the energy tax, the President took the setback in stride. Even with the new budget legislation, the national debt would grow by $1 trillion over the next five years. But Mr. Clinton is still saying publicly, though few believe him, that he expects to recommend middle-income tax relief during his term.
There are further deficit-reduction steps that most economists, regardless of ideology, believe would be wise: requiring wealthy retirees to pay a larger premium for health insurance under Medicare; abolishing Government programs that have outlived their purpose and continue to exist only because a small number of people and communities depend on them; eliminating duplication and overlap in Government agencies; scrapping tax breaks for business entertainment and vacation homes.
But each of those measures would be fought to the death by lobbyists and by lawmakers whose constituencies might suffer. Republicans and Democrats in Congress oppose them with equal vigor.
 
Lots of Constituencies
 The problem, said Mr. Sperling, the White House economic policy assistant, is that "any program that exists has a constituency."
But no one lobbies for raising taxes or cutting programs. There is no constituency for that.
This is why Mr. Clinton's supporters say he deserves so much credit. He stepped up with real deficit-cutting proposals based on real numbers -- not the gimmicks and black boxes of the Republican years. He did not have to be dragged to the table the way George Bush was.
The President's plan was bound to be unpopular. While he failed in some aspects, he got much of what he wanted. And perhaps next year he can get more, and the next year even more.
If Congress approves this package, the new President will have won a partial victory. By any measure, that is better than a defeat on the most bedeviling issue in American politics today.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BILL: Back Home;
Letter Writers Lay Down Their Pens as Vote Nears

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Though some members of Congress are wringing their hands over whether to vote for a budget bill that includes higher energy taxes and other contentious items, they are, to their surprise, not hearing a lot from their constituents.
And with a few significant exceptions, Washington's major lobbying organizations are mounting only limited campaigns against the proposal -- or none at all. 
 Representative Mike Synar of Oklahoma is a strong supporter of the Clinton budget, but he is troubled by the gasoline tax endorsed by the Senate-House conference committee that has just reached a compromise on a five-year budget bill.
But when he was back in his home district a couple of weeks ago, talking to constituents at town meetings and in other settings, "almost nobody brought it up," he said. "They were concerned about all sorts of other things."
Amy Weiss Toby, an aide to Mr. Synar, said: "People were worried about health care. They were coming to his town meetings handing him their hospital bills." As for faxes, mail and phone calls from lobbyists, she said, "Right now it's just a trickle."
 
Interest Ebbs
 Senator David L. Boren, another Oklahoma Democrat, complained last week that he was getting 10,000 letters a day about the budget proposal. He was one of several members of Congress who suggested recently that pressures from lobbyists and unusually high levels of concern from voters back home were forcing them to reconsider whether to vote for President Clinton's budget. He announced Sunday he would not vote for the budget.
But Dan Webber, an aide to Senator Boren, said the volume of mail and phone calls coming into the office "has slackened off in the last two weeks." As for the Senator's comment, Mr. Webber said: "That was true, up to two weeks ago."
Indeed, many Senators and Representatives and their staffs said they have been surprised about how little pressure they seem to be getting from anyone to vote one way or another on the budget bill.
There are big exceptions. In California and a few other states, a battle over the budget has developed among Democrats, Republicans and followers of Ross Perot. And some Texans say their constituents are quite concerned about the proposed increase in the gasoline tax -- both because Texas is an oil producer and because many of its residents drive long distances.
Two months ago, when the budget bill was being considered in the Senate and the House, most members reported extraordinary interest, both from lobbyists and the public. The experience of Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat, was typical.
"We were getting just an enormous amount of mail, and phone calls," said his aide, Bette Phalen. "We were bringing volunteer help and interns into our district office to handle the phone calls."
Much of that mail was generated by the American Energy Alliance, a coalition of more than 1,000 businesses and associations opposed to the broad energy tax in President Clinton's original budget bill. But that proposal is no longer a part of the budget bill, so the American Energy Alliance is inactive.
"We're not doing anything," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, the lead member of the coalition. "We don't anticipate being actively engaged" in the remaining budget debate.
Some other lobbyists, however, are still engaged. As an example, the American Trucking Association is lobbying against the gasoline tax. Ken Simonson, a senior economist for the association, said 50 staff members were taken off their normal jobs so they could run a phone bank. "They're calling all our motor carrier members saying, 'Look, if you care about a gas tax, call today,"' he said.
Mr. Simonson said he found five other associations or trade groups willing to lobby against the proposed tax increase, and they are making calls to their members. But by recent standards, this campaign is relatively modest. The truckers have not set up toll-free phone numbers or bought advertising. Nor do any of the associations appear to be trying to broaden the campaign beyond their own constituents.
At the same time, the American Association of Retired People is continuing to rally its members against new limits on Medicare and Social Security benefits proposed in the budget.
"But it's nothing particularly new," said John Rother, a senior lobbyist. "We're trying to achieve a steady stream" of calls and letters to members of Congress. But the association is not buying radio, television or newspaper advertisements.
A few other groups, including the Christian Coalition, are trying to make their displeasure known. But the biggest lobbying effort is coming from Citizens for a Sound Economy, a conservative organization based in Washington that says it has 250,000 members nationwide. It is opposed to tax increases of any kind and has bought buying advertising intended to influence what it considers wavering senators from six states: Wisconsin, Nebraska, Arizona, Nevada, Georgia and Louisiana.
"It's a major push," said Jeff Nesbitt, spokesman for the organization. But so far, it does not appear to be having much effect.
In Louisiana, for example, Senator Breaux described the mail and phone calls coming into his office late last week in this way: "There's still a lot of interest, and it's mostly negative, but it has slowed down. People wrote once, and now they feel, 'O.K., I've done my deal.' "
Another Louisiana legislator, Representative W.J. (Billy) Tauzin, a Democrat, caused a bit of stir last week when he made it clear he could not vote for an energy tax. But he said, "We're not hearing a whole lot on the gas tax from constituents, or from lobbyists." Still, he added, "I don't have to hear from constituents on a gasoline tax to know that it would be awful for Louisiana."
On Friday, Beth Gonzales, press secretary for Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat who is among the targets of the Citizens for a Sound Economy's campaign, said: "There are little blurbs of people calling in when the they see the ad from C.S.E. But it's low key. Interest has really died off since May."
Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, helped shape the debate on the budget when he made it clear that he would not support an increase in the gasoline tax of more than 4.3 cents a gallon.
An aide to Mr. Kohl, Lynn Becker, said that a reporter from a Wisconsin newspaper wanted to follow the Senator around for a day back in the state last month, to see what Mr. Kohl was hearing from constituents. Questions and comments would be mainly about the budget, the reporter thought.
"But," Ms. Becker said, "the things they approached Senator Kohl about were across the board, on every issue, not really about the budget. The reporter came back here and told us that he didn't really hear enough to write anything."

HEADLINE: Ross, Still Bobbing and Weaving

 BODY:
You'd think that by now Ross Perot could keep a few basic facts in his very own head. We're not asking for much, just a few numbers that would help ordinary folks understand how he intends to do the one thing he says Bill Clinton can't do, which is to bring the budget deficit to zero. After all, this is a man who's been talking economics day and night for two years, usually with a pointer and charts. But without the charts, Mr. Perot can't remember a thing.
The funny thing about those charts is that they're never there when somebody else wants to consult them. They're always within easy reach when Mr. Perot wants to show the weaknesses in Mr. Clinton's ideas. But ask him a pointed question about his ideas and darned if he didn't leave his charts back on the kitchen table. 
 Mr. Perot's charts first mysteriously disappeared in May on the "Today" show. Bryant Gumbel tried to pin him down on what he'd cut to balance the budget. Mr. Perot said: "If I had known you wanted them, I would have brought my charts."
Last Sunday, on "Meet the Press," Mr. Perot brought the charts he wanted but not the charts anyone else wanted. At the beginning of the show he said Congress should forget the Clinton deficit-reduction plan because it wouldn't do the job, "and I got the charts here to show you."
His interrogators wanted to know what Mr. Perot would do differently -- specifically, how he would carry out his 1992 campaign pledge to cut $141 billion from Medicare and Medicaid. "Well," he replied, "if you had told me that you wanted that, I would have come in with a very detailed list and given it to you. I don't have the list with me."
"We're not talking about some piddling little details," complained one panelist, noting that the Medicare and Medicaid cuts represented half of Mr. Perot's proposed reductions. To which Mr. Perot replied, "If you had told me in advance that you wanted it, I would have brought my charts. . . ."
Mr. Perot has been suffering memory lapses and bristling at people who pester him for inconvenient specifics ever since he surfaced on the political scene early last year. So this latest exchange would hardly be noteworthy were it not for two stubborn and irritating facts.
The first is that he remains a figure to be reckoned with. After betraying his followers by abandoning the 1992 race in midstream, he came back and won 19 percent of the vote, partly because he had some bold ideas but largely because he served as a magnet for voters discontented with both major parties. Recent polls suggest that his following is bigger than ever.
Which leads to a more disturbing fact: Mr. Perot is shamelessly and recklessly exploiting his popularity not to advance his professed cause of deficit reduction, but to sandbag the one plausible deficit-reduction plan on the table. Mr. Clinton's program is hardly perfect but at least it has a rough coherence and at least it's out in the open.
Should it survive, it will have withstood the sort of rough-and-tumble politics that Ross Perot professes to stand above but actually fears, having shrunk from political combat at nearly every turn. Mr. Perot's plan, meanwhile, remains unsullied. It's still on the charts, if anyone can find them.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Dinghy Of State

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Composed after deep immersion in news accounts of the clownish budget dispute in Washington:
Chairman Rostenkowski is from Chicago, which may explain why he may be indicted before it's all over, although of course he may not be. If he is it would be catastrophic for President Clinton's health-care program, or maybe it wouldn't, depending on what happened next. 
 In any event, President Clinton doesn't actually have a health-care program yet and may never have one. That's because Senator David Boren is sworn to veto anything the President proposes, though both he and the President are Democrats, as is Vice President Albert Gore, who cast the tie-breaking vote that overturned Senator Boren's last veto.
And what about Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Democratic chairman of the powerful Senate Something-or-Other Committee? As Bismarck said of Talleyrand, so we too may say when pondering the Moynihan question, "What indeed about this great statesman?"
Meanwhile the Republicans are pledged to vote unanimously against absolutely everything. Though not necessarily everything down to the crossing of the last "t" and the dotting of the final "i."
After all, when Senator Robert Dole, the brilliant Republican Friend of the Taxpayer, was asked if the Republicans would even vote unanimously against Senator Boren, did Senator Dole not reply, "I refer you to what the Oracle of Delphi told Mithridates"?
Senator Dole's tendency to give these oblique replies to blunt questions irritates young Clinton staffers whose musical tastes run to groups like Fleetwood Mac. They assume Senator Dole is taunting them about their youth when he refers to old-timers like Mithridates and Oracle.
The real question, however, was the B.T.U. tax. Real or not, alas, the question was vetoed by Senator David Boren who threatened to veto the tax as well, no matter what the House of Representatives did.
The Black Caucus met. Ross Perot charged. At week's end another week had ended. Indecision ran rampant but also sat leadenly on both sides of the Capitol. President Clinton stumped.
Several more gigantic corporations "downsized," adding tens of thousands of loyal company men as well as loyal company women to the rolls of the loyal unemployed and once again making a mockery of President Clinton's campaign pledge to "grow the economy" and create more jobs.
Henry Salomon of Kaufman & Brothers saw little to cheer in the G.D.P., but Henry Brothers of Salomon and Kaufman was immensely cheered by the latest figures, while Salomon Kaufman of Henry, Brothers & Co. said he hadn't taken the G.D.P. seriously since people quit calling it the G.N.P.
It was unclear why the old-fashioned G.N.P. had been renamed the G.D.P. or what the renaming might mean for housing starts. With hundreds of thousands becoming unemployed every week because of the "downsizings," it was not clear either where the tycoons in charge of the "downsizing" expected to find well-paid employees to buy the products pouring out of their "downsized" plants.
Behind this nagging uncertainty was the heroic struggle of Senator Breaux Bummel, the Gasoline Purchaser's Friend, to hold any new gas tax to a maximum of 4.3 cents per car.
The entire Senate, Republicans excepted of course, closed ranks behind Senator Bummel's gas-tax cap, with several members pointing to a study of restaurant prices showing Americans are now paying $19 a plate for pasta as evidence that it would be cruel to make them pay any tax at all on gasoline.
Meanwhile, President Clinton stumped again, which was one stumping too many for Rush Limbaugh. On his radio call-in show, Limbaugh suggested the President might be using a Japanese stump and urged the economically hard-hit American stump industry to investigate.
Senator David Boren has taken the first step toward vetoing the President's stump. This has put the Republicans in a quandary. Since they are pledged to vote unanimously against absolutely everything, they would have to vote against Senator Boren's stump veto, which of course would amount to a vote for the President's stump.
Such are the agonizing dilemmas that engage our statesmen. Pathetic, is it not?

HEADLINE: Just Say No to Clinton's Package

BYLINE: By Ronald Reagan; Ronald Reagan, President from 1981 to 1989, heads the Reagan Center for Public Affairs.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Have you heard about the new White House "diet" plan? Maybe you've seen the Clinton Administration's television "infomercial" about this miraculous discovery. The diet is quite simple. You can eat anything you want, any time you want, as much as you want. It costs quite a bit more, but they guarantee you'll lose all the weight you want. The only catch is you won't see any weight loss for five years.
Does this diet make sense? Hardly! But it's about as logical as the deficit reduction scheme President Clinton is pitching. 
 The White House is flooding the airwaves in Washington, D.C., and several states with a slick television infomercial. Through this propaganda masterpiece, it is trying to persuade us to "feel good" and be "proud" about jacking up our taxes and feeding the insatiable Washington spending machine. It's time for the public to send a strong signal to the manipulators at the White House: "We won't be fooled."
The President's "wonder plan" could be cited for deceptive advertising by the Food and Drug Administration. Job-killing taxes come right away, and hazy spending cuts are on the distant horizon. The five-year plan will likely impede economic growth and not come near its claim of $500 billion in deficit reduction. And it will fall far short of its spending cut goal of $250 billion.
Every person in this country realizes the serious need to reduce the Federal deficit. There is no disagreement on this issue. But the tax-and-spend plan being shoved through Congress does not accomplish that goal. It is not a deficit reduction plan. It will only cause the deficit to increase and quite likely wreck any hopes for an economy recovery in the process.
But the White House feels that if it labels it a "deficit reduction plan" and talks as if it will reduce the deficit, somehow Congress will vote for it. And if the Clinton team beats the drum enough about what "political courage" it takes to vote for this "bold" plan, they feel they can make Congress feel good about it.
It has been more than five months since President Clinton's plan was presented to the public. And, as we have learned more about what's in it, public support for it has dropped like a rock. Virtually every economic indicator released since the public has had a chance to react to the plan has been negative. Consumer confidence is down. Despite lower interest rates in place from the last Administration, people are afraid to commit to purchasing homes. And, in poll after poll, Americans say more than ever before that our country is heading down the "wrong economic track."
When candidate Clinton promised to get this country moving, most Americans thought he meant forward. Instead, his Administration has gone backward on the economy, backward on reducing Government and backward on its promises.
All except one, perhaps. Candidate Clinton promised to "raise taxes on the people who did well in the 1980's." Since practically every American benefited from that era of low inflation and strong growth and since President Clinton wants to raise the taxes of nearly every citizen, I guess in a roundabout way this is a promise he's actually trying to keep.
He knows Americans have always been kind and generous. In war and peace, they have been willing to make great sacrifices to serve a greater good. Today, the White House is trying to appeal to this great quality by getting us to go along with the largest tax increase in the history of our country. But we shouldn't.
The fact is, there is no "greater good" in this plan. Despite the slick presentation, talented spin doctors and White House talking heads all over TV, the simple truth is that this plan is bad for America.
Recognizing their predicament, the bill's supporters have resorted to desperate arguments. I have heard from Democratic friends of the heavy pressure on the Democratic senators to vote for this bill because "the President has so much political capital invested in it" and a defeat would have "serious political conse- quences" for him. Since when does the political standing of any elected official count more than the well-being of our nation? Our economy is too important to be dealt this devastating blow because of White House fears about how a failure could make the President look.
His economic package was bad policy to start with and has only been further worsened by the myriad special-interest concessions added along the way. It is so flawed, the only reasonable alternative is to flatly reject it. Then, with a healthy dose of reality in mind, let the process start again. There is no "fine-tuning" or "refining" that can save this package.
The process must begin anew with real cuts in spending and a reduction in personal and business tax rates. The Democrats should be reminded that sharp reductions in tax rates created growth and prosperity in "our" 1980's and "their" 1960's.
Under the Clinton plan, people will be zapped with new taxes that take the incentive out of saving and investments (assuming they're left with any money to do so). Furthermore, the spending increases are a travesty. They just aren't needed and they are sure to dig us deeper in the deficit hole. Of course, there will always be new needs for Government spending, like Midwestern flood relief, but there are billions of dollars in various other Federal programs that can be redirected.
Over the years, I have been known as an optimist -- always believing that better days will lie ahead. But, right now, I have serious concerns about the future of America if this tax-and-spend plan becomes law. I fear for the loss of opportunities that Americans have always had to make better lives for themselves and their families. And I worry about America's place in the world if our economy falls into the deep doldrums that this program will certainly bring.
I urge each member of Congress to reject the White House pressure, refuse the special concessions the White House offers his or her constituents and stand firm in the face of special-interest lobbying. They should vote their conscience. Sometimes saying no can be a great act of statesmanship, not to mention a good way to start a sensible diet.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BILL: On the Fence;
Clinton Seeks 1 'Yes' Vote From 6 Unhappy Democrats

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
With Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma insisting he will change his vote and oppose the budget bill, President Clinton has to get at least one other unhappy Democrat to change his mind and support it.
Six Democrats voted against the Senate version of the bill in June, and with all of the chamber's 44 Republicans also in opposition, the measure passed only after Vice President Al Gore cast the tie-breaking vote. 
 The Republicans are still solid in their opposition, so the White House is looking to those six Democrats for the one vote it needs to counter Senator Boren's defection.
Most of the six have argued that no budget proposal emerging from the House-Senate conference would be likely to cut spending enough to win them over. And most also argue that it would raise taxes too much.
 
Clinton Lobbies 4 Senators
 President Clinton today sought to lobby four of the Democratic Senators indirectly, by giving interviews to editorial writers in their home states. But he left out representatives from the states of Senators Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, apparently regarding those two Senators as beyond redemption.
The bill's pain cuts most deeply for three of the six Senators who could be facing very difficult re-election campaigns next year: Mr. Lautenberg and Richard H. Bryan of Nevada and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona.
Mr. Shelby and the two other Senators do not face as early a test. But the two, Senators Bennett J. Johnston of Louisiana and Sam Nunn of Georgia, appear almost immovable as Mr. Shelby.
Senator Lautenberg, who held a news conference to announce that he would vote against the earlier bill, said recently it was "hard to imagine" that the bill would be sufficiently improved in conference to win his vote.
 
'More Taxes' Won't Help
 The two-term Senator said "both the House and Senate versions hit hard on middle-class New Jerseyans without creating the kind of economic growth and job expansion that we need."
Coming from a state where a political revolt against taxes swept Republicans to control of the Legislature in 1992, Mr. Lautenberg said: "New Jersey is really hurting. More taxes won't put people back to work or lift us out of the recession."
Mr. Lautenberg has not been particularly popular in his state and could suffer in next year's elections from the anti-Democratic sentiment prompted by Gov. Jim Florio's pushing through higher taxes in 1990.
New Jersey Republicans are waiting to see if former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a popular figure, will challenge Mr. Lautenberg in 1994.
Senator DeConcini, who comes from one of the nation's most conservative states, has objected to the absence of a specific provision guaranteeing that additional taxes will go to deficit reduction, not additional spending.
House-Senate Conferees and Administration officials have been discussing whether such a guarantee could be made by executive order, since Senate rules will apparently keep it out of the bill.
Senator Bryan has told the President he would offer no opinions until he can study the final compromise bill, a spokesman said. But he has felt that the original bill did not have enough spending cuts, and he was unhappy at the shift from a broad-based energy tax to a higher gasoline tax. Mr. Bryan also fears that further cuts in Medicare will hurt his constituents, who have complained of earlier cuts, the spokesman said.
 
Seeking More Cuts
 Senator Nunn has said he is leaning against the conference report but will study it before he decides. But he wanted a bill covering five years, not 10. And another complaint, that it was too light on spending cuts, seems unlikely to be much changed by the House-Senate conference.
Senator Johnston has told the President not to bother lobbying him until he has had a chance to study the result. He had originally opposed the bill because of its broad-based energy tax, but stayed opposed even when it was greatly reduced in the Senate. He said too much of the bill's deficit reduction came from tax increases and not enough from spending cuts.
Mr. Shelby, who has voted with Republicans all year long on economic issues, is also unhappy with the ratio of spending cuts to tax increases, a spokesman said. Senator Shelby has also voiced concern that most of the spending cuts come after 1996.
Of course, the Administration also has to worry that no other Democrats who once voted yes will join Mr. Boren, a model of vacillation on this issue all year, and desert the bill. For example, several senators have joined Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, in calling on the President to summon Congress to a 10-day special session to find more spending cuts.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 4, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Democratic senators who initially voted against the budget plan referred incorrectly to reservations that Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia has about the measure. He said he would prefer a bill covering 10 years, not five.

HEADLINE: Titan Lost Payload: Spy-Satellite System Worth $800 Million

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The explosion of a Titan IV rocket over the Pacific on Monday destroyed its secret payload, an $800 million spy-satellite system, wiping out most of the savings Congress took from the intelligence budget this year and damaging the nation's most expensive espionage program, Government and intelligence officials said today.
"Every penny we cut is gone," said a Senator who fought to cut an additional $700 million from the budget for spy-satellite programs requested by the Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey. The cost of replacing the destroyed system would exceed the savings wrung from Mr. Woolsey by the Congressional intelligence committees last month. 
 They said the highly classified system destroyed in the explosion consisted of a trio of solar-powered ocean-surveillance satellites, each about the size of a small car, used by the Navy to track foreign ships and listen to their communications.
Together, the satellites and the rocket cost at least $1 billion, making Monday's explosion the most costly space accident in monetary terms since the 1986 Challenger shuttle disaster. It will also cost the Central Intelligence Agency time and money as it struggles to rearrange programs to buy and launch new satellites, the most expensive intelligence-gathering systems in the world, Government and intelligence officials said.
They denied reports in the press that the rocket's cargo was an even more expensive satellite, code-named Lacrosse, that uses radar to take photographs from space.
Spy satellites now under development can cost up to $2 billion apiece. They cost so much because they are hand-made to exacting specifications -- like a two-ton Swiss watch -- and because they are built in absolute secrecy, requiring elaborate security measures.
 
Weighing the Value
 The new satellites, which can see through clouds and listen in on generals in bunkers, cost so much that Congressional intelligence committees and Mr. Woolsey spent hours behind closed doors this summer arguing fiercely over their future. In the end, Congress cut about $1.3 billion from Mr. Woolsey's $29 billion intelligence budget request.
The debate concerned the value of intelligence satellites over spies. While extraordinarily capable of tracking military movements, satellites cannot conduct conversations in bazaars, like a spy, or translate political broadsides or interpret economic data, like an intelligence analyst. And the cost of Monday's Titan IV explosion was roughly equal to the total annual pay of every spy and analyst at the C.I.A.
After the Challenger disaster, the nation's intelligence agencies relied solely on the Titan IV to launch satellites. But there will be no new launches of espionage equipment until the Air Force determines what went wrong with the rocket. The craft cost $200 million, according to the Air Force, though Congressional staff members say the figure is $360 million.
 
'A Catastrophic Failure'
 "I've got to ground the fleet," said Col. Frank Stirling, the Air Force's Titan IV program director. "I've got to understand what happened."
"We had a catastrophic failure," Colonel Stirling said. "The vehicle essentially blew up," 101 seconds after it was launched into a clear blue sky from Vandenberg Air Force Base, 140 miles northwest of Los Angeles.
The $10.4 billion Titan IV program was placed under review today by the Air Force, which has commissioned 41 of the rockets, more than half of which are completed or under construction. The contractor for the program is the Martin Marietta Corp., the largest aerospace electronics company in the world.
Colonel Stirling said the review could take several months. When the review is completed, the last remaining set of the ocean-surveillance satellites could be launched.
Monday's explosion and the suspension of new launchings may send shivers down the spine of the National Reconnaissance Office, the agency responsible for building and managing spy satellites.
 
Concerns at Agency
 "If I was at the N.R.O. or C.I.A., my first reaction would not be, 'Oh, my God, we've lost this vital ocean-surveillance capability,' but 'Oh, my God, we won't have any more launches until we find out what's wrong with Titan IV,' " said Jeffrey T. Richelson, author of "America's Secret Eyes in Space" (Harper & Row, 1990), one of the few authoritative books on spy satellites.
Tracking foreign navies has become a much less urgent intelligence mission since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Spy satellites that collect information over land are more vital to today's intelligence concerns, Government officials said.
Replacing the lost satellites would put some strain on the reconnaissance office's classified budget, which exceeds $6 billion -- more than three times the size of the State Department's budget and twice that of the C.I.A.'s. But debate over satellites is itself a strain for the office, because almost everything about it has been kept secret. As the office has become less arcane, Congressional overseers and independent analysts have become more aware of its shortcomings.

The Economy

HEADLINE: Trading Is Brisk as Dow Posts Small Gain

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Stocks closed narrowly mixed yesterday, with profit taking and concern about the economic recovery constraining the type of sharp upward movement that marked Monday's market.
Many investors had one eye on Washington, where the budget debate appeared to be moving toward a conclusion and the other on Europe, where Monday's agreement to widen the trading ranges for European Community currencies allowed the Exchange Rate Mechanism to survive -- at least in name. The currency turmoil is sparking another debate as to whether the decline in European interest rates will be beneficial for American companies. 
 "The market was trendless," said Robert Turner, chairman of Turner Investment Partners, a Philadelphia money-management firm. "People were waiting to hear how President Clinton would address the budget plan in the evening."
 
A Fractional Advance
 The Dow Jones industrial average inched up 0.28 point, to close at 3,561.27 and the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.35, to 709.01. But the Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks fell 0.88, to 449.27.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was strong, with 253.1 million shares traded. There were 1,051 advancing issues and 920 stocks that declined.
Adding to the day's uncertainty was the release by the Commerce Department of the June index of leading economic indicators, which predicts the rate of economic growth for the next six months. The index rose just a tenth of a percent; economists had predicted that it would grow three-tenths of a percent.
The announcement yesterday of an agreement between Unisys and Intel to develop a series of advanced parallel processing computers pushed the price of both stocks higher. Unisys, among the most active stocks on the Big Board, advanced 3/8, to 10 1/4, while Intel, traded on Nasdaq, increased 3/8, to 53.
As the floods in the Midwest seemed to be easing, Wall Street turned its attention to some pollution-control companies that might profit from the cleanup. Browning-Ferris was up 1 1/8, to 24 3/4, and WMX Technologies was up 3/4, to 31 5/8.
Winn-Dixie, the largest food retailer in the South, announced record earnings on Monday -- and above analysts' expectations -- for the fiscal year ended June 30, and the stock rose 1 7/8. Yesterday the price soared 3 7/8 to close at 62 3/4.
Prudential Insurance said it would sell the bulk of its shares in Dr Pepper/Seven-Up, which went public in February. As a result of the anticipated dilution of earnings, Dr Pepper declined 3/4, to 17 3/4.
U.S. Healthcare rebounded 7/8, to 48, after sinking 1 7/8 on Monday when the company requested a 6 percent rate increase in New York and some analysts called the request inadequate. Yesterday, other analysts noted that the company's market share gains would be an important factor in earnings growth.
Another provider of health plans, Oxford Health Plans, also advanced, gaining 1 3/4, to 78 1/2. Oxford announced plans for a 2-for-1 split.
Primerica gained 1, to 55, after the financial services corporation held ameeting with analysts on Monday. The financial services company, which last month reported earnings that surpassed most Wall Street forecasts, completed the acquisition of the brokerage and asset management operations of Shearson Lehman Brothers from American Express at the end of last week.

HEADLINE: As Colombia Oil Flow Spurts, So Do Worries About Money

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Oil has begun to flow from a large field with reserves estimated by British Petroleum at 1.5 billion barrels, and production is being accompanied by a lively debate in Colombia over what could be the nation's biggest economic bonanza ever.
Predictions vary from bright forecasts of prosperity to doomsday predictions of misspent funds, runaway inflation and wasted opportunities. 
 By 2000, Colombia could be exporting half a million barrels of crude oil a day from the field, at Cusiana, about 100 miles east of Bogota; current crude oil exports run about 200,000 barrels daily. The operating company is the British Petroleum Company, which has also surveyed a nearby field at Cupiagua, whose reserves B.P. estimates at half a billion barrels. The two fields are in Casanare Province.
The discovery has been described by B.P. and others as the largest in recent years in the Western Hemisphere; the last big find was the 10-billion-barrel reserve at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, in the 1970's.
 
The Companies Involved
 The field is being developed at a planned cost of $7 billion by B.P., the Triton Energy Corporation of Dallas (each of which have a 19 percent interest) and the Total group of France (which holds 12 percent). The state-owned oil company, Ecopetrol, holds 50 percent.
Earnings from Cusiana, which could start to pour in by 1996, could reach $2.5 billion a year by 2000, and finally total $14 billion.
One troubling unknown is the ongoing battle between guerrilla forces and the Government. The rebels have been terrorizing several rural areas for a decade, including the region around the new oil finds, and despite on-and-off peace talks, no let-up is in sight.
Many in the Government have compared Cusiana to winning a lottery: If the money is well spent, it will create prosperity; if not, the winner will eventually be poorer than at the start.
"This country is used to regarding bonanzas with terror," said Guillermo Fernandez de Soto, president of the Bogota Chamber of Commerce, which represents about 25 percent of the country's businesses. "This makes us unable to take full advantage of them."
 
Monetary Conservatism
 Colombia's monetary policies have been conservative compared with the rest of Latin America. The country has never experienced hyperinflation, and in the 1980's, it had one of the highest, most stable growth rates.
But earlier, in the mid-1970's, a coffee bonanza created an unusually large pool of international reserves held by the private sector, beyond the control of the Government, and as money poured in, the peso experienced a 30 percent rise against the dollar.
Now, many fear a similar experience with oil. A very strong peso could put exporters at a disadvantage as the Government opens up the economy.
"The money that Colombians have abroad is worth three or four times the money from Cusiana," warned an economist, Antonio Urdinola, the Colombian representative to the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean. "Because of expectations of revaluation, money may begin to pour in now, provoking more revaluation."
Should such funds return to Colombia, drawn by a boom economy and a stronger peso, the Government could set up a stabilization fund with the oil income it gets through Ecopetrol's 50 percent share in Cusiana. The Government would in effect buy up the excess money flowing back so that a sharp rise in the supply of money does not fuel inflation.
There is also disagreement on whether part of the oil money should be used to pay Colombia's $13.8 billion in foreign debts. "It is a good idea to pay the debt but that depends on what the cost is and how much money there is," Development Minister Luis Alberto Moreno said.
 
Fear of One-Legged Economy
 Others caution against what they call a petrolization of the economy, similar to that which struck Venezuela in the mid-1970's when oil prices soared. They warn that no oil bonanza lasts forever, and that once prosperity begins to dwindle, the ensuing economic hardship could pave the way for a political crisis.
Even if such concerns are unwarranted, as the optimists have asserted, any oil bonanza could put Colombia on uncertain ground.
"The estimated reserves are modest in comparison to those in nations such as Kuwait, so Colombia cannot go ahead and build an oil-dependent economy and let other industries lag," Mr. Urdinola said. "On the other hand, that bonanza is big enough to change Colombia's economic perspective."
Despite these concerns, most officials and independent experts conclude that the debate is a sign that the money from Cusiana will be wisely spent. There is already consensus that whatever money is not allotted to the stabilize the peso should be used to develop communication and transport systems.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The White House;
CLINTON PUSHES FOR BUDGET, REASSURING PUBLIC ON TAXES AND VOWING ECONOMIC GAINS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Declaring that "it would be irresponsible not to take decisive action" to reduce the budget deficit, President Clinton appealed to middle-class taxpayers tonight to support the economic plan that will face crucial votes in Congress this week.
"We're on the verge of breaking out of the old false choice between tax and spend and trickle down, between abandonment and entitlement," Mr. Clinton said. He brandished colored bar graphs to support his insistence that the plan is fair and includes genuine cuts in Federal spending. [Transcript of the President's address, page A14.] 
 The President, going over the heads of a reluctant Congress and appealing directly to the people, repeatedly emphasized that the burden of taxes in the budget would fall on the wealthy. Congressional negotiators reached agreement on the budget plan on Monday, but its fate is uncertain as it goes to a vote in both the House and the Senate.
The Republicans immediately struck back. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, appeared on television after the President's speech and criticized the budget compromise. [Excerpts, page A14.]
 
Fighting Hoarseness
 Mr. Clinton, occasionally fighting back hoarseness, appeared confident and optimistic during the 19-minute address to the nation, casting himself as a lone soldier fighting Washington gridlock to solve a problem he inherited when he took office. And he said there would be dire consequences if the plan did not pass.
"Now there are only two choices," he said. "Our plan or no plan."
Seated behind his desk in the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton portrayed his plan in historic terms, saying it had been decades since a President took action to break the economy out if its stagnation. He said he intended to "revive the American dream by restoring the American economy."
"No more something for nothing," Mr. Clinton said. "We're all in this together."
Mr. Clinton said he would sign two executive orders on Wednesday: one would require that all new taxes included in the package go toward reducing the deficit; the other would put controls on annual spending in Federal entitlement programs, something demanded by Democratic moderates who wanted deeper spending cuts.
This week's budget battle was only part of an agenda of change, he said. Holding a chart showing how his plan would gradually reduce the Federal budget deficit to about $202 billion a year from $285 billion this year, he said the welfare and health care systems must also be overhauled.
He vowed to end welfare "as we know it," and asserted, "If you want the deficit to go down to zero, as I think most of you do, we have got to challenge the health care system."
Senator Dole took aim at Mr. Clinton's use of statistics and portrayed the budget plan as emphasizing new taxes rather than spending cuts. Natural growth in the American economy would create more jobs over the next four years than the President promised through Congressional passage of the budget, he said.
Mr. Dole also contended that the Federal deficit would skyrocket in the three years after 1997.
The President, whose prime-time address was broadcast live by the networks, outlined a plan developed by his advisers to improve his political standing by emphasizing the battles to come.
Aware that the struggle to get the budget bill passed may leave him looking battered, at least to some voters, the President and his aides sought today to trumpet impending victory loudly enough to drown out naysayers.
As he prepared for this week's decisive House and Senate votes on the compromise, Mr. Clinton spent the day polishing and rehearsing his speech. He consulted with a small army of advisers, including Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; Leon E. Panetta, the President's budget director, and Robert E. Rubin, director of the National Economic Council.
Mr. Clinton also met with Gov. David Walters of Oklahoma, presumably in the hope of swinging the vote of Senator David L. Boren, a disaffected Democrat, and with reporters from Nevada, the home of Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Democrat who voted against the budget when it was before the Senate.
 
Themes to Promote
 In every venue, Mr. Clinton pounded home what he has settled on as the most persuasive elements of his plan: that it is fair and that it does a responsible job of reducing the deficit by a total of $496 billion over five years.
But neither in person nor on the telephone did the President appear to be playing bare-knuckled politics. Few, if any, threats flowed from the White House. Indeed, some undecided lawmakers privately expressed astonishment that Mr. Clinton had stopped short of bluntly demanding their votes.
Mr. Clinton's mood today was upbeat, in part because the rest of the day's events had helped him considerably. The Senate, in a spate of pre-recess activity, approved Mr. Clinton's nominations of Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court and Sheldon Hackney to head the National Endowment for the Humanities as well as passing his national service program. In addition, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved his nomination of Judge Louis B. Freeh to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
But the tense battle over the budget remained the central issue, and the President and his chief advisers began warning darkly of a cloudy economic future if the measure should fail.
 
Interest Rate Warning
 Mr. Rubin predicted that interest rates, which have dropped steadily in recent months, would rise if the deficit-reduction provisions of the bill were not enacted.
"I think you'd have a tremendous chill on the economy because I think consumers and business would simply feel that Government can't deal with its problems," he said.
Using blunt language and multicolored charts of the sort Ross Perot made popular in his televised talks in the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he was not out to punish the successful. But he asserted that more than 80 percent of the new taxes would be paid by families with incomes over $200,000. And twice he said that working families with incomes under $180,000 a year would not pay higher income taxes.
Older Americans, too, would not be expected to sacrifice unfairly, the President went on, promising that he would "not balance the budget on the backs of older Americans" while protecting the wealthy.
Displaying another chart, Mr. Clinton asserted that of every $10 in spending cuts and tax increases that will be raised by the plan, only $1 would come from higher taxes on the average American. He said $5 would come from spending cuts and $4 from taxes on those with incomes of more than $200,000.
Mr. Clinton also defended his plan as one that would generate jobs, particularly by providing tax incentives to small businesses that invest in new enterprises and research and development.
"This plan is fair, it's balanced and it will work," he said.
White House officials as well as House and Senate leaders have been confidently predicting that they have assembled the votes they need to pass the economic package now that various interest groups have been satisfied.
"Sure there have been some compromises," said one senior adviser, George Stephanopoulos, "But he has gotten the bulk of what he set out to do."
Some members of Congress, however, and even some in the Administration have complained of a President who does not deal sharply enough with his advisers and who, even at this late date, is acting too hesitantly.
 
Signs of Frustration
 "All this high-powered talent," one discouraged Administration official said after emerging from a strategy meeting. "I bet they argue for hours about how many angels can dance on the head of a pin."
White House officials insisted that they were taking no votes for granted, with Mr. Clinton courting individual members. At the same time, Mr. Clinton's political and polling advisers roamed the West Wing offices today, planning the evening's speech and plotting future action, including a meeting on Wednesday with House Democrats.
 
Economic Crisis
 "In the spring, we did not do as good a job as we might have in explaining and communicating what the plan is all about," said Mark Gearan, the White House communications director. "It is our belief that most Americans realize how deep and compelling an economic crisis this country is in, and they're willing to pay their fair share."
White House officials are hoping that by casting the impending vote in broad terms they will win the public opinion wars as well as the narrow victory the President needs. As the vote draws nearer, each day's statements become more apocalyptic.
"We're either going to do something to regain control of our own destiny, or we're going to let the economy continue to spin out of control, and we'll be helpless to influence it," Mr. Clinton told the Nevada reporters today. "So it's just a question of whether we're going to do this for the long run or not."

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Journal;
A Chain-Store Invasion Of the Proudly Quaint

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3

 BODY:
In this city of distinctive neighborhoods, none clings more proudly to its image than Chestnut Hill. Situated at the city's northwest corner, it has won designation as a national historic district, maintaining the rustic ambiance of generations past, when only the rumble of trolley cars pierced the quiet of a summer afternoon and most folks knew one another by first names.
At Chestnut Hill's commercial center, blocks of small, upscale, family-owned businesses with names like Little Nook Gift Shop and the Happy Butterfly line cobblestoned Germantown Avenue, some in stone buildings more than 200 years old. If any business owner needs help in deciding what color to paint a store, the Chestnut Hill Community Association will happily provide 29 pages of guidelines on how to "create visual harmony with the village character and ambiance of Germantown Avenue." 
 But troubled times have come to the avenue, and more than the trolleys, which still run on weekends, are making noise. Scores of residents have expressed sharp opposition to the plans of Kay-Bee Toys, a national chain, to open a store in the fall.
It has rented a storefront that had been occupied for nearly 50 years by a dress shop, which went out of business two years ago. In a campaign being played out largely in the pages of The Chestnut Hill Local, a weekly published by the community association, Kay-Bee's opponents have argued that chain stores belong in malls, not among the specialty shops that give the area its cachet.
More than a debate over what kind of signs Kay-Bee might place at the front of the store or whether it might sell chemistry sets or plastic rifles, the arguments reflect a community's effort to protect its identity against the backdrop of a sluggish national economy, the crime rates of adjacent neighborhoods and fears of an influx of people outside of Chestnut Hill's normal clientele.
"I've lived around Chestnut Hill all my life," said Gerry Romig, 55. "It's changing, and I'm not so sure it's for the better."
Mr. Romig and his wife, Judy, own the Wooden Train, a small store across the street from the Kay-Bee site that sells ageless toys like wooden trains and building blocks. He expressed ambivalence about Kay-Bee's opening a fourth store in Philadelphia among its 1,200 nationally, saying, "I could lose some business, but I also suspect Kay-Bee might bring some customers to us."
But Mr. Romig wondered about the long-term effects of national chains like Banana Republic, the Gap and the Limited, all of which have opened stores in Chestnut Hill over the last five years. Referring to a trendy men's store across the street that is owned by the Limited, he said: "There is probably nothing I would buy there. So who are the people buying those kinds of clothes? People normally not associated with Chestnut Hill. Those stores attract a different class of people."
Clee Coleman, who manages the Trolley Stop florist shop on Germantown Avenue, one of only a handful of businesses among Chestnut Hill's 120 stores owned or operated by blacks, was blunt in assessing the motives of chain-store opponents. "They don't want more blacks in the neighborhood," he said, a judgment that the community's civic leaders deny.
At opposite poles in the debate are Carol Dilks, a writer who has lived in Chestnut Hill for seven years, and Shirley Perch, a member of the partnership that owns the storefront.
Mrs. Dilks, who did not return several messages left on her answering machine, began a campaign to oppose Kay-Bee in May, shortly after the partnership agreed to rent the 5,000-square-foot property to the chain, based in Pittsfield, Mass.
In the July 1 issue of The Local, Mrs. Dilks asked people to think about what they wanted the area to be in 10 years. "The gap in quality between this store and the others on Germantown Avenue is big," she wrote. "It's glaring."
Mrs. Perch, who also lives in Chestnut Hill and whose family has owned the property since 1918, said she understood the opposition, in that a "fine store" like the dress shop that once occupied the storefront "represents a buffer against the breakdown of property values."
By last week, passions had subsided a bit. Mrs. Dilks and several other residents had met with Kay-Bee officials and won promises that the store would accommodate many of their concerns. But an editorial in The Local July 29 cheered the efforts of Mrs. Dilks and placed the ultimate responsibility for the future of Chestnut Hill on property owners. "In the future," The Local wrote, "they may look back and lament they fouled their nests, and the community as well."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shirley Perch, a member of a partnership that has rented space to a chain store in Philadelphia's Chestnut Hill district. (Sal DiMarco Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Supporter Of Holtzman Tied to a Loan

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A political supporter of Elizabeth Holtzman played an important role in a bank's decision to grant a $450,000 campaign loan last fall to Ms. Holtzman's Senate campaign, bank executives, campaign officials and others with firsthand knowledge of a city investigation into the loan say.
The supporter, James P. Murphy, a vice president at the Fleet Financial Group, is the chairman of the board of trustees of the City University of New York. He helped raise money for the Holtzman campaign during the summer of 1992 and was the first bank official the cash-starved campaign approached last August when it sought the loan, according to bank officials and aides to Ms. Holtzman, the City Comptroller since 1990. 
 The loan, made by Fleet Bank, a subsidiary of the financial group, has become the subject of a city investigation because seven months after it was granted, Fleet Securities, a sister company of the bank, was awarded a lucrative designation as an underwriter of city bonds on the strong recommendation of Ms. Holtzman's office.
 
Dinkins Took Action
 Mayor David N. Dinkins, who jointly chooses underwriters with the Comptroller, decided to cancel the bank's city underwriting status after news reports disclosed the existence of the loan.
Thomas L. Lavelle, a spokesman for the bank, said Mr. Murphy, who coordinates the bank's lobbying and municipal finance operations, referred the request from Holtzman campaign officials to a loan processing officer at the Long Island branch of the banking company.
He said Mr. Murphy "did not do the credit analysis, the underwriting or the approval of the loan."
But according to two people with knowledge of the city investigation into the loan, the Long Island bank executive, who has not been identified, initially was hesitant to approve the loan because it was to a political campaign. The executive consulted top executives at Fleet's headquarters in Rhode Island and in New York, including Mr. Murphy, and was told that nothing in the bank's guidelines prohibited political loans, those sources said.
Mr. Lavelle would not comment on whether Mr. Murphy was instrumental in that decision. He said the loan -- which carried a 7 percent interest rate and was secured by Ms. Holtzman's personal guarantee and future campaign receipts -- was processed by bank officers in New York and met the bank's lending criteria and the legal requirements under Federal election laws.
Campaign disclosure documents filed with the Federal Election Commission over the weekend show that the Holtzman campaign for the United States Senate still owes more than $255,000 of the debt and has not made any payments since February. The campaign also failed, Federal officials said, to file the required documents detailing arrangements that have been made with the bank for paying back the debt.
Aides to Ms. Holtzman said the campaign had paid back about $14,500 more in July.
Ms. Holtzman did not return telephone calls yesterday seeking comment. Her spokeswoman, Maerwydd McFarland, confirmed that Mr. Murphy was a fund-raiser for the campaign in 1992, but she said his role was peripheral. She said Mr. Murphy was one of about 300 committee members and had helped organize "one dismal fund-raiser."
She also said Ms. Holtzman did not know Mr. Murphy personally.
"He was not in any way an active fund-raiser," she said. "He was not in any way involved with the campaign or the decision making."
Mr. Murphy also did not respond to numerous telephone messages left at his office over the last week, including yesterday. A woman who identified herself as his secretary said Mr. Murphy was in Washington on a lobbying trip.
 
Co-Sponsor of Fund-Raiser
 Mr. Lavelle confirmed that Mr. Murphy was the co-sponsor of a fund-raiser for Ms. Holtzman in May 1992 and raised between $3,000 and $3,500. He said Mr. Murphy "does not recall being approached or providing consent" to be a member of the campaign's finance committee.
Mr. Murphy was hired by Fleet in 1989 after serving for 13 years as the executive vice president of the New York State Bankers Association, a banking lobby organization. His responsibilities at Fleet include lobbying city, state and Federal governments, husbanding special low-interest loan programs for housing that are mandated by Federal law and overseeing the bank's municipal finance business, including its bond underwriting operations.
In that role, Mr. Murphy is in charge of several lending programs and bond underwriting operations that have dealings with Ms. Holtzman's office. Apart from seeking to sell city bonds, Fleet is also currently a lender in at least two low-interest housing programs that involve city pension funds.
Ms. Holtzman, who as the City Comptroller is the manager of the city's pension funds, has considerable say over which banks are chosen to participate in the housing programs, but Fleet was chosen for the programs before she took office, city officials said.
Specifically, Fleet is a lender in the Project H.O.M.E. and the Red-Lined Neighborhood Aid programs, which use city pension funds to buy a portion of federally guaranteed mortgages issued by banks.
A Holtzman campaign official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Murphy had given $1,000 to Ms. Holtzman's 1989 campaign for comptroller and became a member of the campaign finance committee.
 
'Very Highly Regarded'
 A bank official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Murphy was hired because "he is very highly regarded in political circles." His main task, the official said, is to build good relations with local governments and to coordinate the bank's affordable-housing programs.
Ms. McFarland, the Comptroller's spokeswoman, said the campaign considered Mr. Murphy the logical person to approach about the loan because he was the bank's "government relations officer."
"That's the logical route for the request," she said. "His role was just as a liaison."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: Personal Finances;
For Well-Off, Tax Proposal Hits Home

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
To Marc Evans, the grass looks invitingly greener on the other side of the top tax bracket.
While Congress moves this week toward raising his taxes, Mr. Evans is planning to shut down his software consulting business, sell his house north of Boston, move back to his solid working-class roots in rural New England and maybe even repair Saabs for a living. 
 "Essentially, I am dropping out of society," Mr. Evans said when asked how the deficit-reduction legislation on which Congressional negotiators agreed Monday would affect him. "It's not worth it. The costs, mentally and to the family, of trying to maintain a high middle income is too much to pay at this point, given what the Government takes."
Mr. Evans and his family can scarcely be considered typical taxpayers, either in their financial condition -- their income is in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, and their net worth is far higher -- or in their reaction to the coming tax increases.
But they are not entirely atypical of those who would be touched most by the legislation. Of the $170 billion in new income taxes to be collected from 1993 through 1997, an estimated 80 percent would be paid by households with income exceeding $200,000 a year, according to Congressional tax aides.
The tax rate on the last dollar earned -- the so-called marginal tax rate -- would go from 31 percent to 36 percent for couples earning $140,000, and to 39.6 percent for those earning $250,000.
 
40 Percent Tax Rate
 When other tax provisions that would also affect the wealthy are added in -- an increase in the amount of income subject to Medicare taxes, for instance, and a phase-out in the eligibility for deductions and personal exemptions -- some taxpayers would be paying at a marginal rate in excess of 40 percent: $400 for each additional $1,000 they earn.
Further, the new rates, the phase-outs and most other tax provisions of the bill would be retroactive to Jan. 1.
Relatively little impact would be felt outside the highest tax brackets. The net income of the working poor would actually grow, through new subsidies, and the vast middle class would pay only increased taxes on gasoline and, in some cases, on Social Security benefits.
So the impact will be heaviest on people like Mr. Evans, whose reaction, although extraordinary, does help illustrate what experts have long said about large tax increases on the rich: that their financial behavior is likely to change when their taxes do.
 
One Family's Reaction
 Mr. Evans, who is just 30 years old, hacked at computers as a teen-ager and, without having gone to college, flourished as the sole proprietor of Synergytics, which provides computer services on contract. He said he would be giving up an annual income of $300,000 a year and aiming to earn perhaps a tenth of that. He can do so because he and his wife have no debts and have built a substantial nest egg. They have one child, 2 years old, and are expecting a second.
Mr. Evans's accountant, Michael Fetzner, said he was advising a less radical course: minimizing taxable income through the use of profit-sharing and retirement savings plans, accounting techniques and a change in investments. This is the kind of advice many upper-income taxpayers will hear if the bill becomes law.
"That's why he has an accountant," Mr. Fetzner said. "He's not really going to be hurt that badly."
But Mr. Evans insisted that he was absolutely set on his course.
Interviews with several other upper-income taxpayers and their accountants suggested that many would be changing their financial behavior, although perhaps not so strikingly as the Evanses. How they do so could greatly affect how much money the tax increases ultimately provide the Government, an issue disputed by economists of different ideologies.
Whether both spouses should work, whether savings should be put in tax-free bonds, whether to shelter investments in retirement accounts or instead pursue capital gains -- these and a myriad of other decisions are driven in part by taxes.
 
Benefits of House and Child
 Many accountants said they were urging people with teen-age children to shift income-producing investments to them, so that the income would be taxed at lower rates. This made sense for most wealthy people even under the old system, said Thomas Ochsenschlager, a tax partner at Grant Thornton. There also remains one of the most widely used tax breaks, deductions for mortgage interest payments.
But there are those who say that they can find few tax strategies that make sense, and that their only recourse is to work a little harder to maintain their financial status quo.
A doctor in Massachusetts, who discussed his situation on condition of anonymity, said tax changes were leaving him few loopholes. He said that he paid $76,000 in tuition for four children and that in his marginal tax bracket he would have to earn $150,000 in pretax income just to cover the tuition bills.
Like others interviewed, he said he believed that it was necessary to raise taxes, but he added, "I've never made so much money and had less."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Asked how he would handle the tax increases proposed in Congress, Marc Evans, a computer services entrepreneur in Pelham, N.H., said: "Essentially, I am dropping out of society. It's not worth it. The costs, mentally and to the family, of trying to maintain a high middle income is too much to pay at this point, given what the Government takes." (Paula Scully for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: Business Expenses;
Bill's Effect on Business and Industry Would Vary

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Corporations would feel the effects of the big budget-reconciliation bill in two ways: as it directly affects the taxes they pay, and as it affects the performance of the broader economy in the years ahead.
For example, large retailers would lose by paying a new top tax rate of 35 percent on corporate income, an increase of two percentage points over the current top rate. But they would also gain by being able to take advantage of a newly reinstated tax credit for hiring chronically unemployed workers. 
 And they would be watching to see how the big increases in taxes on the wealthiest consumers affected demand for products, especially during the Christmas season.
"The effect on consumption, and, from the retailer's point of view, sales, is probably of more concern than the direct impact of the tax bill on retailers," said Edward J. Abahoonie, a tax partner and retailing specialist at Coopers & Lybrand.
Retailers, like other big companies, would also face substantial amounts of paperwork as they refigured this year's taxes, and even last year's, since many provisions of the new bill are retroactive.
 
Luxury-Tax Refunds
 For example, customers who paid luxury taxes on furs and jewels in the first part of this year would now be allowed to claim refunds of those taxes, which the retailers collected. And the newly reinstated jobs tax credit could be retroactively claimed by corporations all the way back to July 1, 1992, when it expired.
For some corporations, relatively arcane provisions of the legislation might have considerable repercussions.
For example, provisions allowing companies with overseas subsidiaries to defer taxes on certain foreign earnings would be tightened, and a tax credit for companies with factories in Puerto Rico would be limited. Both could have important effects on companies with plants abroad and could lead to corporate reorganizations, according to David Benson, Coopers & Lybrand's international tax expert.The bill would have other effects on business. Companies would be required to use a 15-year schedule in depreciating intangible assets like customer lists, the first time a single schedule has been applied to such assets. There would be somewhat shorter write-off periods for a few categories of intangible assets, like purchased rights to service a mortgage.
Beginning next year, deductions would be denied for club dues and lobbying expenses and, in many cases, for the part of an executive's salary that exceeds $1 million a year.
And the bill would allow people actively engaged in the real estate business to deduct passive losses, a device that was one of the main shelters eliminated by the tax changes of 1986. To help pay for this, however, the depreciation schedule for commercial property would be extended to 39 years, from the 31 1/2 years provided under current law.
