HEADLINE: Europe's Turmoil Aids U.S. Banks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
As Europe's governments continue to wrestle over the fate of the ever-more-elusive dream of currency union, their actions have an unintended beneficiary: American banks. In the second quarter, the five largest New York banks and the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco reported combined revenues of $2.2 billion from trading, an all-time record. And if the volatile markets continue, the banks are positioned to best that record this quarter.
With profits shrinking from traditional corporate lending, the big banks saw trading as a way to cash in on the rapid growth of international investments by corporations, pension funds and mutual funds. So over the last few years, banks have built vast trading desks around the world, many with hundreds of traders sitting at banks of computer screens, rapidly barking prices for currencies and securities into their telephones.
 
 
Need to Change Positions
 Volatile markets, like those in Europe last week, force these investors to change their positions quickly to protect themselves against currency devaluations and interest rate shifts -- resulting in a flurry of profitable trading for the banks. 
 Trading is the most profitable business banks have. Indeed, the six top American banks split profits of more than $900 million for three months of trading activity, which represented more than 40 percent of their total profits, according to industry analysts. And the results were nearly as good for most of last year.
"It is a very rich market because there are lots of fundamental shifts in the market taking place," said Kelly Doherty, head of the global trading group at Bankers Trust, which now makes 80 percent of its profit from trading.
Banks have profited, Mr. Doherty said, not only because of the currency crisis, but also because interest rates are declining in Europe and Japan and because interest rates are gyrating on political uncertainty in the United States.
This money could not have come at a better time for banks. It is replenishing their capital, which had been depleted by waves of bad real estate loans. Moreover, the banks see their success in trading as an important stepping stone in their efforts to compete with Wall Street, where trading is closely tied to the more lucrative underwriting of securities.
Yet many investors worry that like other booms the trading bubble will eventually burst when the markets calm down. Then the banks will have to keep paying for their huge trading rooms with the ever declining profits from their traditional businesses. In the last three years, for example, J. P. Morgan & Company has doubled the size of its trading department to 2,000 people, who now generate about half the bank's profits, according to industry analysts.
This very success raises the question of whether the fate of the banking system is increasingly dependent on the payoff from gambling in a vast global casino. Many European central bankers and politicians have severely criticized the banks and other market participants as profiteering "speculators."
The banks, however, play not so much the gambler, but the casino itself. Trading, of course, entails risk, and many of the trades made by an active bank will lose money, sometimes a large amount.
 
Odds in the Banks' Favor
 But the odds are decidedly stacked in favor of the banks because of their ability to look at the hands of other players. Most of a bank's trades -- if not always most of the trading profits -- come from transactions with its customers rather than from speculation on the markets. These customers can range from companies that have to bring home their foreign profits to mutual funds that make international investments. But it is information from these trades that allows the bank to profit from its own positions.
In theory, the bank profits from the "spread," the difference between the price a bank's trader pays for a currency or a security and what the trader sells it at. With some smaller customers or those in remote areas that cannot or do not shop around for price quotes, the spread can be quite high. For example, Citicorp had trading revenues of $572 million for the second quarter, a record for any American bank, in large part because its enormous network of 70 trading rooms, which do business in 117 currencies, reaches more of these customers than any one else.
 
Tiny Bets
 But for larger customers in most markets, the spread has become very small. And the bulk of the trading profits of a bank comes from making tiny bets while managing its position. Because the traders can talk to customers and see the patterns in their decisions, they can decide whether to get out of a position right away or to hold it for a short time.
"We keep positions open for several minutes to several hours," said Michael G. J. Davis, the deputy head of Chase Manhattan Corporation's risk management department. "Being a market maker gives you a fast read on the way the market is going."
Beyond the short-term positions they take while dealing with customers, banks also have a separate -- and often more profitable -- business in what they call "proprietary trading," which involves somewhat longer-term positions taken for the bank's own account. Sometimes these are naked bets that an interest rate or currency will move in a particular direction. Often they are betting that the relationship between two rates will change in a particular way.
In these trades, the banks are competing with investors ranging from large international bond mutual funds and short-term speculative hedge funds. But proprietary traders who sit at desks where they can overhear colleagues doing business with customers have an edge.
 
Comfort in Reading the Market
 "Trading has a lot to do with comfort," Mr. Doherty said. "We have intimate knowledge of small ebbs and flows in the market. When you feel like you know what's going on, it gives you confidence."
 Most banks are shy about talking about their proprietary trading in part because investors do not see it as a stable and reliable source of earnings and thus penalize the stock of companies that engage in it.
For that reason, the Chemical Banking Corporation will not allow proprietary trading to grow beyond 20 percent of its trading profits, even though it has stepped up its proprietary trading since its merger last year with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, said Donald H. Layton, who runs the trading business.
J. P. Morgan, however, is expanding. "Morgan has always been very, very strong in proprietary trading," said Peter L. Woicke, the co-head of Morgan's trading group. "Market making for customers has not become more important than proprietary trading, but the proportion has increased over the last two or three years."
Another reason that banks are keen on doing business with customers is to sell them new derivative products, which are far more profitable to trade than simple currencies and securities. Derivatives are customized contracts that let corporations and investors modify the risks of their positions. For example, Chase Manhattan recently sold a large option to a European contractor involved in building the new Hong Kong airport that wanted protection against a potential drop in the Hong Kong dollar.
"When markets get more volatile, customers start to demand insurance policies against some forms of their risk," Chase's Mr. Davis said. "If you offer a product that is more finely tuned to what they need, they will pay more for it."
While derivatives are designed to appear simple to the customer, the bank must hedge its risk in offering the contracts through a computer-generated series of offsetting trades. A number of regulators and central bankers have worried that this hedging process can get so complicated that a bank may have substantial losses.
Indeed, while derivatives have yet to prove any more risky than other instruments, some banks have made costly mistakes in trading. For example, J. P. Morgan lost more than $50 million last year trading mortgage-backed securities. But that loss is minor in comparison with Morgan's $959 million in trading revenue last year and total profit of $1.4 billion.
 
Higher Return and Lower Risk
 Trading, however, offers banks a far higher return with lower risk than most traditional bank lending. And to some observers, the risks from trading are even decreasing.
"The banks are not making as many big mistakes as they did several years ago because more and more of them are using sophisticated quantitative methods to control the risk they take," said William Ferrell, the head of Ferrell Capital Management, which runs a fund that invests in proprietary trading.
The biggest question is whether the current lucrative trading environment will continue. If it does not, the banks will have fallen into the same trap that often snares Wall Street brokers who expand during bull markets only to be dragged down by bloated costs during the inevitable bear markets.
The banks' biggest fear would be a long period of calm and stability in the markets, which would lull companies and investors into slowing their trading activities. "The worst thing for us is a marketplace where nothing happens," Mr. Davis said.
But the bankers believe that investors will continue to move money across borders and that politicians will continue to provide reasons to shift those investments around.
"If you tell me that economic policy, fiscal policy and monetary policy will be perfectly coordinated on a global basis, I'll tell you we have to make a business shift," said Marcus Meier, the co-head of Morgan's trading group. "I continue not to see that."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE;
Excerpts From Republican Response to President's Address

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Republican response to President Clinton's address, delivered by the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, as recorded by the Federal News Service:
The President just told you about his economic plan, and a number of other plans. And he's asked for your support. Many of us in Congress, including some Democrats, oppose the plan. And let me get right to the point and tell you why. We oppose this plan because it takes America in the wrong direction, because we believe by working together we can do much better, much, much better for you and all other Americans. 
 Now, we hear lots of so-called experts full of facts and a lot of fancy charts, and we've seen some this evening. You'll see a lot in the next 48 hours before the voting starts. And as you wade through all of the numbers and promises, keep in mind that passage of this bill will effect your job, your business, your family and your retirement.
So, ask yourself four questions. And the answers to these questions are not my opinions, they are the facts.
The first question is, does President Clinton's plan increase taxes? And the answer is an emphatic yes. Yes to the tune of $260 billion in increased taxes and fees. One of my Democratic colleagues stated that this plan is not just the largest tax increase in American history, but the largest tax increase in world history.
But the President says the tax increases will only punish upper-income Americans, as if that was something to celebrate. Well, he's wrong. Under his plan, millions of you, who might think you were a member of the middle class, will be paying more in taxes. Two- career families, more that 800,000 small businesses, over five million senior citizens and millions of others will soon be sending more hard-earned dollars to Washington.
And what really bothers me is that President Clinton and the Democrats in Congress are so anxious to raise your taxes, they've made the income tax increase effective Jan. 1, 1993. That's right. You heard it right, Jan. 1, 1993, 20 days before President Clinton even got to the White House.
President Clinton says his plan is historic, and he's right. Never before in American history has the Government increased tax rates retroactively. And by doing so, President Clinton is telling millions of individuals and small-business men and women who have been paying their income taxes at the current rate that what you've sent in the past seven months is not enough; you must pay more, a lot, lot more. In some cases, at least a 67 percent increase in income taxes for the balance of the year, and that's just five months.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Now, some taxpayers have told me that they'd be willing to pay a little more in taxes to reduce the deficit, if Government would just cut spending first. So, the second question is, does the President's plan reduce government spending? And the answer is, no, not really. The President's plan does not eliminate a single Federal program. It does not tell Government bureaucrats to spend less money. It says, "Government programs will be increased, but the increase will not be quite as big as expected.
 
Spending Cuts Urged

Now, keep in mind, again, that the tax increase in the President's plan started seven months ago -- Jan. 1, 1993. But the so-called spending cuts are only promised for some time in the future. In fact, 80 percent of those promised spending cuts won't occur, if at all, until after the next Presidential election in 1996.
Now, Republicans and some Democrats in Congress heard the message you sent us last November. You wanted us to cut spending first -- and we had a plan to do just that. It was a good plan. We tried to eliminate the President's requested tax increases. We tried to make real cuts in Government spending. But, unfortunately, the President and the liberal Democrats in Congress defeated all of these proposals.
The third question you should ask is, does the President's plan help put Americans back to work? And the answer is, no -- N.O. -- No.
Back in January, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office told us that if Congress did not do anything, if we did not pass any economic package, our economy would create 9.4 million new jobs over the next four years. President Clinton now says that his plan will create perhaps 8 million jobs -- new jobs over the next four years. In effect, by passing the President's plan, we could lose 1.4 million jobs.
So, if you're a restaurant worker in Nevada or a small-business man or woman in Wisconsin, an aerospace worker in California, a defense worker in Georgia, a family farmer in Nebraska, an insurance salesman in Connecticut, an engineer in Alabama, or even a senior citizen in Arizona -- look out. The Clinton plan is bad news for you and all other Americans. It's bad for your job and bad for your families.
Still, despite all of this, there may be a few -- just a few -- out there who are saying, "So what if my taxes are increased? So what if more jobs would be created if we did nothing? If this plan reduces the deficit, then I will support it." Well, I share your concern, and have said for many years and have backed it up with tough votes, that reducing the national deficit must be our No. 1 priority.
So, the fourth question is, does the President's plan reduce the deficit? Unfortunately, for America's future and the future of our children and grandchildren, the answer is no. Yes, President Clinton's massive tax increases will drop the deficit from $285 billion this year to an estimated $202 billion in 1997. But just three years after that -- just three years after that, most analysts project that the deficit will skyrocket to well over $350 billion.
And, by the way, don't be fooled by what the President just said about his so-called deficit reduction trust fund. Members of the President's own economic team dismissed this as a gimmick, and the director of the Congressional Budget Office has testified that this trust fund will not reduce the deficit by one dime. So, don't be fooled by this gimmick.

 	 	 		. . .	 	So, my fellow Americans, contrary to what some may be saying, the world will not end if this bill is defeated. In fact, defeating this bill will mark not an end, but a new beginning -- an opportunity to begin again and to agree upon a new plan, a better plan, and a plan that truly moves America in the right direction.
I want to join the President in wishing our best and saying we're going to cooperate in a non-partisan way with all of those who've been affected by the flood in the 10 Midwestern states. And I would say to all of you who are listening: pay attention to this plan. It will affect your life and it will affect your future.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Bob Dole preparing his response to President Clinton's address. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MIDWEST FLOODING;
Floods, and Fear of Them, Disrupt Tourist Industry

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 31

 BODY:
Compared with other tourist destinations along the rivers of the upper Midwest, St. Joseph is one of the lucky ones. Although its industrial south side was inundated and a flooded water-treatment plant left 85,000 residents without drinking water for five days, the historic sites that draw up to 250,000 visitors a year to this city were untouched.
Burlington, Iowa, suffered extensive flood damage to its tourist attractions, including historic buildings and a municipal auditorium. And vast stretches of Katy Trail State Park in Missouri, a 200-mile hiking and bicycle trail between St. Charles and Sedalia, were flooded by the rampaging Missouri River, which the trail parallels for most of its length. 
 While few tourist sites in the region have been washed away, the overall devastation has disrupted tourism by cutting off transportation and utilities and generally frightening people away. And tourism officials fear that the images of disaster will linger long after the waters subside, postponing the revival.
 
Staying Away in Droves
 "I'm surprised anyone at all came," said Katherine Wilder, working behind the reception desk at the Jesse James Home in this Missouri River city. As she spoke, a lone visitor examined the one-story white frame cottage where the outlaw was killed by one of his gang members in 1882.
It is equally bad around the corner at the Patee House Museum, once the headquarters of the Pony Express, which ran between St. Joseph and Sacramento, Calif.
"We should be getting 175 to 200 people a day, but we're getting 17, 14," said Gary Chilcote, the director of the nonprofit museum. "If we don't make it this time of year, we won't be able to meet our expenses."
At the nearby ice cream parlor, housed in the replica of a Japanese tea house, not one customer had appeared all day.
All up and down the swollen rivers of the Midwest, similar stories are being told.
In Des Moines, 61 of the city's 65 hotels were closed for several days because they lacked electricity and clean water for guests. In St. Louis, sightseeing buses stood empty, waiting for tourists who never showed up. And in riverfront towns all along the Mississippi and the Missouri, excursion boats were beached when those rivers were closed to traffic.
 
Extent of the Damage
 There are no estimates of the overall damage to tourism. In Illinois, where tourism is a $15 billion industry employing about 250,000 people, officials hesitate even to hazard a guess about the extent of the damage.
"About 24 of our 102 counties are affected," said Donna Shaw, the director of the Illinois Bureau of Tourism. "And in the flooded western part of the state, where tourism is their economic lifeline, it's down at least 70 percent."
But the officials say there is simply no way to assess not only the financial impact but also the social impact when heavy rains saturated grounds and forced Nauvoo, Ill., to cancel the City of Joseph Pageant this week, a Mormon commemoration that usually attracts 100,000 spectators every August. Or how civic pride may suffer from the cancellation of this year's charity baseball game at the field near Dyersville, Iowa, that has become a tourist mecca since it became the scene of the 1989 movie "Field of Dreams."
"People still show up here," said Jacque Rahe, director of the Dyersville Chamber of Commerce. "But a lot of group tours have canceled out even though the worst we had was a stream across home plate for two days that swept a couple of Port-a-Potties away."
 
Woeful Grasp of Geography
 Inevitably, perhaps, residents throughout the flood areas accuse their countrymen of having a woeful grasp of geography.
That may be one reason traffic is down even in the Ozark Mountains, where the water problem is not a surfeit of rain but a lack of it.
"Traffic at our R.V. park has slowed to a trickle," said Mae Nobert, manager of the Dorwood Valley recreational vehicle park in Mansfield, a city of 1,500 people in south-central Missouri. "Once people heard about floods in Missouri, we started getting cancellations from all over."
Even the Ozark town of Branson, Mo., a center of country-western music and perhaps the nation's fastest growing tourist destination in recent years, has felt the effects of the flood.
"We've lost a lot of bus tours," said John Bowers, executive director of the Branson Chamber of Commerce, "because many of them go on to Hannibal or St. Louis, and the perception is that both cities are under water."
Misconceptions are not confined to Americans. "We get international calls asking if the bridges in Chicago are under water," said Ms. Shaw, the Illinois tourism director, "and we have to explain, 'No, Chicago is 200 kilometers from the floods.' "
 
Few Strangers in Hannibal
 Hannibal, Mo., the Mississippi River port and boyhood home of Mark Twain, is another city long on tourist attractions but short on visitors. "We had a party and nobody came," lamented Dick McHargue, a board member of Hannibal's Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Tourism is off 80 percent in Hannibal, Mr. McHargue said. "I can document 1,200 canceled reservations" at the Molly Brown Dinner Theater since mid-July, he added. "Restaurants, motels -- everything's hurting."
While most Interstates and major highways in the nation's heartland remain open, many bridges are out or have been closed.
The Mississippi rose so high that the Mississippi Queen, one of the few remaining overnight paddlewheel steamboats in the United States, could not pass under the bridges at St. Louis. So, even before the river was closed to traffic, three of the steamboat's cruises were rerouted to the Ohio, Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers. Her sister ship, the Delta Queen, also changed schedules for each of the four cruises scheduled this month.
But not all tourist spots in the Midwest have suffered from the floods. Some hotels, for example, lost tourists but were filled with relief workers and camera crews.
"We never missed a beat," said Gary Inks, vice president of sales and marketing for Jumer's Casino in Rock Island, Ill. "Even though we received a tremendous number of cancellations at first, the President riverboat in Davenport had to shut down for two weeks, because of flood waters, so we got a lot of their regular customers on our boat."
 
Wet Sense of Humor
 All the states in the region, as well as many cities and counties, have established toll-free "flood hot lines" with updated information about road conditions and flooding.
And in an attempt to salvage something, anything, from the remaining days of summer, states and cities that only recently attracted legions of tourists are planning advertising campaigns that they hope will at least bring individual travelers.
Some of the proposed ads indicate that whatever else Midwesterners may have lost in the floods, a sense of humor was not one of them.
Des Moines, for example, which went 12 days without drinking water but had plenty from the skies and rivers, has been toying with the slogan, "Come on in, the water's fine." And Hannibal, according to Mr. McHargue of the Visitors Bureau, is considering using the slogan, "High, Dry and Open."

HEADLINE: Turkey Loses Its Allure as a Patron in Central Asian Nations

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey

 BODY:
When the cold war ended and the remote Soviet fiefs of Central Asia became independent states, an idea emerged here and in Washington that Turkey should expand its role from bulwark of the Western alliance to patron of emerging nations stretching east to the Chinese border.
The idea had instant allure for many Turks, reviving forgotten dreams of pan-Turkic influence among distant Muslim kin awaiting a march toward Western prosperity. For the United States, facing the prospect of ever more complex nationalist strife abroad as Soviet power crumbled, Turkey seemed a reliable proxy to fill the Central Asian vacuum. 
 These days, that dream appears to be fading.
Facing its own economic troubles recently, this nation of 60 million has been unable to provide the aid to cement its influence over the region, Western diplomats say. Its diplomacy has been hesitant, reflecting a deep fear of being drawn into Central Asia's ethnic strife. Only now are its policy makers acknowledging how difficult the region's ethnic and political crosscurrents can be.
 
Strains in the Caucacus
 While Turkey has carefully avoided disputes with Russia, diplomats also worry that Ankara may end up at loggerheads with Moscow in the Caucasus, a region rich in oil where their historical rivalry has led to wars in centuries past.
Most of all, the chaos in Azerbaijan -- the centerpiece of Turkey's regional aspirations -- has exposed Ankara's reluctance to act as an aggressive patron, still less a protector. Its protege in Baku, Abulfaz Elchibey, has been overthrown, devaluing Turkey's influence in the eyes of countries farther east.
"Azerbaijan was the model to show what would happen in the future," said Nur Batur, the diplomatic editor of the Istanbul daily Milliyet. "Now they will be much more distant."
A Western diplomat said: "A couple of years ago, it was possible to talk of Turkey being the patron of Central Asia, but the results have been different. If they can't do it in Azerbaijan, who thinks Turkey is going to be a major player in other places?"
While Turkish Government officials dispute such conclusions, they have begun to scale back their assessment of what Ankara can do or should be expected to do in a region where many speak Turkish and supposedly strive for Turkey's brand of secular democracy but have not forgotten more recent ties to Moscow.
"It is not up to Turkey to play the role of regional superpower," said Ozdem Samberk, a high-ranking Foreign Ministry official in Ankara. "Turkey's effort was to help Azerbaijan make a soft landing after the collapse of Communism. In no way was Turkey claiming that we were pretending to run the country."
President Suleyman Demirel, who has been faulted for his caution in diplomacy, said, "If anything happens in these countries, why should Turks be responsible?"
Developments in the Caucasus region have also shown the limits of Turkey's influence in an area where history and faith anchor its appeal to Muslim lands.
Its effort to mediate in the territorial dispute between Azerbaijan and predominantly Christian Armenia, for instance, has faltered. Some Azerbaijanis have accused Turkey of selling them out by supplying electric power to Armenia this year when Azerbaijan was trying to squeeze the Armenian economy through a fuel blockade, Ms. Batur said.
 
Oil Could Be the Spark
 Government officials and diplomats also speculate that disputes are likely to surface between Turkey and Russia over the single issue that may end up at the center of the regional struggle: oil.
A source of cheap oil during Soviet rule, Azerbaijan is now viewed as one of the world's last major untapped reserves. When the Soviet Union collapsed in December 1991, Azerbaijan was one of the few components that declined to join the Commonwealth of Independent States. As American and British oil companies sought exploration deals in Azerbaijan, talk turned to shipping the oil out through a pipeline running through Turkey.
The problem was getting the Azerbaijani oil into Turkey so it could link up with the pipeline that carried Iraqi oil to the Mediterranean before the United Nations embargo severed Baghdad's outlets. American oil companies did not like the idea of their oil passing through revolutionary Iran. But how secure could a pipeline through the Caucasus be while Armenia and Azerbaijan were at war? The answer, diplomats here said, was to build spurs through both areas and link them up in Turkey.
As negotiations on the 660-mile pipeline progressed, however, Mr. Elchibey was overthrown. The timing stirred suspicions among diplomats and commentators here -- echoed by Mr Elchibey -- that Russia was somehow behind it all.
In the 19th century, the Russian and Ottoman empires collided in the contest for influence in the region. Such historical considerations clearly figure in the caution being shown by Turkey.
"Turkey's policy is not to look back to history but to the future," Mr. Samberk said. "We would like to put these old demons away, not provoke them."

HEADLINE: Reluctant Politician Dives Into Haiti's 'Hot Water'

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 3

 BODY:
With the passage of more than a month since he was asked in private by Haiti's exiled President to be his new prime minister, Robert Malval, has had plenty of time to contemplate the state of politics here.
Asked what he had discovered as he awaits approval of his nomination by a stalled and bickering National Assembly and is petitioned expectantly by all manner of supporters of the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Mr. Malval, a businessman who had shied from politics in the past, quickly pronounced two words: "Tough. Vicious." 
 The assessment at once captured two realities, one about Haiti, the other about the man whose daunting assigned task is to guide the hemisphere's poorest and least stable country through its internationally assisted return to democratic government.
 
An Interim Leader
 The first is that Mr. Malval is a profoundly reluctant public figure who has accepted the job only on the condition, which he calls nonnegotiable, that he will play a strictly transitional role and will be replaced by a new prime minister by Dec. 15.
The other is that as Haiti's political and economic elites reluctantly await Father Aristide's return as President, scheduled for Oct. 31, many of the same bleak realities, from the intrigue and power contests, both petty and grand, to the stark class divides that led to the military coup in the first place remain intact.
Perhaps because of the scope of the challenge before him, Mr. Malval, a 50-year-old who has built his printing business, Le Natal, from scratch in 1976 to become one of the country's most successful medium-sized enterprises, states his goals simply.
"We are not a political bunch or a gang, my family," he said in a recent interview in his offices, speaking in an accent-free English polished as an undergraduate at the University of Miami.
 
'Jump in the Hot Water'
 "But we have always had a dream, and that is the creation of a state where rights are respected. I never wanted this job at all, but finally decided that if I had to jump in the hot water to achieve that, it was worth it."
Even before he can be sworn in, however, Mr. Malval has received a taste of just how hot the water can be. His selection has been the target of sniping behind the scenes by many among the leftist President's disparate backers who have complained that he is too light-skinned and too wealthy.
He has also been criticized for not being a professional politician, a trait he shares with Father Aristide, and as the imposed choice of Washington, a notion that all concerned dismiss as ridiculous.
For his part, Mr. Malval readily acknowledges the division of opinions about him, but with characteristic modesty, adds that the critics will eventually accept him "because the main criterion is that they know that I am the President's real choice."
 
Key Role in Talks
 The most visible public sign of the President's confidence came during United Nations-led negotiations on Haiti's future in New York last month during which Mr. Malval clearly eclipsed a number of better-known figures among Father Aristide's advisers.
Another source of tension has been the composition of a new Government. Impatience among the President's supporters for a return to public life after nearly two years of exile and frustration has been running high, and competition for a limited number of jobs has been fierce.
The resulting government, not yet announced, but already well known within political circles here, is composed of people considered close to the President, ideologically or personally, and not ministers necessarily chosen for their technical qualities or with a thought to creating a broader political consensus.
"The thing is Lavalas times Lavalas plus Lavalas," an official said, reflecting a common perception in among diplomats that Father Aristide has again drawn too heavily upon members or close sympathizers of his political movement, known as Lavalas. "It is a catastrophe that risks repeating all of the mistakes of the past."
 
Overthrow of Aristide
 Father Aristide was overthrown by soldiers in a violent coup in September 1991, after his style of governance, tightly reliant on an inner circle of trusted friends, had alienated many on the country's political scene, including one-time allies.
Mr. Malval, who himself became friends with Father Aristide in 1986, when he published some pamphlets for the priest, has earned respect from many for his forthrightness, including a willingness to express disagreement firmly with the ousted President.
Told of the controversy about the new government, Mr. Malval said the concerns of diplomats and others, though understandable, were misplaced.
"In 1991 we had a Government of friends of the President," he said in an interview a day before flying to Washington to meet with Father Aristide for the final time before a vote on his ratification, which is expected soon. "Now we have the political allies of the President, what I would call the a small concord.
"When the President is actually back in Haiti, he has made clear that we will then have a government of large concord. In the meantime, there is major job to be done."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Malval, Haiti's Prime Minister-designate. (Daniel Morel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: Strategy;
Short One Vote in the Senate, Clinton Allies Prowl the Hill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
One vote short; four days to find it.
With that premise, the White House and senior Democrats abandoned most pretenses of finesse today and began beating the halls of Congress, searching for the single Democrat who might give President Clinton's budget package a winning margin in the Senate. 
 By day's end, they appeared to have located him. He is Senator Dennis DeConcini, an Arizonan who opposed the $500 billion package of taxes and spending cuts when the Senate voted on its version of the proposal in June.
"I think we've got him," a senior Democratic leader in the Senate said this afternoon. "If we haven't got him, there is no bill."
For his part, Mr. DeConcini was adamantly, insistently, noncommital. "I'm not ready for any interviews," he called out, not even turning his head, to a reporter who pursued him into an off-limits corridor deep inside the Capitol.
 
Clinton Reaches Out
 Reaching out to Senator DeConcini, President Clinton mentioned him in his White House address tonight, praising his proposed amendment to create a deficit-reduction trust fund.
Mr. Clinton said he would sign an executive order on Wednesday requiring that all new taxes included in the package go to deficit reduction.
Mr. DeConcini faces both a difficult re-election race next year and intense pressure back home to oppose the compromise version of the budget measure that House and Senate negotiators reached on Monday.
To swing him around, the negotiators reduced the number of affluent retirees who would owe higher taxes on their Social Security benefits. Arizona has a lot of well-off pensioners.
A top Administration official insisted today that Mr. DeConcini had not sought that prize, and that it had not been explicitly offered to him. Regardless, his purported willingness to cast his lot with the President is the bright spot for Democrats in what otherwise looks like a desperate hunt for votes. Indeed, Senate leaders say, Mr. DeConcini appears to be among the White House's last hopes.
All 44 Republicans and 7 Democrats, including Mr. DeConcini, are on record as opposing some version of the budget package, leaving the Democrats with but 49 votes in the 100-member Senate. Mr. Clinton has to convert at least one dissenter, giving him a tie that Vice President Al Gore could break -- if no further Democrats defect.
 
Counting the Noses
 Today, two of the seven rebel Democrats, Senators Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, said they would oppose the budget measure when it reached the Senate, probably on Friday. And the veteran Senate Democrat who offered the prediction on Mr. DeConcini said that three others -- David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Richard H. Bryan of Nevada and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama -- appeared beyond reach.
That leaves only Mr. DeConcini and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia as potential converts, and hopes of drawing Mr. Nunn into the coalition appear slim.
As if that were not enough, other Senate Democrats who supported the package in June showed signs of disaffection. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, who has groused that the bill does not do enough for small business, refused to declare himself an outright supporter today.
Potentially more ominous was the silence of Nebraska's junior Senator, Bob Kerrey, who has called for a special session of Congress to address the spending cuts that he says Mr. Clinton's budget package sidesteps.
 
Leaning Which Way?
 Mr. Kerrey was not talking to reporters today. Two senior Democrats who have talked with him had different opinions on his stance.
Steve Ricchetti, the White House's top Senate lobbyist, said: "He hasn't said yes. He hasn't said no. We're still working on him."
With Mr. Clinton's reputation and a five-year, $500 billion package of taxes and spending cuts on the line, the Democrats began throwing themselves and anything else they could find into an effort to win over new support.
The President spoke on national television tonight trying to rally grass-roots support, and he planned an early-morning visit to House Democrats on Wednesday.
 
Take Nothing for Granted
 Some conservative Democratic representatives, led by Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, have indicated that they will switch sides and vote against the bill this time to protest the 4.3-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax that the negotiators agreed to. Mr. Stenholm voted for the bill last time.
The White House and Democrats in Congress expressed confidence, nonetheless. "We would have a problem in the House if we ever made the mistake of taking it for granted," said Mr. Clinton's chief lobbyist, Howard Paster. "We don't take it for granted."
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, made the same point, saying, "We're confident; we're not complacent."
The Senate's majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, was outwardly just as confident. "We're going to have the votes when the bill comes before the Senate, and we're going to pass it," he said.
 
The Most Affluent
 Democratic senators and representatives emphasized that higher income taxes would be owed by only the most affluent 1.2 percent of taxpayers, and that families with incomes below $30,000 would pay lower taxes because of an expansion in the earned-income tax credit.
Effective this year, the top income tax rate, now 31 percent, would be raised to 36 percent for single people on their taxable incomes from $115,000 to $250,000 and for couples on their taxable incomes from $140,000 to $250,000. The new rate would be 39.6 percent on taxable income above $250,000. Fewer than two million of the nation's 115 million taxpayers would be affected.
Taxable income is what is left after deductions and personal exemptions are subtracted from adjusted gross income. A couple with a taxable income of $140,000, for instance, generally has a total income of about $180,000.
Democrats called the expansion of the earned-income tax credit, which reduces taxes and in some cases pays rebates to poor and lower-middle-income workers, the most important antipoverty measure in years.
 
The Childless Poor
 The maximum annual credit for a working couple with two children would be $3,554. For a couple with one child, it would be $2,050. This is the benefit the President has said was designed to make certain that no one with children who worked full time would have incomes below the official poverty line, defined in 1991 as a yearly income of $11,140 for a family of three.
At least some benefit under the tax credit would be available to workers with two children and incomes up to $27,000 and those with one child and incomes up to $23,760. But the size of the benefit would diminish with each dollar earned after $11,000 a year.
For the first time, childless poor people would be entitled to a small credit. The maximum would be $300 a year, and some benefit would be available to childless workers with incomes below $9,000 a year.
Congressional staff members estimate that 18 million people would qualify for the tax credit, six million more than now qualify for a less generous credit.
 
Affecting Some Retirees
 Higher income taxes would also be owed by 5.4 million affluent retirees, who would be required to pay taxes on up to 85 percent of their Social Security benefits, instead of 50 percent as they do now. Single retirees with incomes (including half their Social Security benefits) above $34,000 and couples with incomes above $44,000 would be affected. Thirteen percent of all Social Security beneficiaries would owe the higher taxes.
For weeks now, Democrats have tried to conceal those and other provisions from public scrutiny, lest lobbyists and angry voters generate pressure. Today, they changed strategy, a propaganda offensive that cast the compromise package as the nation's best and last hope, at least for a while, of getting the Government under control.
The locations of the battle fronts betrayed their strategy. The Democratic National Committee ran television advertisements in the states of Senators Boren, Nunn, Bryan, Kerrey and DeConcini, as well as in Washington.
The White House budget director, Leon E. Panetta, presented himself to Mr. DeConcini's home-state press for interviews. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has all but moved in with Senator Nunn, one Administration official said, and other Cabinet secretaries have been dispatched to the same roster of battleground states.
The President himself courted Mr. Boren's business and political friends today and met by satellite with the press from Mr. DeConcini's state. He also wooed Senator Bryan and others, not for the first time.
"I'm very fond of the President personally; he's very effective," said Senator Bryan, who was called by Mr. Clinton this morning, a change from the usual Oval Office visit.
 
'Tired of the Food'
 "Everybody's been down there so much, they're tired of the food," one Democrat, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, said of Mr. Clinton's shuttle diplomacy between the White House and Congress.
Whether they wanted it or not, some Democrats like Mr. DeConcini also have gotten sweeteners in the budget measure intended to make it easier for them to vote for the package.
The hope, said one senior Administration official who demanded anonymity, is that Presidential carrots and public-relations sticks will soften the political opposition enough to convince at least one senator that it is safe to change his mind.
"All they need, if they're in a mind to vote with you, is to give them a difference with the first time around," that official said. "It gives them a legitimate way to go back to the folks at home and say, 'I couldn't vote for the bill before, but I got this or that fixed for you, and now I think it's important to lower the deficit.' "

He listened to testimony at a Senate Judiciary committee on assault weapons yesterday in Washington. At right was Senator Paul Simon. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A16)

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2808 words

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE;
Transcript of the President's Address on the Budget Compromise

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's address to the nation last night from the Oval Office, as recorded by The New York Times:
Good evening. 
 Tonight, I want to report to you on the progress we've made, and to ask for your help on our nation's most urgent priority: reviving the American dream by restoring the American economy.
It's been at least 30 years since a President has asked Americans to take personal responsibility for our country's future. It's been 25 years since our Government had a balanced budget. For at least 20 years, middle-class incomes have been nearly stagnant, with too many Americans working nights, weekends and holidays just to make ends meet.
For at least 10 years, costs in our health care system have exploded while millions of Americans go to bed each night worrying that if they lost their jobs or their children get sick their health insurance will be taken away.
And for the last several years, our economy has failed to generate jobs, good jobs that pay enough to own a home, buy a car, pay the bills, educate your children and retire with dignity.
For too long our Government has failed to tackle these problems. We've been given the politics of entitlement, Government handouts without asking anything in return. And we've been given the politics of abandonment: cutting taxes on the well-off and asking nothing of them in return either, while raising taxes on the middle class to pay more for the same government, instead of investing in our jobs and our future.
The results: fewer jobs, stagnant income, a massive debt for ourselves and our children, higher costs and greater insecurity in health care and a host of problems simply neglected.
 
Call for Responsibility

Well, tonight we're on the verge of breaking out of that old false choice between tax and spend, and trickle down, between abandonment and entitlement, on the verge of a new way of doing things grounded in our most enduring values, a philosophy that says America owes all of us an opportunity if we'll assume responsibility for ourselves, our communities and our country. No more something for nothing; we're all in this together.
This means we must make Government work for the people who pay the bills.
All of us have been awed in the last few weeks by the vast power of the Mississippi River breaking its banks and the devastation that has followed. But we've also been awed by the courage of the flood victims and the compassion of other Americans who have joined them in fighting back the waters and trying to restore normal life. I'm especially proud that this time the Federal Government has been fighting alongside the people.
That is what we must do on all fronts. We must do more, much more, to turn this country around, and now we have the chance to change. We're on the eve of historic action.
This week Congress will cast a crucial vote on my plan for economic recovery. In a comprehensive economic plan there are always places for give and take. But from the first day to this day, I have stood firm on certain ideas and ideals that are at the heart of this plan. Tonight I can report to you that every one of those principles is contained in the final version of the plan.
First, the largest deficit reduction in history -- nearly $500 billion -- with more spending cuts than tax increases. Rather than the games and gimmicks of the past, this plan has 200 specific spending cuts and it reduces Government spending by more than $250 billion. We cut more than 100,000 positions from the Federal payroll by attrition, we freeze discretionary spending for five years, we limit pay increases for Federal employees.
Why must we take extraordinary action now?
Well this chart shows you why. America faces a choice: We can continue on the path of higher deficits and lower growth, or we can make a fundamental change to improve our nation's economy by adopting my economic plan.
Now it won't be easy and it won't be quick, but it is necessary. Without deficit reduction we can't have sustained economic growth.
Economists and business leaders alike warn us that growth will falter if we don't take dramatic steps to tame this deficit and soon. With so much at stake, it would be irresponsible not to take decisive action. With this plan in place, the economy will grow and more than eight million new jobs will be created in the next four years. Without it, we put the economy and our standard of living at further risk. If we take this important first step now, over the long run we will see deficits go down and jobs go up.
The second principle of this plan is fairness: those who have the most contribute the most. As this chart shows, we asked the well-off to pay their fair share, requiring that at least 80 percent of the new tax burden fall on those making more than $200,000 a year and very little on any other Americans, not to punish the successful but simply to ask something of the very people whose incomes went up most and whose taxes went down during the 1980's.
For working families making less than $180,000 a year there will be no income tax increase. I repeat, for working families making less than $180,000 a year there will be no income tax increase.
The third principle is that we must protect older Americans from punitive cuts in Social Security, Medicare and veterans' benefits that some have proposed.
While all Americans must do their part, I will not balance the budget on the backs of older Americans while protecting the wealthy. Every alternative offered by the opponents of change begins with deep cuts in the health care of older Americans.
I believe we must build a better future for our children without sacrificing the security of their grandparents. We can control health care costs, but only by reforming the health care system, not simply by hurting the elderly.
The fourth principle is that we must keep faith with the hard-working middle-class families who are the heart and strength of our nation. We worked hard on this plan to insure the lowest possible tax on the middle class.
The plan asked an average working family to pay no more than $3 a month in new taxes, less than a dime a day, with a 4.3-cent-a-gallon increase in the gas tax. This is the only new tax working people will pay.
Let me be plain about where the deficit reduction comes from. Look at this chart. Out of every $10 in deficit reduction, $5 -- and actually a little more -- comes from spending cuts; $4 comes from taxes on incomes of those with more than $200,000 a year in income; and just $1 comes from everyone else.
This plan is fair. It's balanced. And it will work.
Finally, we must have an economy that creates jobs and lifts up the American people. In the past, deficit reduction efforts have failed because they neglected incentives for business growth and investments to make Americans smarter and stronger and safer.
 
Incentives for Business

This plan is very different. It generates jobs. In fact, over 90 percent of the small businesses in this whole country are eligible for tax reductions, tax cuts, if they invest in their future and create new jobs. If you have the courage to invest in a new business and the vision to hold that investment for five years, this plan will cut your capital gains tax in half. If your business invests in research and development, this plan will reward you. If your small business creates new jobs and buys new equipment, this plan will provide incentives for growth by nearly doubling the expensing provision for new investments.
While we make deep cuts in spending, we also make room for some needed investments. Our plan invests in people and makes special investments in our children and our families through Head Start, nutrition for pregnant mothers and immunizations for poor children. These things pay for themselves in healthy growing strong children. We will revolutionize the student loan program so that all Americans can better afford to finance a college education and we make bold changes in worker training so that high school graduates can get high-skill, high-wage jobs.
Perhaps most important, this plan rewards work over welfare by lifting out of poverty every parent with children at home who chooses full-time work over lifetime welfare. We do this through the earned-income tax credit, which reduces taxes for 20 million working families and households earning less than $27,000 a year. It does this without creating a new government bureaucracy and simply using the tax code.
This sends an enormously powerful message to the people who struggle against great odds to raise themselves and their families. It empowers them; it says we're on the side of people who work and care about their children. It's pro-work, it's pro-family and it is a critical first step to one of my most important priorities: ending welfare as we know it.
Every element of this plan is a departure from business as usual, and if there's anything our country needs, it's to put business as usual out of business.
I know full well that Americans are very skeptical of any claim by the government. You must wonder if these cuts are for real and whether the taxes will really be used to pay down the deficit. Well, our plan is fundamentally different from business as usual. Here's why:
First, the plan is based on conservative estimates of future revenues. It presents line-by-line, year-by-year specific cuts in government spending. And it offers new incentives so we can expand the economy and generate jobs.
It minimizes the burden on the middle class and asks the wealthy to pay their fair share.
And, finally, it puts into place two clear safeguards to keep a watchful eye on future Federal spending while protecting the savings produced by this plan.
All the money we save will be locked away in a deficit-reduction trust fund so the savings will not be spent on politicians' pet projects. Because some in the Senate have used technicalities to block Senator DeConcini's amendment to create the deficit reduction trust fund and frustrated the efforts of many other Senators and a clear majority of the House of Representatives who support it and who support controls on annual spending and entitlement programs, I will sign executive orders tomorrow putting both these safeguards in place so that you know the money must be spent on deficit reduction. And if we miss our deficit-reduction targets over the next five years, I will be obliged to present a plan to correct the course to make sure we keep doing what we're telling we're going to do. Now this is a new direction.
 
Effect on Interest Rates

This plan has been carefully examined by the most conservative and skeptical critics of all, those who run our nation's financial markets. They've studied the plan and determined that over the long term, paying down the deficit will be good for the country. And as we have made progress in enacting this plan, the markets have lowered interest rates. Lower interest rates, in turn, make it easier to own a home, finance a business, buy a car, pay off credit cards and borrow for college. For example, if you're a middle-class family with a $100,000 mortgage at 10 percent interest, you should be able to refinance the mortgage today down to 7.5 percent and save $175 a month right away as millions of Americans have already done.
The chief executive officers of 80 of our country's most successful companies, Republicans and Democrats alike, have also supported this plan. So do many small business organizations from the National Small Business United and the National Association of the Self Employed to the National Venture Capital Association. The men and women whose business it is to create jobs and growth have been solid in their support of this historic endeavor.
At this exceptional moment of promise, why are so many in Washington so reluctant to take action? Why is it so hard for so many in this city to break the bad habits of the past and take the steps we all know we have to take?
For five months, our critics had the chance to offer alternatives. And all the major plans came up with the same thing: less deficit reduction or more pain for older Americans, or both; protections for the wealthy from paying their fair share of the taxes, and no new incentives for business to create jobs or investments in the American people.
And every one of these alternatives was soundly rejected in the Congress. Now there are only two choices: our plan or no plan. Our opponents want to bring the plan down; the guardians of gridlock will do anything to preserve the status quo, to serve special interests and to drag this thing out.
They practice partisanship when we need progress. They call for delay when we've been waiting for 12 years, and working on this project for months. They talk and talk about what to do instead of doing what must be done.
When I was the Governor of Arkansas, our state had one of the lowest tax burdens in the country. I inherited this big Federal deficit just like you did, and I don't like taxes any more than you do. But our nation is in economic danger, and now we've got to take this problem we inherited -- you and I -- and do something about it. We have to take responsibility for change.
Passing this plan will be a bold step and the first step on a longer journey toward giving our nation a comprehensive national economic strategy. This economic strategy begins with putting our house in order, but it cannot end there.
We must also have the courage to reform our health care system so never again will a family be denied health care or a business be bankrupted by health care costs. Let me show you this first chart one more time.
If you look at this deficit, under our plan we can bring the debt down solidly for five years. If you want the deficit to go down to zero -- as I think almost all of you do -- we have got to challenge the health care system. It is bankrupting the private sector, bankrupting the public sector and millions of Americans live in insecurity and constant fear of losing their health care. So dealing with health care is good for the economy, good for bringing the deficit down further and good for the American people.
We also have to end welfare as we know it. We can move millions of idle Americans off the welfare rolls and onto the work rolls if we'll change the system.
And we've got to revolutionize government itself, cleaning out waste, corruption; bringing state-of-the-art management that will give more savings to the taxpayers, have government work better and put it back in charge of the people who are paying the bill. And we must continue to work to open foreign markets to create American jobs.
All of these things come together to form an economic strategy that will give opportunity to every American and ask responsibility from every American.
But we can't take any of the steps if we don't take the first step.
That's why the decision Congress must make this week is so terribly important. We cannot afford not to act.
I need your help. I need for you to tell the people's representatives to get on with the people's business.
Tell them to change the direction of the economy -- and do it now -- so that we can start growing again, producing jobs again, and moving our country forward again.
 
Previous Successes

In the last six months, we won some important battles here. A new family and medical-leave law just taking effect that allows young parents to take time off to care of a new baby or a sick child or an ill parent without losing their jobs. A new national service corps that will help tens of thousands of our young people to pay for college through service to their country in their communities. A new Supreme Court Justice confirmed just today without partisanship or rancor.
New policies to develop high-technology jobs and to convert defense facilities and plants to productive civilian purposes, expanding jobs and opportunity.
And, from a summit in Vancouver, Canada, to help save Russian democracy; to a summit in Tokyo to help revive the world economy, there are now new opportunities for Americans and a new respect for America's leadership.
We Americans are a people both privileged and challenged. We were formed in turbulent times and we stand now at the beginning of a new time -- the dawn of a new era. Our deeds and decisions can lift America up so that in our third century we will continue to be the youngest and most optimistic of nations -- a people on the march once again, strong and unafraid.
If we are bold in our hopes, if we meet our great responsibilities, we will give the country we love the best years it has ever known.
Good night and may God bless you all on this journey.

HEADLINE: Those Who Live by the Air-Conditioner;
A Day of (Electric Bill) Reckoning Comes Along With More Heat

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
None of the 90 windows in Peter Obletz's single-story building in Manhattan has been open since the temperature surged past 90 last month, so no one heard Mr. Obletz groan when the electric bill came. Thirty days of round-the-clock air-conditioning cost him $552.82, $190 more than in the windows-open-in-the-evening month of June.
"You pay for what you get," said Mr. Obletz, a transportation consultant. "We got cool." 
 Another heat wave has arrived just as New Yorkers are discovering the legacy of the last round of high temperatures: high utility bills.
The temperature yesterday climbed to 94 degrees in Central Park, two degrees short of a record. But from Sea Cliff, L.I., to Sea Bright, N.J., people with air-conditioner knobs that go to 10 wished for 11. Some wondered if they would feel any cooler if they taped little ribbons over the vent where the not-cool-enough air comes out.
Others remembered the line in James Agee's "Knoxville: Summer of 1915" about the time of evening when people sit on their porches, rocking gently and talking gently. In Knoxville yesterday, in the summer of 1993, the temperature was only 85. But in sweltering Manhattan, the problem with sitting on the porch or the front stoop or the high-rise balcony -- and trying to carry on a conversation -- was that hum. "You expect a nice, quiet summer night," said Gail J. Franck, a Manhattan consultant. "Instead, you get the dull roar of all the air conditioners."
And customers get big bills. In one household on the Upper West Side, the Con Edison bill brought an unexpected memory of the weekend the couple left the steamy, sweaty city behind -- and left the air-conditioner on. For the cats, of course. The bill for July came to $138.70, $63 more than for June.
In other apartments where air-conditioning is a must, not a maybe, the added cost was, pardon the expression, no sweat. Andy Cahill, a talent agent in Manhattan, said the bill for her two bedrooms was $100 in July, $20 more than in June.
"This is money well spent," she said. "My business is detail work and listening carefully. If I'm exhausted and hot, I can't do contracts because I start making mistakes."
She has been hot a lot. The National Weather Service said that so far this year, there have been 29 days of temperatures of 90 or above: one in May, five in June, 20 in July and two in August. The July figure smashed the mark of 17 days of 90-plus readings, set in 1944.
The figures on how much electricity was used in the hottest July on record are not in yet. Con Edison said it would not have the total until Thursday. Elaine Davis, a spokeswoman for the Long Island Lighting Company, said demand yesterday afternoon was 3,550 megawatts, below the record-setting 3,970-megawatt day July 9 but still above average.
And in Connecticut, power companies said they were not straining. The United Illuminating Company, which serves New Haven, Bridgeport and 17 towns in between, said they could handle the demand because so many manufacturing customers had left the area in the recession.
 
Living by the Thermostat
 Conservation may also make a difference. Millie Stempa, the owner of a restaurant in Great Neck, L.I., said she turns the lights off and the air-conditioning down between 3:30 and 5 P.M. every day. "When the dinner crowd starts arriving," she said, "I turn the A.C. up again."
Milt Caffyn of Eatontown, N.J., installed timers on his central air-conditioning system: on at 3 P.M., a couple of hours before he and his wife get home from work, and off at 7 A.M., shortly before they leave. Even so, his wife estimated that they pay up to $200 a month for electricity when all the appliances are running, about $50 more than in cooler weather.
But Bob DeSimone has no gizmos in his house. He makes his living repairing air-conditioners, but at home, "we go back to basics." In other words, fans.
"They work great," he said.
Better, apparently, than his customers' compressors. He said his workload doubled in July.
"I am flooded with calls," he said. "People are complaining that their units are malfunctioning. The problem is people go season to season and never bother to call their air-conditioning people to do maintenance on their system. The system malfunctions; it breaks down. Usually it will trip a circuit breaker or blow a fuse."
 
By Degrees and Dollars
 Mr. Obletz said he had changed the filter a dozen times in the last six weeks and had done his supposedly once-a-year maintenance twice, checking the belts, hosing out the condenser, lubricating the fan bearings.
"It's a life-support system," he said. "If it's anything above 72 outside, I'll turn on the air-conditioning. In the evenings, it used to be possible to open the windows if I was working late. I used to keep them open until about 11."
Now his time-controlled thermostat goes into cryogenic mode at 9 A.M. At 2 A.M., about the time Mr. Obletz usually stops working for the night, it raises the temperature by 8 degrees. "I can live with that," he said.
The bill, with its chart showing month-by-month usage, was harder. "The little bar graph on the bill went down, down, down," he said, "and then whoops, it jumped way up."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Stuck in the snarl of Manhattan traffic, air-conditioning for Peter Kaczynski, left, and his mates at Ideal Fire Control Company was as remote as an easy drive through the Garment District. Their only relief was to open the windows. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond at a Low of 6.52%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year bond neared 6.50 percent briefly yesterday but the buying lost some of its momentum in the afternoon. Yet the yield still ended at 6.52 percent, a 16-year low for the yield on the 30-year bond.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 15/32 of a point as the yield fell from 6.55 percent Monday. The yields on other Treasury notes followed the same volatile pattern to end the day down. But they are still above the lows reached for this year. 
 The yield on the 10-year note dropped to 5.79 percent, from 5.83 percent Monday, with the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rising 9/32 of a point. The yield is still well above the 5.69 percent hit on July 16.
The yield on the two-year Treasury note fell to 4.15 percent, from 4.18 percent the day before, but it is still above the 3.71 percent reached on April 22 and the 3.67 percent touched last Oct. 5. The price of the two-year note rose 2/32 of a point.
 
Yields Near Lowest Levels
 A volatile market seems to be the order of the day recently, with yields at or near their lowest levels in decades and the economic outlook still uncertain. The wait for the vote in Congress on the President's deficit reduction plan is adding a special dose of concern this week.
All it took was a minuscule one-tenth of a percent increase in the Government's index of leading economic indicators to set the buying off this morning. Then rumors of Democratic defections that could sink the reduction plan in the Senate erased some gains in the afternoon. Some traders were also disappointed when the Federal Reserve, as some analysts had predicted, did not buy some Treasury notes as part of its regular market operations.
Since the Commerce Department report last week that the nation's economy grew at a paltry annual rate of 1.6 percent in the second quarter, the bond market has rallied on the belief that continued slow growth will assure that inflation will not become a problem soon. In addition, short-term maturities have been helped by the view that the Federal Reserve would not move to raise interest rates with the economy still so weak.
But themes change quickly in this market. Just the week before this current rise in Treasury prices, there was a selloff after the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, convinced investors that the economy would be stronger than expected in the second quarter and that the next move by the Federal Reserve would be to raise short-term interest rates to counter any inflationary pressures.
Now, investors could get some new data within the next two weeks that could again suggest the reverse: that the economy is a little stronger than the meager growth rate for the first half of the year indicates. In other words, the market may still be on a seesaw.
On Friday, the Labor Department releases the employment report for July. It is expected to show a growth in nonfarm payroll jobs of 185,000 jobs, according to the consensus forecast of Bloomberg Business News. But if the increase is much higher, investors could decide to sell with the market already at such high price and low yield levels.
On the following Friday comes the Consumer Price Index for last month, with the Bloomberg consensus increase at one-tenth of a percent. But some forecasts are at three-tenths of a percent, which could be more worrisome if the employment report is also stronger than expected.
 
Municipal Bonds
 The municipal-bond market was flooded with more than $3 billion of new bonds yesterday and could soon surpass its record of new issues set last year.
According to the Securities Data Company, new issues totaled $169.1 billion through July, up from $129.6 billion through July of last year, an increase of 30.4 percent. In all of 1992, new issues reached a record total of $234 billion.
Of the total of new issues this year, $111.3 billion, or 66 percent, were for refunding outstanding bonds as states, cities and towns took advantage of interest rates now at their lowest levels in decades.
But while the new issues are on a pace to set a record, the selling appears to have slowed in the last several months. In July, new issues totaled $21.9 billion, with 755 separate issues, down from $30.2 billion and 1,334 issues in June and $28.3 billion and 1,236 issues in May. April was just a bit lower than July at $21.8 billion while March came in at $29.7 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Economic and Trade Fears Broadly Depress the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar sank to one more postwar low against the yen yesterday amid concern about Japan's trade surplus with the United States. Weak American economic data and a gradual return of calm in the European Monetary System depressed the dollar against European currencies, too.
The dollar fell at one point to 104 yen in Tokyo trading, dropping below the 104.05 yen level in New York on Monday. But it bounced back slightly in New York late yesterday, where it was quoted at 104.42 yen, up from 104.37 yen late Monday. And despite rounds of purchases by the Bank of Japan, the dollar fell in Tokyo to 104.35 yen, from 104.61 on Monday. 
 "The market is pricing in Japan's current account" surplus data, to be reported today, said Lars Pederson, international economist at Chemical Securities in New York. The surplus, a measure dominated by foreign trade, is expected to widen to $11 billion from $9.36 billion a year ago. That might spur American demands for a stronger yen to lessen exports by Japan while increasing imports, currency dealers said.
 
More Bad News
 The dollar was set back when the Commerce Department reported in Washington yesterday that leading economic indicators in June rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, less than had been expected by many forecasters.
"Since there are no strong U.S. figures, there's no strong incentive to buy dollars," said Ryuichi Shimokawa, foreign exchange manager at Sumitomo Bank in New York.
"The market is basically long dollars," said Jim Phoenix, a dealer at Canadian International Bank of Commerce. "There's still some unwinding of safe haven positions" built up in the dollar as money has recently been withdrawn from European currencies' dropping against the dollar, the yen and the German mark. Rebounds by the dollar only produced selling by European central banks' seeking to replenish funds that had been spent to support the weak currencies.
The dollar was up for a short time against the mark yesterday after the German central bank lowered its 14-day repurchase rate to 6.80 percent from 6.95 percent. But in late New York trading, it fell to 1.7065 marks, from 1.7085 marks on Monday.
The British pound rose to $1.5015 in New York, from $1.5040 on Monday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Declines as Platinum Gains on Labor Unrest Talk

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold and silver prices sagged yesterday as confusion in the European currency markets subsided. Platinum futures, meanwhile, rallied on talk of a strike against a large South African producer.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery fell $2.50, to $403.40 an ounce; December gold, the most actively traded contract, fell $2.60, to $407.60. And September silver tumbled 7.3 cents, to $5.385 an ounce. 
 Gold rose more than $13 an ounce last week after the German central bank decided not to cut a key lending rate. The move set off a rash of speculation in weaker European currencies and drove investors to gold as a safe haven.
On Monday, European officials loosened exchange-rate constraints and yesterday the German central bank lowered a short-term interest rate. The moves helped to quiet the European currency markets.
"It's taken away an important short-term prop from the gold market," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metal trading for the Swiss bank Credit Suisse in New York, said the gold market appeared to consolidating recent gains in preparation for another upward move. "Gold is back in fashion with a lot of investors because of the mistrust in currencies now," he said.
October platinum, meanwhile, rose $1.60 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $424.70 an ounce on hazy reports of a strike against Impala Platinum, the second-largest South African producer of the metal.
On other commodity markets, energy futures slipped. Light sweet crude oil for September delivery fell 12 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $17.85 a barrel.
