HEADLINE: Index of Leading Indicators Was Up a Scant 0.1% in June

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The Government's main forecasting gauge barely inched up in June, and its decline in May was slightly larger than had originally been estimated, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.
The index of leading indicators, which is supposed to offer a six-to-nine-month look ahead at the economy, rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in June. May's decline was four-tenths of 1 percent, not the three-tenths of 1 percent originally reported. 
 The gain in the index was less than expected; many forecasters had anticipated a gain of two-tenths or three-tenths of 1 percent.
Investors took the so-so report as another sign that the economy would remain relatively weak in the second half of the year, so they bought bonds and sold stocks and dollars. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ended at 6.52 percent, a new 16-year low, after dropping as low as 6.50 percent earlier in the day.
 
More Momentum Possible
 But some economists, while acknowledging that the economy was growing at a modest pace, said that other recent data suggested more momentum than the index of leading indicators seemed to reflect.
"Growth won't be robust, but it should be in the 2.5 percent to 3 percent range or even higher" for the second half of 1993, said David Mullins, vice chairman at the Federal Reserve Board. Growth in the first half of the year averaged 1.2 percent.
The index, a compilation of 11 forward-looking indicators of economic activity, from consumer expectations to new building permits, was slightly lower in June than it was last December but still well above most of last year.
Six of the components rose and five fell. A drop in first-time unemployment claims, higher stock prices and a big jump in orders for new equipment and contracts for business construction helped push the index up slightly.
At the same time, though, factory orders for long-lasting goods, a portent of future production, got a lot thinner and the time it takes businesses to fill orders, a sign of how busy factories are, shrank.
Most economists say the leading indicators are of limited use.
"The index really tells us June was a sluggish month, which we already knew," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "But it doesn't tell us much about how the rest of the year will develop."
The economy, he said, has been doing better than it looks on the surface. Consumers and businesses, despite their sour moods, spent briskly during the spring. The main reason the economy grew at a sluggish 1.7 percent annual rate was that business cut inventory growth sharply.
What's more, car and truck production is scheduled to rise sharply this month, and that could lift sales for a host of businesses that supply Detroit. And construction spending, which sagged in the spring, may turn up. Builders started enough new projects in the last three months to lead to sizable gains in construction outlays in the third quarter. In addition, mortgage applications, a forward-looking indicator of home building, jumped in July.
"The economy is going to look stronger in the second half than in the first half, even though the leading indicators aren't alerting us to that possibility" Mr. Steinberg said.
The economy added nearly a million jobs in the first half of the year, more than in all of 1992.
"Adding jobs, along with these other factors, has to reduce the downside risk," Mr. Mullins said, noting that Friday's report on jobs for July would shed more light on how strong or weak the economy is.
Some supply-side economists have been predicting that raising the top marginal income-tax rate for high-income Americans could stop the economy dead in its tracks. But other economists dismiss that possibility.
"Most people aren't going to see their taxes change," Mr. Steinberg said. "It's not clear that the Government will increase withholding taxes from paychecks this year."
Besides, he added, whatever the effects on the economy, they are more apt to show up next year.
The Government's index of coincident indicators, which is meant to measure current, rather than future, activity, fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in June, after rising by the same amount in May.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

DATELINE: McMINNVILLE, Ore.

 BODY:
E ACH week's mail brings notice of yet another wine conference. Or wine symposium. Or judging. Or festival. Few of these gatherings seem to concern themselves with the simple enjoyment of wine -- which is why I routinely throw out the invitations, including one from the International Pinot Noir Celebration, held in Oregon.
A mistake. I should have looked closer. Fortunately, word trickled down. Gerald Asher laid it out in Gourmet magazine a few months ago. He talked of "the gaiety of the event and its lack of pretension." Of drinking wine for pleasure. 
 He was singing my song. So, a couple of Thursdays ago, I found myself driving out of the Portland International Airport toward this bustling little city (population 20,000), 45 miles to the southwest toward the Oregon coast.
McMinnville is Oregon's unofficial wine capital. There are some 50 wineries in the Willamette Valley, most of them less than an hour from here. McMinnville is also the home of Linfield College, which is so all-American that it could have been ordered by Louis B. Mayer for an Andy Hardy movie. Since it began in 1987, the Pinot Noir Celebration has been held on the Linfield campus.
Many of the regulars at the celebration are involved in the wine business, but many are not: a high school principal from Chicago, for example; two retirees from British Columbia; a young couple, both San Francisco lawyers, with their baby in a backpack carrier, and dozens of others whose only interest in wine is drinking it.
There are no serious lectures; no wisdom dispensed from on high. Everyone mingles. Your table mate at lunch may be a wine maker from Burgundy, or a grape grower from New Zealand, or a high-school principal from Chicago.
The formula seems to work. This year's celebration was sold out in April, and many attendees this year signed up for 1994 before they left. It helps that the weekend is limited to about 550 people -- something like a big family reunion.
Sixty wineries took part this year: 20 from Oregon, 21 from California, 13 from France, two each from Italy and Australia, and one each from New Zealand and New York State.
Throughout the weekend, from Friday through Sunday, the selection of wines available -- not just to taste but to drink -- was extraordinary. And there were plenty of good white wines, too, mostly chardonnays from Oregon and Burgundy.
To the delight of the amateurs, the professionals regularly misidentified blind-tasted wines. Comments like "obviously Burgundian" and "clearly an Oregon wine" were wrong as often as they were right. This took the experts down a peg; it also demonstrated how close in quality the American and French wines were.
True Burgundian-style pinot noir was, for years, an elusive goal for American wine makers. Andre Tchelistcheff, the doyen of California vintners, recalled making a fine pinot noir at Beaulieu Vineyards in the late 1940's. But he said ruefully that he doesn't recall how he did it, and he admitted he was never able to do it again.
In the late 1960's and early 1970's, a few Oregon wine makers discovered that they had the soil and the climate to create fine Burgundy-style pinot noir. Unlike Mr. Tchelistcheff, they have been able to do it again and again, although not every year and not always with Burgundian panache.
By the mid-1970's, Oregon wines were winning prizes in France. Then in 1983, Robert Drouhin, a leading Burgundy wine producer, paid Oregon the ultimate tribute: he planted grapes and built a winery here. Since 1980, Oregon's pinot noir acreage has increased tenfold, and it is neither inaccurate nor unfair to say that today, in blind tastings, Oregon pinot noirs regularly equal or surpass competitors from the Cote d'Or in France and from California.
The Pinot Noir Celebration owes much to the chefs who come here each year both to taste the wines and to show off their culinary skills. This year they included Michael Wild from Bay Wolf in Oakland, Calif., Thierry Guillot from La Cote d'Or in Nuits-Saint-Georges in Burgundy and half a dozen chefs from popular Oregon restaurants.
Most meals were taken in the college dining room, with much passing of bottles from table to table. Wine stewards in black tie were on hand but had little to do as people wandered through the room trading, say, a 1987 estate bottling from Knudsen Erath in Oregon for a 1990 Pommard from the Domaine Parent in Burgundy.
The gustatory highlight of the weekend was a Saturday night salmon bake under the ancient oak trees on the Linfield campus. The salmon are cooked on barrel staves jammed into the ground over a huge fire pit. And, yes, pinot noir does go with fish.
The International Pinot Noir Celebration is held on the last weekend of July. Information is available from the festival's director, Pat Dudley, at P.O. Box 1310, McMinnville, Ore. Telephone: (503) 472-8964.
 
TASTINGS
Franciscan Vineyards Meritage, 1988, Oakville Estate; about $20.
 
These are, we are told, hard times in the California wine country, what with the recession and phylloxera insects in the vines. Perhaps, but you'd never know it from some of the prices. It's hard to find a winery of some repute that isn't pushing a $35-a-bottle cabernet. Well, here's a $20 cabernet that's as good as almost any of the $35 versions. Franciscan is a Napa Valley winery that consistently produces high-quality wines at reasonable prices. Its Meritage may be a bit softer and rounder than some others, but there is no lack of depth, richness or intense cabernet flavor. Meritage is a name the Californians dreamed up to allow them to get around the rule that says any wine labeled cabernet sauvignon must contain 75 percent of that grape. By using the name Meritage, they can add cabernet franc, merlot or anything else in whatever proportions they choose to achieve the desired blend. Even when the blend contains more than 75 percent cabernet, a wine maker will use the Meritage name because it has come to be recognized as a winery's best.

HEADLINE: Europe Beyond the Franc

 BODY:
Europe's latest monetary breakdown is more embarrassment than crisis. But embarrassing it is, especially to the Eurocrats of Brussels who had vainly tried to decree a kind of financial unity before real coordination of national monetary policies had been achieved.
That stroke of hubris compelled European governments participating in the Community's Exchange Rate Mechanism to try to maintain their currencies within a narrow band of fluctuation while simultaneously trying to respond to the different economic conditions each faced at home. 
 Predictably, the Exchange Rate Mechanism plunged into crisis every time currency traders sensed that the economic prospects of member nations seriously diverged. A sudden showdown between the German mark, British pound and Italian lira badly dented the mechanism last fall.
Now a rift between Europe's two central currencies, the mark and the French franc, has forced Community governments to all but abandon their attempt to fix exchange rates in a narrow band. By allowing rates to fluctuate as much as 15 percent above or below their nominal levels, they have stepped back from their proclaimed goal of a common European currency before this decade's end.
The downward pressure on the franc this time didn't come from the usual culprit, inflation. In fact, France's current 2 percent rate is half that of Germany. But the same high French interest rates that kept inflation low also blocked recovery from a severe recession. Money traders reasoned that France would eventually have to lower those rates, while Germany seemed as determined as ever to keep its own interest rates high. Hence the flight from wobbly franc to firm mark.
One by one, the overambitious goals of the 1991 Maastricht treaty have had to be drastically scaled back or abandoned. The difficulty of achieving a common foreign and defense policy was exposed by the fumbling response to the Bosnian war. Now the premature dream of a common currency has been rudely set back.
But so what? The future of European integration has never depended on technical details and timetables. What counts is the political will to expand and deepen the Community. A series of referendums and parliamentary votes in all 12 member countries show that that will remains alive within the Community. And non-member states in Central and Eastern Europe continue to knock loudly at the Community's door.
Americans thus needn't worry about Europe breaking down under narrow nationalistic pressures. And in purely economic terms, the currency crackup could prove beneficial to the U.S., and Europe as well. With economies like the French now freer to stimulate their way out of recession, demand is likely to go up for both domestic and foreign products. That could help U.S. export sales. And more favorable exchange rates for European currencies will please American tourists.
Meanwhile, Europe will seek to put the Community on firmer foundations. A common currency, if it is really desired, can be achieved through gradual convergence of monetary and fiscal policies. Better foreign policy coordination can be learned from two years' worth of catastrophic mistakes in the Balkans. Even the arrogance of Eurocrats can be cured as ill-conceived schemes like the narrow-band Exchange Rate Mechanism come crashing down around their heads.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In America;
The Real Jobless Rate

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
The Federal Government will release its latest unemployment figures on Friday. But behind the official statistics is a truer picture -- a scarier picture -- of the nation's employment crisis.
Crowded into this picture are the millions of Americans (there are no precise totals) who have become discouraged and stopped looking for work, who are working part time but would like to work full time, who are working at jobs beneath their education or skill level, who are working at temporary jobs, who have set up some form of self-employment because they can't find other work, who are living on severance and savings and don't know what the future holds, who have retired prematurely, and on and on. 
 These are all people who would like to be gainfully employed but have been unable to land a good job.
Thomas J. Plewes, associate commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, explained that three "tests" must be passed before someone is officially considered unemployed: The person must be out of work, must be available for work and must have actively sought a job at some point in the last four weeks. There were 8.9 million people in this category in June, the latest month for which figures were available.
In addition, according to Mr. Plewes, the Government is aware of 1.2 million discouraged workers. Having thrown in the towel, they are not counted among the officially unemployed.
There are also 6.3 million partially employed people -- part-timers who would like to be full-timers. "That," said Mr. Plewes, "is a very large number at this stage of a recovery."
Another "very large" group comprises individuals working in jobs for which they are overqualified. This is a category that cannot be accurately measured. "It's very, very subjective," said Mr. Plewes.
In this group are many college graduates and professionals who once felt secure in their work. They are now doing all sorts of things -- painting houses, delivering pizzas, driving cabs -- to make ends meet.
Where jobs are available, there is a crush of applicants. M-G-M officials expect more than 100,000 applications for the 8,000 jobs at their new Grand Hotel and Theme Park in Las Vegas. Thousands of job seekers turned up in 100-degree heat on Monday night just to submit resumes.
The structure of employment in the U.S. is changing radically and workers are at a clear disadvantage. Millions of good jobs have vanished. Millions of workers are fearful and many are desperate. Job security is becoming a thing of the past. Workers in good jobs worry that they will not be in them for long.
The Harvard economist James Medoff, who did a study of "The New Unemployment," said, "No matter where you look, labor is hurting a great deal." He described the demand for workers as "weak."
In his paper Professor Medoff said: "Today's unemployment rate is roughly the same as it was at various points since 1976. However, until very recently, job availability, as measured by help wanted advertising, was much greater than it is today. The unemployment rate by itself cannot describe the ultimate vulnerability of American workers."
Not only are fewer jobs available, but the quality of the jobs has declined. Huge numbers of manufacturing jobs that provided relatively high wages and good benefits have been replaced over several years by service jobs that pay less and offer fewer or no benefits.
Now unemployed white-collar workers, jolted by the latest recession and its aftermath, are also walking down the path to the service-sector jobs.
Among the most vulnerable workers, according to Professor Medoff, are those who are middle-aged. In a report titled "Middle-Aged and Out-of-Work," he found that middle-aged Americans "were 45 percent more likely during the 1980's to be unemployed due to permanent layoff or job loss than was true during the 1970's," and are 55 percent more likely in the 1990's than in the 1970's.
Across the board the employment outlook is grim. Consumer confidence is weak, and when the employment picture comes into focus you wonder how it could be otherwise. It will be difficult for President Clinton or anyone else to bring about a strong economic recovery without addressing the fundamental problem of employment.

HEADLINE: Concrete Walls Aren't Best for Floods

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Let's hope the city fathers get busy building a wall against the next time," you advise downtown Davenport, Iowa, in "The Power of Water" (editorial, July 26).
That's a 16-foot, concrete wall severing downtown Davenport from its baseball stadium, from LaClaire Park, from the gambling boat around which hope for economic stimulus revolves, and hiking-bicycling paths. 
 Flood walls also often don't work and contribute to flooding problems elsewhere by accelerating river flows. Within the Army Corps of Engineers, as well as among environmentalists, there is recognition that river manipulation needs rethinking.
You should advocate comprehensive, basinwide and long-term solutions to river flooding, with less emphasis on construction.
Taxpayer dollars can be better spent than in building Berlin walls in Iowa or elsewhere on urban riverfronts.
 
ANN BREEN, DICK RIGBY
Directors, Waterfront Center
Washington, July 28, 1993

HEADLINE: No Need for More Unemployed College Grads

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Workers of the World, Get Smart" by Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich (Op-Ed, July 20) perpetuates the dangerous myth that demand for college-trained workers is limitless. Mr. Reich argues that if we can simply train enough workers with "problem-solving skills," we can have both high wages and high employment.
Yet America is suffering from too many college-educated workers. Unemployment of Ph.D.'s is high, college graduates are experiencing the worst prospects for landing college jobs, and the last recession witnessed large-scale white-collar layoffs. 
 The Labor Department's own Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that about 20 percent of college graduates work in occupations that do not require a college degree, such as secretary, retail sales clerk and factory production worker. Since the early 1970's, colleges and universities have poured out diplomas at a faster rate than the economy could absorb them. The percentage of graduates unable to land college jobs is expected to exceed 30 percent by the year 2005.
Mr. Reich bases his argument on two "clues": wages of college graduates have been rising relative to those of lesser-trained workers, and unemployment is less among college graduates. Yet this ignores the large numbers of college graduates unable to find work in their chosen professions who downgrade and displace lesser-trained workers. In the 1980's, a degree became preferred, if not required, for many jobs for police officers, farm managers and managers of convenience stores.
Mr. Reich presents this problem as afflicting all advanced industrial nations, yet only America has pursued a higher education policy that sends fully half of our youth to college.
Japanese and European societies limit the number of students who can attend college. In most European countries, including the former West Germany, less than half as many students have an opportunity to attend a university as in the United States. These countries, however, offer apprenticeship, technical and on-the-job training programs to those who do not go to college.
We cannot build dynamic apprenticeship programs if governmental policy makes it too easy to attend college. One-fifth of the country's state universities are required to accept any high school graduate who applies, yet Mr. Reich wants to make college even more accessible.
Improving work-force skills is no longer compatible with increasing access to college. Perpetuating myths about the demand for college graduates forestalls movement towards effective apprenticeship and job-training programs.
 
JIM BESSEN
Wallingford, Pa., July 22, 1993
 
The writer is founder of a software company, which he headed 1984-93.

HEADLINE: No Need for More Unemployed College Grads;
Misguided Policies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert Reich's proposed solutions to unemployment in the United States and the industrialized economies (Op-Ed, July 20) miss the mark: Jobs are not being created and upgraded because of the costs Government imposes on the job creators in the private sector, particularly the small and medium-size businesses that create the majority of the jobs.
Government regulation and taxes create a wedge between what it costs a business to employ a worker and the net benefit a worker receives. Any increase in this wedge raises the cost of hiring new workers and reduces the net wages workers receive. In addition, overgenerous Government welfare and social benefit programs like those in Europe make nonwork more attractive than work. 
 The size of government -- and the accompanying tax, spending and regulatory burdens and disincentives -- has increased dramatically in the last three decades in all major industrialized countries. From the 1960's to the 1980's, the public sectors of the Group of Seven nations mushroomed from an average 32 percent to 43.5 percent of gross domestic product. Not coincidently, all of those countries experienced reduction in the rate of economic growth and job creation.
Mr. Reich complains about the decline in demand for less-educated and lower-skilled workers in industrial countries, yet he supports policies like indexing the minimum wage and raising payroll taxes to pay for job-retraining programs that would raise business costs and destroy entry-level positions for these workers.
The solution to unemployment is not increased Government spending on job training, but to reduce misguided policies that raise private sector costs.
 
CESAR V. CONDA
Executive Director
Alexis de Tocqueville Institution
Arlington, Va., July 26, 1993

HEADLINE: No Need for More Unemployed College Grads;
Who Is Protected

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert Reich (Op-Ed July 20) makes a distinction between the more and less educated segments of the American work force. His answer for less educated workers is to raise their education and skill levels.
A more useful distinction would be between those who are forced to compete against workers in the third world and those protected from such low-wage competition. 
 The tariffs or quotas that might protect blue-collar workers from imports produced by low-cost third world labor are usually the sort of "protection" that free traders like Mr. Reich attack. The professional restrictions and racism that protect physicians, lawyers, academics and other professionals from competing with equally skilled individuals from the third world are rarely noted by proponents of free trade.
It has taken years of arduous negotiations to create the sort of mobility of capital necessary to force United States auto workers into competition with workers in Mexico, Thailand and other low-wage havens. If similar negotiating efforts had been made at standardizing training and licensing requirements (and minimizing immigration restrictions), professionals in the United States would be earning salaries far more "competitive" with the third world than they do.
When promoting free trade, economists, politicians and journalists seem far more likely to notice the restrictions that protect the United Auto Workers than the American Medical Association or the American Bar Association.
 
DEAN BAKER
Washington, July 20, 1993

LENGTH: 302 words

HEADLINE: No Need for More Unemployed College Grads;
Shorten the Workweek

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Strong Companies Are Joining Trend to Eliminate Jobs" (front page, July 26), on the increase in "part-time" jobs and elimination of "full-time" jobs, omits one element.
Those of us urged to do career planning at the dawning of the Age of Technology, as I did in a California junior high school, circa 1955, were told to map out and nourish leisure activities, the premise being that, as technology entered the workplace, work would require less time. 
 That leisure time has never appeared, largely because of the outdated concept that the 40-hour work week is the norm. Anything less than 40 hours a week consequently constitutes only "part-time" employment.
The notion of worker productivity must be redefined. Productivity is adjusted by cramming into each worker's 40 hours as much as body and mind will bear. The results are noticeable in, for example, the United States Post Office, where worker dissatisfaction has led to violence.
Neither business nor politics has considered what social impact might be achieved were the time saved by technology made "productive" by diverting worker time and energy into pursuits beyond the workplace.
The arbitrary distinctions that govern full- and part-time jobs must be eliminated. There are clear -- but artificial -- lines drawn: above the threshold, the worker is entitled to full benefits; below the line, nothing. Eliminating the rigidity by which benefits are given or denied would eliminate the incentive to business to create low-paying, part-time employment at the expense of gratifying, economically productive work.
Reducing the normal work week to 40 hours helped restore the economy during the Depression of the 1930's. We need such rethinking and redefinition today.
 
STEPHEN E. PHILLIPS
Brooklyn, July 27, 1993

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NORTHEAST UTILITIES TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Citing the need to control costs because of competitive pressures and a recession in New England, Northeast Utilities said it would cut its work force between 6 percent and 7 percent by the end of 1994. That would reduce employment at the region's largest electric utility by 600 to 700 from the current 10,000 employees. 
 Northeast Utilities, based in Hartford, said it hoped to achieve the reduction by offering voluntary early retirement but would lay off employees if necessary.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The Senate;
Budget Opposition Brings Senator to Center Stage

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey has rarely taken center stage in the United States Senate. But he put himself squarely there today by announcing that he would again vote against President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan.
Mr. Lautenberg's announcement came in a spare, eight-line press release that called the budget plan unfair to the middle class. Although he has long been identified as a loyal, if not predictable liberal Democrat, his decision came as no surprise. What was surprising was that the White House did not fight harder for his vote. 
 After all, the New Jersey Senator is running for re-election next year in a state still reeling from a 1990 revolt against state tax increases that almost brought down Senator Bill Bradley.
 
Wincing at Criticism
 Senate Democratic leaders wrote Mr. Lautenberg off days ago, if not weeks ago, and they are still wincing at his harsh criticism of the President's plan when it first squeaked through the Senate in June.
Mr. Lautenberg was one of six Democrats to vote with the Republicans against the President then, forcing Vice President Al Gore to cast a tie-breaking vote.
Now that Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma has joined the ranks of Democratic opponents, the Administration is looking for a way to persuade one of the original Democrats who voted against the plan to change his mind.
Today's announcement closed the door to any possibility that Mr. Lautenberg would be the one to help the President on the most crucial vote the Democratic Party has faced in years.
As for Mr. Lautenberg, he called his decision today "a biggie," but no more fateful than his votes opposing the use of military force in the Persian Gulf or in favor of the 1990 budget agreement.
 
'Laborious' Decision
 "I came to this decision very laboriously," he said. "I had calls from the White House. I sat with the President. I hate to vote against the President's program, but I don't consider this a disloyal act. It's unpleasant because we have gotten calls that number in the thousands. Some are threats, like: 'I'll never vote for you again.' "
The New Jerseyan described the pressure he came under from the Administration as modest, mostly coming in the form of encouraging his local supporters to write and call him.
There were no last-minute White House threats to encourage a primary opponent and no hard-nosed calls to Mr. Lautenberg's contributors or political consultants -- none of the things past administrations have done when the time came to shove all their chips into the pot.
But the Administration played a little hardball two weeks ago, when President Clinton and other senior officials gave an exclusive briefing to New York and New Jersey reporters stressing the benefits of the budget plan for the metropolitan area.
 
Facing the Electorate
 Obviously referring to Mr. Lautenberg and other recalcitrant Democrats, Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, said: "How do you think they would like to go back to the electorate if this thing fails and has their name on that? To have seen interest rates start to go up again and the stock market start to go down? The electorate would hold them responsible for that."
The officials went on to say that the budget plan, if passed, would bring New Jersey 96,000 jobs by 1996.
Mr. Lautenberg privately complained to the White House that he did not appreciate the thinly veiled slam at his election prospects.
And today, he questioned their job figures, but politely: "I'm not sure they have a basis for their projection."
"My mission here is not primarily to support the President," he said. "If the bill goes down, another bill will be written."
 
Ribbing From Other Senators
 Among the unpleasant consequences of his stance is the critical whispering among Senate Democrats who think Mr. Lautenberg's opposition reflects more devotion to his own political interests than to those of the President or their party.
Acknowledging the heat from his colleagues, Mr. Lautenberg said: " 'Don't you see this as good for the country?' they ask. And I say: 'No, you're wrong. You need more deficit reduction.' "
The Senate is usually a genteel, subdued place, like an exclusive club. And as a self-made millionaire among millionaires, the 69-year-old Senator normally glides through his workday with little fanfare.
But in the minutes after his announcement, his colleagues made him the center of attention, giving him a relentless ribbing as he commuted from the Senate floor to his office in the Hart building on the Senate subway.
In an elevator, Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, perhaps the most hard-line Democratic opponent to the Clinton economic program, slapped Mr. Lautenberg on the back and said, "They say you're leaning straight up!" Senator John Glenn of Ohio, a Clinton supporter, chimed in: "Frank says some of my people are for it, and some of my people are against it, and I'm for my people."
In a separate interview, Mr. Bradley said that while he disagreed with Mr. Lautenberg, "As a colleague, you have to respect another person's decision." He added that it was "hard to tell" whether Mr. Lautenberg's vote would hurt or help his re-election bid.
 
'New Jersey First'
 Mr. Lautenberg came to the Senate a decade ago promising to put "New Jersey first," and he hopes his vote against his party's President will make that point. But he insisted that politics were not behind his decision, since no one can tell how the people of New Jersey will view his decision in 1994.
Saying that he had received "more phone calls to vote for it than against it," he added, "The politics are yet to be determined."
Still, he said that in "a state that is taxed so highly and gets such little return" he could not justify voting for $250 billion in tax increases over five years without a long list of changes in the program, including the elimination of the space station, the supercollider and subsidies for miners and ranchers.
Mr. Lautenberg's probable Republican opponent next year is Representative Dick Zimmer, a leading opponent of the space station, who has cast himself as a tight-fisted fiscal conservative.
 
Unaccustomed Cloak
 Whatever role politics played in his decision, Mr. Lautenberg has taken on the unaccustomed cloak of deficit hawk in recent months.
He led a successful fight against $1.2 billion in military spending promoted by Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Then he backed a Republican-sponsored amendment to penalize states that do not make a serious effort at putting able-bodied welfare recipients to work.
Mr. Lautenberg predicted that the Administration would still pass its budget without his support.
By concentrating on transportation, toxic wastes and other state issues that receive little national attention, Mr. Lautenberg has taken a back seat to other New Jersey politicians like Mr. Bradley and Gov. Jim Florio. But he has repeatedly beaten the odds, since he transformed a three-man business into Automatic Data Processing, now a world leader in computer services.
Until his 1982 election to the Senate, the Brooklyn-born Mr. Lautenberg was best known in political circles for his inclusion on President Richard M. Nixon's enemies list for making a $90,000 contribution to George McGovern's 1972 campaign.
 
Prime G.O.P. Target
 Few expected him to defeat Representative Millicent Fenwick, a witty, irreverent Republican, in his first Senate race.
But he managed to paint her as a heroine of the monied classes, even though he spent $4 million of his own money on his campaign. In the Senate, he made few headlines, and he was a prime target of national Republicans six years later.
Mr. Lautenberg was denigrated throughout the 1988 campaign as "a junior Senator" by his Republican opponent, Pete Dawkins, a Heisman Trophy winner at West Point with a golden resume. But Mr. Dawkins ran a poor campaign, which was unable to overcome news reports that highlighted the idea that he was a carpetbagger who searched for a state in which to run.

HEADLINE: Deal Made to Save New York Hospital Surcharge

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
Congressional budget negotiators have agreed on the broad outlines of a plan intended to preserve New York State's fragile hospital reimbursement system for two more years.
The rate system, which allows the state to charge some hospital patients more to subsidize the care of others, has been under legal attack by insurance companies and labor unions. 
 While not disclosing details of the agreement, Congressional leaders said the plan would protect New York's system of surcharges on many hospital bills.
In February a Federal judge in Manhattan said key elements of the system violated Federal law, a ruling that state officials said could bring the entire system crashing down if upheld on appeal.
 
$160 Million at Issue
 A collapse of the rate system would cost hospitals $160 million a year in revenue and jeopardize the state's ability to provide health care to two million people who lack insurance, many of them working poor and immigrants.
But the agreement reached on Monday by negotiators from the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee would keep the rate system standing even if the state loses the case on appeal, state officials said.
The agreement, which is part of a five-year budget plan, must still be approved by the full House and Senate.
"This is one we very badly needed," said Sandra Cuneo, Washington counsel to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. "Had we not received it, our entire hospital reimbursement system could have been thrown into chaos."
At stake are complex regulations intended to help nonprofit insurers like Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to compete with commercial insurers and to provide health care to people who cannot afford insurance but are not poor enough to qualify for Medicare.
Under those rules, the state adds a charge to hospital bills for those covered by some for-profit insurers and health maintenance organizations. Of this surcharge, $160 million goes to hospitals and $90 million to the state's general revenue fund.
Because the nonprofit insurers are exempt from the surcharge, which is 24 percent, they are theoretically able to keep their rates competitive with commercial insurers.
Another surcharge of 5.5 percent, which is tacked on to most hospital bills, including those of people who are insured by nonprofits, raises $1.1 billion a year to subsidize health care for people without insurance.
 
Insurers and Unions Sue
 In separate lawsuits, a coalition of commercial insurers and a group of labor unions have challenged the surcharges, saying they violate the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known as Erisa.
Under the law, employee contributions to health benefit funds may be used for the "sole and exclusive benefit" of the workers and their families.
In a ruling on the case brought by the insurers, Judge Louis J. Freeh of Federal District Court in Manhattan said in February that the surcharges used employees' money for purposes unrelated to their health care, unfairly driving up their insurance costs.
That case is now on appeal. The suit brought by the labor unions is pending in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
Representatives for the unions and the commercial insurers could not be reached for comment tonight.
Although details of the Congressional plan were still being worked out tonight, state officials and Congressional aides said the plan will change the Federal tax code to create incentives for commercial health insurers and health maintenance organizations to continue paying New York State's surcharges.
Under the plan, contributions to health plans in New York State would be tax-deductible only if those plans pay the surcharges, Congressional aides said. As a result, even if the reimbursement system is struck down, companies and individuals would be likely to continue paying the surcharges because it would be economically beneficial, the aides said.
"This provides a very important stabilization factor," said Kenneth Raske, president of Greater New York Hospital Association.
But the changes to the tax code would remain in effect only into 1995, thereby putting pressure on the state to make its reimbursement system less onerous to unions and commercial insurers and their customers. That would also give the Federal Government time to create a national health care policy that could dramatically change the state's hospital reimbursement system.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 13, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 4 about New York state's hospital reimbursement system misidentified Medicare. It is the Federal program that provides health care for the elderly; Medicaid is the combined Federal, state and local program that provides health care for the poor.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The Overview;
Clinton Finds a Convert on the Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
One of the seven Senate Democrats who have opposed President Clinton's $500 billion budget package changed his mind today, converting a shaky bet that the package will squeeze through the Senate on Friday into something close to an odds-on favorite.
Close, but not absolute. Today's decision by Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona to support the measure places 49 Democratic senators solidly behind the package, and there are strong hopes in the White House that one past Democratic supporter -- Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska -- will not decide to break ranks. 
 Mr. Kerrey said again today that he had not decided whether to keep supporting the package, which he says contains too few cuts in Federal spending. But Democratic leaders in Congress and the White House expressed growing confidence in his vote.
Those 50 votes, plus the tie-breaking one cast by Vice President Al Gore, would give the President a one-vote margin of victory in the Senate.
 
Explaining Change of Mind
 In announcing his switch, Mr. Deconcini said he had acted because the alternative -- less deficit reduction and a compromise with a Republican Party that he said was committed to Mr. Clinton's defeat -- was unacceptable.
"I was not sent here to be a part of gridlock," he said at an afternoon news conference. "I was not sent here to collect a paycheck or sent here for a job to take care of myself and my retirement. I was sent here to reduce the deficit in my last election, and I'll continue to work for that. And that's what's driving me to it."
But Mr. DeConcini also walked away from today's announcement with several gifts from Democratic leaders, including changes in provisions for Social Security and deficit reduction, and those are certain to help him in a potentially difficult re-election campaign next year.
The White House's political situation appeared dire until Mr. DeConcini made his move. The Senate passed its version of Mr. Clinton's budget package in June by a single vote, and over the opposition of six Democrats. Even that margin vanished on Sunday when a past supporter of the President, Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, declared his opposition, touching off a scramble by the Administration to flip one of the Democratic foes to friend.
 
Erosion in the House
 While Mr. DeConcini has been won over, the White House today refused to declare the Senate battle won.
"I don't think anyone's going to crack a beer and go home," Mr. Clinton's spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said this afternoon.
Even more reason for that could be found in the House, which will vote on the package first, probably on Thursday. There, leading Democrats said they detected a small but steady erosion of conservative support for the measure. So far, that has been offset by other conservatives who have jumped aboard the package, but whether that trend can continue is uncertain.
"The perception is that we're there," said Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a member of the House leadership, "but we've got a few votes to go. We'll get there, but it'll be tight."
 
Republicans Continue Attack
 Republicans criticized the package again today, particularly a clause that applies the higher personal income tax to all money earned this year, even though the increase is just now being considered.
"Increasing taxes is bad enough, but increasing taxes retroactively is a terrible precedent," said Senator Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho.
Mr. Clinton responded to his critics in a speech to the National Urban League, saying: "So much misinformation has been put out. As soon as this bill passes, we will clear away the murky fog of misinformation, and reality will take over."
The White House must also cope with the beginnings of what is sure to be furious lobbying against the measure in the next two days. A coalition of scores of business groups, led by the National Federation of Independent Business and the United States Chamber of Commerce, announced today that it opposed the package.
The groups said the package, which includes $250 billion in new or increased taxes and $250 billion in spending reductions, has too many taxes on business and too few guaranteed cuts in spending. But they offered no specific alternative and presented few uncontested statistics to support their claim that the package would bring the economy and small-business job growth to a screeching halt.
But Mr. DeConcini's announcement, capping a day of unconcealed nail-biting, fueled the impression that Mr. Clinton's supporters were at last picking up steam.
Mr. DeConcini had been virtually mute on his intentions toward the bill. Not even the President knew what he would do until the chief White House lobbyist, Howard Paster, took a call from the Senator a few minutes before his news conference.
Asked what led Mr. Deconcini to drop his opposition, one senior Administration official said, "Sweet reason."
Mr. DeConcini described his internal debate in almost anguished terms. "I have labored with that act for some time now," he said. "I've worked on it. I've dissected it. I've pulled it apart. I've put the pieces back together."
Mr. Clinton and his subordinates wooed the Senator for two weeks, publicly and shamelessly. Mr. DeConcini visited the White House twice, including a 15-minute chat today, and was the recipient of several Presidential telephone calls. On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton singled him out for praise in a nationally televised prime-time speech.
Today, the President escorted Mr. DeConcini before cameras in the Oval Office to witness the signing of an executive order on deficit reduction, an order tailored to allay the Senator's stated fear that the budget package would not dent the rising Federal debt.
The White House has also pelted Mr. DeConcini with visits by big names: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, a fellow Arizonan; Secretary of State Warren Christopher, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who talked at length with Mr. DeConcini today and, one Administration official said, parted without any firm commitment.
The official said that "Bentsen was talking real turkey with him" but that on parting Mr. DeConcini had only said, "Trust me, Lloyd."
 
Lowering Tax Liability
 If public bouquets helped, so did the candy borne by friends in the White House and the Senate, as Mr. DeConcini won at least two major concessions from budget negotiators.
The first was an agreement to raise the income threshold at which retirees will pay taxes on an greater portion of their Social Security benefits. In the Senate version of the bill, the threshold was $32,000 for individuals and $40,000 for couples; the negotiators made it $34,000 and $44,000. The change deprived negotiators of about $2 billion in anticipated tax revenues through 1998, which had to be made up elsewhere in the package.
Mr. Clinton himself delivered the second gift, two executive orders that he signed today. The first establishes a Federal fund -- an accounting device, really -- that will hold in trust all the revenues from new taxes in the budget package. It requires that those revenues be spent only to reduce the annual Federal deficit; Mr. Clinton's package contemplates that anyway, and, in effect, the order merely puts into writing a pledge to adhere to the package plan.
Many analysts, including the General Accounting Office, call the trust fund a gimmick, but Mr. DeConcini said he disagreed. "It's a new, innovative approach," he said. "It's never been done before. The American public, I believe, is prepared to pay more taxes, to make more sacrifices if they truly, truly believe, that it's going to go to deficit reduction. This guarantees that."
Mr. Clinton's second order requires the White House to report annually on whether spending on Federal benefits programs has exceeded the forecast and to state what the President intends to do about it, if anything. Lawmakers would then have to adopt his recommendation or approve some better alternative.
 
Down to the Line
 The order is an effort to prevent the explosive growth of benefits programs from gobbling up the increases in tax revenues, as happened after the last deficit-cutting accord, in 1990. But lawmakers, and the President, would still have the option of doing nothing to redress the imbalance by cutting spending somewhere. The real impact of the order is to force a public vote on spending, something Congress has been loathe to do.
Mr. DeConcini said he made his decision on the budget package between his private meeting with Mr. Clinton at noon and about 3 P.M., when he asked an aide to call a press conference.
"It's not a light switch," he said in an interview later. "It's like, 'When did you finally decide to ask your best girlfriend to marry you.' "
The President took him aside at their meeting, Mr. DeConcini said, and told him, "'I sure hope you can come around"' and 'I'm glad you pushed us into this," referring to the deficit-reduction fund.
Mr. DeConcini said he then told Mr. Clinton, "I'll have to let you know."
He added in the interview, "It's hard to say no to the President."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: Income Taxes;
Tax Bill Would Let Wealthy Stretch Out Their '93 Payments

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The wealthy taxpayers most affected by the new tax increase in the Clinton budget package will not feel the full effect immediately because the Administration has agreed to allow them to spread their payments of 1993 taxes over two extra years.
In effect, they will be getting a two-year loan at no interest. And for the wealthiest the loans could amount to tens of thousands of dollars. 
 The plan, designed to defuse complaints that the tax increase will apply retroactively to all income earned this year, was agreed to by Congressional tax conferees today. It would let taxpayers defer most of the tax increase on 1993 earnings by paying it in three annual installments beginning next April 15, without the penalty or interest charges usually assessed on late payments.
 
Could Cost $300 Million
 Allowing taxpayers to defer some payments will cost the Treasury about $300 million in 1994 and 1995, Administration officials said. Tax experts calculated that the deferral would amount to just a quarter of a percent of the total collected from tax increases.
Administration officials insisted that the idea had been under discussion for weeks, and was not a last-minute concession brought on by the condemnation of retroactive taxes that the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, made in a televised speech after President Clinton's television address on Tuesday night.
But they did not offer a public explanation as to why the proposal had not been mentioned publicly until today.
A senior White House official said that President Clinton had given his approval to the plan on Tuesday afternoon in part to blunt criticism from those who opposed the tax increase's being made retroactive. The official said the proposal was too small to merit mention in Mr. Clinton's television address and had won final approval from Congressional conferees only this morning.
Senator Dole escalated his attack today, noting acerbicly that even the draft constitution approved by the Russian Federation last month ruled out retroactive tax increases. Representative Wayne T. Gilchrest, Republican of Maryland, went a step further and proposed a constitutional amendment to the same effect for the United States.
Senator Dole called the retroactive tax increase "unprecedented," but Treasury Department officials listed more than a dozen examples in which taxes had been imposed retroactively.
In fact, it had been assumed by most tax experts since before the Administration took office that any income tax increases would be retroactive, although for a time legislators had considered phasing in the increases by adopting one rate increase for this year and another for next year.
Many taxpayers long ago acted on the assumption that increase would be retroactive and took the widespread advice of tax accountants to declare as much income as possible for 1992 rather than 1993, or to shift investments into tax-free instruments at the start of this year.
Tax lawyers and accountants who have been following the deliberations closely said that they were caught completely off guard by the idea of letting taxpayers defer some of this year's tax increase and that they assumed it was a last-minute response to the Republican criticism.
 
Long Discussion Cited
 The provision allowing the deferred payments, which tax experts in Congress spent today drafting, would markedly ease the burden on people who otherwise would have to come up with thousands of dollars to pay 1993 income taxes before next April 15, while the amount being withheld for next year's taxes would simultaneously increase.
Although the decision was not disclosed until today, Leslie B. Samuels, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, said that it was made on Tuesday before President Clinton's televised speech supporting the tax bill.
Mr. Samuels said that the matter had been under discussion for weeks and that the Internal Revenue Service had already explained how it could be implemented. He said the likely political repercussions of the move had been considered in making the decision, as had the economic effects of making taxpayers liable for 1993 tax increases.
Mr. Samuels also said the tax bill signed by President Ronald Reagan on Sept. 3, 1982, had increased the taxes of people who had received unemployment benefits earlier in the year. The tax on the unemployed, he said, was imposed retroactively to Jan. 1, which he said should be recalled by Senator Dole, who was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee at the time.
The plan to defer taxes would apply only to 1993 income tax increases caused by the proposed new law, not to 1994 tax increases or tax liabilities that would have existed without a change in law.
Because the deferral applies only to the increase, the decision will also mean that the tax instruction books sent to all taxpayers next year will give them the tables and formulas needed to calculate exactly how much their taxes were increased. That is something that politicians normally do not want to remind people about it with hard, cruel numbers.
Most tax increases would be paid by people earning more than $200,000 a year, and many of them are not being hit hard enough to make them want to defer the payments.
A family of four with adjusted gross income of $200,000 and itemized deductions of $30,000 would pay $45,348 in income taxes under the new law, $1,308 more than under the old law, according to an analysis by Deloitte & Touche, a major accounting firm.
The deferral provision would allow the family to pay $436 of the increase on April 15, making the rest of the payments in equal installments one year and two years later.
Unlike most instances when taxpayers are late with their payments, these would not be subject to the interest charges assessed at market interest rates prevailing at the time.
If a family of four had income of $500,000 and itemized deductions of $70,000, its income tax liability would rise by $21,990 under the new law. Deferring two-thirds of that, or more than $14,000, would make a lot of sense. The money, for example, could be used to buy a new car, with the loan effectively coming from the I.R.S. without interest.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: News Analysis -- Beyond the Superlatives;
Clinton-Dole Jousting Over Budget Bill Shows How Assertions Can Mask Truth

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
On television Tuesday night, President Clinton called the budget legislation now before Congress "the largest deficit reduction in history."
Not to be outdone, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, went on the air a few minutes later to say that the measure was actually "the largest tax increase in world history." 
 Between the two of them, more claims and counterclaims were made Tuesday night than were staked out in the Oklahoma land rush, and some of them were just as suspect.
This is an attempt to sort some of them out.
When the dollars are adjusted for inflation, this year's budget bill is neither the biggest deficit reduction measure nor the biggest tax increase in recent years.
Over five years, in 1993 dollars, the bill would lower the annual deficits by a total of $496 billion. Of that, $241 billion would come from tax increases.
The budget agreement that Democrats in Congress developed and George Bush signed in 1990 contained $482 billion in deficit reduction -- higher taxes and lower spending. Adjusted for inflation, that plan, some of which is still in effect, was worth $532 billion in 1993 dollars.
As for taxes, the 1982 law enacted under Ronald Reagan raised taxes by $215 billion over five years, which amounts to $286 billion in 1993 dollars, considerably more than this year's figure.
Senator Dole was simply wrong when he said, "Never before in American history has the Government increased tax rates retroactively."
The Treasury put out a list today of 13 such rate increases since 1917, the most notable of which was Lyndon B. Johnson's surtax, imposed in 1968, to help pay for the Vietnam War. The law was passed on Oct. 22, and the tax was retroactive to Jan. 1 for corporations and April 1 for individuals.
 
Retroactivity Is Common
 A law enacted in October 1976 raised the minimum tax rate for those who claim many tax deductions and other breaks to 15 percent from 10 percent effective the previous Jan. 1. The constitutionality of this retroactive rate increase was upheld by the Supreme Court.
In fact, it is commonplace for changes in the tax law to be retroactive, and this year's budget bill contains 14 retroactive tax breaks, according to the Senate Finance Committee staff.
Mr. Clinton's statement, repeated twice, that there would be no income tax increase on working families earning less than $180,000 is not precisely correct.
Income taxes for couples would be raised on taxable income of over $140,000. Taxable income is what is left after deductions and personal exemptions are subtracted from adjusted gross income. As a rule of thumb, a couple with a taxable income of $140,000 probably has a total income of about $180,000. But some surely have an income below that, accountants say.
 
On 'Working Families'
 Moreover, it was only the careful use of the words "working families" that made Mr. Clinton's assertion even remotely correct.
More than five million retirees with annual incomes as low as $34,000 (counting half their Social Security benefits) would see their income taxes increase because they would be taxed on up to 85 percent of their Social Security payments, from 50 percent.
And even the term "working families" does not cover the thousands of cases in which one spouse works and the other is retired or disabled and receives Social Security benefits.
Still, Mr. Clinton was accurate, according to most official and private estimates, when he asserted that 80 percent of the higher taxes would be paid by taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and 90 percent by those with incomes above $100,000.
 
On Deficit and Debt
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole agree that the national debt, the accumulation of all annual deficits over the years, would grow by $1 trillion in the next five years even if the Clinton plan becomes law. If the plan does not become law, it would grow by $1.5 trillion.
Mr. Clinton's statement that with his plan in place, the economy would create eight million new jobs over the next four years is in line with the forecasts of most public and private economists. They also say that roughly this many jobs would be created without the plan. The fact is that in the short term, tax increases and spending cuts are not conducive to job creation.
Before the plan was announced, the Congressional Budget Office projected about nine million new jobs over the next four years. Senator Dole seized on the budget office's January forecast and contended that the Clinton plan would actually cost more than a million jobs. But budget office officials say that is a misinterpretation of the data.
Mr. Clinton is relying on the average of three private forecasts that were made more recently than the budget office projections.
 
What Businesses Want
 Mr. Dole's statement that 800,000 small businesses would owe higher taxes was probably true, but it lacked perspective. The business owners who would see their taxes increase represent less than 4 percent of the 21 million taxpayers who report business income. Many more small businesses would see their taxes cut than would see them raised under the legislation.
But Mr. Clinton's assertion that many small business organizations, including the National Association of the Self Employed and the National Venture Capital Association, were backing his plan also needed perspective.
Most business groups, including the National Federation of Independent Businessmen, the largest association of small businesses, oppose the legislation.
And when Mr. Dole said that 80 percent of the spending reductions in the bill would come after the 1996 election, he was making a good point but exaggerating the numbers.
Most of the spending cuts in the five-year plan would indeed come in the fiscal year 1997, which begins Oct. 1, 1996, or in the fiscal year 1998. But the proportion of spending cuts is 61 percent in the last two years if lower interest payments are counted as a spending reduction and 53 percent if they are not, Senate Budget Committee calculations show.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole agree that if the plan is enacted, deficits will skyrocket after the 1997 fiscal year. They just put the point differently.
Mr. Dole presented it to argue that the Clinton plan would be ineffective. Mr. Clinton used it to show how important it was to bring medical costs under control in a new national health program.

HEADLINE: Japan Ends 38 Years of Liberal Democrat Rule

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa formally ended 38 years of Liberal Democratic Party rule over Japan this morning when, as expected, he and his Cabinet resigned in advance of the opening of a special session of Parliament to elect his successor.
Parliament is to convene this afternoon and will probably elect Morihiro Hosokawa, the head of a coalition of seven opposition parties, as Prime Minister, another step in the whirlwind of change that has altered Japanese politics over the past two months. The Liberal Democrats lost their majority in last month's elections. 
 Mr. Miyazawa, 73, and his 20-member Cabinet were merely following the constitutional provision that requires the Government to resign at the opening of Parliament after an election.
But the routine event had historical weight: A non-Liberal Democrat will be forming a government for the first time since the party was formed in 1955, with United States backing, as a bulwark against Communism.
Whether Mr. Hosokawa will be able to announce his cabinet is uncertain. As of this morning, the coalition members were said to be still negotiating the distribution of cabinet posts. They have reportedly agreed to elect Takako Doi, a Socialist, as the first woman to become Speaker of the lower house, a symbolic but highly visible post.
In addition, Mr. Hosokawa has said he will name several experts who are not members of Parliament to some key posts. There have been rumors that he has offered the Foreign Ministry to Akio Morita, the chairman of the Sony Corporation, who has written for years of Japan's need both to resist some of Washington's more insistent trade demands and to break down the fortress mentality that has kept Japan's markets closed.
At the heart of the coalition taking power are several dozen Liberal Democratic Party defectors, including Mr. Hosokawa. Though they now oppose their one-time mentors and colleagues, these politicians remain conservative on most issues and thus they are not expected to begin any major policy shifts, at least in the short-term.
But they represent a new generation eager to put the rigid political and economic structures of the cold war behind them and, not least, to clean up politics after five years of corruption scandals.
Several dozen Liberal Democrats bolted after Mr. Miyazawa failed to fulfill a promise to pass legislation that would reform the electoral system. They forced a no-confidence vote, which Mr. Miyazawa lost, and then the election. After forming several parties, these defectors helped forge the new coalition.
The first order of business, Mr. Hosokawa and his backers have said, will be to pass the electoral reform, creating new electoral districts and banning corporate political donations, as the coalition has promised.
In addition, the group is expected to offer spending increases and tax cuts to stimulate the economy, which is struggling to lift itself from nearly two years of recession.
If the coalition can hold on to power, which remains highly uncertain, it is expected over time to push for policies that shift the Government's focus from supporting major corporations to looking after the interests of consumers. It has also promised to deregulate the economy and to decentralize power for economic and other decisions.

HEADLINE: Fed Finds Slow Pace Of Growth

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Neither flood nor rain nor searing drought is choking off the nation's modest economic recovery, even though they have been devastating to the Midwest and the South.
The 12 Federal Reserve Banks reported today that economic activity in most districts, including the Midwest, continued to expand "slowly to moderately" in June and the first half of July. 
 "The effects of flooding were said to be highly concentrated and were not seen to threaten overall economic expansion," the Federal Reserve said in its latest survey of regional economic conditions, a report known as the beige book.
The Federal Reserve's latest appraisal of economic conditions was based on surveys of farmers, bankers and business executives conducted before July 27. The Federal Reserve Banks assess economic conditions and price trends before the Fed's monetary policy meetings, which are held roughly every six weeks. The next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which decides whether to raise or lower short-term interest rates, is scheduled for Aug. 16 and 17.
 
 
Price Pressures Mixed
 The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has been watching for signs that prices are starting to rise faster as the economy keeps growing, which could lead the Fed to raise rates to check inflation. But the report today found that price pressures were mixed.
Although there are fears that food prices will rise later this year, the Fed's assessment of the nation's agriculture sector is surprisingly upbeat. "Agricultural conditions were said to be generally favorable, although flooding and drought have destroyed crops in several districts," the Fed said.
But the flooding has spread since the Fed made its assessment, and crop damage may well turn out to be more significant than what the Fed found a week ago.
"It's worsened in our area in the past 10 days since the beige book was put together," said Glenn Miller, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo. "More land is under water. The rains and wet weather have slowed the wheat harvest down a lot. The losses are even bigger now."
The Fed report depicted an economy that over all is neither faltering nor gathering much steam. Housing and construction are picking up just about everywhere, even in districts that have been hit by flooding and heavy rain. Retail sales and services seem to be growing at least a bit in most districts. But manufacturing is weak pretty much across the board except for a few pockets of strength.
Growth remains markedly uneven around the country, with the South and Mountain states strongest, the Midwest showing modest growth in spite of the flood and the two coasts still struggling.
The recovery still has not reached California, which is part of the San Francisco district. California business leaders are not expecting anything but very gradual improvement in the year ahead.
But in the Northeast, the New York and Boston banks report, there are more signs of life. In New York and New Jersey, businesses reported brisk sales in June. Office vacancies are still edging down. Builders say they are digging foundations at a fair to good pace. In New England, insurers, automotive suppliers and biotechnology companies have reported gains. And consumers are spending, though cautiously.
In the Midwest, which has been doing better than much of the rst of the country, the economy is still growing modestly, largely because of the strength so far this year in housing and cars. That may be explained by the fact that all the counties that have been declared disaster areas together account for 7 percent of the nation's personal income.
"So far the major problems are in agriculture, but they did not spread to manufacturing," said Stephen S. Strongin, vice president for research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. Apart from huge damage to roads, rail tracks and bridges, houses and farmland, he said, "You have crop losses and lower retail sales in the flood areas and those are impacting economic growth."
Nonetheless, the effects of the flooding are major in the areas along the rivers that are under water or deluged by relentless rain.
 
Flooding's Effects 'A Big Deal'

"It's a big deal in the third quarter in this district," said Art Rolnick, research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Crop losses so far total $1.9 billion for his district. Even if no factories produced less or stores sell less, that could shave four percentage points from the district's growth rate this summer.
"Looking at the future,the economic expansion is probably going to continue," he said. "But we lost some income, and in local areas, the losses are very large."
Administration officials and private economists have been estimating that the flooding could shave roughly a quarter of a percentage point from economic growth in the third and fourth quarters. And that lost growth may be partly or completely made up in the next year as Federal aid -- the Administration's latest request is for $5.8 billion -- pours into the disaster areas.

HEADLINE: Neighbors Hail Demise Of Bridgeport Trash Pile

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 4

 BODY:
The former site of a 35-foot illegal dump known as Mount Trashmore was officially turned over to the City of Bridgeport today as more than 150 residents of the city's East End gathered to celebrate.
"I had my doubts that this day would ever come," said James Drayton, 75, "but we fought hard and I just thank God that we won." 
 The site on Central Avenue was cleared of the debris in January after a lengthy battle by neighborhood residents to clear the two-acre lot, where the owners of a wrecking company had dumped five years' worth of construction debris.
"I had to live with the smell for five years as we all watched that dump grow and grow and grow," Mr. Drayton said. "The smell was practically unbearable for an eight-block area."
Today, however, residents gathered at the site to eat hamburgers and hot dogs and to hear public officials describe the city's plan to develop the property as part of a $1 million renovation project.
Singing "We Shall Overcome" and wearing T-shirts that read "Don't Dump on Us," neighborhood residents and members of East End Baptist Tabernacle Church, who staged more than 80 marches to protest the dump, were led again by the church's pastor, the Rev. Vernon S. Thompson, for a final, symbolic march.
"It's been a long journey and I'm just happy we have gotten here," said Mr. Thompson, who is also heads the city's Human Resources Department. "We're now going to make the community the healthy place it should have been long ago."
The Mount Trashmore site was seized by the state and the huge pile of debris was hauled away after a five-year legal battle. Geno R. Capozziello Sr. and his brother, Russell Sr., who ran the Connecticut Building Wrecking Company, were jailed and fined for illegally hauling demolition debris from construction sites to the lot, which they had owned. The debris included such hazardous wastes as lead, creosote and asbestos.
Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, who attended the ceremonies today, said the state would keep trying to collect $868,000 in fines from the Capozziello brothers. He said the brothers have appealed to the State Supreme Court, and he expects a ruling on the case in the next few weeks.
Mayor Joseph P. Ganim told the gathering that the combined efforts of the community, city officials, city businesses and the state had eliminated Mount Trashmore.
The state paid for most of the $800,000 cleanup, and the city paid the rest. Dozens of truckloads of debris were carted off and burned at an incinerator in Bridgeport.
Mayor Ganim said that while plans were not complete, a city was establishing a fund to revitalize the neighborhood. With matching state and Federal grants, the fund could grow to $1 million, he said. Under the preliminary plans, the site would probably be turned into a parking lot or courtyard for new housing.
Shortly after, to symbolize the renovation plans, an old house that bordered the lot was demolished by a city wrecking crew.
Many in the crowd cheered as the bulldozer began crushing the house. James Reid, a church member, stood nearby and prayed.
"I'm just so happy for this day because that dump was a hazard for the children -- and for everyone," he said. "I was just standing here thanking God that it is finally gone."
