HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: White House Memo;
An Excess of the Pulpit And Not Enough Bully?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Staring defeat in the face, Richard III melodramatically offered to trade his kingdom for a horse. In an equally tight spot this week, President Clinton has talked himself to the brink of laryngitis, but his wheeling and his dealing have been strikingly subdued.
Without the vote of Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, a conservative Democrat who finally agreed late this afternoon to support him, Mr. Clinton seemed likely to be beaten when his budget proposals come before the Senate on Friday. Some incentives had been offered to Mr. DeConcini, including a less onerous tax on high-income recipients of Social Security, designed to appeal to the many wealthy retirees in Phoenix and Tucson, and an executive order pledging new tax revenues to deficit reduction rather than new spending. 
 But when Mr. DeConcini went to the White House this morning to watch the signing of the order, did the President bear down in hopes he could seal the deal and parade the Senator before the television cameras? He did not. Asked whether he remained undecided, Mr. DeConcini said that indeed he did.
What, someone wanted to know, was Mr. Clinton going to do to move him? The President seemed nonplussed and finally answered, "Good government." Aides said later that he had not been sure what the Arizonan planned to do until just before Mr. DeConcini made his announcement.
 
Reluctant to Get Tough
 It was a strangely disjointed episode in the thoroughly perplexing story of Bill Clinton's quest for a program he and many others have long thought he needed to survive.
Many in Washington, including some undecided lawmakers, have been deeply puzzled by the President's seeming reluctance to get tough with the Democrats who have made the passage of this centerpiece of his Administration such an arduous undertaking. Several House members said the President had never told them, crisply and unambiguously, that he had to have their votes.
Mr. Clinton is not playing hardball, politicians and lobbyists say, partly because of an ingrained reluctance to crack down, partly because the political realities on Capitol Hill have changed and partly because he has so many tough fights ahead that he does not want to expend all his ammunition at once.
"I have been criticized in some quarters for not talking tough enough," Mr. Clinton acknowledged this morning in a speech to the Urban League. "My theory is that if you do the tough things, actions speak louder than words."
George Stephanopoulos, one of Mr. Clinton's top advisers, argues that his boss is getting a bum rap. "There is a difference in your approach 14 days out, 7 days out and 2 days out," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "You don't want to start shouting too early. But I can promise you this: In this final 48 hours, nobody will leave the Oval Office or get off the phone with the President without feeling that they have been asked for their vote."
But among some who have worked on Congressional relations in other Administrations, many of them now lobbyists, there is disdain for Mr. Clinton's performance, even though he will probably prevail.
Several weeks ago, a senior member of the White House staff was told by an old-timer, "Sooner or later, the President's going to have to tell one of these senators that like it or not, he's going to support the Administration, he's going to get nothing for it, and if he doesn't he'll pay for it, period."
The Clinton staffer answered, "But these guys don't know that game."
 
'The Boom Is Broken'
 Tom C. Korologos, a White House mainstay under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, was somewhat more generous. One reason that Mr. Clinton has not lowered the boom on wayward Democrats, he said, "is that the boom is broken."
It is true that many of the techniques used by past Presidents are no longer available. Some were always dicey. In 1970, President Nixon successfully encouraged Republican voters in New York to back James L. Buckley, a Conservative, over Senator Charles Goodell, a Republican foe of the Vietnam War.
But Franklin D. Roosevelt, one of the most popular Presidents, failed in his attempt to purge five Democratic senators and one Representative. All but one were renominated easily.
"Nowadays, the most successful Senate candidates are elected by going against the grain, picturing themselves as standing up for their state or region against the evil knights of Washington," said one of Mr. Clinton's strategists. "If a President is too ham-handed, you only help the guy you're trying to hurt. And believe me, they don't care whether or not you campaign for them or help them raise money, which was one of F.D.R.'s main levers."
 
A Lot of Machines
 Anne Wexler, who worked in the Carter White House, says any modern President is dealing not with Democratic and Republican blocs in the Senate but with "100 separate political machines." Ms. Wexler, now a lobbyist, gives Mr. Clinton credit for "a good political ear" and suggests that with a heavy and complicated political agenda, he has to be careful not to get into a trading posture, where lawmakers can say, "I'll vote for the budget if you'll give me a pass on health care."
In fact, the Clinton Administration tried to make an example of Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, a Democrat who defected early in the battle over the economic package. A small office of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was moved out of his state, and he was limited to a single ticket when the national champion University of Alabama football team came to the White House for a reception.
It didn't work, partly because members of the President's staff bragged about their maneuvers. Mr. Shelby was looked upon as a hero at home, and he is one of six Democrats who are expected to vote "no."
Presidents once disciplined mavericks, or tried to, by regulating the flow of dams, highways, airports and post offices. Far fewer of those sorts of things are available to the needy chief executive today.
 
The Subtle Touches
 Still, as Mr. Korologos said, there are subtle things a President can do.
"You get a guy from the West who's causing you trouble, you have the Interior Department spread the word, quietly, that he can't get things done in Washington," Mr. Korologos suggested. "You get a guy from Florida, let it be known that the Corps of Engineers can't work with him. Summertime, cut the allocation of tour passes for the White House. Keep him off Air Force One. Don't return his calls. Cut his wife from the First Lady's social list."
And there are some new techniques. The Reagan Administration compared computer lists of its own contributors with lists of those who had given to balky legislators. When it found a match, it asked the donor to put the pressure on the legislator but not to mention the White House. It often worked wonders.
But Mr. Clinton has held back. In the case of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the New Jerseyan who is another of the six Democrats expected to oppose the President, no attempt was made to twist arms or to enlist Gov. Jim Florio to change the Senator's mind. Some White House strategists thought that doing so would only risk losing Mr. Lautenberg's seat when he runs for re-election next year and paring the Democrats' narrow Senate majority.
Even in the best of times, relations between Presidents and Congresses are fiendishly difficult to manage.
With a lifetime of experience on Capitol Hill, Lyndon B. Johnson usually knew just what blend of sugar and vinegar would work. But not always. Once, when Southerners were giving him trouble on the 1964 civil rights bill, he invited Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia to the White House. After a few suitably flattering remarks, he put his arm around the Senator's shoulder.
"Bob McNamara says we have to close that Norfolk naval base of yours," he said, according to a onetime Johnson aide, "and I don't much want to."
Mr. Byrd got the message. But he still voted no.
Jimmy Carter, like Mr. Clinton a newcomer to Washington, failed to provide good seats at his inauguration for the guests of Representative Thomas P. O'Neill, the powerful Speaker of the House, and Mr. O'Neill never forgave him. Mr. Clinton and his team have made no gaffes on that scale.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The Senator Who Switched;
For DeConcini, the Vote Is a Gamble

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Aug. 4

 BODY:
The temperature was heading toward 108 degrees today in the Valley of the Sun, and Leah Akers was sheltering under a japonica tree with the rest of the Oasis Senior Citizens Association, a clump of gray hair, bright prints and collective cynicism over Senator Dennis DeConcini's decision to change his vote and give President Clinton a chance for a victory in his budget battle.
"DeConcini is trying to maneuver himself into buying votes, but he's not going to get mine," said Ms. Akers, a retired clerk. The group snickered in derision at the mention of the "deficit-reduction trust fund" that Mr. Clinton agreed to establish at the urging of Senator DeConcini, a three-term Democrat who faces a tough re-election battle next year against Democratic and Republican opponents. 
 And the group was not much impressed that the final plan would partly reduce the increase in taxes on Social Security benefits for retired people; it was still more taxes on people living on fixed incomes.
Taken against the complex politics of this conservative state, Senator DeConcinci's vote switch was a gamble that many political experts doubted he would win in the long run. The consensus was that it might help him somewhat in beating back an expected primary challenge from Richard Mahoney, the Arizona Secretary of State, but could be a damaging issue in the general election, when the Republican candidate is expected to be Representative Jon Kyl, 51, who has represented Arizona's Fourth Congressional District since 1987.
 
Singled Out by Clinton
 Mr. DeConcini was the only Senator mentioned by the President in his address Tuesday night. And he stayed in the spotlight today with a trip to the Oval Office for a declaration from Mr. Clinton establishing the deficit fund, and with a news conference a few hours later announcing his support of the Clinton economic plan.
It was a role the 56-year-old Senator has often relished, as an unpredictable Democrat who straddles political fences and delays his decision on close votes to gain leverage, sometimes voting with his party but often with the Republicans. This strategy has kept him in office even though Arizona has 40,000 more registered Republicans than Democrats. In 1988 he won 57 percent of the vote in defeating Keith Green, a little-known Republican opponent.
But Mr. DeConcini's political fortunes have faded in recent years, especially since 1989, when he was named as one of the Keating Five who met with a Federal savings and loans regulator on behalf of Charles Keating, now imprisoned in California for securities fraud in the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loans.
 
'Appearance of Impropriety'
 In February 1991, the Senate Ethics Committee issued mild reprimands to Mr. DeConcini and three other Senators, including his Republican colleague from Arizona, John McCain, for intervening with regulators on behalf of Mr. Keating in exchange for campaign contributions. The committee said Mr. DeConcini, who received $85,000 from Mr. Keating, "gave the appearance of impropriety" in taking the money.
Senator DeConcini's role in the budget battle has been followed closely throughout the state, from his native Tucson near the border with Mexico to the Navajo Indian reservation in the north. The President's economic plan is highly unpopular in Arizona, particularly among the elderly people who have flocked here from other states to retire in recent years.
They are people like Fred Saunders, a 65-year-old retired computer analyst from Oak Forest, Ill., and his wife Dorthea, who live in Chandler, Ariz. He said he voted for Senator DeConcini five years ago but would not again.
"The Clinton speech proved he bought DeConcini," Mr. Saunders said. "He sold his vote. Under this budget, the deficit will increase $1.25 trillion in four years. That's not a cut."
Although the Senator said there was no quid-pro-quo, political strategists here were quick to speculate that Mr. DeConcini demanded more than just the deficit-reduction trust fund from the President, and may have sought help in putting pressure on Mr. Mahoney to stay out of the Democratic primary.
Mr. Mahoney, a 42-year-old professor of foreign policy at the American Graduate School of International Management in Phoenix, was elected Secretary of State in 1989 campaigning as an anti-Washington outsider. He has said he opposes the Clinton budget.
In a telephone interview from Washington, Mr. Kyl said the vote "will have an effect" on the campaign. "It goes against the popular sentiment in Arizona," he said. "Our switchboard has been lit up all day. A lot of calls were from people who wanted us to pass on a message to DeConcini because they could not get through to his office."
Still, Mr. DeConcini, who was the Pima County Attorney in Tucson before being elected to the Senate in 1976, has a considerable base of support in Arizona.
"He made a good move by recommending the establishment of the deficit-reduction trust fund," said Alison Hughes of Tucson, vice chairwoman of the Arizona Democratic Party. "Arizona is a tough state for Democrats, but people vote for the person. It depends on how short a memory the public has. Whether it will bother them in the coming election, I don't know."
 
Support From a Liberal
 And if the affluent elderly here in Scottsdale are dubious, he has considerable backing elsewhere, such as up in Coconino County, where Tom Chabin is a staunch Democrat and a county supervisor who represents part of Flagstaff and parts of the Navajo and Hopi reservations.
"I really want DeConcini to vote for Clinton's package," Mr. Chabin said. "Absolutely. The Republicans are obstructionists. They want to destroy the Clinton Presidency.
"Ultimately, DeConcini is going to vote for it, and that gives me reason to support him even more. Personally, I'm extremely loyal to him. For someone who's as basically liberal as I am, DeConcini can be frustrating. But he has used his influence to help me get elected. He's a genuine person when it comes to helping those who help him."
And Republicans are not entirely writing him off.
"DeConcini was in a very difficult position," said Robert Robb, a Phoenix political consultant who is acting chairman of the Kyl campaign. "A vote against the President would have hurt him in a tough primary. A vote with the President, presumptively, will hurt him in the general election. But how it will look a year from now is a very different matter. If the economy recovers, a lot could be repaired for DeConcini."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona at a news conference in Washington at which he announced he would vote for the Clinton budget. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Money Woes In Europe May Aid U.S.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Official Washington hardly wishes to be seen celebrating a difficult and embarrassing moment for European leaders, but quietly, very quietly, many on this side of the Atlantic say that the currency crisis last week may turn out to be a blessing in disguise.
After the Exchange Rate Mechanism, the European Community's system of substantially fixed exchange rates, threatened to come apart, finance ministers and central bankers reluctantly agreed to let their currencies trade within much wider ranges. 
 The move will give the French, Italians and others more room to lower interest rates. Many analysts have said that lower rates and cheaper currencies are just what the doctor ordered to revive recession-bound European economies.
 
A Brake on Protectionism
 "It diffused tensions that drove interest rates up in Europe," David Mullins, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said of last weekend's decision. "Better economic conditions in Europe are positive for the U.S. and positive for the climate on trade, including the chances for reducing protectionist sentiment."
There is always the risk that rancor over the sharp braking of Europe's march toward a single currency could do wide damage, undermining global trade talks. But government officials, economists and executives on this side of the Atlantic are focusing on the economic and political prospects for reviving growth in the recession-ridden countries.
Sir Alan Walters, an adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when she held office and now vice chairman of the AIG Trading Corporation, a subsidiary of the international insurance company, put it bluntly. "Europe now has a chance of coming out of its deep slump," he said. "If it's good for Europe, so it's good for the United States economy."
American executives of companies with operations in Europe talk of the prospect of many nations' now lowering interest rates. The lower rates, in turn, could revive moribund economies and sales.
"This will help Thermo Electron," said John N. Hatsopoulos, chief financial officer of the company, based in Waltham, Mass. "The fact that they'll be able to cut their rates is going to be a lot of help."
Such optimism increased after the German central bank, which touched off the crisis by declining to lower its most important interest rate last week, lowered repurchase rates on Tuesday and again today.
 
Perils of Volatility Questioned
 The major prospective danger -- currency swings -- may not be as bad as people fear. Executives of companies that would be affected say they have learned to hedge against such fluctuations, and that the swings may not be large ones.
Hans Menhard, vice president at Siemens U.S.A., commented that "setting free exchange rates may not have as big an impact on actual exchange rates as people anticipate when they read about the 15 percent range," the upper limit agreed to Monday. Letting exchange rates find their natural levels, instead of forcing them out of line with individual nations' economic conditions, executives said, might mean less volatility.
For the Clinton Administration, which has been hampered by a sluggish, stop-and-go economic recovery, lower interest rates and the possibility of growth in nations countries is welcome indeed. Officials expect a mild increase in American exports to Europe as the recession there fades.
Economists and executives also say that the recent French-German tension could make it harder for the United States to get cooperation on international undertakings like the long-sought world trade treaty being negotiated under the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "It makes life more complicated politically," said John Lipsky of Salomon Brothers.
The currency crisis dented the credibility, and perhaps effectiveness, of some European Community governments. For the United States, such weakness poses a problem. "It's harder to get effective international cooperation, which often requires squishing domestic political opposition, when you have weak partners to deal with," an official here said.
And Mr. Mullins said, the weakness in the Exchange Rate Mechanism could make it harder to avoid a return to 1970's-style inflation at some point. "They do have a challenge ahead," he said. "They're free to cut rates, but they also have to worry about inflation credibility."
Some Administration officials said they see the currency crisis as a spat between married partners, not a basic threat to European unity. Optimists argue that the turmoil could actually make it easier to persuade Europeans to sign a trade treaty.
"This is good news on the Uruguay Round," said Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics and a former trade negotiator. "It'll provide some pickup in growth and blunt protectionist sentiment." And over the years, he said, when Europeans have been unable to cooperate in some area, they redoubled their efforts on another.
There is little disagreement that the economic effect, even if modest, is likely to be positive. If France, and especially Germany, reduce rates, the European currencies would presumably weaken somewhat against the dollar. The slightly stronger dollar, in turn, could help keep rates low by reducing expectations of inflation.
"European rate cuts will push up the dollar," said Rudiger Dornbush, an M.I.T. economist who is a strong advocate of loosening exchange rates. "With Greenspan's angst, that will come in handy."
Early corroboration seems to be coming from the bond market. On Tuesday, long-term yields dropped to the lowest level in 16 years as investors reacted to the prospect of lower European rates and signs that American growth remains anemic. Today, the price of the 30-year bond dropped slightly, raising its yield to 6.55 percent -- still a very low level.
Consumers could get a bit of a break, too, from last week's European monetary ferment. Americans traveling in Europe next year might suffer less sticker shock. "It's good news, but good news travels slow," said Rex Fritschie, head of a Chicago travel agency. "We're hoping this will have some effect in 1994.
 
Life Will Be a Cabernet
 A cheaper franc, lira and peseta might be a boon for wine lovers, said Don Zacharia, owner of Zachys, a big wine shop in Scarsdale, N.Y. "It's going to bring wine prices down." But he cautioned that with a lot of wine already in the pipeline, price breaks will not show up for six months to three years.
Of course, a stronger dollar would also make United States exports to Europe less competitive by making them expensive for Europeans to buy. About a quarter of American exports now go to Europe, a huge market for machinery, computers, aircraft and communications gear.
But an earlier revival of growth in Europe could give European workers and businesses more money to spend on American products, offsetting the negative effect of a stronger dollar.
American multinational companies with operations in Europe expect higher sales. "It adds to the uncertainty, but what's important to our business is whether the French feel confident about their future and therefore are willing to invest more," said Brad Allen, director of investor relations at Digital Equipment Corporation, the computer maker, half of whose sales are in Europe.
Digital, Bechtel and other multinationals hedge their international transactions to protect them form currency losses.
"It's business as usual for us," said Stephen C. Williams, vice president and manager of finance at Bechtel International, whose projects typically stretch over two or three years. "Even when the Exchange Rate Mechanism was in place and it might have been relevant for transactions over a few weeks," he said, "we had to hedge our position in currency, and we'll continue to do that."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
An idea for countering the deficit: forcing citizens to save.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IF Democrats do manage to shoehorn through a budget this week, what will they have accomplished? Something close to $500 billion in deficit reduction over the next five years -- $500 billion the Government would otherwise have bid away from private investment or borrowed abroad.
More than some people expected, perhaps. But to William Gale and Robert Litan, economists at the Brookings Institution, this glass is decidedly half empty. By their reckoning, the fact that Washington has turned itself inside out just to buy a few years' grace on the deficit is evidence that the long-term fight for fiscal rectitude has already been lost. 
Their startling alternative, to be published next month in the Brookings house journal: mandatory private savings to offset government's unwillingness to tax as much as it spends.
The premise is simple. Mr. Gale and Mr. Litan point out that the budget package will reduce the deficit to a still-substantial 3 percent of national output. After 1998, the percentage will begin to rise again unless spending is cut or taxes are raised. And in light of the political capital that Democrats have been forced to burn to prevail on this round of deficit reduction, the Brookings economists are deeply pessimistic about the prospects for another.
What to do? Look past the deficit to the core problem, say the economists: anemic national savings.
Japan runs as large a deficit as the United States when it is calculated as a fraction of national income, they note. But no one -- or, at least no economist outside Japan -- really worries because families and corporations still generate more than enough savings to finance very high rates of domestic investment. Almost two-thirds of Americans' net private savings, in contrast, is offset by Federal borrowing.
Some analysts who acknowledge that the deficit problem is a savings problem see incentives for savings as the solution. Indeed, that is why Washington offered a variety of tax benefits to encourage savings during the 1980's.
But the Brookings team is skeptical that tax incentives can work. In spite of all those carrots for savings in the Reagan era, they point out, the overall private savings rate fell to a record low. And research on the most popular of these initiatives, individual retirement accounts, suggest that they added barely a tenth of a percentage point to the total savings rate. Much of the tax benefit, it seems, went to the affluent, who would have saved anyway.
The Brookings economists propose to use sticks instead of carrots, requiring everyone under 65 to save who can afford it. More specifically, they would set a 4 percent minimum savings requirement for families with incomes between $20,000 and $40,000. The percentage would rise progressively, with a top savings bracket of 10 percent for those with incomes of more than $80,000.
Family savings would be measured from cash flows -- the difference between purchases and sales of assets. Failure to meet the minimum would be discouraged with stiff taxes on any shortfall. But exceptions would be made for people paying for college or burdened by catastrophic medical bills.
Mr. Litan acknowledges there would be plenty of ambiguity in the definition of savings, and thus plenty of loose ends to any regulations. But he thinks forced savings would be far more popular than tax rises or government spending cuts -- after all, savers could park the money pretty much anywhere they chose and get it back with interest when they retired. And he estimates that it could add up to 4 percentage points to national savings, a significant advance in an economy that currently saves 2 percent of income in a thrifty year.
Conservatives are not persuaded. Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, offers the classic objection: "I dislike government mandates." Some are not even amused: John Makin of the American Enterprise Institute calls the proposal "sick and wrong," adding, "It would be a major invasion of personal liberties."
What may surprise, though, is that forced savings also draws criticism, albeit more tempered, from nonconservatives. Richard Cooper, a Harvard economist who served in the Carter Administration, does not think added private savings would be an adequate substitute for deficit reduction. For one thing, he argues, the ballooning deficit is itself a problem, forcing Washington to devote an ever-greater portion of revenues to interest payments. For another, he thinks the linkages between national savings and future living standards are weaker than conventional wisdom suggests.
What counts most to future output, he says, is the rate of investment. And as long as foreigners are willing to lend the difference, investment will not be much affected by the level of domestic savings.
Such criticism leaves Mr. Litan more than a little frustrated. Will foreigners always be willing to underwrite America's growth? he wonders. Would Americans rest easy with the dependence? "I want to make one last stab at raising national savings before we give up," he says.

HEADLINE: U.S. Business Failures Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
United States business failures fell nearly 10 percent in the first half of this year as the American economy revived, according to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
A record number of businesses failed in the United States last year. But the rate of increase in failures peaked during the year and declined in the fourth quarter. 
 For the first six months of 1993, business failures were down in all major industries and nearly every region, the company reported.
Over all, business failures dropped 9.9 percent, to 45,749, from 50,793 in the corresponding period in 1992. Except for places with lingering problems -- California, Hawaii and Connecticut, for instance -- the turnaround is broad-based, said Joseph W. Duncan, vice president and corporate economist for Dun & Bradstreet.
"The current pattern of business failures reflects the fundamental strength of the United States economy," Mr. Duncan said.
This means larger companies are failing less, Dun & Bradstreet reported. The dollar value of liabilities associated with business failures declined 53.3 percent, to $25 billion, from $54 billion in the year-earlier period.

HEADLINE: Dow Off, but Nasdaq Index Closes at High

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Stocks moved in aimless fashion yesterday, as traders focused on the scheduled votes in Congress today and tomorrow on President Clinton's deficit-cutting package.
The Dow Jones industrial average declined 9.22 points to close at 3,552.05, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks fell 0.73 point, to 448.54.
 
Intel Paces Nasdaq
 But the other major market barometer, the Nasdaq composite index -- fueled by buying interest in secondary stocks and a two-point gain by the Intel Corporation, the second-largest Nasdaq company -- rose 4.78 points to set a record close of 713.79. 
 On Tuesday, Intel and Unisys said that they intended to develop new computer systems to replace large mainframes. The previous Nasdaq high of 712.49 was set on July 14.
"The market is in a tight trading range that gives ground grudgingly," said Alan Ackerman, executive vice president of Reich & Company. "It is treading water in anticipation of the President's budget bill and of the employment numbers due on Friday."
Mr. Ackerman added that Wall Street was not expecting a significant change from June's 7 percent unemployment level when the July unemployment rate is disclosed tomorrow. "This is clearly frustrating because not enough jobs are being created," he said.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate, with 230 million shares changing hands. Advancers led decliners by 969 to 938.
 
Kmart Rises on Heavy Trading
 Kmart, the most active Big Board stock, rose 1, to 21 5/8, after announcing that it was considering the sale of its Payless Drug Store subsidiary. Other retailers were also up for the day, though Tiffany lost 1 5/8 to close at 29 on lower earnings estimates by analysts.
In the latest development of the tobacco wars, Philip Morris said that it would cut prices of its discounted cigarette brands, instead of raising them as planned.
As a result, its stock dropped 1/2, to 47, while RJR Nabisco, whose R. J. Reynolds unit had declined to match the initial Philip Morris plan to raise prices, was unchanged at 5 and was the fourth-most-active stock on the New York exchange.
 
Auto Stocks Weak
 With July sales of domestic cars and trucks below analysts' expectations, auto stocks were weak yesterday. Ford Motor fell 7/8, to 53 3/4; Chrysler declined 5/8, to 43 1/4, and General Motors, on the most active list, was unchanged at 49 1/4.
Among the stronger insurance stocks, General Re, a property and casualty reinsurer, was up 2 1/2, to 125 1/2. After the market closed on Tuesday, the company reported a 16 percent gain in second-quarter earnings -- a larger increase than anticipated by Wall Street.
Selective buying was also noted during the day in some stocks that were heavily sold down recently. Apple Computer advanced 1 1/4, to 30 1/4; Cisco Systems increased 7/8, to 54 3/8, and Wellfleet rose 1 1/2, to 52 1/2.
Charter Medical said that it was considering the sale of 10 acute-care hospitals and that it had narrowed its third-quarter loss to $5.3 million. In reaction, the company's stock increased 1 1/4, to 20 3/4, a new 52-week high.
In contrast, Lockheed said that its missiles and space operation would cut about 1,600 jobs by December, following an earlier 1,600-job reduction this year. Its stock fell 4, to 62 1/2.

HEADLINE: Lautenberg Unpressured Over Budget

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the only Democratic Senator from the Northeast to oppose President Clinton's budget proposal, is being allowed to hold his ground without any challenge from New Jersey party leaders or arm-twisting by the White House.
No attempt has been made to enlist Gov. Jim Florio to try to change Mr. Lautenberg's mind, and party leaders said in interviews that they respected Mr. Lautenberg's decision. It is a decision that Democrats in New Jersey and in Washington understand to be a politically pragmatic one: the Senator faces a potentially tough re-election bid next year, fiscal policy is likely to be the main issue and New Jersey is a tax-weary state. 
 Mr. Lautenberg's position has forced party leaders to weigh the possibility of losing a Senate seat against a break in party discipline over the importance of the budget.
A senior Senate aide in Washington who spoke on the condition that he not be identified said the White House and the Democratic National Committee were aware of Mr. Lautenberg's future campaign. "I don't think they are leaning on him," he said. "I think they figured out a couple of weeks ago that he was a goner, that they had lost him.
 
'Don't Need to Be Said'
 "In terms of him going to the Democratic National Committee or the White House and saying, 'I need out on this one,' I don't think that happened," he said. "But these sorts of things are understood in Washington and don't need to be said."
Mr. Lautenberg could be running next year against former Gov. Thomas H. Kean or Representative Dick Zimmer, a two-term Republican Congressman who voted against two state budgets, including Mr. Kean's last budget, when he was a member of the New Jersey Senate.
Mr. Zimmer, who has said he would defer to Mr. Kean if the former Governor decides to run against Mr. Lautenberg, has become something of a fiscal watchdog in Washington. As a member of the Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs, and Science, Space and Technology Committees, Mr. Zimmer has been among those leading the fight to scrap the space station program as wasteful.
Mr. Lautenberg has said his campaign did not figure in his decision to oppose Mr. Clinton's budget, but in discussing his reasons for opposing the plan with reporters, Mr. Lautenberg said some expensive items should have been excised to make it more equitable, "such as the space station and the supercollider."
 
Whitman Echoes Stand
 The only apparent pressure on the eve of the votes in the House and Senate came today from Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for New Jersey governor, who urged Mr. Lautenberg to stick to his guns. Mrs. Whitman also sent letters to members of the state's Congressional delegation, urging them to follow Mr. Lautenberg's lead. Senator Bill Bradley is supporting the bill; in the House, all six New Jersey Republicans and three of seven Democrats opposed it in June.
But that bit of campaign maneuvering aside, the 69-year-old lawmaker has shielded himself from being viewed by party regulars as deserting under fire by making his opposition to the budget clear in June
The minority leader of the State Senate, John A. Lynch of New Brunswick, said Mr. Lautenberg had paid his dues to the party and had been able to justify his position. "If this was an ideal budget plan it would be worth a damn to put political blood into it," he said. "If it was real good and Frank wouldn't step up to the plate, some people here would be unhappy with him.
"But it is not ideal and he is running next year," Mr. Lynch said. "He certainly has been supportive of the party and good for New Jersey."
Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's spokesman, said the White House had never asked the Governor to intercede with Mr. Lautenberg and that the Governor had never expressed an opinion about the Senator's position. "I don't know what they're doing, but they have not asked us to help," Mr. Shure said of the White House.
State Senator Raymond Lesniak, the New Jersey Democratic chairman, said he was asked by the Clinton Administration to talk to the entire Congressional delegation "about the need to address the budget deficit to keep interest rates down and the economy rolling and to get this poor economy behind us, but I was never asked to twist anyone's arm."
"If there is any pressure on Senator Lautenberg it's not coming through me or anyone I'm aware of, in terms of the White House or the Democratic National Committee," he said. "They understand he made his decision and it's going to stand."
Mr. Lesniak also said Mr. Florio was out campaigning for his own re-election in November and leaving the question of the President's budget proposal up to the state's Congressional delegation.
But while there may be no direct pressure from his party colleagues to change his vote, Mr. Lautenberg is one of a number of Democratic Congressmen and Senators in several states whose constituents are being called by the Democratic National Committee. Staff members began calling the constituents on Tuesday and asking those who support the compromise budget worked out by a Senate-House Conference Committee to phone their Representatives and urge them to vote for it.
A woman who lives in Summit said she received one of the calls and was asked if she would be willing to be put through to Mr. Lautenberg's office. "I waited and they connected me with his voice mail," she said. "All I got was a message saying the mailbox was full before it hung up."
The telephone lines at the New Jersey district offices of both Senators Lautenberg and Bradley were busy throughout the day today.
Mr. Lautenberg said in June that the budget plan was bad for New Jersey. He said the President had made several concessions to Senators from Western states over mineral and grazing rights in order to round up votes but had not recognized New Jersey's problems, including the impact on the state's large elderly population of the increase in taxes on Social Security benefits. "An elderly couple in a nursing home are not rich at $45,000 in the state of New Jersey." he said. "We're a state with high enough taxes."
Mr. Lautenberg added that it was not at all clear that his vote would help his campaign. "Next year's campaign could be influenced either way," he said. "If the economy stays strong and things prosper, there will be those who might say I should have voted for it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg was in his Washington office yesterday, free of last-minute calls trying to persuade him to change his opposition to President Clinton's budget package. The Democratic leadership had decided to stay away in light of his re-election prospects next year in a tax-angry state. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germans Trim Another Rate And Give a Lift to the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday as a cut in a German interest rate spurred selling of the mark.
The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, reduced the 28-day security repurchase rate 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.70 percent. On Tuesday, the Germans trimmed the 14-day repurchase rate. The moves reinforced speculation that the German central bank might reduce its benchmark discount rate late this month. 
 "This is the first time the repo rate is lower than the discount rate," said Tom Leonard, assistant vice president at Postipankki Bank. "That's enough reason for investors to be long dollars." The German discount rate is currently 6.75 percent.
A Bundesbank council member, Otmar Issing, bolstered this view by saying that officials there would carefully review their ability to take monetary-policy steps, partly to calm markets after the overhaul of the European Monetary System last weekend.
Dealers who had expected rates to tumble in other European countries instead sold considerable quantities of marks that had been hoarded at the height of the monetary crisis. Speculators traded marks mainly for French and Belgian francs, indirectly increasing the dollar's value against the mark.
Outside Germany, one dealer at an American bank in London said, "short-term rates are still painfully high so people are looking to bank profits" made on the mark in the last week.
Yesterday, in late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7100 marks from 1.7065 marks on Tuesday.
The dollar also rebounded some against the yen. It was quoted In New York at 104.88 yen in late trading, up from 104.42 on Tuesday.
Dealers said the currency markets had already anticipated a widening of Japan's current-accounts surplus for the 27th month. Japan said yesterday that the surplus, a broad index of trade in goods and services, increased sharply in June, to $10.71 billion from $9.44 billion a year earlier.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Court Backs G.M. on Plant Closing

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 4

 BODY:
A Michigan appeals court today reversed a ruling handed down in February that had prevented the General Motors Corporation from closing its Willow Run assembly plant in Ypsilanti, Mich.
The ruling was a victory for G.M. The auto maker had determined in 1992 that it wanted to consolidate production at a plant in Arlington, Tex., because of financial losses and declining sales of its large, rear-wheel-drive cars like the Chevrolet Caprice, Buick Roadmaster and Cadillac Brougham. 
 "Obviously, we're pleased," Margaret Holmes, a G.M. spokeswoman, said. On Thursday, she said, G.M. will petition the appeals court to make the decision effective immediately so that the company can shut Willow Run permanently. The plant has been temporarily closed since early July.
 
 
Appeal Is Promised
 Doug Winters, a lawyer for the Township of Ypsilanti, said he would immediately appeal the decision to the Michigan Supreme Court. In a statement, Mr. Winters said, "the township firmly believes that it will ultimately prevail in its position that G.M. made a binding promise" to build cars in return for tax abatements "that it cannot breach with impunity."
The legal proceedings have come to resemble a condemned prisoner's efforts to fend off execution. Ms. Holmes declined to elaborate on whether the company was prepared to start production again, pending the State Supreme Court's decision on whether to hear a further appeal. "We are prepared to do what we have to do," she said.
The decision was a blow to Local 1776 of the United Automobile Workers, whose 2,500 members face losing their jobs. Union members have been living under a sword for nearly two years, since G.M. determined that it would operate only the Ypsilanti plant or the Arlington one. The decision in February by Judge Donald Shelton was a reprieve, but G.M. and many legal experts predicted then that it would not stand.
For the moment, the legal maneuvers have a practical benefit: members are still able to draw jobless benefits that approach full salaries.
The issue is whether G.M. promised Ypsilanti to continue production at the plant in return for a total of $13.5 million worth of tax abatements granted in 1984 and 1988. Judge Shelton ruled that G.M. had closed the plant to maximize production in Arlington, not because of insufficient demand for the models.
 
 
The Union's Theory
 Union officials had theorized that G.M. chose Arlington precisely because it was willing to add a third work shift and the Ypsilanti plant was not. G.M. declined to say exactly why it chose Arlington.
G.M. had tried to repay back taxes in an attempt to mollify the city and defuse the lawsuit, but Judge Shelton disallowed the move.
The three-justice appeals court ruled unanimously that statements by the auto maker that were interpreted as promises "were, instead, expressions of defendant's hopes or expectations of continued employment at Willow Run."
Mr. Williams said he was confident that the State Supreme Court would agree to hear the case and would reinstate Judge Shelton's ruling. "No one should step in the ring with a heavyweight if they do not expect to be hit a few times," he said in his statement. "In this case, the first round went to the township, the second round went to General Motors. There are many more rounds."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unless the Michigan Supreme Court reverses an appeal won by General Motors yesterday, the Willow Run assembly plant in Ypsilanti, Mich., will close as a result of a corporate effort to consolidate production. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: Zero Hour for the Budget

 BODY:
The budget compromise that Congress will now vote on isn't as bold or inspiring as President Clinton asserted in his television address. But neither will it lead to the economic Dunkirk forecast by Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader. To the President's and the conference committee's credit, the plan would begin to bring the deficit monster under control without imposing undue harm on a fragile economy. Where the plan comes up short is in its failure to tilt public and private spending toward investment -- the key to long-term growth.
This budget does not embody the economic plan Bill Clinton ran on or the economic agenda he set forth in his compelling speech to a joint session of Congress in February. He promised then to stimulate the economy, to strengthen the country's economic base with innovative investment programs and to reduce the deficit through new taxes on the rich and cuts in Federal spending. Both the stimulus and the investment initiatives have all but disappeared, leaving a deficit reduction program. 
 But that program is coherent and fair; and while the plan does not promise salvation, a weary Congress would do a weary public a huge favor by passing it now, returning to unfinished business later on. A special burden falls on the balky Senate Democrats who, if all vote no, will torpedo the bill. Not one of them advances a sufficiently riveting principle to justify a negative vote. But their obstinacy could damage the economy and the vitality of their party and its leadership.
The compromise budget cuts deficits by almost $500 billion over five years, primarily by raising taxes on families earning more than $100,000 a year and raising taxes on everyone else by less than a dollar a week. It would cut defense spending by about $100 billion and Medicare by about $55 billion.
The conferees didn't preserve many of Mr. Clinton's investment initiatives because, to reach a compromise that could get past Senate Democrats, they scrapped the President's $70 billion broad-based energy tax and adopted instead a Senate-passed gas tax that would raise only $20 billion. The conferees made up the difference responsibly -- by chipping away at but not eviscerating the President's programs to provide new money for low-paid workers (including, for the first time, those without children), families on the verge of breaking up, childhood immunization, food stamps and economic development for urban slums.
The conferees made several unwise decisions. In a triumph of petty bookkeeping over economic good sense, they chose to impose more taxes this year, when the economy is limping along, than the Senate had proposed. They also approved several "temporary" tax breaks even though they know that Congress will almost surely extend them when they expire. Under the budget rules, that means Congress will then have to find offsetting spending cuts and taxes.
Finally, the proposed "cuts" in Medicare are essentially disguised tax hikes. Congress wouldn't cut benefits for retirees, but would reduce reimbursement for doctors and hospitals, which will be expected to make up the loss by raising fees for their non-Medicare, mostly middle-class patients.
The plan is not, contrary to Mr. Clinton's claims, a first step to a "national economic strategy." It's deficit reduction, pure and simple. But it would impose the burden of reducing the deficit on those most able to afford it. And it is far better than anything its opponents in either party have offered.

HEADLINE: Embattled at the Source

BYLINE: By Robert F. Kennedy; Robert F. Kennedy is a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Hudson Riverkeeper.

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
Last month, Mayor David Dinkins proposed a $720 million plan that could protect New York City's water supply for decades. This program has been rightly praised by environmental and community organizations for its emphasis on protecting drinking water at its source -- the 2,000 square miles of watershed land that surrounds the 18 city-owned reservoirs -- and for seeking a partnership with upstate communities and recognizing the high economic and social costs of pollution.
It is vital that the City Council support it when it votes on the Mayor's revised capital budget in September. A concerted short-term effort can save billions over the long haul. 
 The importance of keeping the water clean was reinforced by the outbreak of E. coli bacteria in the drinking water in various lower Manhattan neighborhoods last week. City officials believe that the outbreak was caused by contamination in a Westchester County reservoir.
Strong support of the Mayor's plan is essential if it is to clear a major hurdle. If the Environmental Protection Agency is not convinced by December that the city will protect its drinking water, the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act mandates that the water must be put through billion-dollar filtration systems.
The E.P.A. has wide discretion in deciding whether a filter system is needed, and the city must convince the agency that it will protect the water supply for the next 20 years.
The Mayor's program would set aside $272 million to acquire land around all 18 reservoirs to insulate them from pollution. The plan would also allocate $120 million to help towns that border the reservoirs to create their own protection programs, $230 million to hire technicians to insure that the facilities and communities are complying with environmental laws and $128 million to rebuild antiquated sewage plants upstate that may contaminate the supply.
By using existing surpluses from water and sewage fees, Mayor Dinkins and the Commissioner of Environmental Protection say they can deliver the program without violating a two-year moratorium on raising water rates.
Already, the city has spent more than $600 million to filter the water coming from its Croton Reservoir system in Westchester County -- where overdevelopment has polluted the supply. The remaining 90 percent of the city's drinking water -- from the Delaware and Catskill systems -- is naturally so pure that it doesn't require filtration. But the E.P.A., remembering failures of past city administrations to protect that water from contamination, is understandably skeptical about our ability to do so now.
If the agency decides against the Mayor's proposal, a filtration plant large enough to treat the Catskill and Delaware water would cost $8 billion -- more than one-fourth of the city's entire budget. Annual costs for operation and maintenance would be about $300 million.
And a filter plant does not guarantee pure water. Although it would remove most disease-bearing organisms from the city water, it would miss some: The outbreak of lethal cryptosporidium in Milwaukee this spring originated in filtered water. The filter would not remove many of the toxic and organic chemicals, as well as carcinogens like benzene and some pesticides, that would build up in unprotected reservoirs. Also, a giant filtration plant would take decades to build, leaving New Yorkers vulnerable in the interim.
To pay for the filter plant, the city would likely have to double water rates for most residential users. The costs would hit poor New Yorkers and their landlords particularly hard. Low-income dwellings tend to use more water than more affluent counterparts because they tend to house more people per unit, get more daytime use (because the residents are often unemployed) and are more likely to have leaky pipes.
Landlords who, because of rent-control laws, cannot pass increased water costs on to their tenants might slip into arrears on their water and sewer bills. Rate increases would cause some of them to abandon rent-controlled properties or other buildings with marginal profits, and the city would be forced to take ownership. City-owned buildings do not pay taxes or water bills; it costs the equivalent of the tax revenues from three private apartments to subsidize each city-owned unit. The city spends $200 million each year maintaining 40,000 housing units, and 50,000 more units in the city's poorest neighborhoods would be in jeopardy of being abandoned if water rates rose dramatically.
A traditional obstacle to a strong watershed protection program has been opposition by upstate communities to land-use and pollution controls. So the Dinkins administration is making sure these communities would be major beneficiaries of the new program.
Many of these towns draw their water from city aqueducts and profit from the city's efforts to keep it clean. In Westchester County, 80 percent of the water comes from the New York City supply. If the E.P.A. ordered the city to filter its water, these towns would be forced to build their own water treatment plants, which, because of economies of scale, would cause greater hardship to local residents than to the people of New York City.
Since the city pays taxes on the water system's land (it is the biggest taxpayer in the Catskills), local communities pocket this money without having to shoulder infrastructure improvements for water, sewer and schools. The plan's allotted $120 million partnership would help clean up local environmental problems and finance badly needed infrastructure improvements.
And the esthetic benefits of the green buffer lands, beautiful waterscapes and recreational fisheries would enhance local property values.

HEADLINE: Essay;
President Hobson

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Thomas Hobson ran a rent-a-horse agency for the hard-riding scholars of Cambridge, England. His system was not customer-friendly: renters could take only the next available horse, thereby saving wear and tear on the more popular models. This led the poet Thomas Ward to coin a phrase in 1630: "Where to elect there is but one/ 'Tis Hobson's choice, -- take that or none."
President Clinton adopted Hobson's style in his Oval Office address the other night. "Now there are only two choices: our plan or no plan." He then zapped opponents of the Democratic plan as "guardians of gridlock." (I would have added an alliterative advance adjective, "grim," to convey the full nattering-nabobs-of-negativism flavor, but speech writers today are more restrained.) 
 There it is, my recalcitrant fellow Democrats, says President Hobson: Pass the leadership compromise or pass nothing. And if it's to be nothing, then the deficit and interest rates will soar and the stock market and the sky will fall.
But that's not the way the world of Washington works. Reality check:
Victorious Democrats decided to put forward an economic plan all their own, with tax increases starting back before the inauguration and promised reductions in the planned increases of spending starting three years out (unless something comes up). Because this is the opposite of what most voters want, Democratic leaders found it hard getting a tax-now, maybe-cut-later plan through the Democratic Congress.
That explains the tinkering and compromising: Clinton's initial leftward lurch has been modified to Congress's leftward lean. We are now down to the short strokes and Democratic leaders are pretending it's all or nothing.
That's unreal. If a further adjustment in the "final" plan is needed to win a handful of votes in the House, the Speaker has the leeway to make yet one more deal. If Senator Dennis DeConcini had refused to fall on his sword -- against the interests of his retired constituents in Arizona -- the majority leader could have found some special, last-minute legislative seduction to make Sam Nunn the new Democratic hero.
To paraphrase Yogi Berra, it's not over because it's never over. If the impossible happened, and the "final plan" were defeated on Friday, a new "final, final" plan would surely emerge next week or next month.
Don't be fooled by the outrageous "our plan or no plan"; Hobson doesn't live here anymore. Whatever Democratic budget ultimately passes will be "our plan" and be declared a famous victory.
With that firmly understood, it was a pleasure to see the President make a prime-time speech from the Oval Office, the opposition leader make a serious rebuttal, and the networks carry it all and the best newspapers print the texts. Gridlock, shmidlock; that's democracy in action.
Note that I just wrote, and you just read, "the President," meaning Bill Clinton, without straining. Oval office addresses, like East Room news conferences, do what talk shows and town-hall rallies cannot do: confer the ineffable heft of Presidentiality on a politician. The President sat there and quietly sought to persuade in an organized fashion, growing in stature before the nation's eyes.
No, he should not have aped Ross Perot in using the pitchman's charts; yes, he needs to learn how to modulate his voice and change his pace. But the speech was a creditable effort and his delivery has markedly improved.
Bob Dole's "four no's" were as negative as a series of no's usually are; the gallant rear guard must not let itself turn into the Old Guard. The Republican strategy -- to let the Democrats squeeze their own juice and stew in it -- is aimed at winning the Senate in '94, but cannot suffice for reclaiming the White House in '96. In coming rebuttals, the party should showcase Kemp, Alexander, Cheney, Wilson, Weld and other out-of-towners with no's in newer clothes.
The Democratic plan is quick to tax and slow to cut. That's a mistake liberals are born to make. For conservatives, the alternative is not to accept Hobson's choice, to say "O.K., then, no plan at all." Instead it's to say: "You guys won the election. Now fix your plan to reduce the deficit the way the electorate is ready to accept: Tax a little, cut a lot."

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Clinton Budget Plan Doesn't Do Enough

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Nine Wayward Democrats" (editorial, July 30) characterizes those Senate Democrats who have stopped to question the deficit-reduction package moving through a conference committee as irresponsible or "engaged in reckless personal aggrandizement." I disagree.
I do not have misgivings about the package because it has "gas taxes that are too high." I will support an increase in the gasoline tax, and those who quibble over a difference of a few cents therein are wasting time. 
 You are correct, on the other hand, to say that I object to "spending cuts that are too low." I believe that a majority of the Senate would support real, straightforward spending cuts. Several of my colleagues and I have asked Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, to call a special session of Congress exclusively to cut the Federal budget.
But please remember how the country got into its budget mess. Throughout the early 1980's, Congress -- blinded by rhetoric of gridlock and economic crisis -- subverted its better judgment to that of a President whose budget proposals were economically suspect.
President Clinton's plan is ambitious and sincere. But it can be improved. And if it is as worthy as you say, surely it can sustain the debate you disparage.
 
BOB KERREY
U.S. Senator from Nebraska
Washington, July 30, 1993

HEADLINE: Drug Treatment Referral in Criminal Courts Must Continue

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As judges assigned to Manhattan Criminal Court, we are confronted daily with defendants who have committed quality-of-life crimes, such as shoplifting, jumping subway turnstiles, tampering with public telephones, trespass, possession of small amounts of drugs, disorderly conduct. 
 Many of these defendants are addicted to narcotics. Imprisonment does not address the reasons they continue in their criminal conduct.
Recognizing this, members of the bench and court administration approached the Deputy Mayor's Office for Public Safety hoping to initiate an alternative to incarceration that could break the cycle of addiction and crime in certain cases. After a series of meetings, and with vital support from the Manhattan District Attorney, the result was a court treatment referral office at 100 Centre Street.
For the last year and a half, this office matched defendants with drug treatment programs throughout the city. To be placed in a program, a defendant had to commit himself or herself to treatment for up to one year. Offenders were interviewed by the office's sole staff member. If found qualified, they were enrolled in court-monitored drug treatment at outpatient and inpatient facilities. If an offender failed to complete treatment, he or she typically faced a substantial jail sentence.
We have just learned that the program is being effectively terminated. The program's one staff member has resigned and, citing a hiring freeze, the city will not replace him.
Since the entire annual budget of the referral office is less than the cost of maintaining two prisoners at Riker's Island for a year, this decision could not be more shortsighted. (Conservative estimates place the annual cost of incarceration of one individual at $35,000.)
Defendants who plead for treatment as an alternative to jail will now have to seek programs on their own, greatly reducing the likelihood of placement and making monitoring by the court much more difficult.
With judges and criminal justice experts across the country calling for more flexibility in sentencing for cases of nonviolent addiction-based crime, it is a terrible waste to turn our backs on an alternative that is in place. Ending this program, in the name of economy, is not cost-effective. Inevitably, the city will bear a much higher price in continued crimes and the cost of subsequent incarceration.
 
LAURA E. DRAGER
ARLENE GOLDBERG, RUTH PICKHOLZ
LAURA SAFER-ESPINOZA
New York, July 27, 1993
 
The letter was signed also by 10 other Manhattan Criminal Court judges.

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1007 words

HEADLINE: New York City Fined Again on Homeless

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Frustrated by lack of progress in housing homeless families, a state judge yesterday imposed a new round of fines on New York City and again held four top officials -- including two Deputy Mayors -- in contempt of court.
The ruling marked the second time since last November that the judge, Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, cited officials as individuals, a rare legal move aimed at prodding the city into action. She said in a 23-page decision that she would soon rule on whether to levy individual fines or even jail the officials for failing to provide prompt housing. 
 The decision "is indicative of the fact that the judiciary is sick and tired of excuses from city officials for violating court orders," said Steven Banks, coordinating lawyer for the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project, which filed the lawsuit. "For three and a half years, senior city officials have acted as if they were above the law and didn't have to comply."
 
Long Legal Battle
 Yesterday's ruling was the most recent action in a decadelong legal battle in which the court has tried -- through fines and individual accountability -- to force the city into reforming its vast bureaucracy serving the homeless.
In her decision, Justice Freedman raised the specter of jail or fines after citing a decision by the State Appellate Division last week barring her from her first choice: forcing the officials to spend a night in an emergency assistance unit, the city offices where homeless families apply for shelter and, against the court order, currently stay when shelter cannot be found.
O. Peter Sherwood, the city's Corporation Counsel, called the decision "counterproductive." He said the city has been working to restructure its massive and complex homeless system -- which cares for more than 5,000 families each night -- and has acted in good faith to meet her demands.
He said he was especially disturbed by Justice Freedman's decision to cite four officials individually: First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel; Cesar A. Perales, Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services; Barbara J. Sabol, Administrator of the Department of Social Services, and Kenneth Murphy, Deputy Commissioner for Crisis Intervention Services.
"It's dramatic but frankly it serves no purpose other than to embarrass the men and women who have been working hard to resolve the problem," Mr. Sherwood said. "They are being held in contempt not for not trying but for not being wholly successful."
 
Money to Go to Families
 In her decision, Justice Freedman acknowledged their efforts and said she was actually "reluctant" to hold them in contempt.
"But the record of continuing and repeated violations leaves me with no choice," she wrote. "It is not a defense that the municipal defendants were attempting to comply or acting in good faith."
The order did not appear to expand or resolve the questions in the lawsuit, one of many legal actions aimed at improving services for the homeless. The fight has focused on the city's practice of housing some families in three city offices -- often overnight and longer -- when there is no space available in shelters.
What the order did do was impose new fines on the city for violating the order prohibiting it from keeping the families in the offices. Mr. Banks said he had documented some 7,000 violations involving thousands of families since last November.
It is too early to tally the cost of the fines, which would be paid to the families directly. The fine schedule is $100 to each family forced to remain in the offices from midnight until 8 A.M., $50 more past noon and $250 for each 24-hour period.
 
Fines and More Fines

 
The city is already saddled with another set of fines for the period from January to June 1992. This amount has not been tallied because the city is seeking to appeal the fine to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. But Thomas Crane, chief of the General Litigation Division of the Corporation Counsel's Office, said it could be as high as $1 million.
The ruling yesterday also switched one of the four officials named in the original order last November. Jeffrey L. Carples, a former H.R.A. deputy commissioner in charge of the shelter system, has been taken off the suit and replaced by Mr. Perales. Mr. Carples is now Mr. Perales's chief of staff.
An intriguing question raised by yesterday's order is whether Justice Freedman would take the drastic step of jailing any of the four officials, an option under state law. Mr. Sherwood said he could think of no case in the country in which a government official was jailed under similar circumstances.
Arguments on contempt penalties will begin in the next few weeks. In an interview, Justice Freedman declined to reveal her intentions but seemed hesitant about incarceration.
"All of these people are good, hard-working honest people," she said. "And they certainly don't deserve to go jail."
The city is also seeking to appeal to the Court of Appeals any individual fines.
 
Visit to Two Offices
 On July 13, Justice Freedman visited two of the offices where families are held after hearing that an average of 42 families a night were kept at the offices between July 1 and July 9. In her decision, she described children "doubled up in cribs, on the floors and in strollers." A number of people among the 48 to 60 families there appeared to be ill and there appeared to be few placements in shelters.
She said in an interview yesterday that her difficulty with the city was "an inability to really take hold of the situation one way or another."
Charles V. Raymond, Commissioner of the newly created Department of Homeless Services, said the city had been working diligently to overhaul the entire homeless system. The office is developing a long-term plan for more transitional and permanent housing, working to return homeless people to their families and trying to provide services to deal with mental illness, substance abuse and unemployment.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 11, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A subheading on Thursday with an article about a judge's order of fines against New York City and his finding of four officials in contempt over lack of progress in housing the homeless misattributed a quotation. It was the plaintiff's lawyer, Steven Banks, and not the judge, who said, "Senior city officials have acted as if they were above the law."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Clinton Plan's Economic Drag Cited

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Should the long end of the bond market rally when -- and if -- Congress approves President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan, he probably should not regard the buying as strictly investor applause.
In his televised address to the nation Tuesday night, the President used this year's bond market rally, which has pulled the yield on the 30-year bond down to its lowest level in 16 years, as a signal of approval from what he called "the most conservative and skeptical critics of all, those who run our financial markets." 
 But the reasons interest rates have been dropping are not, in general, the reasons Mr. Clinton has invoked to urge approval of the five-year budget plan: to reduce the deficit and to get the economy moving.
 
 
Opposite Reason
 In fact, rates are coming down partly for the opposite reason. Many analysts expect that the tax increases and spending reductions in the budget plan will restrain economic growth in the near future, which should make inflation less of a concern to investors. Inflation is the enemy of fixed-income investors because it nibbles away at their returns.
The fact that the plan calls for making an income tax increase on the so-called wealthy retroactive to Jan. 1 of this year will just add to that economic drag.
Another force pulling down the yield on the 30-year bond has nothing to do with the economy or the deficit. It is the supply factor: the Treasury has cut the annual sale of these bonds by about 40 percent and will begin auctioning them only two times a year, rather than its customary four times.
The planned deficit reduction, $496 billion over five years, is also regarded skeptically by some analysts and investors because many spending cuts would not become effective for several years. Also, the deficit would not be reduced significantly below current levels but rather just below the higher levels it would reach if no plan were approved.
 
 
'Subject to Question'
 "The deficit reduction impact of the Clinton plan is certainly subject to question," Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said. "But it will put a drag on the economy and thereby prevent inflation from accelerating."
David Munro, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics and an analyst who has praised the deficit reduction plan, agreed that many analysts would cite the fiscal drag as a reason for a decline in interest rates. "The Republicans are going to be saying that, and not because they are being partisan but because it is their intuition," he said.
He argued that "it will be the passage of the uncertainty that will spark the market."
But Mr. Munro agreed that the deficit reduction in the Clinton plan was not large. "It is not so much deficit reduction as it is that at least we've got a bridle-on-the-horse type of thing," he said, adding that the benefit of the President's plan is that something is being done after many years of drifting.
Mr. Munro agreed that the plan's combination of tax increases and spending cuts would create a drag on the economy, but discounted its severity. He estimated that annual economic growth would be about one-quarter of a percentage point lower over the next several years than it would have been without the plan in place.
Mr. Fine said that the decline in interest rates this year, which the Clinton Administration has been counting on to spur the economy, would not be enough to offset the fiscal drag. "High interest rates are good at choking off activity but low interest rates are not as good at stimulating growth when things are slack," he said.
 
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices fell yesterday and yields rose as some investors worried about the outlook for approval of the deficit reduction package. But the plan's prospect improved after trading ended when Senator Dennis DeConcini, a Democrat of Arizona who had opposed the original plan the Senate approved, said that he would support this version.
The price of the 30-year bond was off 15/32 of a point as the yield rose to 6.55 percent, from 6.52 percent on Tuesday. The yield on the 10-year note jumped to 5.87 percent, from 5.79 percent the day before.
The Treasury announced the details of its quarterly auctions, saying it would raise a record $38.5 billion next week.
On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction $16.5 billion of 3-year notes, followed by $11 billion each of 10-year notes on Wednesday and 30-year bonds on Thursday. After next week, the 30-year bond will only be auctioned every six months.
The Treasury also said that it would continue its test of the single-price auction with two-year and five-year notes through next August. It had been scheduled to end in September, but the Treasury said it needed more data before it could decide if the technique would be used in other auctions.
Under the single-price auction all securities are awarded at the highest yield bid by primary dealers. It has resulted in both aggressive bidding that has saved the Treasury money and weak bidding that has cost the Treasury in the last year, according to traders.
Under the traditional auction system still being used for other Treasury securities, the securities are awarded based on the yields bid, starting with the lowest yield. This system has a so-called winner's curse, in which the low-yield bidder can pay more than other dealers whose higher bids are accepted.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 12, 1993, Thursday

A chart in Business Day on Aug. 5 headed "Freddie Mac Yields," with an article about the previous day's trading in the credit markets, misstated average weekly yields on the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's 30-year and 15-year participation certificates on fixed-rate mortgages. HEADLINE: Victim's Cousin Accused of Killing Family

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
To people who knew him, John Camacho was a troubled young man who had received a golden chance to straighten out his life: the help of a cousin and her husband in Connecticut. The couple, Santa and Al Marquez, gave him advice, let him stay in their home and tried to keep him away from what they saw as his aimless life in Brooklyn.
But on Tuesday night Mr. Camacho, 22, was arrested and accused of killing the Marquezes and their children, Jonathan, 14, and Crystal, 6. The police charged another man, Luis Garcia, 22, with helping Mr. Camacho to take the bodies of Mrs. Marquez and her children last Friday from the family's home in South Windsor, Conn., to Brooklyn, where they were dumped by the East River. 
 Investigators in Connecticut and New York said that near the end of June, Mr. Marquez, frustrated in his efforts to help Mr. Camacho, ordered him out of the house.
"It's our understanding that he was in fact told to leave the house," said Sgt. Thomas C. Hart, a spokesman for the South Windsor police. Mr. Camacho, who is unemployed, stayed at the Y.M.C.A. in Hartford after that, the police said.
 
An Extended Family
 The killings struck an extended family that reaches from Connecticut to New York to Puerto Rico. Mr. Camacho was a second cousin of Mrs. Marquez and had known the couple all his life. Mr. Marquez, who was 48 and a supervisor in the Hartford Public Works Department, and Mrs. Marquez, 46, a nutritional counselor at Hartford Hospital, had long taken an interest in him, said Susana Ortiz, Mrs. Marquez's sister.
"We know there was a problem there," Ms. Ortiz said. "But really, this is hard to talk about. We're all so close."
Working on a tip, New York City detectives arrested Mr. Garcia, a messenger, early Tuesday morning near his home at 244 Bond Street in the Gowanus housing project in Brooklyn. He then led the police to Mr. Camacho, who was picked up early Tuesday evening at 28th Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan.
Mr. Camacho was charged with four counts of murder while Mr. Garcia was charged with hindering a prosecution and tampering with physical evidence.
 
Hearing Scheduled
 Late last night, Mr. Camacho and Mr. Garcia appeared before Judge Martin G. Karopkin in Criminal Court and contested a request for extradition. A preliminary hearing was set by Judge Karopkin for Aug. 17. A request for bail for Mr. Garcia was denied.
A young man outside Mr. Camacho's residence at 417 Baltic Street in Brooklyn, who would not give his name, said Mr. Camacho had graduated from John Jay High School in Park Slope. The man said Mr. Camacho had worked at odd jobs but had not had steady employment.
A neighbor who said her daughter grew up with Mr. Camacho and is his friend said, "He didn't cause nobody no trouble." She added that Mr. Camacho always showed "respect and manners." She also declined to give her name.
 
Gun Recovered
 Deputy Inspector John Lynch of Brooklyn detectives said that investigators found checkbooks and credit cards belonging to Mrs. Marquez at Mr. Garcia's apartment, as well as a .44-caliber handgun that they believe is the murder weapon. It was Mr. Garcia, the detectives said, who provided more details of the killings.
Investigators said that Mr. Camacho went to the Marquez family's home at 721 Kings Street in South Windsor on Friday evening, where he shot his victims several times.
He then called Mr. Garcia for help in removing the bodies, and made the two-hour trip to get him at about 9 P.M., the investigators said. They said that the pair returned to South Windsor and placed the bodies of Mrs. Marquez and her children in the family station wagon.
They dumped the bodies about 5 a.m. near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the investigators said.

(V&P News Service)
