HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE;
HOUSE PASSES BUDGET PLAN, BACKING CLINTON BY 218-216 AFTER HECTIC MANEUVERING

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
After a day of frantic maneuvering to lock up the final votes, the House of Representatives narrowly approved President Clinton's five-year economic plan tonight, putting him on the verge of the most important victory of his young Presidency.
The vote, in doubt until the final gavel, was 218 to 216. All 175 Republicans voted against the measure, but they were joined by only 41 Democrats. The victory was provided by the 217 Democrats and one independent who stood with the President. 
 If only one more Democrat had voted with the opposition, the bill would have failed on a tie vote. The last two Democrats to vote and provide the margin of victory were Representatives Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, a freshman who represents a heavily Republican district in the Philadelphia suburbs, and Pat Williams, who represents the entire state of Montana.
 
'Margin Was Close'
 All week long, Democratic leaders had predicted that the bill would pass but did not know whose votes would provide the margin of victory. As late as dinner time, the final votes were not in line.
President Clinton praised the House tonight for "putting the national interest ahead of the narrow interest."
Speaking from the South Portico of the White House to jubilant aides, Mr. Clinton declared, "The margin was close, but the mandate is clear."
Mr. Clinton ended his remarks by saying, "I congratulate those who voted, I urge the Senate to follow their lead, and I look forward to continuing the battle tomorrow."
 
Hinging on Kerrey
 In the Senate, the final vote, expected Friday night, hinges on the decision of the only Democrat Senator who has not announced his position, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia announced tonight that he would vote against the bill.
The Democrats hold a 56-to-44 majority in the Senate, and all the Republicans and six Democrats have now announced their opposition. If Mr. Kerrey votes for the measure, he would create a tie that could be broken in the President's favor by Vice President Al Gore. If Mr. Kerrey votes against it, the bill will fail.
The wrap-up of the debate tonight was one of the rare moments of real drama in Congress. Almost every representative was seated in the chamber. The galleries were full. Pages and staff assistants lined the walls. Leaders paced the aisles like sheep dogs keeping their flock in line.
The President's plan is not perfect, said the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington. But, he continued, "it is a critical beginning on that difficult road back."
Republicans, Mr. Foley said, were "marching in lock-step." He added, "We on this side must bear the burden of responsibility."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said it was important "to see that the country we hand to the next generation is not as good but is better than the country that was handed to us."
 
'Change for the Worse'
 Republicans said their opposition was not a matter of partisanship but of principle.
"This debate defines the difference between Republicans and Democrats," said Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas. "Democrats believe prosperity comes from bigger Government. Republicans know it comes from ordinary people acting on behalf of themselves and their families."
The change President Clinton stands for, Mr. Armey said, is "change for the worse."
The White House and the Democratic leaders were forced to plead and deal all day and into the evening to keep enough Democrats in line for a majority.
To win a few votes from conservative Democrats, for example, they announced tonight that additional steps would be taken this fall to restrain, or at least appear to restrain, Government spending.
Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky and Mr. Williams had told their party leaders that they wanted to vote against the measure but would not do so if their votes were the margin of defeat, a leadership assistant said. Representative Ray Thornton of Arkansas, who voted "no," had said the same thing, so the leaders may have had one extra vote in reserve.
In the face of a solid Republican front, the Democratic unity was remarkable. Eighty-four percent voted with the President. The freshmen were on his side, 58 to 8. Twenty-two of 23 committee chairmen voted "yes," with only the Veterans' Affairs Committee chairman, G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery of Mississippi, against the President. Subcommittee chairmen held ranks, 82 to 12.
The final bill as it came out of the Congressional blender was different in significant aspects from the program the President proposed last February. Most important, Congress rejected a broad tax on nearly all forms of energy and substituted a modest increase in the Federal gasoline tax, the only new tax that most people would owe.
Some of Mr. Clinton's proposals to spend more on various Government programs and to give tax breaks to business to strengthen the economy were also turned down.
But in most respects the bill followed the President's prescription for lowering the Federal budget deficit, reducing military spending and placing a much larger portion of the tax burden on the well-off.
Mr. Clinton and his supporters in Congress stressed that 80 percent of the new taxes would be paid by taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and that 90 percent would be paid by those with incomes above $100,000.
The legislation would lower the annual budget deficit by a total of $496 billion over the next five years, with $241 billion coming from tax increases and $255 billion from spending cuts.
The national debt, the accumulation of all the deficits over the years, would continue to rise by about $1 trillion over the five years. That is because the annual deficit, now about $300 billion, would still be close to $200 billion at the end of five years. In the absence of any budget cuts, the deficit in that period would rise by about $1.5 trillion.
The central elements of the bill would raise the tax rates on upper-income taxpayers, increase the Federal tax on gasoline by 4.3 cents a gallon, reduce military spending and limit the explosive growth in Medicare spending.
 
Views on the Record
 The latest calculations by Congressional statisticians of how much additional taxes various income groups would bear show that taxpayers with incomes over $200,000 would have an average tax increase of 5.4 percent. In no other category would the tax increase be more than 1 percent, and taxpayers with incomes below $20,000 would, on average, get a tax cut.
The tax cut at the low end of the income range would result from a large increase in the earned-income tax credit, a program that gives a tax break -- and in some instances rebates -- to workers who are poor or have incomes just above the poverty line.
Democrats called this provision the most important anti-poverty measure since the 1970's.
For more than eight hours, representatives trooped one at a time to the well of the House to speak for a minute or two about the bill. It was not so much a debate as a chance for the legislators to get their views on the record and on television.
The speeches were generally predictable, the Democrats calling for change and the Republicans decrying tax increases. But some were quite pointed.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, said the tax increases in the Democratic program would amount to "a job-killing poison for the economy."
"Try to soak the rich," Mr. Archer continued, "and you drown middle-income men and women."
But the Democrats held their ground. Representative John Lewis of Georgia said the Republicans were not seriously interested in governing. "They just said no," he asserted.
At the outset, Representative Martin Olav Sabo, the Minnesota Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, told his colleagues: "This package represents the opportunity of a lifetime to turn this country around. There will never be a better time to do it. It will get harder, not easier, if we put it off."
And Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chief Democrat on tax issues, put it this way: "The American people elected Bill Clinton to lead and change the direction of our country. The President has faced that responsibility squarely and asks us to support this plan. Now it is time to govern. The President has my vote -- with pride. He deserves yours, too."
 
Action in Back Rooms
 While these speeches were delivered in public, the real action was in the back rooms and on the telephone.
Mr. Clinton mostly cleared most of his schedule so he could spend the day on the telephone calling Representatives. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen spent most of the day in the Capitol, meeting with recalcitrant Democrats. So did Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, and Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff.
A Rose Garden ceremony honoring teachers was delayed for about 15 minutes, and the President could be seen through the French doors on the telephone in the Oval Office.
"What I keep trying to tell all the members is that this is the beginning of the process, not the end," Mr. Clinton said. "There is a whole lot more work to be done. We've just been here seven months. Finally, they've got somebody here who's serious about responsible budgeting instead of just talking about it."
Secretary Bentsen's pitch to lawmakers, a Texas Democrat said, was that if a representative votes against the package and it passes, that might be good politics. But if the vote is cast against it and it is defeated, it could be disastrous politically. The economy could turn south, and the representative would be blamed.
Democratic leaders and Administration officials helping with the vote count said at midafternoon that 207 Democrats were committed to vote "yes," 11 votes shy of a majority.
 
Tension in the Senate
 Across the Capitol in the Senate, the tension was equally thick. This morning, only 98 Senators had announced their positions: 49 for and 49 against. But then Senator Nunn made his decision, so if Senator Kerrey votes in favor, Mr. Gore can break the tie in the President's favor. But Mr. Kerrey was saying nothing.
Senators operate on such a high plane that they rarely meet with representatives except in conference committees to settle legislation. But Mr. Kerrey, who wants a special session of Congress to address further spending cuts, had an unusual meeting with Mr. Foley on Wednesday night to press his case.
Senate leaders would probably go along with the special session, but Mr. Foley opposes it.
The concessions made by the Democratic leaders tonight to win the votes of conservative Democratic representatives could meet Mr. Kerrey's needs.
The leaders agreed that in September, the House would vote on a measure intended to limit the growth of entitlement programs, that the White House would submit a bill this fall to rescind some spending that had already been approved and that the House would take up a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget if the Senate approved one first.
 
Kerrey's Ties to Moynihan
 The suspicion in the Capitol that Senator Kerrey would vote for the bill was grounded largely in his close relationship with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who, as head of the Finance Committee, is heavily responsible for writing the budget bill.
Mr. Moynihan went out of his way last year to support Mr. Kerrey's attempt to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, and the view among politicians is that Mr. Kerrey has a debt to pay.
An Administration official put it this way: "I can't believe that if at the darkest hour, Moynihan says, 'Bob, I'm calling my chit,' Kerrey won't go along. That's powerful."
Most of the attention surrounding the budget bill has been on taxes. The bill would raise the top tax rate, now 31 percent, to 36 percent for single taxpayers on taxable incomes ranging from $115,000 to $250,000 and for couples with taxable incomes from $140,000 to $250,000. The rate on taxable incomes above $250,000 would be 39.6 percent.
Workers with taxable income below those amounts would have no change in their income taxes. But retired people with incomes as low as $34,000 could face an income tax increase because of the proposed treatment of taxes on Social Security benefits.
Taxable income is what is left after deductions and personal exemptions are subtracted from adjusted gross income.
But beyond the tax increases are some important spending cuts.
A freeze would be placed for the next five years on all Government programs financed by annual appropriations. That means that if spending is increased, say, on education, it must be reduced for some other program.
All taxes and entitlement programs -- like Social Security, Medicare, welfare and farm price supports, which pay benefits to everyone who is eligible for them -- would be on a pay-as-you-go basis. That means that if benefits are raised or taxes cut, they must be offset by raising another tax or cutting another benefit.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Begins Taking Message to the Airwaves

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
After months of intermittent skirmishing, Rudolph W. Giuliani has moved the New York City mayoral campaign into the very-high-frequency war that really counts: paid television and radio advertising that starts by portraying the former prosecutor as a warm, regular guy in an effort to pre-empt Mayor David N. Dinkins's stepped-up attacks on him.
The silent tag line on one of his TV commercials reads: "He'll fight as hard for you and your family as he does for his own." 
 For most New Yorkers, it means the beginning of intensive exposure to the campaign, and it puts Mr. Giuliani's paid message on the air unusually early, especially since the Republican-Liberal candidate has repeatedly resisted being drawn into a head-to-head contest with the Democratic Mayor before the Sept. 14 primary.
His move marks a shift to more aggressive tactics and starts a high-cost war of nerves because the conventional wisdom is that once candidates begin television ads, they should maintain some presence on the air throughout the rest of the race.
The commercials -- a mix of unscripted 30-second and 60-second appearances featuring the candidate and his family -- began airing last night. One shows Mr. Giuliani sitting in Carl Schurz Park near his apartment on the Upper East Side, looking into the camera and saying that while most people know he was a prosecutor and came close to winning the last election, "They don't know about the most important part of my life: My wife, Donna, and my two children, Andrew and Caroline."
Over pictures of Caroline, who is nearly 4, blowing big soap bubbles, the candidate continues: "Donna and I feel very strongly that Andrew and Caroline should grow up in New York, like I did, but in order to make that possible," parks and playgrounds and schools must be improved. "We're just letting those kids down, and we've got to really change it and fight back for New York City."
Another commercial shows a casually dressed Mr. Giuliani talking about economic development, job creation and small business as statistics are displayed on the screen.
In contrast to the prevailing practice, David Garth, Mr. Giuliani's chief strategist, refused to say when or where the commercials would be broadcast, or to release copies of the videotapes or scripts in advance. He said the radio ads were to begin today.
"I don't want my spots interpreted by the media," said Mr. Garth, who said they were intended to counter what he views as incomplete, unfair coverage of Mr. Giuliani in routine news accounts that have largely ignored the race between Mr. Dinkins and his primary challenger, Roy E. Innis, national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality. "I want them interpreted by the voter."
In recent years television news organizations and newspapers have taken to running detailed analyses of campaign ads, weighing the accuracy and intent of their claims. (For example, Mr. Giuliani moved from Brooklyn to the Long Island suburbs when he was 7, and commuted back to attend high school).
Mr. Garth, who is known for tactical moves aimed at stirring the pot, said he wanted to paint his own pictures: "This is very important. There's a feeling that Rudy is just a tough prosecutor. He's much more. This is one percent of the campaign. It'll build. Basically speaking, this is getting him out there."
Media buyers said a check of broadcast logs showed that the television ads were scheduled to run through Monday, at an estimated cost of $67,000, a relatively small purchase and enough to be seen just once by the typical viewer. The Dinkins camp was quick to dismiss the ads as a tactical effort to call attention to a campaign that is not moving swiftly enough. The Mayor's campaign declined to reveal anything about its own advertising plans.
Of the Giuliani campaign, the Mayor's media adviser, Robert Shrum, said, "They hoped and expected to be doing better at this point than they are."
"Giuliani's attempt to make political capital out of the Crown Heights report didn't work very well, so they're doing this," he added, referring to the recent report on the state inquiry into the Mayor's handling of four days of black-Jewish violence in Brooklyn in 1991.
That may be so, since polls taken after the release of the report showed that the overall race remained a virtual toss-up. But the surveys also showed that Mr. Dinkins had lost support among white voters, especially Jews, while gaining among black voters. Giuliani backers argue that this means momentum has moved their way more than the broad horse-race numbers would indicate.
Mr. Garth said the initial commercials would be followed by another of his trademarks: ordinary New Yorkers talking spontaneously about the city and his candidate.
 
Attacks Intensified
 After months of largely quiet tolerance of criticism by Mr. Giuliani, the Mayor has recently intensified his attacks on his challenger, branding him as a cold-hearted ally of those Republican Federal officials whose policies the Mayor said had deprived the city of badly needed aid, and as a fast-talking waffler on issues who does not have "the temperament" to lead the city.
On Wednesday night at a forum on housing issues in which Mr. Giuliani followed the Mayor to the same platform for the first time of the campaign, Mr. Giuliani retaliated by accusing the Mayor of failing to take prompt or decisive steps to alleviate the problems of the city's homeless.
Yesterday Mr. Dinkins picked up an endorsement from the Speaker of the State Assembly, Saul Weprin of Queens, the second prominent Jewish politician to endorse the Mayor this week. On Wednesday, he was lauded by former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, the city's first Jewish mayor.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: Political Memo;
The Public Is Confused, And Getting Suspicious

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
From Joan N. Baggett, the White House political director, it was a frank admission of reality: As hard as President Clinton tried in his address on Tuesday to portray his budget package as fair, most Americans simply don't believe him.
"My husband said after watching both the President and Senator Dole's response, 'No wonder people are cynical and turned off to Government: You have the President telling them one thing and Senator Dole telling them the exact opposite,' " Ms. Baggett said. "When there's that much confusion, voters have reason to be suspicious." 
 In his speech on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton said his plan would cut the deficit by nearly $500 billion over five years. Mr. Dole said the national debt would rise by $1 trillion. They were both right, though neither would give the other credit for it.
Even if the Clinton plan was to achieve all of its advertised potential, it might do little to end confusion about the nation's finances and restore faith in Washington. Despite the spending cuts and tax increases the President is pushing, the measure would not eliminate budget deficits, merely trim them. As Senator Dole pointed out, the Government would still rely on borrowed money -- and this kind of deficit spending, no matter how small, increases the national debt.
In fact, by 1998 the package would throw $1 trillion onto the debt. In other words, the problem is only going to get worse.
The immediate challenge for Mr. Clinton and the Democrats is to overcome a widespread perception, fueled by the Republicans, that the budget package amounts to a gigantic tax-and-spend extravaganza that would do little good for the economy.
 
Skeptical Middle Class
 To counter such a view, Mr. Clinton has repeated this mantra: no new income taxes for the middle class. Hours before the crucial voting began in the House this evening, fax machines in Democratic offices on Capitol Hill were getting the latest "talking points" from the White House: "The President has always been clear and direct on raising taxes on the top 1 percent."
The message may be accurate, but it is one that the middle class, to a large degree, is not buying, according to polls taken before and after the President's speech.
The White House's failure to change this skepticism is a large factor in the close vote on Mr. Clinton's budget, despite Democratic majorities in both houses.
One reason that Mr. Clinton's message has not caught on is that he and Democratic leaders, distracted in part by doomed nominations, did not start the selling drive that was necessary until recently. But more fundamentally, people have grown distrustful of a Government that has not delivered on its promises of a balanced budget in return for sacrifice.
Remember President Ronald Reagan's inaugural address in 1981, when he declared that continuing decades of deficit spending would "guarantee tremendous social, cultural, political and economic upheavals"? He vowed to balance the budget by 1984. Remember President George Bush's tax increase in 1990? It was supposed to eliminate the deficit by 1996.
"We've been fooled so long that you have to laugh -- or cry," said Paul Hoover, a retired railroad worker from Bellefonte, Pa., who voted for Mr. Clinton last year but says he now feels betrayed by a President who let Congress weaken his economic program. "I don't trust any of them in Congress any more."
Though he is a Democrat, Mr. Hoover, 72, said he sided with Mr. Dole, the Senate Republican leader who contends that the package amounts to an unfair tax increase. "There need to be more cutbacks in the Government -- not the people but the Government," he said.
Gil Bond, a 25-year-old forklift driver from Wallkill, N.Y., who voted for Ross Perot, said he simply did not believe Mr. Clinton's contention that people in his income range would not end up paying more taxes. "I've heard that one before," he said. "Raising the gas tax has got to hurt the lower man. Clinton's not taxing the rich. He's still hammering us. And where are all the jobs he's supposed to create?"
Mr. Bond and Mr. Hoover were among the 35 percent of the 621 Americans who told CBS News, in a survey after the President's speech to the nation Tuesday, that they hope their representatives oppose the plan. Forty percent wanted their representative to vote for it. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Seeing Trouble Ahead
 It is Democrats like Mr. Hoover who terrify White House officials. If he is so pessimistic about the package, what chance does Mr. Clinton have to win over a probably more skeptical group, the 19 percent who voted for Ross Perot?
Although he has refused to detail how he would do this, Mr. Perot has proposed two things that many economists say are absolutely essential to controlling the deficit but which the political parties are loath to do: Significantly raise taxes (which Republicans refuse to do) and significantly cut spending (which Democrats refuse to do).
Instead, many Democrats have sought to blame the package's troubles on botched public relations.
David Wilhelm, the Democratic Party chairman who had been criticized for letting the Republicans depict the President as trying to finance lawmakers' needless pet projects through his withdrawn bill to stimulate the economy, said the party had fought back. But he said the effort had been harder than expected, and he sought to lay the blame on past Republican administrations.
"We're forced to deal with a lot of very justified skepticism," he said. "People don't believe that the deficit is real because they've had 12 years of rosy scenarios and blue smoke and mirrors."
The nervousness over perceptions does not stem only from worries over whether the budget package will be enacted; at stake is how people perceive Mr. Clinton over time.
"We do believe that these defining budget and economic votes have a character to them that lives with you for years," said Stanley Greenberg, the President's pollster. "To this day, people remember George Bush for breaking 'read my lips' and taxing the middle class."
With all the Democrats' anxiety over why they have not been more successful in altering perceptions, one basic principle has been obscured: Americans may detest gridlock, they may despise the deficit, but nothing seems to bother them more than a tax increase.
"It's easy to say that one side got its message out and the other side has not," said John Alford, a political scientist at Rice University. "But the notion of any taxation is just a difficult message to carry."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The House approved President Clinton's budget plan, putting him on the verge of the most important victory of his young Presidency. The vote, in doubt almost until the final gavel, was 218 to 216. The victory was provided by 217 Democrats and one independent. The final vote in the Senate, expected tonight, hinges on the decision of the only Democratic Senator who has not announced his position, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. [Page A1.] 
 Factory orders rebounded in June, gaining 2.6 percent, after three consecutive monthly declines. Also, the number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell last week by 60,000, despite the fact that more flood victims showed up at unemployment claims offices. [D2.]
The nation's retailers reported mixed sales results for July, with overall sales up an estimated 8.6 percent from July 1992 and 2 percent from June. [D3.]
Local phone companies may have less to fear than they thought from the F.C.C.'s vote to expand competition. News Analysis. [D2.]
 
Markets
Gold prices plunged at least $22 an ounce in a frenzied day of trading. Investors dumped holdings amid rumors of sales by China's central bank and the easing of Europe's currency crisis. [D1.]
The stock market meandered indecisively in a narrow range, as it awaited the vote on the Clinton budget plan. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.08 points, to 3,548.97. [D4.]
Treasury prices advanced. The 30-year bond rose 14/32 of a point, to yield 6.52 percent. [D13.]
The dollar hit another postwar low against the yen, fetching 103.85 yen in midday trading in New York. In later trading, the dollar stood at 104.05 yen. The previous record low, touched on Tuesday, had been 104 yen. [D14]
 
International
The United States and Canada settled a five-year-old trade dispute over beer sales. Also, new details emerged about the Clinton Administration's plan to create a joint agency with the Mexican Government to clean up the United States-Mexico border region. [D1.]
Japanese hopes for a rebound from deep recession may be dashed by the sharp rise in the exchange value of the yen. Unlike in much of Europe, where recent currency turmoil is likely to spur export sales, exports from Japan will cost more abroad. [A10.]
 
Companies
Delta Air Lines' fares cuts were matched by rivals, who added three weeks to the start of the sale. Delta had hoped to get past the busy Labor Day weekend before putting the discounts into effect on Sept. 15, but its rivals countered by allowing travel beginning Aug. 23. Delta then agreed to the earlier date. [D1.]
British Telecommunications and MCI reached definitive agreements on an alliance to offer global networks for multinational corporations, and named a chief for the venture. [D3.]
DNA Plant Technology's test-market results of its premium tomato were three times greater than expected. [D3.]
Richard Branson vowed to fight for the right to open his Virgin Megastore record and book shop in Paris on Sundays, despite the threat of huge fines if he continues to defy French law. [D3.]
Arthur Andersen agreed to pay $82 million to settle Government claims that negligent audits contributed to the collapse of several savings institutions. [D10.]
 
Today's Columns
Guess? Inc.'s prospectus for a private debt offering provides a rare peek into a private company. Market Place. [D1.]
Saatchi & Saatchi loses a $20 million cellular telephone account. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold's Long, Seductive Climb Ends in a Flash

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Gold prices plunged yesterday in a frenzied day of trading as investors dumped their holdings amid the easing of Europe's currency crisis and rumors of sales by China's central bank.
The sharp drop in prices came amid what traders described as a marketwide panic. A broad swath of international investors, mutual funds and speculators unloaded gold on fears that demand was softening even as the price was reaching a speculative peak. 
 "The market just crashed," said Patrick MaGilligan, a precious metals trader with Merrill Lynch & Company. "At some points during the day, there were absolutely no bids."
Yesterday's plunge in prices, which came after large numbers of professional and individual investors flocked to gold in hopes of easy profits, was a grim reminder of the volatility and riskiness of the commodities markets.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery, which hit a high yesterday of $400.70 an ounce, fell at rapid speed to a late price of $377.20, some $22 below the previous day's close. During the day, the price had sunk even more, to a low of $372 an ounce.
The most actively traded gold contract, for December delivery, ended trading at $380.70 an ounce, down $22.60. The collapse brought spot gold and all of the major gold contracts below the psychologically important level of $400 an ounce, which could make it difficult for the precious metal to regain any upward momentum in the next few weeks, traders said.
Other precious metals also fell. Silver for September delivery plummeted 48.2 cents to end at $4.783 an ounce on the Comex, and platinum for October delivery sank $25 to close at $394.60 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Gold's drop left prices about where they were four weeks ago, before the recent run-up, and only somewhat below the $390-an-ounce level reached two weeks ago.
Many of the biggest speculators in gold are still ahead of the game, since many bought in months ago, while prices were well below $350 an ounce. Sir James Goldsmith, a British-French financier, and George Soros, a renowned fund manager and speculator based in New York, made heavy bets on gold back in April. Of course, traders like Mr. Soros and Mr. Goldsmith rarely buy and hold commodities for long periods.
The sharp losses yesterday stemmed partly from the crisis last week in the European currency exchange system. On Friday, when that crisis reached its peak, gold hit its 34-month high on speculative buying as large institutional funds bet that a breakdown of the exchange system could set off a dash for the gold markets.
 
 
Huge Hoards of Gold
 Over the weekend, order was restored to the currency markets when European central bankers modified the exchange system, leaving many gold investors holding hoards of the metal and contracts on it, all of which had been purchased on an investment theory that proved false.
That left many investors anxious, knowing that the recent arrivals to the gold party could decide to dash out the door with the push of a button on a trading computer. And, as any trader knows, anxiety begets a collapse in any market.
Gold prices dropped during each trading day this week, and the number of open gold futures contracts, a statistic that traders say is an important sign of potential growth in market demand, stopped rising.
By yesterday morning, the market was ripe for a fall. Rumors began in London that the central bank of China, where gold demand has been especially high in recent months, was selling 6 to 10 tons. "That spooked a lot of funds," Mr. MaGilligan of Merrill said.
On top of that came additional rumors that the Chinese Government was planning to further restrict purchases of gold by individuals, a move that could well give China's central bankers better control over their currency, but would choke off a significant source of demand. And figures released yesterday by the World Gold Council showed that imports to Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore were already slowing, falling to 161 metric tons in the second quarter, from 306 tons in the first quarter.
 
 
 
'A Chain Reaction'
 With the market already jittery, the selloff simply fed on itself. "It was like a chain reaction," said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metals marketing with Credit Suisse. "Once it started, it just kept going."
One reason for the sustained plunge was that the funds that had pushed prices so high had also put in place orders to sell gold if it fell below a certain level. And those orders, known as stops, got hit repeatedly during the trading yesterday, pushing prices down more each time.
"At all levels, we hit all these stops from funds with major positions," said Daniel Weisman, head precious metals trader at the MTB Bank in New York. "As those stops got hit, there was no quality buying to absorb that kind of selling."
Even with the collapse in prices, traders said yesterday that they expected gold to resume its upward moves after Labor Day, when demand historically picks up, as long as there were no significant shocks to either the supply or the demand. But other analysts said that gold producers, most of whom have not been selling on anticipation of higher prices, may well begin to sell holdings out of fear that the market has hit its highs and may be headed lower.
"This will probably be overdone on the down side, as these selloffs are when there is such a sharp drop," Mr. MacDonald of Credit Suisse said.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
BOSNIA PRESIDENT REFUSES TO BUDGE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Aug. 5

 BODY:
With international mediators saying he has been strengthened by renewed talk of using NATO air power against his Serbian enemies, President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia refused to compromise today in the stalled peace talks, forcing the mediators to postpone a resumption in negotiations until Monday.
"There has been no progress on the maps," Mr. Izetbegovic said as he left the United Nations offices here after talks with the mediators on carving up Bosnia and Herzegovina into three loosely linked ethnic republics. 
 The President, who is a Muslim, said he was still unable to accept Serbian and Croatian proposals for dividing such sensitive areas as Sarajevo and Muslim areas in eastern Bosnia. Mr. Izetbegovic also continued to insist that Serbian forces pull back from two strategic mountains that they had seized outside Sarajevo.
 
'Weekend of Reflection'
 After hearing the Bosnian demands, officials said the mediators, Lord Owen of the European Community and Thorvald Stoltenberg of the United Nations, concluded that there was no realistic chance of an agreement between President Izetbegovic and the Serbian and Croatian leaders, who returned home on Wednesday after waiting for three days for the Bosnian Government side to return to the table.
The mediators therefore decided against inviting the Serbs and Croats to come back here on Friday to resume talks, as they had hoped to do. But rather than formally suspend the negotiations, Lord Owen and Mr. Stoltenberg gave Bosnia's 10-member collective presidency a "weekend of reflection" to see whether this produces any change in its position.
Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, and Mate Boban, the Bosnian Croat leader, agreed to return to Geneva on Monday to resume negotiations. By then it should be clear whether Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander, has honored a commitment he made to Mr. Karadzic today to withdraw his forces from the two mountains, Mount Bjelasnica and Mount Igman, on Friday and reopen two main roads into Sarajevo to allow the free passage of civilian traffic.
 
Awaiting Decision by NATO
 United Nations officials here also believe that the Bosnians are stalling until they see what comes out of a NATO meeting on Monday in Brussels. The meeting has been called to consider whether to give the go-ahead to detailed plans now being drafted for NATO air strikes against Serbian positions around Sarajevo and other locales that are under attack in defiance of a Security Council resolution that designated them "safe areas."
Lord Owen and Mr. Stoltenberg say they are convinced that once the Clinton Administration and then NATO started talking publicly about the possibility of air strikes, Bosnian Government leaders hardened their position in the belief that Washington and its allies might finally come to their rescue.
But like Britain, France and Canada, which all have peacekeepers in Bosnia, the mediators think that any resort to force now would end all hope of a negotiated settlement to the war and probably compel the United Nations to halt its relief operations, on which some two million people depend.
 
30% of Bosnia and Access to Sea
 Since earlier this year, when increasingly bitter clashes destroyed the uneasy alliance between the Croatian nationalists and the Bosnian Government, the mediators have argued that the balance of forces inside Bosnia would compel the outgunned Bosnian Army to accept the demands of the other two factions or face extinction.
The current round of negotiations was intended to reach agreement on a Serbian-Croatian proposal to divide the country, with the mediators determined to secure Bosnian Muslims an economically sustainable state of their own, providing them with at least 30 percent of Bosnia and guaranteeing them access to the Adriatic Sea.
The Serbs and the Croats have already agreed in principle to a Muslim state of this size and offered to give back land that they have conquered.
As of last Sunday, President Izetbegovic agreed to abandon his attachment to a multi-ethnic, unitary state. He and the other faction leaders had also largely agreed on at least the core territory that should belong to each republic, although differences remained over sensitive regions.
 
Balkan Update
 Serbian nationalist leaders in PALE announced a pullback of their troops from around SARAJEVO, the capital of BOSNIA, apparently fearing NATO air strikes. They also said they would open routes for aid convoys and the free movement of civilians.
United States officials said in WASHINGTON that they were pressing NATO to broaden military contingency planning to include roads, bridges, supply depots and command posts.
Bosnia's President refused to compromise in the stalled negotiations in GENEVA, forcing mediators to suspend talks until Monday.
A delegation of officials from Islamic nations, meeting in Geneva, assailed a plan to divide Bosnia along ethnic lines.
Fighting flared up in CROATIA, when rebel Serbs fired on the vital MASLENICA BRIDGE that Croats were supposed to yield.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Higher After 3 Monthly Drops

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Factory orders rebounded in June after three consecutive monthly declines, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts predict additional modest increases in the months ahead but caution that new manufacturing jobs will remain scarce.
Orders rose 2.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $254.8 billion, the best showing since December, but much of the gain was concentrated in the volatile aircraft industry. 
 Another Government report today showed that the number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell last week by 60,000, to 336,000, despite the fact that more flood victims showed up at claims offices.
Manufacturing has been one of the economy's weak spots this year, in part because consumer demand has been spotty after strong Christmas buying and in part because downturns abroad have led the Europeans and Japanese to buy fewer United States goods.
Economists, noting low business inventories and advances in auto sales this summer, expect an improvement. But they caution that productivity-minded companies will continue to show reluctance to hire.
"I look for manufacturing to pick up, in part because of the pickup in auto sales, but nothing dramatic," said Samuel D. Kahan, an economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago.
A key barometer of future factory employment worsened in June. The backlog of unfilled orders decreased eight-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $458.3 billion, the lowest level since September 1988. It was the fourth consecutive drop.
A dwindling backlog is an indication the current factory work force is having little difficulty keeping up with the flow of new orders.
"The backlog concerns me," said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. "It means businesses don't have to expand."
Some analysts, though, are not overly worried. They say much of the backlog decline is concentrated in the defense industry.
Durable goods manufacturers -- those making big-ticket items such as cars and computers -- said orders rose 3.8 percent. Nondurable goods makers reported a 1.3 percent increase.
The Labor Department's report on first-time filings for unemployment benefits showed a larger-than-expected decline in claims, but economists noted that it came after the previous week's numbers had been skewed by a temporary shutdown at the General Motors Corporation for retooling.
Department analysts said states such as Illinois and Iowa were beginning to report an increase in claims from workers whose jobs had been disrupted by the Midwest flooding.
Even with this week's decline in claims, the four-week moving average still rise, climbing to 353,000, the highest level since April 17.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Move Upward

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose and yields declined yesterday, even though key votes were still pending on the President's deficit-reduction package and the July employment report would be released today.
In addition, the Commerce Department reported that factory orders rose 2.6 percent in June, which was a larger increase than expected. And next week, is the Treasury's quarter auction, in which the Govenment will sell a record $38.5 billion of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. 
 Despite news that might normally disturb traders and investors, the market seems to be holding its own. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond, due in February 2023, rose 14/32 as the yield fell to 6.52 percent, from 6.55 percent Wednesday and matching the 16-year low it hit on Tuesday.
The price of the 10-year note rose 7/32 as the yield fell to 5.84 percent, from 5.88 percent the day before but still above its recent lows.
 
Intermediate Notes Also Rally
 Intermediate Treasury notes also rallied but remain locked in a tight trading range. The yield on the five-year note fell to 5.15 percent from 5.22 percent but has been caught in a range of 5.00 percent to 5.40 percent since mid-February.
"The market seems to be trading less and less in response to economic indicators and more on what will happen after a tax increase," said Pat Rothstein, a senior managing director at Bear, Stearns & Company. He was referring to the belief of some traders and investors that the deficit reduction package will slow the economy and make bonds and long-term securities more attractive by lessening the inflation risk.
"The data we have had could have been interpreted negatively," Mr. Rothestein added, but it's a market that wants to go up."
Traders and analysts said the market received a lift in the morning from the sharp drop in the price of gold overseas and a fall in the Commodity Research Bureau Index of Commodities, both barometers of inflation expectations.
 
Calmer Currency Markets
 While gold was cited as a catalyst, it did not seem to shake the market as much as it did a week ago when its price popped throught the $400-an-ounce level as concerns rose about the impact of a possible breakup of the European Monetary System.
The papering over of the damage to the European Monetary System has, for the time being, lead to calmer currency markets and is one of the reasons some fund managers began selling gold yesterday. Rumors of selling by the Chinese Government also added to selling pressure. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery fell $22 an ounce, ending the day at $377.20.
The House of Representatives began debating President Clinton's deficit package in the afternoon but there was no vote before trading finished for the day. Last night, the House narrowly approved the package.
The Senate is expected to vote on the deficit package later today. The vote will come well after the release of the Labor Department's report on July employment, and the uncertainty over the outcome may affect how some traders and investors react to the new data.
Michael H. Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International, said that the aanouncement by Senator Dennis DiConcini, Democrat of Arizona, that he would support the President's plan had eased concerns about the vote and helped Treasury prices rise yesterday.
Mr. Strauss noted that some investors took profits in the afternoon to take advantage of the flattening of the yield curve, which is the narrowing of the spreads between the yields on Treasury securities of different maturities, such as between two-year notes and the 30-year bonds.
 
Rise In Short-Term Rates
 This spread has narrowed sharply in the last three months because short-term rates have risen and the yield on the long bond has dropped, in part because the Treasury is cutting the annual issuance of these bonds by about 40 percent.
The spread has narrowed from 3.06 percentage points on May 7 to 2.42 percentage points yesterday. In a trade to take advantage of the narrowing of the spread, an investor buys 30-year bonds and sells two-year notes, betting that the price performance of the 30-year bond will be better as the yield curve flattens. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
The employment data today are expected to show a jump of about 165,000 nonfarm payroll jobs, according to the consensus forecast reported by Bloomberg Business News. But Mr. Strauss is forecasting a rise of 225,000 and he said it could be higher.
The impact on the market will depend not only on the July number but also on whether the very weak 13,000 increase in nonfarm payroll jobs reported for June is revised upward. In the when-issued trading that occurs ahead of a Treasury auction, the yield on the 3-year note to be sold Tuesday was 4.50 percent; the yield on the 10-year note to be sold Wednesday was 5.81 percent and the yield on the 30-year bond to be sold Thursday was 6.45 percent.

HEADLINE: Hope and Fear on a Phone Ruling

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
When the F.C.C. voted earlier this week to open the local telephone market to further competition, the howls of complaint from local phone companies were extreme, even by Washington lobbying standards.
What can realistically happen in the near future is a great deal less than what the phone companies fear. And it seems to be much less than was hoped for by the upstart communications companies, which are supposed to benefit from the Federal Communications Commission's decision. 
 Seemingly at stake is the more than $86 billion annual market for local telephone service, which exceeds the economies of Greece and Egypt combined. But in fact, at least initially, the competitive stake may amount to less than $300 million a year for alternative phone companies like the Teleport Communications Group of Staten Island, which as an industry currently have a market share of two-tenths of a percent.
For its part, one potential competitor to the regional Bells finds much of the debate overblown. Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable-television company, is a minority investor in Teleport. Tele-Communications is also developing fiber-optic technology that could not only provide cable-television service but also telephone service, but it has not decided what it will do.
"Teleport and the other competitive-access providers would swoon with joy if they attained just 2 percent market share by the turn of the century," said Robert Thomson, senior vice president of Tele-Communications.
In its complex ruling on Tuesday, the F.C.C. removed more regulatory barriers to competition, helping carriers like Teleport and MFS Communications of Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.
Using Manhattan as an example, the new rules are expected to work as follows.
Currently, long-distance carriers like A.T.& T. pay fees to New York Telephone for completing long-distance calls over the local phone network in Manhattan. Industrywide, the part of this business that the F.C.C. is throwing open to competition represents about $4.2 billion a year to the local phone companies. But in the near term, because local rivals are so few and so small, as little as $264 million may be at stake, Teleport says.
Under this week's F.C.C. ruling, Nynex would be required to let Teleport lease access to the local network. Teleport could then compete for A.T.& T.'s business and complete an A.T.& T. long-distance call in Manhattan through Teleport lines.
For now, only business calls would be subject to such rival bids, but the Bell companies see the new rules as the first steps to opening most local and long-distance calls to competition.
And hence the phone companies' concern that increased competition, however trivial now, could undermine what is known as universal telephone service. In general, rates charged to urban customers, for whom service is cost-effective, subsidize the cost of phone service to suburban and far-flung rural customers. Indeed, in some cases, these rural customers may even lose money for the phone company.
The implication for the near future is unclear as telecommunications companies forge their information superhighway. But at the extreme, one result of free-for-all competition could be a caste system of telecommunications haves and have-nots: multimedia wonders with videophones for Manhattan, but plain old telephone service for farms in upstate New York -- and at higher prices.
This week's F.C.C. decision was designed to benefit upstart concerns like MFS and others whose total industry revenue is less than $200 million annually. But the much larger cable-television companies like Tele-Communications and Time Warner Inc. could also benefit as well. Their industry revenue exceeds $19 billion.
At least in theory, the big long-distance carriers -- the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the MCI Communications Corporation and the Sprint Corporation -- and the regional Bells could also enter the fray. For example, the $10.3 billion U S West could compete in the $15.4 billion BellSouth territory to provide some form of network access, probably by leasing BellSouth's lines.
Competition may bring faster change in the local-telephone market than it did in the long-distance market. In long distance, it took more than a decade for then-tiny rivals like MCI to erode A.T.& T.'s market share significantly.
In its order this week, the F.C.C. took the unusual step of mandating that for every dollar that a big local carrier loses to a rival, the rival must rebate 80 cents to the phone company, in part to compensate the big carrier for providing such universal service. This arrangement is supposed to be only temporary, though it is unclear how long it may last.
"What the F.C.C. is trying to do in its ruling this week is prevent sticker shock for the consumer," said Dee A. May, regulatory affairs director for Nynex.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at New Low in Tokyo, But Up Modestly in Europe

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
With trade tensions between the United States and Japan showing no sign of letting up under a new Japanese leadership, the dollar reached still another postwar low yesterday against the yen.
But it rose against some European currencies in reaction to strong American economic data. 
 The dollar fetched 104.05 yen in late trading in New York yesterday, up a bit from an intraday low of 103.85 yen, but off markedly from 104.88 in New York late Wednesday. The previous record low, touched on Tuesday in Tokyo, had been 104 yen.
In Tokyo today, the dollar was quoted at 104.20 yen at midday.
Currency dealers and bankers theorized that a strong yen seemed to be the only way to reduce Japan's trade surplus. "The new government is not going to get a new trade agreement" with the United States, said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president of Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, alluding to the shaky and unsettled political situation in Tokyo.
Some currency dealers, believing that the dollar will soon fall to 100 yen, tried to hasten the process by quoting lower prices even in the absence of market-moving news.
"The market wants to move dollar-yen lower," said Belal Khan, a senior dealer at the Bank of Tokyo.
"There are rumors of big stop-loss orders" to sell dollars at 103.95 yen," said Jack Griffin, a vice president of Fuji Bank. "Dealers are just trying to find out if those stops are there."
The dollar rose against European currencies on news that first-time American jobless claims were lower than expected and that factory orders were up 2.6 percent in June. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.7123 marks from 1.7100 marks on Wednesday.
Money traders also seemed relieved that European central banks were not selling large quantities of dollars to replenish funds spent supporting weaker European currencies during last week's speculative run.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Weather Failed to Sink Big Retailers' July Sales

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Retailers reported mixed sales results for July yesterday, with shoppers hunting for bargains at end-of-season clearance sales.
Flooding in the Midwest and heat waves in the East and South had little effect over all. But Sears, Roebuck & Company, which had particularly strong increases, cited storm- and heat-related sales as helping results.
Based on estimates by Edward Johnson of Johnson Redbook Service, sales in the month were up 8.6 percent from July 1992 and 2 percent from June.
"July is a transitional, trans-seasonal month characterized by clearance sales," said Joseph Ronning, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman, "and some companies that reported solid gains were unloading merchandise they didn't sell at full price in April, May or June."
He said he expects lackluster sales in August, "once we get back into a full-price environment."
 
Gains for Sears
 July's strongest performer was Sears, the third-largest United States retailer, whose same-store sales rose 15.4 percent. Sears cited increased demand for appliance-repair service in the flood-stricken Midwest and said a heat wave in the South spurred sales of air-conditioners.
Analysts use same-store, or comparable-store, sales to measure sales strength because they discount the effect of new or closed units.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, recorded a 9 percent increase in July same-store sales, while the Kmart Corporation, the second-largest retailer, said same-store sales were up 3.7 percent.
But July was disappointing for Venture Stores Inc., whose comparable-store sales fell five-tenths of 1 percent. Venture's chairman, Julian Seeherman, said, "A difficult economic climate along with effects of the flood of '93 on consumer shopping made business weak in most of our markets."
 
Salomon Index Up
 Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst for Salomon Brothers, said his company's same-store index, a barometer of sales performance, was 5.7 percent for July, up from 5.6 percent in June but down from 6.4 percent a year ago.
Kurt Barnard of Barnard's Retailing Marketing Report noted a 2 percent decrease in same-store sales at the Gap Inc. and a decline of two-tenths of a percent in comparable-store sales at Federated Department Stores Inc.
"As in June, we've seen a continuation of a pattern of strength in stores catering to home-oriented merchandise," he said. "By and large, apparel stores are falling flat."
 
Retailers' Sales Detailed
By The Associated Press
Here are domestic July sales reported yesterday by some of the nation's largest retailers:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
Month of July: Same-store sales rose 9 percent; overall sales totaled $5.44 billion, up 26 percent from $4.31 billion.

HEADLINE: Kill All the Lawyers? Maybe With Kindness

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
As if 54,386 lawyers in five boroughs are not enough, New York suddenly has 13,000 more.
For the next six days, the city is playing host to the American Bar Association, which is holding its 115th annual meeting here. Lawyers from throughout the country, along with bar leaders from 35 countries, along with various spouses and dependents, will fill 21 hotels and clog the city's sidewalks in their annual ritual of enlightenment, enrichment and entertainment. 
 By any standards, even those of New York, A.B.A. conventions are gargantuan productions. The bar group is bringing 150,000 pounds of paper and equipment to New York and expects to produce more than 500,000 documents while here. And for all the talk of lawyers hurting the nation's economy, this particular group will pump more than $9 million into the city's coffers.
The numbers could go still higher, depending on how many stragglers show up. "People registered real late," Mary Cavalini, director of the bar group's meetings department, said in an interview from the convention's nerve center in the New York Hilton. "It could be the cost, or the World Trade Center incident might have been a problem."
 
Bellmen in Wigs
 Hotels, filled to capacity with lawyers, are filled with good will for them. This week, at least, no one in them is paying much heed to a survey in The National Law Journal which showed that "resentment of lawyers is running at a fever pitch," especially among the more affluent and educated. At the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza on Broadway, where lawyers are occupying two-thirds of the 770 rooms, the bellmen are wearing wigs and robes, chocolate gavels will be placed atop all pillows, and a fake metal detector has been installed in the lobby, just to make the courtroom types feel at home. On the menu are such dishes as "cross-examined salmon," while what has temporarily been renamed the "Bar Bar" features "precedent punch," "constitutional cooler" and "contempt of court crush."
"When I started reading that there's a lot of attorney-bashing, I wanted to do something positive, something that would make them feel good about themselves and make them realize that New Yorkers can ignore what others are saying throughout the country," said Michael Silberstein, the hotel's general manager.
For local politicians like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo (one speech) Mayor David N. Dinkins (one Sunday morning prayer breakfast plus two receptions at Gracie Mansion), the convention, the bar's first meeting here since 1986, is a coveted, conspicuous chance to play gracious host. Among the few local lawyers apparently not planning to attend is Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Dinkins's electoral adversary. "His schedule is booked over the next week," said Ken Frydman, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani.
 
Displays of Class and Whimsy
 For local law firms, the convention is a chance to show their influence, their class and, for some, their sense of whimsy. For $30,000 or so, the Morristown, N.J., firm of Pitney, Harden, Kipp & Szuch has rented the Temple of Dendur for Monday night. Going head-to-head against them is Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn, which is offering what it calls "a magical evening" at Radio City Music Hall.
Both must compete with Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, which will take over F.A.O. Schwarz at the same time. "The store will remain open exclusively for the shopping pleasure of guests," the firm's invitation reads. (Cravath, Swaine & Moore, where Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr. is a partner, is holding a more traditional reception in its offices on Eighth Avenue.) The evening amid the toys promises to be a far greater draw than a breakfast discussion the following morning at Debevoise & Plimpton on the Family and Medical Leave and the Americans With Disabilities Acts.
Topping the official A.B.A. agenda is yet another debate over abortion rights, an issue that has become as much a part of bar conventions over the past four years as cocktail parties and dinner dances. Since the bar group took a pro-choice stance last year, some 5,000 of its 370,000 members have resigned in protest.
And perhaps the session's most intriguing program is a mock retrial Monday of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg.
 
A Chance for Exploration
 But for many conventioneers, the meeting will be more a chance to explore spicy, dicey New York than to talk law or politics or ethics. By adjournment on Wednesday, groups of lawyers will have climbed the Empire State Building (by elevator) with King Kong, eaten "melting pot-luck suppers" in Chinatown or Astoria, heard the Harlem Boys Choir at the Sheraton Center and sailed around Manhattan courtesy of the Chicago Title Insurance Company.
Tours of the Guggenheim Museum, Ellis Island, West Point and Hyde Park are sold out. Tickets for breakfast at Planet Hollywood, followed by a tour of the Museum of Television and Radio, are selling briskly, as is a visit to what the program refers to as "the trendy Upper West Side." In this crowd, at least, even Mets tickets are coveted. But at least one program -- "Queens for a Day" -- was canceled for lack of interest.
To Tony Napoli of Briggs Red Carpet Associates, who arranged the expeditions, the conventioneers have proved surprisingly ordinary in their selections, generally favoring the same Broadway shows and bread-and-butter attractions as members of the Congress of Thrombosis and Haemostasis, whom he assisted last month.
"You'd think lawyers are more sophisticated or discriminating, but they still want the basics," he said. "They might come to town on business all the time, and don't have time to see the Statue of Liberty or the top of the Empire State Building or the United Nations."
This year's gathering features a record-breaking 2,619 meetings and events and 2,250 speakers, all detailed in a 675-page program book. Some are famous: featured attractions include Attorney General Janet Reno, Justice-to-Be Ruth Bader Ginsburg, F.B.I. Director-to-Be Louis J. Freeh, Connie Chung, Bianca Jagger, Mary Higgins Clark and E. G. Marshall, and do not include President Clinton, who begged off.
Other speakers may be less lustrous but are far more loquacious. The bar group's current president, J. Michael McWilliams of Baltimore, is scheduled to speak 25 times, while the man who will replace him at convention's close, R. William Ide 3d of Atlanta, will speak 21 times. R. Harrison Pledger, a lawyer in McLean, Va., will present the A.B.A.'s 1993 "Dignity in Lawyer Advertising" award. Among the other speakers are 16 Smiths, 7 Cohens, 12 Browns, 7 Whites and 3 Blacks.
Together, they will talk on topics including "Lost Words: Economic, Ethical, and Professional Effects of Bad Legal Writing"; "If I'd Wanted to Be in Sales, I Wouldn't Have Gone to Law School! -- Making Marketing Painless"; and "Why is My Client Nuts? An Inquiry Into the Psychodynamics of Divorce." Judith S. Kaye, Chief Judge of New York, will speak at a seminar Saturday titled "Is the Law Male?" -- one of nine speeches she is scheduled to give.
 
Hidden Attractions
 Even seemingly innocuous seminars can contain hidden attractions. For instance, a discussion Saturday morning called "Some Things Your Mother Never Told You About the Revised Uniform Commercial Code" features Anita F. Hill. Professor Hill will give a luncheon address afterward and take part in a panel discussion Sunday on the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Neither Justice Clarence Thomas nor any other member of the Supreme Court is expected at the convention.
While it is dwarfed by next month's gathering of the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., which will draw 50,000 to the city, for local businesses, the convention is a bonanza -- so much so that New York is already vying for the 1998 bar gathering. Tavern on the Green, for instance, has booked functions for several of the astonishing array of subgroups that make up the A.B.A. So, too, has the Rainbow Room.
"We have one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight parties," said Joseph Baum at the Rainbow Room, ticking off reservations by the National Association of Bar Executives, the A.B.A. law practice management section, the executive council of the National Conference of Bar Presidents, and the New York firm of Shearman & Sterling. "That's all private rooms, and I haven't given you the a la carte business. I wish they came more often."

HEADLINE: Perversely, Yen's Rise May Prolong the Japanese Recession

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The sharp swings in European currency markets may ultimately encourage a recovery in some of Europe's depressed economies by bringing down interest rates and making foreign products cheaper. But in Japan, the crisis may well have the opposite effect and could extinguish early flickers of an economic rebound.
While attention has been focused on the decline in the value of the French franc, the level of German interest rates, and the future of the European Monetary System, the yen has jumped in value against the dollar, setting off concern that Japan's nascent recovery from a long recession may be cut short. 
 The dollar slid to another postwar low today, fetching 103.85 yen at one point in New York. In late trading, the dollar sold for 104.05 yen, down from 104.88. That compares with 108.125 yen a little more than two weeks ago. More notably, since the beginning of the year it has fallen 16 percent.
By international currency standards that is a huge change, affecting hundreds of billions of dollars in trade, investment and currency.
 
No Boon to Industry
 The yen's relative increase makes it more expensive for Americans to buy Japanese exports with their weaker dollars, and also makes imported goods cheaper for Japanese paying in yen. While that helps consumers, it falls hard on manufacturers here -- pushing down profits, risking a reduction in already weak capital investment, and eating into bonus payments that make up a substantial portion of workers' incomes.
"The yen has become an obstacle to recovery," said Hirohiko Okumura, chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "The basic problem is not new; the dollar was already declining against the yen and we have been lowering our forecasts for economic growth this year. But now it is certain that if there is not a big stimulus to the economy, there will be no rebound."
Besides benefiting from its role as a currency haven at a time of international uncertainty, the yen has been helped by Japan's huge trade surplus, which is expected to exceed $150 billion this year. This encourages Japanese companies to sell dollar earnings and purchase yen, economists say.
But with an untested new coalition government poised to take power, the rising yen is threatening to become a political football.
There are already debates over what new measures the government should take to stimulate the ailing economy, whether the Finance Ministry will resist a tax cut as a stimulative measure, and whether slower growth will set off criticism in the United States.
Already, the government-to-be is finding that uncertainty is its unwanted companion. Today, Parliament was to choose Morihiro Hosokawa of the Japan New Party as Prime Minister. But the long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party blocked his election, demanding that one of its own be elected Speaker of the lower house and that the brief legislative session be extended so that Mr. Hosokawa could state and then defend his policies.
The new coalition has said that its first priority will be legislation to reform the electoral system after five years of scandals based on illegal payments to top politicians. The economy has been regarded as important, yet secondary. The recent concerns, however, could increase pressure on the coalition to tackle economic issues at the same time and to prepare a major package of stimulative measures, the third in a year.
Corporate Japan has also been turning up the heat for assistance from the new government.
Gaishi Hiraiwa, chairman of the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations, the most influential business group, commented, "There is a limit to companies' ability to deal with the relentless appreciation of the yen, which has already gone beyond what would be an appropriate level based on the economic fundamentals."
The issue could become a highly divisive one for the fragile coalition of seven parties that is to govern. Barring more surprises, it is to replace the Liberal Democrats, who held office for 38 years. Even many Liberal Democrats are now critical of the arrogance that so long a stretch of power has bred. Yet economic policy-making has been much easier with one party than it is expected to be with seven.
 
Not Everyone Would Cut Taxes
 The Socialists, the largest party in the new coalition, have indicated that they will support cuts in income taxes instead of a big increase in spending on construction and public works, so that the stimulative measures will benefit individual Japanese and not just corporations. But Ichiro Ozawa, a highly influential conservative figure in the coalition, has said that he will resist a tax cut out of concern that it would increase the budget deficit.
Tsutomu Hata, another conservative figure and a former Finance Minister, acknowledged this week that the tax issue was a divisive one and that arriving at a decision might be tough.
Officially, the Government has said that it expects the economy to grow 3.3 percent in the current fiscal year, which ends on April 1, 1994. That, however, is about twice the pace predicted by most private economists. Mr. Okumura said that under continued pressure from a strong yen, the rate of economic growth could be as low as seven-tenths of 1 percent if the government did not act.
Kazuaki Harada, chief economist at the Sanwa Research Institute, has said that he expects 1.6 percent growth for the year, but that figure has rested on the assumption that the dollar would not fall below 115 yen.
In recent days, the Government has announced that auto sales are declining and that department-store sales continue to fall, as well. They have been falling for 16 months.
Toshiro Kiribuchi, chief financial officer of the Omron Corporation, a major electronics manufacturer, said that for such exporters, the yen exchange rate that puts Japanese business on equal competitive terms with foreign producers is about 120 to the dollar.
Below that level, he said, manufacturers face severe pressure to move their factories out of the country, and all companies are more inclined to hire illegal aliens, who have been streaming into Japan and often working for lower wages than Japanese will.
Mr. Harada has laid out three scenarios for the economy. In the most optimistic, which he has embraced until now, a slow recovery will begin soon after the economy bottoms out from the nearly two-year recession. In the two others, the economy will stagnate and then make a very anemic recovery or level off, only to move back into recession. "If the yen stays at 104, it is quite likely we'll move to the second scenario," he said. "I'm getting more pessimistic."

HEADLINE: Explosions in Southeastern China Kill Scores, Official Report Says

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A series of huge explosions shook the southern city of Shenzhen today, possibly killing as many as 70 people, an official report said.
The explosions, shattering windows for miles around, occurred just across the border in China from Hong Kong, in the Shenzhen "special economic zone." Shenzhen (pronounced shun-JUN) is the centerpiece of China's economic liberalization program and one of the richest cities in the nation. 
 The blasts are likely to raise new questions about industrial safety in China, particularly as a nuclear power plant is to go on line soon in Daya Bay, not far from Shenzhen.
 
No Sign of Sabotage
 The first explosion was set off by a leak of nitric acid from a warehouse for hazardous materials. The fire from that blast then ignited a natural gas plant nearby, and by evening 8 of the 10 warehouses in the area had exploded in succession, the official New China News Agency reported. It is not clear what goods were being stored in the first warehouse, or precisely what ignited them, and there has been no indication of sabotage.
The agency did not give a precise death toll, saying only that more than 100 people had been killed or injured. Another China-controlled news service, the Hong Kong China News Agency, said that one hospital had admitted 200 injured people and that the number of dead could reach 70.
Many of the dead were firefighters, police officers and medical workers who had rushed to the scene after the first explosion. Among those killed were 2 deputy directors of the Shenzhen Public Security Bureau.
The Associated Press reported from Hong Kong that the Shenzhen authorities had requested help from the Hong Kong government, and that the British territory's director of fire services had flown to the area to assess the fire.
Official reports said the first blast had occurred at a warehouse operated by the Anmao Dangerous Goods Shipping and Storage Company, apparently an army-owned enterprise. The army has a wide range of profit-making companies engaged in everything from tourism to clock manufacturing.
As in most developing countries, safety standards are relatively lax in China, and the local authorities are sometimes willing to excuse problems in army-owned companies. But the Government has tried to raise consciousness about safety in recent years and has initiated campaigns to improve industrial safety.
Shenzhen abounds in small factories, mostly producing toys, clothing and electronic goods for export to the United States and other destinations through the port of Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: Airlines Give Travelers a Three-Tiered Fare Cut

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Travelers who played the waiting game this summer were rewarded yesterday when rival airlines not only matched the fare cuts announced by Delta Air Lines on Wednesday, offering discounts of up to 35 percent for travel through Dec. 15, but added three weeks to the start of the sale.
Delta had hoped to get past the busy Labor Day weekend before putting the discounts into effect on Sept. 15, but its rivals countered by allowing travel beginning Aug. 23. Rather than risk losing passengers to other carriers, Delta also agreed yesterday to the earlier date. But it dropped the 14-day advance purchase required by most other airlines, although a spokesman said last night that the carrier was reviewing whether to reinstate it. 
 "It's a creative attempt to solve the industry's problem of lagging leisure traffic, but even if it works the carriers still have serious structural problems," said Chris Miller, pricing analyst for USTravel, the nation's fifth- largest travel agency.
 
A Traffic Turnaround?
 The new fares are intended to address the lackluster traffic so far this year and predictions of an equally mediocre autumn. While fares have increased sharply in 1993, load factors -- the percentage of seats filled with paying passengers -- have been up one month and down another. Earlier this week, Jim Landry, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents major United States airlines, said the industry lost more than $400 million during the first six months of 1993, and $10 billion over the past three years.
The discounts announced this week are to some degree extensions of the 30 percent discounts on leisure travel that America West Airlines has offered in a series of eight sales since last November, the latest of which is good for travel through Sept. 30. But America West accounts for only a little more than 2 percent of the market, whereas Delta, which initiated this round, accounts for almost 18 percent.
The new fares are nonrefundable, take effect toward the end of the summer travel season, and impose other restrictions intended to prevent a repetition of last summer's disastrous fare war.
The discounts will be offered in stages -- somewhat like the fare structure that cruise ships have introduced over the last two years. The savings will be 35 percent on tickets purchased now through Aug. 17, 30 percent from Aug. 18 to Aug. 31 and 25 percent from Sept. 1 to Sept. 15.
Compared with the normal New York-Los Angeles round-trip excursion fare of $578, the new fares will be $376 for tickets purchased through Aug. 17, $405 for tickets purchased Aug. 18 to 31 and $433 for tickets purchased Sept. 1 to 15.
The new fares have several attractive features for leisure travel. While they require a Saturday night stay, they do not impose the usual travel blackouts over Labor Day and Thanksgiving. Tickets can be purchased during a period of almost six weeks, instead of the five to 10 days allowed in most promotions. The fares also apply to travel to Alaska, Hawaii, the United States Virgin Islands and San Juan, P.R., as well as Canada, Bermuda and Nassau in the Bahamas.
For passengers with time on their hands, agents said, the new fares were well worth waiting for. "I have a list of people who have been waiting for a sale, and asked me to call back when fares go down," said Jacqueline Kovach, owner of Community Travel Center in Fairmont, W. Va. "So today and tomorrow we'll be busy doing that."
 
Continuous Sales
 But Ms. Kovach also pointed to what many airline officials and analysts view as a dangerous byproduct of trying to stimulate traffic with repeated discounts: "The airlines have conditioned travelers to expect sales," she said, "and many people won't fly until there is one."
Mr. Miller of USTravel said low fares were financially feasible in a lagging economy only if carriers have a low-cost operating structure.
"If the economy picks up and your traffic improves, you have more options because you can vary the fare mix," he said. "But in a weak economy, you can't keep leisure fares up to where they should be and you can raise fares for business travelers only for a time before you reach a price resistance point."
