HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: Reporter's Notebook;
The Joy of Being Undecided: Senators Bask in the Lights

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
If nothing else is clear after the three-month public debate over President Clinton's budget package that ended tonight, this is: the Senate is not the House. Not in style, not in oratory, not in political machinations. The House is lightning, unpredictable and borne along by political squall lines that trigger sudden ruckuses and then die.
The Senate is the lightning bug, but would clearly prefer to be known by the more dignified Latin appellation: lampyridae. 
 Maybe nothing underscores that more than the two climactic votes on Mr. Clinton's economic program, in the House on Thursday and in the Senate tonight. Days before the House vote, Democratic leaders pronounced their grip secure and predicted that the budget package would be approved by what passes, in Landslide Bill Clinton's Administration, for a comfortable margin.
Instead, the bill passed by the very narrowest of margins and its fate was decided by a freshman Representative, Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, who had gone unknown and unnoticed until then, and who promptly went on vacation and into seclusion.
Compare that with the Senate, where Mr. Clinton's bill was in equally dire straits, but where the wavering senators do not merely stand out, but often thrust themselves before the television cameras to insure that they do so. Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, one such Democrat, held news conferences to declare that he might or might not support the measure. Senator Dennis DeConcini and Senator Bob Kerrey, until this week undecided Democrats from Arizona and Nebraska, have literally run gantlets of lobbyists and reporters who resemble nothing so much as teen-age girls at rock concerts.
This is not to say that most senators do not like it.
"The senators all believe they have a national constituency," said Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Democrat who served four terms in the House before moving across the Capitol this year. Then he voiced a novel idea: "My opinion is, if you're going to vote for or against it, you ought to vote and shut up. This idea of holding a press conference to say you're undecided is really something."
Mr. Campbell was collared as he was ducking down a set of stairs to dodge the throng of reporters and lobbyists who hang out at the Senate's elevator banks, waiting for sound bites.
"Like being attacked by a plague of locusts," he grumbled. "Now I know what a grain of wheat feels like."
 
Polite Peck on the Check
 The Senate even high-fives in more muted, magisterial fashion than the House. The House, after Wednesday's two-vote victory, was a high-school gym in which the crowd swarmed onto the court after an unheralded freshman fired the game-winning goal. The celebration -- wild cheers, raised arms, clenched fists -- spilled out of the cloakrooms and into the marble halls. There are reports, reliable but unverified, that spirits may have been consumed on the premises during the voting process.
The Senate? Vice President Al Gore cast the tie-breaking vote in dead silence and declared the measure passed. Some in the gallery and many Democrats let forth a huzzah, and Mr. Gore promptly gaveled them down in the manner of a schoolmarm rapping knuckles.
The revelry that followed was in the Senate tradition, that is to say, something akin to the receiving line for relatives of the deceased. Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, strode over and shook the hand of Jim Sasser, the Democrat who heads the Budget Committee and was the titular leader of the debate. Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, shook the hand of the vanquished Republican leader, Bob Dole. Democratic senators Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois and Diane Feinstein of California hugged. Pushing the envelope, Mr. Bradley hugged a Texas Republican, Kay Bailey Hutchison, and Democrat Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware pecked Ms. Moseley-Braun on the cheek.
Then they capped off the victory with a jolly round of talking, which Mr. Gore promptly gaveled down, again and again. Mr. Sasser tried to make a brief speech praising his staff, but Mr. Gore's gavel and the low buzz of conversation drowned him out. "I'm standing two feet from the Senator from Tennessee, and I can't hear him," Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont complained, in best party-pooping fashion.
Mr. Sasser finally gave up and asked Mr. Gore to print his full remarks in the Congressional Record. Then everyone went home.
 
Bargaining Chips Wanted
 No one really knew until the very last moment whether the key holdout, Mr. Kerrey, would deal his party and the White House a mortal blow. But the Democratic senators coming on and off the elevators today offered no hint of that. Rather, they were jovial, in a senatorial sort of way.
"I've bolted," Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey told the usuals, trying to persuade them that he had switched to oppose Mr. Clinton's package. "I'm off the bill. Think I'm kidding? Read my statement."
A reporter, perhaps thinking of the billions in concessions that other senators have extracted for their votes, corrected Mr. Bradley. "Bolting doesn't get you anything," he said. "You have to waver."
Mr. Bradley burst out laughing. "I'm wavering!" he cried as the doors closed, "I'm wavering! Fifteen years here and I'll learn."
 
Cool Hand on the Phone
 The telephone was spouting brimstone on Thursday morning in Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's office: big chunks of invective about the White House budget package aimed at the New York Democrat, who is one of its principal architects. But Senator Moynihan's receptionist, a lean man with deep-set eyes and graying hair, was unfazed.
As caller after caller railed against the Administration package and called for Congress to enact more spending cuts, the receptionist calmly defended Mr. Moynihan's handiwork and suggested that the Republicans, not Democrats, were to blame for deficits. When one North Carolina supporter of Ross Perot called the Democrats reckless budget-busters, he deftly suggested that the caller dial up the Senator Dole, who had tried just hours ago to add $4 billion to an Administration flood-relief bill.
Not bad for a phone jockey. But, of course, this was not Mr. Moynihan's regular receptionist. It was Senator Kerrey who had dropped by Mr. Moynihan's office for a head-clearing talk and decided as a lark to field constituent calls.
The callers never knew that, for a few minutes, they had the ear that lobbyists, lawmakers and the President longed for.
"If there was anyone in Washington they wanted to talk to, this was the guy," one Moynihan aide said. "Moynihan's vote was already committed. But this was the one single guy in the United States Senate who could decide the President's fate."
 
Flourishes Good and Bad
 Every debate has its oratorical aeries and gulleys, too. Not surprisingly, the inspired high point may have been reached by Mr. Moynihan, who was innocently asked this week how he enjoyed his first opportunity to put together a budget measure.
"It's like the fabled parson's egg," he replied without missing a beat. "Some parts are better than others."
A day of research produced the conclusion that Mr. Moynihan was alluding to a cartoon in the November 9, 1895 issue of Punch, the British magazine, in which a young clergyman is depicted eating a spoiled egg and saying, apparently to conceal his revulsion, that "parts of it were excellent."
Pin another ribbon on Mr. Dole, the Republican leader and master of the rhetorical short knife, for his warning tonight, just before the budget package passed, to the television audience. "All you viewers out there watching this debate on CNN and C-SPAN," he said. "Put down your remote control and grab your wallet, because your taxes are going up." That even drew a rare burst of applause from the gallery.
The low point? We almost forgot. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, delivering his assessment of the package tonight: "If you vote for this bill," he said, "you're voting for deep doo-doo."

HEADLINE: July Jobless Rate Dipped to 6.8% As Payrolls Increased by 162,000

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate edged down to 6.8 percent in July, the lowest rate in nearly two years, the Labor Department reported today. And the number of private-sector and government jobs swelled by 162,000, to 110.3 million.
The July gains suggest that the gradual improvement in the job market that took hold in the winter is continuing and that this recovery is indeed putting people back to work. 
 "You can't call this a jobless recovery anymore," said James Annable, the chief economist for the First National Bank of Chicago.
 
Little Change in Region
 In the New York region, unemployment fell a bit in New York State, dropping to 7.5 percent in July from 7.8 percent in June. In New Jersey, the unemployment rate held steady at 6.9 percent. [Page 49.]
"It's more drift than deterioration," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "But from the viewpoint of job recovery, New Jersey and New York have really yet to get on track."
Despite layoffs at brand-name corporations, military cutbacks and the flood in the Midwest, business and government have added 1.2 million new jobs so far this year, less than in some previous recoveries, but twice as many as were added during all of last year. The unemployment rate, stuck around 7 percent all year, is a percentage point lower than it was last summer.
"We're hiring," said D. Joseph Fleming, vice president of Compass Transportation Inc., of Youngstown, Ohio. The trucking company, which shuttles parts between auto and steel factories, is benefiting from rebounding production. "We're seeing business pick up everywhere, and we're actually trying to add 120 drivers between now and the end of the year," Mr. Fleming added.
But the job market continues to vary widely by region and industry, and many workers who are finding jobs are not necessarily satisfied with them.
In California, where the economy has been hit hard by cuts in military spending, the unemployment rate surged to 9.8 percent in July, from 9.1 percent in June, well above the national rate.
Nonetheless, consumers are starting to notice the slow improvement in the job climate, said Jordan Goodman, who oversees the Money magazine/ ABC News consumer comfort poll. "Consumers are feeling better about their own personal finances and about the national economy," he said. Spirits have been perking up bit by bit since early July, he added.
The evidence that the economy is indeed creating jobs comes as the Clinton Administration is trying to reassure average Americans that the economic recovery is sturdy enough to withstand the double whammy of tax increases and less growth in Government spending in its budget plan.
Administration officials were encouraged by the employment report. "We're on the right path," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said.
 
Fears for Small Business
 Republican opponents of the President's budget found little in the report to ease their anxieties. "I do think the economy is struggling back, trying to overcome bad public policy," said Representative Richard Armey, Republican of Texas. "But it's very anemic, and small business, which is the job-creating engine, is going to take the brunt of the tax increases."
Mr. Reich said that if the economy were to continue to create jobs at the July pace, President Clinton would meet his goal of eight million jobs by the end of 1996. At that rate, said Jack Bregger, assistant commisssioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, it would take a year or so to whittle the unemployment rate down by another percentage point.
But even if that happens, the improvements in the job market may not come fast enough to dispel the intense dissatisfaction that so many Americans feel with the economy, said Ted Van Dyk, a Democratic political analyst. "It's going to be trench warfare all the way economically -- inch-by-inch improvement."
Today's employment report gave several hints of why the modest recovery in the job market has felt so little like one. For starters, for many workers who have jobs, pay has not kept up with inflation. Hourly wages, which edged up two-tenths of a percent in July, have risen just 2.4 percent since last year.
 
More Temporary Workers
 Then, too, many business people -- unnerved by the prospect of new taxes or Government regulations and still uncertain about the economy's strength -- are reluctant to hire permanent workers. Temporary-help agencies added 27,000 jobs in July alone and have accounted for about one in five of the jobs that have been created this year. Finally, the legions of Americans who are working part time but wish they had full-time jobs is still large -- stuck at about 6.5 million for the last couple of years.
As the latest data show, companies in scores of industries are adding jobs. The Labor Department even turned up 31,000 more jobs for June and 23,000 more jobs for May than it had reported last month.
Builders took on 24,000 extra hands last month, thanks to better weather and lower interest rates that promoted construction. Some of the most solid construction markets are in the Southeast, where rebuilding from Hurricane Andrew, migration from other states and relatively strong manufacturing are bolstering economic growth.
As usual, it was the sprawling service sector that supplied the job numbers. From airlines to restaurants to warehousing, the business segment that employs most American workers grew by 153,000 jobs in July, after expanding by 600,000 in the previous three months. Employment in the retail sector, which rose 33,000 in July, is at a record high. Health care, which never did stop churning out new jobs during the recession, accounted for 21,000 hirings.
Government employment is stagnating, as it has been all year, rising a negligible 4,000 in total. The Federal Government has shrunk by 70,000 workers so far this year, but state and local governments have added nearly that many.

HEADLINE: Norwegians Claim Their Whaling Rights

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: REINE, Norway, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Norway has a reputation for being ecologically correct. Its melodramatic mountains and fjords are kept pristine. Hotels are apt to post notes requesting guests to reuse their towels to cut down on the use of detergents. Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland is so widely known as an environmentalist that she has been nicknamed "the Green Queen."
So it is an odd twist of fate that Norway is becoming a pariah among ecologists and a target for direct action campaigns by groups like Greenpeace. It is the first country to face the serious prospect of trade sanctions by the United States for undermining a conservation effort.
 
Insist on Their Right
 The reason is to be found in this tiny harbor village of 500 people in the Lofoten Islands, 60 miles north of the Arctic Circle. It is home to men who insist that they have a right to do what their fathers did -- to venture across the icy waters to hunt the minke whale. 
 "They say we have to protect the minke," said Bjorn Hugo Bendiksen, a 29-year-old whaler who began learning his trade on his father's boat when he was 15. "There's no reason to protect them. They're plentiful. Killing a minke is no different from killing a deer."
Sentiments like these horrify Greenpeace campaigners who have been chaining themselves to Norwegian tourist offices and fishing boats this summer as Norway became the first country to resume commercial whaling in defiance of a 1986 moratorium imposed by the International Whaling Commission. The commission was set up in 1949 to regulate whaling at a time when whales were rapidly disappearing.
So far this season, Norwegian fishing boats, most of them from Reine, have killed 153 minke whales, only 7 short of the commercial quota of 160 set by the Government.
Other whales remain strictly off limits, and in an effort to head off charges of profiteering, Norway has promised not to export whale meat to consumer countries like Japan.
But Norway's defiance has touched off an international boycott. A German supermarket chain has stopped buying Norwegian prawns and salmon. A British company has stopped importing Norwegian sleeping bags. And Greenpeace and other groups are promoting a move to keep travelers away from next year's Winter Olympics at Lillehammer.
 
Trade Restrictions Feared
 More worrisome from Norway's view is the possibility that the United States might impose restrictions on some of the $2 billion in imports from Norway under an amendment to the 1967 Fishermen's Protective Act. [On Aug. 5, Secretary of Commerce Ronald Brown certified that Norway's actions had "diminished the effectiveness of an international program for the conservation of endangered or threatened species," giving President Clinton 60 days to decide on sanctions.]
Given that the House of Representatives passed a resolution condemning Norway, 347 to 0, only six months ago, there is little doubt how the political wind is blowing. "This is more than a scientific question," an American diplomat said. "It's a political issue. When you get a vote of 347 to 0, you can count whales all day, but there's no way we could support their hunt."
Along Norway's northern coast, where whaling and fishing are part of a mystique of rugged self-reliance, the condemnation from abroad raises puzzled consternation. The outside world has mixed up David and Goliath, the people here say.
"People in the U.S. are totally misinformed," said Georg Blichfeldt, secretary of the High North Alliance, a pro-whaling group. "They think there's a big whaling industry, factory ships out there hunting down the last few whales. We're just a bunch of stupid little boats owned by families fighting for our rights. The only big organizations living off the whales today are Greenpeace and the Whale and Dolphin Society that use them as symbols for money raising."
For a whaler like Mr. Bendiksen, being on one of the 28 Norwegian whaling boats, alloted a quota of five or six whales each, has meant the difference between just scraping by and relative affluence. In the early 1980's, when whale quotas were higher, the minke catch doubled his total fishing income, bringing in an extra 100,000 krona, or $15,000. For the last six years, once the winter cod ran out in April, he dreaded the idle summer months.
Now, after his boat's haul of 33,000 pounds of whale meat selling at about $3.60 a pound, he is breathing easier. He has just purchased a modest house in the center of town for his wife, Nina, and their 7-month-old son, Sverre. On summer evenings when it never really gets dark here, he tosses whale meat onto the barbecue -- "the finest beef in the world," he proclaims -- and as he looks up at the mountains, he feels that all is right in the world.
Reine is a cluster of two-story pink, yellow, white and brown houses with white picket fences and is surrounded on three sides by sheer cliffs. Still pockmarked with snow, the cliffs disappear into enveloping clouds by mid-morning. On the outskirts of town are brightly painted cottages on stilts over the marshes for itinerant workers.
The village lives off fishing, and people here say the last six years have been tough.
"Before the ban there were 80 boats," Mr. Bendiksen said of the village's total fishing and whaling vessels. "Now, there are 40. In another 5 or 6 years, there'll be 6 or 7. We'll have to pack up and move away."
Norway contends that among the 80 or so species of whales, the minke, which is relatively small at about 30 feet and between 6 and 8 tons, is plentiful enough to sustain a controlled harvest. It cites figures accepted by the Whaling Commission's scientific committee that there are about 87,000 minke whales in the northeastern Atlantic. Although the Government insists that it could kill some 800 minkes a year without depleting the stock, it limited the quota this year to 160. An additional 136 minke whales are hunted by Norway for "research."
 
Census Called Unreliable
 Organizations like Greenpeace assert that Norway's whale census is unreliable and that the country's defiance could cause other whaling nations like Iceland and Japan to turn their backs on the moratorium. They say the whole system to protect threatened species could come tumbling down.
"Frankly, no one really knows how many whales are out there," said Andy Ottaway, Greenpeace's whale campaign coordinator. "The numbers are uncertain. There are so many unknowns. What's the effect of climate change? Of overfishing? No one can say for sure.
"Norway has killed more whales than any other nation on earth," Mr. Ottaway asserted. "It's time they were stopped. Whaling's a thing of the past. It belongs condemned to history, to a time when sadly we knew no better."
Norway insists that there must be a scientific basis to sound ecological management and that a quota system for an abundant species of whales makes sense.
In an interview, Prime Minister Brundtland said Norway had a long tradition of "sustainable development," or using resources without depleting them. She maintains that campaigns to save an unthreatened species of whale simply divert public attention from the real threats -- the pollution and high energy consumption of countries like the United States, Britain and Germany.
 
'We Feel Dictated To'
 "Of course we feel dictated to," she said. "It's a completely illogical, irrational, wrongly based campaign."
The Prime Minister, who is facing an election in September, stands to gain politically from allowing the whaling to resume. But she asserts that she has acted on principle.
On the other side, ecologists and others argue that the whales are not Norway's to deal with as Norway wishes, since the minke migrates thousands of miles to summer in the Arctic. They have long been outraged that Japan and Norway are allowed to kill even a limited number of whales for "research" -- to obtain information on the effects of pollution, feeding patterns and breeding -- and to sell the meat of the whales thus harvested on the open market.
As animal welfare groups gain in influence in the ecology movement, there is growing sentiment that the killing of whales is inhumane and morally wrong. Those campaigning for whales view them as unique and majestic mammals of humbling size. There are many stories about their intelligence and their bond of family.
To the whalers, the minke is just another animal. To appease those worried about inhumane deaths, the Government has sent an inspector on each whaling ship with a stopwatch to time the deaths from an exploding harpoon. The whalers say the average death is well under 4 minutes, but Greenpeace says it is closer to 10 minutes.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The House;
Whips Use Soft Touch To Succeed

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The excruciatingly slim victory for President Clinton's budget package in the House of Representatives on Thursday was fabricated from equal parts of flattery, cajolery and promises of sweetmeats to come.
Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan was upset that no one was consulting him in drafting a crime bill, and he voted against the budget package out of pique. House Democratic whips swarmed over him like bees to honey, and eventually he switched his vote, falling into line after being told he would be a prime player. 
 Representative Matthew G. Martinez of California first voted no because he said he did not like the gas tax. The whips went into action, and got the President to personally call Mr. Martinez on the floor. He is mum about what Mr. Clinton promised him (though he says he got something), and became a switcher with a minute or two to spare.
 
Party Loyalist Switches Vote
 But the biggest stampede of the whips -- a spectacle one Congressman compared to the storming of passengers onto the last departing train out of Grand Central Terminal on a Friday night -- was set off by a vote against the plan by Representative Jamie L. Whitten of Mississippi, an 83-year-old Democratic loyalist. First, Mr. Whitten protested that he could not vote against the rest of his state's delegation. But then, after the whips spoke a few honeyed words to him, he dutifully changed his vote.
With those three votes in hand, the Democrats were still two votes short. And so fate knocked for Representatives Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky of Pennsylvania and Pat Williams of Montana, an unlikely pair of Democrats who had hoped this moment would not come.
As the voting went on, Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky stood by the leadership desk, rubbing her arms nervously and hoping against hope that she could vote no to keep her skeptical constituents happy. As in May, the leaders held her in reserve to vote for the President's five-year economic plan only if her vote was absolutely needed.
The first-term Congresswoman had come out against the plan, having won election last November in her Main Line district, a group of mythically prosperous Philadelphia suburbs where winning candidates usually wear striped ties, by only 1,373 votes. A former television newscaster in Washington, she was one of the surprises of 1992, and thousands of her constituents will now be paying higher taxes next year as she seeks re-election.
 
Cheers and Jeers
 At the last moment the whips gave her the word that she was needed, and she walked down the aisle. One Democrat after another hugged her, patted her on the back and touched her as if she were Joan of Arc. As she finally voted aye, her Democratic colleagues cheered as the Republicans jeered, "Goodbye Marjorie."
Her vote, and Mr. Williams's, decided the issue.
The search for votes was a spectacle of petty dealmaking, rough-and-tumble peer pressure and a clash of oversized egos, punctuated occasionally by selflessness, as one member after another reluctantly fell into line to provide the 218-to-216 victory.
The vote was so close that House leaders were not really sure they had the votes to win when the vote began. They had 213 sure ayes, with eight to 10 up in the air. Seven Democratic lawmakers said they would not cast nay votes if they were needed, although three voted no anyway.
"It was a role of the dice," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat. "It was the closest, toughest vote I have seen in my 18 years as a legislator."
 
Making 'the Tough Choice'
 Perhaps the defining moment came at 5 P.M. when Congressman Williams finally got around to returning the President's call, who had phoned several times during the day. There are few more loyal Democrats than the Montana subcommittee chairman, but Mr. Williams was firmly opposed to a gas tax, which he said is unfair to his constituents who drive long distances.
"He said: 'Pat, I can't win this without you. My Presidency is at stake,' " Mr. Williams recalled. "His count was better than mine. I didn't think he would need me."
Mr. Williams wanted to help Mr. Clinton, but he said his overriding concern was that at a time when the public is skeptical about politics and the nation's political institutions, he wanted to demonstrate that "Congress can make the tough choice to keep the country moving."
After his talk with the President, Mr. Williams decided to wait to the last minute to vote, just in case his aye was needed.
 
It's Down to Four
 With the official time for the vote over and only a handful of votes left, it came down to Mr. Williams, Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky and Representatives Ray Thornton of Arkansas and David Minge of Minnesota.
Mr. Williams found Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky and Mr. Thornton, and shepherded them down to the well to vote. He first turned to Mr. Thornton, who as an Arkansan and old associate of the President, was thought to be a fairly safe vote.
But Mr. Thornton balked, saying he favored the original energy tax based on the heat content of fuels over the gas tax. Then the Montana Democrat turned to Ms. Margolies-Mezvinsky, and they took the plunge together as Mr. Thornton and Mr. Minge edged back from the abyss.
House leaders expressed frustration with Mr. Thornton today, wondering how he could have abandoned a President from his own state. "My job is to represent the people of the Second Congressional District," Mr. Thornton said.
Mr. Minge, a conservative freshman, also voted no. No one, not even apparently Mr. Minge, knows how he would have voted if his vote was needed.
"I was not prepared to vote yes," he said shortly after the vote. "But if it had been 217 to 217 I don't know what I would have done. It was an impossible situation."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE;
Excerpts From the Senate's Debate on the President's 5-Year Economic Plan

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Senate debate on President Clinton's five-year economic plan, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
Bill Bradley
Democrat of New Jersey
Mr. President, last year voters in this country voted overwhelmingly for change. They were fed up with economic hardship and fear for the future. This demand for basic change swept Bill Clinton into the White House and brought this package before us today. Most of the provisions in this bill the President advocated in the campaign, and the people elected him. With this bill we begin dealing with one of the primary national problems: the staggering deficit and the astronomical debt. The President deserves credit for acknowledging deficit spending as a problem. 
 Last January, I hoped he would boldly move on the debt and put on each legislator's desk by spring the vote of that legislator's lifetime, a vote that challenged special interests and asked all Americans to give up a little now so that they could have more later, and dealt a death blow to the exploding debt that, like acid, eats away at our future prospects.
This package is not the vote of a lifetime, but it is an important first step -- the biggest in the last decade -- to reduce the increase in the deficit. Remember, that's all this package does, reduce the increase in the deficit. It's a sad but true comment on our predicament and on the disastrous economic stewardship of the last 12 years. If we do nothing, the debt will go from $4 trillion to $5.4 trillion in five years. With this package, it will go from $4 trillion to $4.9 trillion. It's sobering to think that just 12 years ago the debt was $900 billion. . . .
Because I believe we need more spending cuts and deeper deficit reduction, I know there's going to be a second step, but we will never reach the second step without taking the first today. The first step is $500 billion in real deficit reduction. That's what the vote is today. If you are for deficit reduction, you will vote for this bill. The time for making excuses and passing the buck is over.
If you vote against this package, you must either lay out a specific alternative plan to cut the deficit by $500 billion or be revealed as someone who doesn't care about the burden we're loading on our children's backs. Without specific alternatives with equivalent deficit reduction, opponents of this package are simply playing the old politicians' game, which is to deliver exclusively good news, never to level with constituents, and above all to appear to be all things to all people.
 
Sam Nunn
Democrat of Georgia
Madam President, I regret to say that Washington continues to play the old game we grew up playing, called "Let's Pretend," as children. Many but not all Republicans pretend that we can achieve fiscal soundness with no new taxes. Many but not all Democrats pretend that we can achieve fiscal soundness while doing nothing about runaway growth in entitlement programs.
Both parties pretend that we can get our fiscal house back in order with little or no sacrifice by the vast middle class even though we all know that most revenues come from the middle class and most expenditures of our Federal Government go to the middle class. We don't like to say that, but we're not doing a favor to the middle class if we do not tell the American people those facts.
Madam President, realists in both political parties recognize that we must cut the growth rate of entitlements and other expenditures, we must raise taxes in a fair way that takes into account our present weak economy. And that means the effective date is very important on those taxes. And we must also provide incentives for savings and for investment.
All of these steps are needed to restore fiscal responsibility and to promote long-term economic growth and good jobs -- not simply one of those steps but all of them. All of these steps must be taken together; a piecemeal approach will not deliver the results.
Madam President, the President of the United States cannot be expected to cure all of these problems without a lot of help from Congress, both Democrats and Republicans. If Republicans continue to sit on the sidelines, they shift the political pendulum to the left and help insure the very results they denounce. Until the President and the realists in Congress come together across party lines, the game of "Let's Pretend" will continue, the huge deficits will continue and our economic problems will continue. The losers will continue to be the American people, particularly the middle class, that Washington spends so much time talking about protecting.

So I vote yes, Mr. President, and we pass a bill that seems to follow a perverse interpretation of the Sermon on the Mount: the meek shall inherit the earth.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET STRUGGLE: The Region;
Backlash to Tax Rise Splits New Jersey Democrats

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
While New York and Connecticut Democrats were firmly united behind President Clinton's tax and deficit reduction plan, there were major defections among New Jersey Democrats in Congress.
What engendered opposition to the President's plan in New Jersey, several Democratic leaders said, was a lingering political backlash to the state tax increase pushed by Gov. Jim Florio three years ago, and the residual fear that voters would punish anyone who supported another tax increase. 
 As expected, every Republican representative from the three states voted against Mr. Clinton's five-year economic plan on Thursday night. And Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York kept Republican opposition uniform with his vote against the plan last night.
The vote split along partisan lines in New York and Connecticut. Every one of the 18 Democratic representatives from New York, and all three Democratic representatives from Connecticut, supported the plan in the House vote Thursday night.
 
Senate Votes Compared
 In the vote last night Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee and was a major architect of the budget measure, voted for it. Also voting for it were Connecticut's two Democratic Senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman.
But the two Democratic Senators from New Jersey were divided. Bill Bradley voted for it, as he had indicated all along. But Frank R. Lautenberg, who is running for re-election next year, voted against it. Mr. Lautenberg was one of six Democrats to vote with the Republicans against the President's plan when it first squeaked through the Senate in June, and he announced on Tuesday that he would do so again.
While a state income tax pushed through by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut fostered anti-tax sentiment in that state, it did not prove as enduring as in New Jersey.
Gordon MacInnes, a former New Jersey State Senator and Morris County Democratic leader, noted the difference by citing the problems Senator Bradley had in his 1990 re-election campaign. "No Democrat in Connecticut ever saw a United States Senator as popular as Bill Bradley come within two percentage points of being defeated in the aftermath of the Florio tax fight," said Mr. MacInnes, who lost a bid for re-election to the State Senate in 1975 after he supported Gov. Brendan Byrne's income tax program.
 
Mindful of Earlier Defeat
 One of Mr. MacInnes's fellow Democrats, Herbert C. Klein, also voted for the tax, and was also defeated. But Mr. Klein made a political comeback last year, winning election to the House in a district that includes affluent Essex County communities and working-class neighborhoods in Passaic, where anti-tax sentiment is often fierce. Perhaps mindful of his earlier defeat, Mr. Klein voted against the budget on Thursday night.
Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat who succeeded Mr. Florio in the First Congressional District, which includes Camden, said he voted against the President's plan because it did not include a major jobs program.
But Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat who was first elected to Bergen County's relatively wealthy Ninth District 11 years ago, voted for the Clinton plan, saying to do otherwise would be shortsighted. And yesterday he explained his decision.
"While a strong anti-tax backlash is still a part of the political reality in New Jersey, Jim Florio's re-election in November will go a long way to put it to rest," he said. "And when that happens, voters will say Bill Bradley and the rest of us were right for voting for deficit reduction, and Frank Lautenberg and the others were wrong."
If money is any measure, Senator Lautenberg was the first to suffer yesterday. Mr. MacInnes's wife, Blair, sent the Senator carbon copies of two $500 checks that she said would have gone to him had he stood behind the Clinton plan.
Instead, Mrs. MacInnes, a member of a wealthy Philadelphia family who, like others with high incomes, stands to lose the most under the tax plan, said she was sending the checks to two first-term Democratic Representatives who risked their political future by voting for it -- Karen Shepard of Utah and Majorie Margolies-Mezvinsky of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: After Flood, 2 Towns Diverge About the Next One

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KAMPSVILLE, Ill.

 BODY:
Black waters heaved up from the banks of the Illinois River during the flood, submerging half of this town's homes and most of its businesses.
Not far up the river is Liverpool, Ill., a town of 200 residents that also sits low on the banks of the Illinois, which made sense when steamboats pulled up to the town's docks in the 19th century and young couples from Chicago disembarked to be married in nearby Lewistown. 
 The 20th century, though, has brought dams and levees to the river, drastically raising the height of flood stages, and this summer half of the homes in Liverpool were inundated.
Although the two towns, separated by 80 miles of river, suffered the same fate in the floods of 1993, they are taking opposite approaches in searching for a way to reduce the damage that future floods may inflict.
Liverpool has chosen to entrust its future to a levee. Residents have been campaigning for state and Federal money to build one on the Illinois, a tributary of the Mississippi, since a flood in 1983. Next summer the Army Corps of Engineers is scheduled to begin construction of a 4,400-foot levee at a cost of $2.1 million, a project that Government engineers say will end Liverpool's flood problems.
In Kampsville, the corps said a levee was not feasible. So since 1986 the Government has been buying homes and businesses, most of which have been demolished, and people have moved out of the flood plain. So far, $1.1 million has been spent, but the buyout has caused lingering resentment over the low prices paid by the Government, and much of Kampsville remains in danger of flooding.
 
Questions Are Addressed
 As flood water drains from the 700,000-square-mile upper Mississippi River basin, officials at every level of government are beginning to examine the same questions about policies for controlling catastrophic flooding.
By no means are such questions new. In 1966, a commission named by President Lyndon B. Johnson called for the development of a more economically sensible approach to reducing threats from flooding. The debate has taken on new urgency this year, not only because of the $12 billion in flood damages, but also because of laws passed since 1966 that experts said gave the Clinton Administration more authority than any other Administration to refocus the nation's approach to the problem.
President Clinton indicated in July that he was ready to study the effect of Federal policy on the flooding. Kathleen A. McGinty, director of the White House Office on Environmental Policy, said in an interview that she would coordinate a study that would include the White House Office of Management and Budget and a dozen other Federal agencies.
The Administration wants to "make sure that the Federal response goes to insuring that the next time we have floods, the Government will make the situation better, not worse," she said.
Many conservationists and state wildlife officials contend that the way to reduce damages from catastrophic flooding is to restore the upper Mississippi's natural flood control capacity by encouraging people to move out of the flood plains, by relying more on flood plains, which let flood waters spread out, and less on levees and other barriers, and by restoring sponge-like wetlands.
 
Altered Landscapes
 The natural features of the landscape that once absorbed and helped to control flooding have been altered over the last century by industrial and agricultural development. Along the Missouri River, for instance, 90 percent of the region drained by the river in 1860 was forest and wetlands, which absorb vast amounts of rain.
More than a century later, 70 percent of the region is pasture and cropland, less than 10 percent of the land is forest or wetland, and the rest is residential or industrial. Consequently, conservationists and state environmental officials say, rain rushes off the land into a river system that is unable to handle so much water. It is no accident of nature, conservationists say, that Illinois, Iowa and Missouri -- the three states where flood damage has been the worst -- have lost from 85 percent to 90 percent of their wetlands, according to state and Federal studies.
"Instead of 19 million acres of wetlands that we had in the upper Mississippi and Missouri River basins, what we have are storm sewers and well-drained fields that carry water off the landscape," said Constance Hunt, a staff member of the World Wildlife Fund, an environmental group in Washington. "The thing we need to do is think a little bit before we rush out to rebuild the levees and protect farm fields. We need to think about slowing down the water and keeping it on the flood plain."
Such an approach would be almost a complete reversal of Federal policy as well as a reversal of the economic and cultural tradition of the last century. On the other hand, farmers, town leaders, business owners and many officials in the Army Corps of Engineers are calling for levees to be repaired and for new ones to be built to preserve the development that has grown up.
The sentiment in the Midwest was apparent in Congress in July as the flood waters were rising on the Mississippi and its tributaries. Congress rejected the Clinton Administration's proposal to spend $370 million in the next fiscal year to convert 500,000 acres of farmland, much of it in the flooded region, back to wetlands.
 
Development Praised
 "If you look back at history, it is the development of the valleys and the river banks that has allowed our country to grow," said Earl Bull, a farmer who lives near Liverpool. "I hear all this talk about how taxpayers can't afford disasters like the one we've had this summer. Well, all I ask -- if we're going to force farmers out and move people out of harm's way in the Midwest, are we going to do that as national policy? How about the San Andreas fault?"
Whatever the Administration chooses, the most obvious lessons to be drawn from the experiences of Liverpool and Kampsville are that any changes in flood control measures are difficult to achieve and extraordinarily expensive and take years to conclude.
In the early 1980's, the Federal Emergency Management Agency first proposed buying about 70 homes and businesses on Liverpool's flood plain and moving residents to higher ground, but town leaders rejected the proposal. "We didn't trust it would work," said Mickey Belles, 29, who has lived in Liverpool almost all her life.
So Mrs. Belles's husband, Floyd, led a campaign to build a levee, and construction is to begin next year. "People here say they won't believe it until they actually see it," Mrs. Belles said. "It's taken so long. But it's going to end all the problems we have here."
 
Misery Long After Floods
 In Kampsville, the misery will continue long after this summer's flooding subsides. Because of engineering and environmental restrictions on the Illinois River, the Army Corps of Engineers decided not to build a levee. The state and Federal Emergency Management Agency began buying homes and businesses in 1986, a move supported by most residents.
But the pace has been exceedingly slow, residents said. The state and Federal Governments have spent $1.16 million to buy 60 homes and businesses, most of which have been demolished. But nearly that many buildings are still in the flood plain and now filled with water.
The problem, residents said, is that the Government is not offering enough money for their property. But residents here said the state and Federal Government were costing themselves money by being too chintzy. Louis Hazelwood, who owns the Kampsville Inn, explains it this way: His restaurant near the ferry landing in town was flooded in 1983 and several times since, including once earlier this year. Mr. Hazelwood spends $1,500 a year on Federal flood insurance, a program that is partly financed by the Government. Every time his business fills with water, he receives a check from the Government for repairs.
In all, Mr. Hazelwood said he had collected more than $250,000 in flood insurance payments over the years, not counting the $100,000 to $130,000 check he said he would collect for the July flooding. Mr. Hazelwood said he had offered repeatedly to sell the business to the Government for $125,000, but his proposal had been rejected.
"Listen," he said, "I'll take all the flood money they want to give me. But what they could have done is give me a lump sum years ago, and that would have been it. This here is just a waste."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In 1986, the Army Corps of Engineers decided a levee in Kampsville, Ill., was not feasible. As a result, the Government has bought much property in the town on the Illinois River. But as the waters have risen, so have questions about the Federal policies for controlling catastrophic flooding. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Clinton budget plan passed its final legislative hurdle, passing the Senate by a 51-to-50 vote, with Vice President Al Gore casting the tie-breaking vote. The outcome was in doubt until Democratic Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska declared that he would support Mr. Clinton. [Page 1.]
The U.S. unemployment rate edged down to 6.8 percent in July, the lowest level in nearly two years, the Labor Department reported. And the number of jobs on business and government payrolls swelled by 162,000 to 110.3 million. The gains suggest that the gradual improvement in the job market that took hold in the winter is continuing and that this recovery is indeed putting people back to work. [1.] The jobless rates in New York and New Jersey remained virtually unchanged from June -- at 7.5 percent and 6.9 percent, respectively. [49.]
American consumers increased their borrowing by $7.67 billion in June, the largest one-month jump in six years. [46.]
 
 Companies
Eastman Kodak's chairman was ousted by the company's board. Kay R. Whitmore apparently was not moving fast enough to improve the company's financial performance. [37.] According to three independent directors, Mr. Whitmore had been given every chance to redeem himself with the board. [37.]
Northwest Airlines completed agreements with its lenders and employees, averting bankruptcy. [37.]
Volkswagen's supervisory board and management closed ranks in support of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the auto maker's production chief, who is accused of industrial espionage by his former employer, General Motors. [39.]
Ipalco Enterprises escalated its takeover battle for PSI Resources by raising its bid nearly $1.6 billion. [39.]
Turner Broadcasting is in talks to acquire New Line Cinema. Turner is also talking to Castle Rock Entertainment. [39.]
The Gap is testing a new line of lower-priced basic clothing in an attempt to attract more cost-conscious customers. [39.]
Delta Air Lines is offering frequent fliers a chance to trade in some miles for a one-hour session in a flight simulator. [39.]
 
 International
Western Germany's unemployment grew in July to 7.5 percent of the work force, the highest level for the month since the Government began keeping records in 1949. [37.]
 
 Markets
The stock market moved upward in late trading as investors braced for a Senate vote on the budget package. The Dow Jones industrial average added 11.46 points to close at 3,560.43. [38.]
Treasury prices showed little change as the bond market found no surprises in the July employment report. The 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32 of a point, while its yield rose to 6.53 percent. [46.]
The dollar fell against most major currencies as profit-taking ended a brief rally. [48.]
Silver prices were hammered again by heavy speculative selling, but the gold market posted only modest losses. [48.]

The most important measurement in assessing mutual fund risk is an investor's own reaction when it falls. [35.]
Difficulty in obtaining corporate information is one drawback to "street" accounts.. [36.]

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 NEW YORK CITY
 
 ASBESTOS TESTS FOUND WANTING
New York City officials have determined that asbestos tests to certify the safety of every city public school are so unreliable as to be meaningless. The officials have described the Board of Education's asbestos testing as grossly mismanaged, incompetent and possibly fraudulent. Mayor Dinkins ordered an emergency inspection of each of the city's 1,069 schools. Page 1.
Public School 188 on the Lower East Side is one of the 83 city schools that will get the highest priority in checking for asbestos. Page 24.
Experts agree that asbestos is a threat only if its fibers escape into the air, where they can be inhaled. Page 24.
 
 BACTERIA STILL HAUNT WATER
Bacteria are still appearing in the tap water around New York City at a rate far higher than normal, the Environmental Commissioner said yesterday, adding that more "boiled water alerts" are still possible. But the likely source of the problem, an unusual water routing at the Hillview Reservoir in Yonkers, will be ending. Page 25.
 
 MOVING OF BOMB TRIAL IS WEIGHED
The Federal judge presiding over the World Trade Center bombing case has said he has considered moving the trial to Cincinnati to escape the extensive pre-trial publicity but is leaning toward keeping it in New York City. Page 25.
 
 REGION
 
 STATE LINES SPLIT DEMOCRATS
While New York and Connecticut Democrats were firmly united behind President Clinton's tax and deficit-reduction plan, there were major defections among New Jersey Democrats in Congress. Page 8.
 
 PANEL ON LEGISLATURE NAMED
The Nassau County Executive has nominated the 17 members of a charter commission to create the rules for a new county legislature, following a Federal judge's ruling in April that Nassau's current form of government is unconstitutional. Page 26.
 
 A BANNER WAR AGAINST GOVERNMENT
The plain-talking owner of the Oak Beach Inn on Long Island is taking government to task with signs and banners raging against the ineptitude and corruption that he sees in places both high and low. Page 26.
 
 LEARNING SPORTS AT CAMP
The Cosmos day camp at Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J., is one of many specialized sports programs in the New York region that coach children on improving their skills. Page 26.
 
 GOOD NEWS ON HAZARDOUS WASTE
For the second time this week, test results have indicated that the hazardous-waste problems of Stratford, Conn., may not be as serious as initially feared. Page 26.
 
 UNEMPLOYMENT RATE BARELY BUDGES
In a sign that the New York region has not yet entered a period of sustained economic recovery, the unemployment rate in New Jersey and New York remained virtually unchanged from June to July, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. Page 49.

HEADLINE: A Man Fights Red Tape With His Own Banners

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAK BEACH, L.I., Aug. 5

 BODY:
It began with a truck, a van and a hearse, rolling down the Long Island Expressway, bearing prophesies of doom for the slaves of 9 to 5: "Move Out of New York State, Before It's Too Late."
Soon after, red banners with the same exhortation appeared on overpasses in Long Island and Queens: the Van Wyck, Long Island and Clearview expressways, the Northern and Southern State and Grand Central parkways. They would go up at night, salvos in a game of dialectical guerrilla warfare, and make it through morning rush hour before being torn down by the authorities. 
 For the last few weekends, beachgoers from Coney Island to West Hampton have peered up at slow-flying planes trailing the dire plea across the Atlantic Coast, while radio stations have played commercials on the same theme. And this weekend, weather permitting, New Yorkers will see the message scripted across the heavens above Yankee Stadium or Central Park.
Is it a bird? Is it a plane? Is it a fed-up businessman who estimates he has spent more than $1 million in legal battles with state and local governments?
 
'Go for Their Throats'
 "It got to the point where I said, 'I'm not going to waste my time in court anymore. I'm going to put you guys out of jobs. I'm going straight to the people.' " said Robert Matherson, the plain-talking owner of the Oak Beach Inn, who is spending more than $25,000 a week to urge on the exodus. "I can do what my lawyers can't do: I can go for their throats."
A waterfront nightclub offering escapist diversions like Jet Skis, bungee jumping and drinking till 4 A.M. under a multicolored helium balloon might seem an unlikely caldron for popular revolt, but Mr. Matherson maintains that his gripe is really about the difficulty of running a successful business -- any business -- on Long Island; a raging in six-foot letters against the ineptitude and corruption that he sees in places high and low.
"It's a government not for the people; it's for the politicians," he said. "It's worse than organized crime, because the politicians steal legally."
Mr. Matherson's history along Oak Beach, a sandy strip on the road to Robert Moses State Park, betrays a 26-year seasonal tussle with neighbors and local officials over noise, overcrowding and parking. The fights began with Robert Moses, who lived near the Oak Beach Inn and moved to limit parking in the lot. Since then, the inn has built additions north, south, east and west, swelling the nightclub's capacity to 1,500 from 185.
 
No Parking From Town
 In 1981, the Babylon Town government, which leases the land on which the inn and the private homes of Oak Beach sit, agreed to sell Mr. Matherson the land and to provide parking for several hundred cars, he said. The town has yet to provide the spaces, and so overflow parking has ended up on Oak Beach's two-lane street, fueling the ire of most of Mr. Matherson's neighbors.
"His place overwhelms the community," said Larry Dougherty, president of the Oak Beach Civic Association, who confesses more than a bit of impatience with the Move Out of New York State campaign. "He's a self-made millionaire who's made his money on Long Island, in Suffolk County and most of it at the Oak Beach Inn. Where's his gratitude?"
Mr. Dougherty contends that the club owner's campaign is more gimmick than cry of woe, and says he prays for Mr. Matherson to pack up his bungee crane and hit the road. "He would never leave New York State -- we would never be that lucky," Mr. Dougherty said.
In fact, Mr. Matherson's radio ads end with a plug for his bar.
Mr. Matherson says he does plan to leave, perhaps for Florida, in the fall, but even his closest friends doubt he will.
"He says he's going to, but I can't imagine the Oak Beach Inn without Bob Matherson," said Rosanne M. Rousseau, who is writing a book about Mr. Matherson and has become a close friend. "It would be like selling a major body part."
The New York State Liquor Authority, which seized 127 bottles of liquor in a raid at the Oak Beach Inn last year, became another target of Mr. Matherson's wrath. Barbara Lord, a spokeswoman, said the authority was moving to revoke Mr. Matherson's liquor license for failure to cooperate with an investigation, inciting a riot and selling beer from unmarked taps.
"We treat everybody the same," she said. "A number of people feel they are being picked on. I don't want to say they're paranoid, because that wouldn't be nice to say."
Mr. Matherson, who bought the original Oak Beach Inn in 1967 at the age of 25, now says he sees corruption everywhere. Recently, he took a sample of the concrete from an abutment under the Great South Bay Bridge, which is being rebuilt. He sent it to a lab, which rated the concrete "fair to poor" quality.
"Some inspectors weren't doing their jobs," he said. "A bridge from the 1950's shouldn't need to be rebuilt already."
Though his fights are peculiar to his business ventures, Mr. Matherson's campaign has turned him into a magnet for popular discontent. A Bay Shore woman, who said she could not afford to leave New York because real-estate prices had plummeted, blamed immigrants for her husband's unemployment, and wrote Mr. Matherson: "I thank God for a person like you. The little people like us will never be heard because we can't afford it."
Others are less supportive. "Listening to your radio advertisements aggravates my stomach," wrote an East Hampton woman. "It is sad to see that a bar I have enjoyed for 10 years has been run by such a totally ignorant, over the hill jerk."
But Mr. Matherson, whose hearse will be featured rolling through Bay Shore in what he calls "gloom and doom" television spots next week, remains undeterred.
"She reinforces my commitment," he said, glancing at the letter from East Hampton. "I need to know I'm being effective. It encourages me to go further."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A Long Island businessman who said he grew tired of battling state and local governments in the courts has moved the battle to any arena where a sign can be hung or a message can be broadcast. One of Robert Matherson's messages, "Move Out of New York State Before It's Too Late," hangs on a derelict ferry that is slowly settling into the Oak Beach waterfront near his restaurant on Long Island; "It's a government not for the people; it's for the politicians," said Robert Matherson. "It's worse than organized crime, because the politicians steal legally." (Photographs by Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 11.46 Advance in Dow; Other Big Indexes Gain

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The stock market moved upward late in yesterday's trading, as investors braced for the Senate's vote last night on President Clinton's budget package. Stocks have been generally indecisive all week as Congress headed for a showdown over the President's economic plan.
Although gainers topped decliners on the New York Stock Exchange by only a slight margin, the three key market barometers were all higher. The Dow Jones industrial average added 11.46 points to close at 3,560.43; the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks advanced 0.55 point, to 448.68, and the Nasdaq composite index extended its record run for the third consecutive day, rising 2.58 points, to 718.08. 
 Volume on the Big Board was moderate, with 221.2 million shares changing hands.
 
'Extraordinarily Rational'
 "The market has effectively been put on hold until the outcome of the Clinton economic plan," said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. Late last night, the Senate gave its final approval to the budget by a 51-to-50 margin.
Mr. Johnson noted that the market was encouraged by "moderately good news on the employment front."
The Labor Department announced that the United States unemployment rate dropped to 6.8 percent in July from 7 percent the previous month, marking the lowest level since 1991. About 162,000 nonfarm jobs were created, even though there were 13,000 fewer jobs in the manufacturing sector.
"It was an extraordinarily rational day," Mr. Johnson said. "The stocks of companies that are sensitive to swings in the economy did well."
The story of the day on Wall Street was Eastman Kodak, which announced that Kay R. Whitmore would be replaced as chief executive after an outside successor is appointed. Anticipating that a change in leadership would speed the company's turnaround, traders bid up the stock 3 1/4, to 58 5/8, a 52-week high. Volume was very heavy, pushing Kodak into the most active spot on the Big Board.
Two other big blue-chip stocks, Sears, Roebuck and International Paper, were also market standouts yesterday. Sears, which rose 3/8 on Thursday when it reported a 15.4 percent increase in July same-store sales, yesterday tacked on 1 7/8, to 55. International Paper, another leader in the Dow, gained 2, to 66, because of improved investor sentiment on cyclical stocks.
Some semiconductor stocks, which have been gaining momentum recently, continued to post solid gains. Intel was up 1 1/2, to 57 1/4; Texas Instruments 1 3/4, to 76, and Advanced Micro 1 1/4, to 28 1/4.
Many international oil issues also performed strongly yesterday. Among them, Mobil increased 1 1/2, to 72 5/8; Exxon 3/4, to 63 3/4, and Texaco 1/4, to 62.
 
Big Three Decline
 In contrast, automotive stocks fell after Ford Motor's announcement of a recall of around 15,000 Escorts because of emission problems. Ford dropped 1, to 51 5/8; General Motors fell 7/8, to 47 3/4, and Chrysler lost 1, to 41 7/8.
Shares of 3Com advanced 1 3/8, to 22 1/2, rebounding from a decline of 1 5/8 on Thursday. That was when an analyst reduced earnings estimates for the company and cut its investment rating to hold from buy.
New Line Cinema, which confirmed that it was involved in talks regarding a combination with Turner Broadcasting, eased 1/4, to 16 1/4. On Thursday, New Line surged 1 7/8 on heavy trading.
Southern National signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire the First Savings Bank of Greenville, the largest financial institution with headquarters in South Carolina. Southern National closed down 1, to 20 3/4, and First Savings slipped 1/8, to 15 7/8.
In Tokyo, stocks slipped three-tenths of a percent yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed at 20,357.94, down 67.70 points.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Are Little Changed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury prices showed little change yesterday as the bond market found no surprises in the July employment report.
The 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32 point in late trading, while its yield rose to 6.53 percent, from 6.52 percent on Thursday. Prices on shorter-term issues were mixed. 
 As trading wound down, the market appeared to be anticipating the final passage of President Clinton's budget bill by the Senate and had already factored it into prices.
"Market participants feel fairly confident at the moment that the budget legislation will pass tonight," Carol A. Stone, a senior economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. in New York, said before the vote on the budget.
 
Fulfilled Expectation
 Late last night, the Senate fulfilled the bond market's expectations and gave its final approval to the budget by a 51-to-50 margin.
The Clinton budget package is seen as positive for bonds for two reasons, analysts said: The higher taxes it includes could tend to slow the economy, making it less likely that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates, and the deficit reduction it seeks could mean less Government borrowing, making existing bonds more valuable.
Still, Maureen Maitland, an economist at UBS Securities Inc., said the bond market was more interested yesterday in the Government's employment report than in the outcome of the budget showdown.
The Labor Department reported the nation's unemployment rate fell to 6.8 percent in July from 7 percent in June and said business payrolls increased by 162,000. While an improvement, the results were close to the market's expectations. Ms. Stone said traders had expected an addition of about 150,000 jobs.
Going into next week, the market will be looking forward to Thursday's report on producer prices and Friday's on consumer prices. The bond market watches inflation closely, as inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments and any surge could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
In trading yesterday, short-term Treasury issues rose 1/32 to 2/32 point, while intermediate-term notes ranged from down 1/32 point to up 3/32 point. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, was unchanged from Thursday at 1,308.22.
 
Discount Rates on Bills
 The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills slipped two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.02 percent, while six-month bills were unchanged at 3.18 percent. The discount rate on one-year bills fell five basis points, to 3.35 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest rate on overnight loans between banks, fell to 2.94 percent, from 3.05 percent on Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 1022/32 , unchanged from Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.73 percent, also unchanged.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Rally on Job Figures Gives Way to Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday as profit taking ended a brief rally caused by surprisingly strong United States jobs data.
The dollar surged after the Labor Department reported that July unemployment fell to 6.8 percent, the lowest rate since September 1991. Nonfarm jobs grew by 162,000, below forecasts. But dealers focused on the revised gain of 44,000 jobs for June, up from the 13,000 previously reported. 
 "People were evidently long dollars before the number came out" and the brief jump in the dollar gave them an excuse to take profits, said Jim Phoenix, a dealer at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York.
The selloff grew as dealers decided the data merely confirmed a slow economic recovery in the United States.
"The story of a muted expansion remains intact," said Richard Benzie, a currency economist at UBS in London. "There's no sign yet we're going to get an acceleration in the pace of growth which would cause the Federal Reserve to tighten" credit, he said.
 
Back to Fundamentals
 Moreover, the United States economic data have replaced European monetary tensions as a focus of the market, the dealers said.
"Since the upheaval in the European Monetary System subsided, the market has tended to look at fundamentals again," said one dealer at a German bank in New York.
The talk that the European central banks were buying marks also depressed the dollar, sterling and gold.
"We suspect a lot of them are buying marks, selling dollars to replenish reserves," said Robert Ryan, the manager of corporate foreign exchange at the Bank of New York, who noted heavy spending by central banks recently to support weak European currencies.
The dollar fell to 1.6966 marks in late New York trading, from 1.7123 marks on Thursday.
 
A Rise Against the Yen
 The dollar rebounded yesterday in quiet dealings from a postwar low of 103.90 yen at midday Thursday with the help of Bank of Japan purchases. In New York the dollar fetched 104.35 yen, up from 104.05 yen late Thursday.
The British pound rose to $1.4965, from $1.4948 on Thursday.
Other late New York dollar rates, compared with quotes on Thursday, included: 1.5015 Swiss francs, down from 1.5071; 5.9215 French francs, down from 5.9450; 1,601 Italian lire, down from 1,602, and $1.2914 (Canadian), down from $1.2926 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: Scant Change in Region's Unemployment

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
In a sign that the New York region has not yet entered a period of sustained economic recovery, the unemployment rates for New York State and New Jersey remained virtually unchanged -- at 7.5 percent and 6.9 percent, respectively -- from June to July, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
The figures continued a three-month trend for both states of almost no variation in the number of unemployed, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the statistics bureau, indicating that the "shading in the economy is still primarily gray." 
 "It looks like we're still in a bottoming-out process instead of a clear recovery path," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
 
Above National Average
 Although the figures show marked improvement from a year earlier -- when jobless rates in both states soared to their highest levels in a decade -- the rates for New Jersey and New York, two states hard hit by the recession, are still slightly higher than the national average of 6.8 percent for July. In July 1992, New York's unemployment rate was 9.3 percent; New Jersey's was 9.6 percent.
New York State's rate of 7.5 percent last month compared with 7.8 percent in June, according to the report. This means that nearly 640,000 New Yorkers who were seeking jobs could not find them. In New Jersey, the 6.9 percent rate was the same as in June, meaning that about 271,000 people were without jobs.
Joblessness in New York City was 9.5 percent last month, up from 9.4 in June, although figures for the city, unlike those for states, are not adjusted to account for seasonal surges in the number of job seekers. The city's rate was 12.1 percent in July 1992.
The rate for Connecticut, whose July figures have not been released, was 6.7 percent in June, down from 7.4 percent in May, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Among the 11 large states for which the Federal Government releases employment statistics each month, New York and New Jersey compared favorably in July. Only North Carolina, with a rate of 4.5 percent, and Massachusetts, at 6.3 percent, had lower numbers than New Jersey, which tied Ohio at 6.9 percent. California, with 9.8 percent unemployment, had the highest jobless rate among the big states.
In New York State, an increase in hiring in the service industry of about 42,000 people since last year was offset by the loss of nearly 50,000 manufacturing jobs since last year, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt added that although New Jersey's rate had shown a remarkable recovery from a high of 9.1 percent in April, other economic indicators, like the number of people employed and the number of those seeking jobs, point to continuing weakness in the state's economy.
One bright spot in both states in July was the number of summer jobs for young people. Mr. Ehrenhalt said that more than 80 percent of the young people seeking short-term summer jobs were able to find work.

HEADLINE: Biggest Jump in Consumer Credit in 6 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
American consumers increased their borrowing by $7.67 billion in June, the largest one-month jump in six years, the Federal Reserve reported today.
However, economists cautioned against reading too much into the one-month gain, saying that the central bank had been experiencing problems with its credit survey over the last two months. 
 Analysts noted that consumer credit, after having risen for nine consecutive months, actually fell by $752 million in May. But the Fed attributed that decline to the fact that about $3 billion in loans had been transferred from financial institutions not covered by the survey.
Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm, said that because of this statistical aberration, it would probably be better to average May and June. If that was done, he said, credit would have risen at a more realistic level of $3.5 billion, about in line with recent gains in personal income.
 
'Still Showing Restraint'
 "Consumers are still showing restraint by limiting their borrowing increases to the growth in their incomes," Mr. Evans said. He said consumers were worried about their jobs and taxes.
During the recession, consumers reduced their borrowing and sought to pay off old debts, but over the last year they have been less hesitant about taking on new debt.
The Fed survey showed that overall consumer installment loans were rising at an annual rate of 12.3 percent in June.
The revolving credit category, which includes credit cards, rose by $2.86 billion. That was the biggest increase since March 1991 and it translated into an annual rate of increase of 13.1 percent.
Auto loans increased by $2.2 billion, the biggest advance since February and an increase that translates into an annual rate of 10 percent.
Other kinds of consumer loans rose by $2.61 billion, or an annual rate of 13.9 percent.
The overall borrowing gain of $7.67 billion was the largest increase since a $7.9 billion advance in credit in July 1987.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 111 words

HEADLINE: Wholesale Sales Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Sales at the wholesale level took their biggest drop in two and a half years in June, in another indication that the American economy is continuing to struggle, the Commerce Department said today. The department said sales fell 1.5 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $159.8 billion, after rising 1.8 percent in May. It was the biggest drop since sales fell 2.2 percent in January 1991. Inventories continued the pattern of the last three months, rising three-tenths of a percent in June after a rise of two-tenths of a percent in May. Weak sectors were motor vehicles and other auto equipment, lumber and other construction materials, petroluem products and drugs.
